595360.title: Senior Thesis
595360.description: Thesis committee must approve research plan at least two semesters prior to enrollment in this course. Requires preparation, presentation and defense of a formal thesis. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. (BIOL 498 and CHEM 498 are the same course.)

595361.title: Independent Study
595361.description: Special topics in chemistry selected in consultation with the instructor and approval of department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Only six units may apply toward B.A. or B.S. degree. In some cases, CHEM 499 can be substituted for CHEM 495 to meet degree requirements.
595361.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 301B , CHEM 315 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598681.title: Introduction to Graduate Studies in Chemistry & Biochemistry
598681.description: Introduction to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry graduate program. Principles and procedures of scholarly research, scientific communication and professional development.

595362.title: Seminar: Research Background, Methods and Objectives
595362.description: Gain practical skills on how to deliver an oral presentation focused on describing and analyzing research background, methods and objectives. How to organize, evaluate and present scientific information in a professional manner. May be repeated for a maximum of 2 units.

595363.title: Seminar (Presentation)
595363.description: Student presentation of recent contributions to the chemical literature. May not be repeated for credit. (1 hour seminar)
595363.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 505A with a “B” (3.0) or better.

595364.title: Advanced Analytical Chemistry
595364.description: Theory, application and limitations of advanced analytical topics; including separations, spectroscopy, electrochemistry and contemporary methods. .
595364.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 315 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595365.title: Advanced Instrumentation
595365.description: Spectroscopic instrumentation components and systems. Includes laser spectroscopy, mass spectroscopy, chemical sensor, process control, surface science, and microscopy methods; vacuum technology, optics, electro-optics, and electronics components; design and repair of instrumentation.
595365.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 315 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

598682.title: Organic Reactions and Mechanisms
598682.description: Advanced principles that govern chemical reactivity in organic chemistry, including free radical chemistry, photochemistry, transition-metal catalyzed and electrophilic substitution reactions, as well as the reactive intermediates involved in these reactions.

595366.title: Organic Synthesis
595366.description: Methods of synthetic organic chemistry and their application to construction of organic molecules.
595366.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 301B with a “B” (3.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595367.title: Organic Spectroscopy
595367.description: Theory and use of infrared spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy as methods for the identification of organic compounds.
595367.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 301B , CHEM 306B ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595368.title: Protein Biochemistry
595368.description: Protein isolation strategies and techniques; chemical/physical characterization and modeling; functional characterization (kinetics, binding, chemical modification); molecular biology, including protein expression and engineering.
595368.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 423A , CHEM 423B with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595369.title: Nucleic Acid Chemistry
595369.description: Biochemistry of nucleic acids in living systems at the molecular level. Advances and techniques used in nucleic acid research and biotechnology. Strong emphasis on critical reading, analysis and presentation of primary literature.
595369.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 423A , CHEM 423B with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595370.title: Physical Biochemistry
595370.description: Methods for measuring physical properties of proteins and nucleic acids. Thermodynamic and hydrodynamic aspects.
595370.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 361A or CHEM 371A ; CHEM 361B or CHEM 371B ; CHEM 421 or CHEM 423A ; CHEM 423B ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595371.title: Metabolism and Catalysis
595371.description: Regulation of biosynthetic and degradative reactions in living systems. The control of enzyme activity and concentration. Mechanisms of hormone action.
595371.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 423A , CHEM 423B with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595372.title: Quantum Chemistry
595372.description: Postulates and theories of approximation methods in quantum chemistry, the electronic structure of atoms and molecules, chemical bonds, group theory and applications.
595372.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 371A , CHEM 371B with a “C” or better; or graduate standing.

595373.title: Kinetics and Spectroscopy
595373.description: Kinetics and spectroscopy of chemical and biochemical systems in the gas phase, in the liquid phase, and on surfaces.
595373.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 361B or CHEM 371B with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

598959.title: Teaching Effectiveness in Chemistry Labs
598959.description: Preparation for teaching college-level chemistry laboratories. Introduction to a variety of evidence-based teaching strategies in higher education through a combination of readings from book chapters, research articles, and active participation in class activities and assignments.

595374.title: Project
595374.description: Guidance in preparing a project for the master's degree. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Requires an officially appointed project committee and consent of the department chair.

595375.title: Thesis
595375.description: Guidance in preparing a thesis for the master's degree. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires an officially appointed thesis committee.

595376.title: Independent Graduate Research
595376.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 units. A maximum of 6 units may be used on study plan.

595377.title: Introduction to Ethnic Studies
595377.description: Perspectives through which people of color have come to see themselves in terms of their own heroes, cultures and contributions to the societies in which they live and the world in general. (AFAM 101, ASAM 101, and CHIC 101 are the same course)

595378.title: Communication Skills
595378.description: Basic communication skills, including oral and written expression. A unit on the mechanics of writing and reporting on a term paper is included as part of the course.

598794.title: Introduction to U.S.-Central American Studies
598794.description: Introduction to the interdisciplinary field of U.S.-Central American Studies. Racial, cultural, social, spiritual and political analysis of Black, Indigenous and Mestiza/o Central Americans and their migratory movements, cultural dynamics of diaspora, dislocation and memory in the U.S. (CHIC 105 and LTAM 105 are the same course.)

598319.title: Introduction to Chicano Studies
598319.description: Role of the Chicano in the U.S. The Chicano's cultural values, social organization, urbanization patterns, and the problems in the area of education, politics and legislation.

595379.title: Survey of American History with Emphasis on Ethnic Minorities
595379.description: Survey of American history from prehistoric times (before 1492) to the present with special emphasis on the role of race and ethnicity. (HIST 190, AFAM 190, ASAM 190 and CHIC 190 are the same course.)

598798.title: Chicana and Chicano Environmentalisms
598798.description: Relationships between Chicanx/Latinx communities and environments and ecologies as represented in art, film, literature, oral histories, photography and other forms of cultural production. How Chicanx/Latinx cultural production contributes to understandings about environmentalisms and ecologies.

595380.title: Chicana/o Identities
595380.description: Chicana/o identities, from their indigenous beginnings to the present, through categories of gender, sexuality, race, ethnicity, national origin and class; surveying interdisciplinary, social scientific, historical and literary sources.

598235.title: Introduction to Multi-Ethnic Literatures of the U.S.
598235.description: Introducing multi-ethnic literatures of the U. S., the course considers texts within their cultural, historical, and socio-political contexts. Relates multi-ethnic literature to the creative and performing arts. Themes covered may include diaspora, migration, memory, history, citizenship, and/or ethnic identities. (CHIC 250, AFAM 250, ASAM 250 and ENGL 250 are the same course.)

595381.title: Ancient Mexican Culture
595381.description: Historical and cultural survey of the principal pre-Columbian cultures of Mexico and their significance to Mexican society.

598320.title: Chicano/Mexican Cultures
598320.description: Methodology for studying and analyzing the cultural background of Mexican and Chicana/o populations in order to understand current traditions, practices, beliefs and ideologies. Syncretism, colonialism, modernization, urbanization, migration and resistance.

595382.title: Music of Mexico
595382.description: Historical survey of folk, popular and art music traditions of Mexico and music in Mexican American/Chicano society; pre-Cortesian and contemporary indigenous musical practices; relationship of music to Mexican history and culture. Listening, reading and written work. Intended for non-music majors. May be used as a music-major elective. (MUS 304 and CHIC 304 are the same course.)

595383.title: Chicana/o Families
595383.description: The Chicana/o family's development as an American social institution focusing on cross-cultural, historical and interdisciplinary perspectives.

595384.title: Barrio Studies
595384.description: How Latina/o and Mexican-origin communities develop in urban areas and the role of collective action in the community. Requires service learning.

595385.title: Research and Writing in Ethnic Studies
595385.description: Introduction to research and writing in ethnic studies. Issues of research in ethnic studies (e.g., quantitative v. qualitative analysis, reliability/validity) and specific methods of research (e.g., archives, interviews, oral history). Extensive writing. A "C" (2.0) or better is required to satisfy the upper-division writing requirement. (ASAM 307, AFAM 307 and CHIC 307 are the same course.)

595386.title: La Chicana
595386.description: Cultural influences that the family, religion, economic status and community play upon the lifestyles, values and roles held by Chicanas. (CHIC 313 and GSS 313 are the same course.)

595387.title: Chicano/Latino Theatre
595387.description: Contemporary Chicano/Latino theater in relation to its historical evolution. Plays, playwrights and theater groups expressing the Chicano/Latino experience. Extensive play reading. (CHIC 315 and THTR 315 are the same course.)

598321.title: The Chicano Music Experience
598321.description: Mexican folk and popular music and its relationship to the culture of Mexico. Pre-Cortesian period to the present in Mexico and Southwestern United States.

598139.title: Latina/o Intercultural Communication
598139.description: Explores the intersection of communication and the Latina/o community, including cultural identity or what it means to be Hispanic. Communication between Latinas/os and other cultures are examined from historical, contemporary, political contexts, among a variety of other settings. Requires consent of instructor. (HCOM 321 and CHIC 321 are the same course.)

595388.title: Chicana and Chicano Education
595388.description: Overview of the educational plight of Chicanas/os in the American school system from an interdisciplinary perspective. Addresses educational inequality and social justice phenomenon using various concepts, theories and methodologies.

598748.title: Undocumented Youth in Education
598748.description: Experiences of undocumented youth in pre-K to college, exploring and analyzing literacy instruction in order to properly serve this student population in schools and universities. Service-learning component.

595390.title: The Chicano Child
595390.description: The Chicano child from preschool through grade six. Emphasizes motor, physical, social, intellectual, emotional growth and development and their effect on school adjustment and achievement. Field observation of preschool and grade school children required.

595391.title: The Chicano Adolescent
595391.description: The Chicano adolescent's social, intellectual and emotional growth and development. Bicultural pressures from the barrio, family structure, school and achievement values.

595392.title: Mexican Literature Since 1940
595392.description: Literature of Mexico since 1940: Carlos Fuentes, Rodolfo Usigli, Xavier Villarrutia, Juan Jose Arreola, Octavio Paz, Laura Esquivel and Juan Rulfo. Other contemporary authors may be included.

595393.title: Latin American Literature
595393.description: Major periods and texts in Latin American literature. The transnational context of Latin American literature; reading major works (in English translation) by writers from Mexico, Central and South America, the Caribbean and the Latina/o U.S.

595394.title: Contemporary Chicana/o Literature
595394.description: Chicana and Chicano literature from the 1960s to the present. Considers texts within their cultural, historical, social and political contexts. Relates Chicana/o literature to contemporary U.S. Latina/o writing and to the creative and performing arts.

597740.title: Barrios and Health
597740.description: Links between urban environments and health. How community development and the grassroots help shape health in barrios. Requires service learning with non-profit organizations. (CHIC 338 and PUBH 338 are the same course.)

595395.title: Mexican/Chicano Intellectual Thought
595395.description: Emergence of the Chicano movement dealing with political, economic and sociological facets. Writings of Nahautl, Spanish, Spanish-American, Chicano and contemporary writers.

595396.title: History of the Chicano
595396.description: History of the Chicano from the pre-Columbian period to the present. The Chicanos' changing role in the United States, their cultural identity crisis and their achievements.

607258.title: Latina/o/x Psychology
607258.description: Major issues experienced by Latina/o/x communities from a psychological perspective to understand the Latina/o/x worldview. Immigration, ethnic identity, acculturation, the family context, cultural values bilingualism, language brokering, education, sexuality/gender, spirituality, Latinx LGBTQ+, health/well-being and alternative healing approaches.

595397.title: Mexican Life and Culture
595397.description: Introduction to Mexican culture and civilization. Contemporary Mexican society with focus on social, political, environmental, cultural and historical issues. Requires travel to La Paz, Baja California, Mexico and will only be offered in summer or intercession. Letter grade or Credit/No Credit. (LTAM 350 and CHIC 350 are the same course.)

595398.title: Mexico Since 1906
595398.description: Mexican Revolution of 1910, stressing the political, economic and social aspects, as well as its contributions in the fields of art, literature and social reforms.

598856.title: Literacy Education for Social Change
598856.description: Guides students through theories of critical and de-colonial literacies, alongside exploration and practice in qualitative inquiry, in order to deeply reflect on meaningful educational and social change in schools and societies. Fieldwork component. (READ 360 and CHIC 360 are the same course.)

598951.title: Cariño and Memory in the Time of Pandemic
598951.description: The carino (care), mutual aid and solidarity that racialized communities had and continue to enact during the pandemic. Analyze memory and oral histories of racialized communities surviving and enduring the racial politics of essentialized labor, premature death and mourning.

595399.title: Religion in Latino/a Life
595399.description: National and international expressions of Latino/a religiosity - from popular religion to Marian devotion to curanderismo -  through film, historical documents, poetry, theology, art, sociology and ethnic studies. (RLST 367 and CHIC 367 are the same course.)

598136.title: Border Cinema
598136.description: Examines representations of the U.S.-Mexico border in Mexican and U.S. films from the Mexican Revolution era to the present, as well as border theories in international films and scholarship. (CHIC 369 and CTVA 369 are the same course.)

595400.title: Seminar in Contemporary Chicana/o Issues
595400.description: Study of selected contemporary research topics in Chicana/o Studies aimed at gaining an in-depth knowledge of a particular analytical, theoretical, and/or methodological approach.

598073.title: Art History of the Ancient Americas
598073.description: History of the art and architecture of select civilizations of ancient Mesoamerica and South America. (ART 459 and CHIC 459 are the same course.)

595401.title: The Chicano and Politics
595401.description: Theory of urban politics and evaluation of issues that affect the Chicanos and American society. Evaluations and surveys will be made on political organizations in Hispanic-surnamed communities. (CHIC 460 and POSC 460 are the same course.)

598063.title: Latin American Art History: 1400 - Present
598063.description: History of art and architecture of select regions and nations of Latin America, from Contact to present. Major monuments and art movements. (ART 462 and CHIC 462 are the same course)

598033.title: American Immigration History
598033.description: History of American immigration in a global context. Changes and continuities in the political, cultural, and economic contexts that generated the movement of diverse peoples and structured their experiences of integration within the U.S. (HIST 477C, AFAM 477C, ASAM 477C and CHIC 477C are the same course.)
598033.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

595402.title: Chicanas/os and Immigrants
595402.description: Mexican- and Latino-origin immigration to the U.S. at key social structural levels.
595402.prereqs: Prerequisite: junior, senior or graduate standing.

595403.title: Student to Student Tutorial
595403.description: Learning through teaching. Three hours of work per week expected for each semester unit of credit and may include: tutorial preparations; consulting with instructors; reporting, analyzing and evaluating tutorial experiences. Requires independent research project on topic related to tutoring area.

595404.title: Independent Study
595404.description: Opportunity to study independently under the guidance of the faculty on a subject of special interest and approved by instructor. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. Requires approval by the department chair and instructor(s) in charge of directing the study.

595405.title: Chicana/Chicano Studies Paradigms and Traditions
595405.description: Interdisciplinary approaches, methods and theories used in the study of Chicana/Chicano and Latina/Latino populations and related topics.

595406.title: Independent Graduate Research
595406.description: Individual library research or empirical project, with conferences with instructor as necessary, culminating in one or more papers. May be repeated for credit. Requires permission from instructor.

596760.title: Fundamental Chinese-A
596760.description: For non-native Chinese speakers. Develop listening and reading comprehension and speaking. Introduces writing and develops cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level. Conducted primarily in Chinese.

596761.title: Fundamental Chinese-B
596761.description: For non-native speakers of Chinese. Continue developing listening and reading comprehension, speaking and writing to communicate on a basic level. Conducted primarily in Chinese.

596762.title: Mandarin Chinese for Chinese Speakers-A
596762.description: Expands oral competencies and develops reading and writing up to 800 characters. Conducted primarily in Chinese.
596762.prereqs: Prerequisites: elementary high oral competency; able to read and write at least 500 characters.

596764.title: Intermediate Chinese-A
596764.description: Listening and reading comprehension, and oral and writing practice in Chinese based on cultural and literary materials, with further development in vocabulary and grammar. Conducted primarily in Chinese.

596765.title: Intermediate Chinese - B
596765.description: Continued development of communicative competence in Mandarin Chinese with a focus on listening, speaking, reading, writing, and culture. Vocabulary building and developing grammatical accuracy. Conducted primarily in Chinese.

596766.title: Directed Study
596766.description: Supervised research projects in Chinese language, literature, culture, linguistics, or business, with consent of instructor and department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596767.title: The Art of War and Intercultural Management Strategies
596767.description: Develop an understanding of Chinese ancient strategies for understanding and managing people in dynamic cultural environments, from an organizational and intercultural management perspective. Requires intermediate to low competency in reading, writing, and speaking Mandarin Chinese (testing may be required). Conducted primarily in Chinese.

596768.title: Silk Roads and Ancient Globalization
596768.description: Practice Mandarin Chinese and learn about Chinese culture in the context of studying the Silk Roads and ancient globalization. Conducted primarily in Chinese. Requirement: Intermediate to low competency in reading, writing, and speaking Mandarin Chinese (testing may be required).

596769.title: Introduction to Chinese Civilization
596769.description: Social, intellectual and artistic heritage of Chinese civilization. Reading and discussion of characteristics of Chinese civilization while strengthening linguistic facility in Mandarin Chinese. Conducted in Chinese.
596769.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHIN 202; intermediate high competency in reading, writing, and speaking Mandarin Chinese (testing may be required); GE Area 3B.

596770.title: Contemporary Chinese Culture
596770.description: Reading and discussion to develop understanding of the social, political, economic and intellectual problems, trends and issues of present-day China while strengthening linguistic ability in Mandarin Chinese. Conducted in Chinese.
596770.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHIN 202 ; intermediate high competency in reading, writing, and speaking Mandarin Chinese.

598168.title: Advanced Chinese Cultural Communication
598168.description: Helps students to further develop Chinese competency at the advanced level through the reading of literary texts, with a focus on discussions and essays about various topics related to Chinese culture. Conducted in Chinese.
598168.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHIN 204 or equivalent Chinese communicative competency.

598190.title: Chinese Culture through Cinema and Literature
598190.description: The development of modern Chinese culture and society. Multicultural analysis of global issues through various media, including subtitled films and literature. Conducted primarily in English.

596771.title: Independent Study
596771.description: Supervised research projects in Chinese language, literature, culture, linguistics, or business, with consent of instructor and department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

598038.title: Introduction to Cinema and Television
598038.description: The history, structure and function of the radio, TV and film industry. Current issues, relevance to society, employment options and other topics.

598598.title: Inside The Movies
598598.description: Artistic, technical, and economic aspects of making and distributing feature films. Each week, different guests from Hollywood discuss their work in the film industry.

598040.title: TV Studio Production
598040.description: Introduction to multi-camera, live-to-drive television studio production. Theory and practice of producing multi-camera, studio television programs. Students crew all positions, including producer, director, associate director, technical director, floor manager, camera operator, audio engineer, etc.

598041.title: Production for Non-Production Track
598041.description: Introduction to single-camera video production designed for non-production students. Theory and practice of producing projects on location. Preproduction, production and post-production using digital cameras and nonlinear editing.

598042.title: Writing Short Scripts
598042.description: Techniques for writing short-form scripts for film and video. Analysis of short films in relation to scriptwriting concepts. Develop and critique student-written short scripts.

598043.title: American Cinema: Beginnings-1945
598043.description: History of American film and film style from the beginnings to 1945. Relation to socio-historical, economic, political, cultural, artistic and technological contexts.

598044.title: American Cinema: 1945-1990
598044.description: History of American film and film style from the post-war period to modern times. Relation to socio-historical, economic, political, cultural, artistic and technological contexts.

598806.title: Contemporary American Cinema (1990-Present)
598806.description: American cinema from the early 1990s through the present, exploring major themes and topics that unite various genres and filmmakers, including globalization's impact on content and distribution, advancements in film technology, and the impact of contemporary culture and politics.

598045.title: Language of Film
598045.description: Visual and syntactic components of the motion picture. Detailed analysis of frame, line, space, shape, image size, movement, tone, color and structuring of visual images.

598046.title: Critical Studies: Cinema
598046.description: Formal film analysis in terms of filmic and stylistic elements. Explores how films produce meanings.

598047.title: Critical Studies: Television
598047.description: Formal structures (formats, narratives, genres) and styles of American television. Analyzes how the medium makes its meaning.

598599.title: Film and Television Narrative: The Writer’s Perspective
598599.description: Narrative structures as applied to screenwriting for motion pictures and television. Study the various elements that form a narrative screenplay and identify and analyze them in finished films and TV series.

598549.title: Diversity in Television
598549.description: Critical examination and analysis of the representation of minority groups in American and global television. The intersectional representation of age, disability, gender, race/ethnicity, religion, sexual identity, nation and socioeconomic class.

598048.title: Audio Production
598048.description: Advanced audio projects for radio, TV, film and the internet, including digital storage and distribution. Complete the audio production process, from pre- through postproduction, applying aesthetic concepts and hands-on skills. (2 hours discussion, 3 hours laboratory)

597965.title: Production 1
597965.description: Essentials of shot design, coverage, editing and sound for production students. Planning, directing, shooting, picture editing, and sound capturing and editing for various narrative projects.
597965.prereqs: Prerequisite: CTVA 300 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598049.title: Business of Television
598049.description: The structure, function and economic underpinnings of the companies and individuals in the television ecosphere responsible for creating and distributing narrative content. Each class features a panel of industry experts.

598050.title: Video Games and Storytelling
598050.description: Analyze video and computer game narratives, emphasizing formal and/or functional structure (genres, format, archetypal characters, audience engagement strategies, dramatic devices, etc.)

598458.title: Writing about the Moving Image
598458.description: Analyze and persuasively write about the moving image through discussion, peer review, writing revisions and secondary research. Topics: American Television; Video Games; Classic Films.

597943.title: Story Structure
597943.description: Analyze and develop script structure and viable, narrative story elements. Acts, scenes, premises, conflict, plots, characters, action, etc. Write critical analyses of professional scripts and author own treatments. Meets upper-division writing requirement for CTVA majors. One or more sections may be offered in any online format.

597944.title: TV Scriptwriting: Sitcom
597944.description: Theory, principles and practice of writing for situation comedies. Students analyze scripts, study program episodes, and develop and write an original story and spec script for a current half-hour prime-time sitcom.
597944.prereqs: Prerequisite: CTVA 350 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

597945.title: TV Scriptwriting: Drama
597945.description: Theory, principles and practice of writing for episodic television dramas. Students analyze scripts, study program episodes and develop and write an original story and spec script for a current one hour, prime-time TV drama.
597945.prereqs: Prerequisite: CTVA 350 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598422.title: Genres for Writers
598422.description: Film genres, from classic to revisionist. Their evolution and hybridization of genres and how screenwriters can implement and benefit from understanding film genre components. May be repeated for credit with different topics for a maximum of 9 units total.
598422.prereqs: Prerequisite: CTVA 350 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596083.title: Aging and Public Policy
596083.description: Origin, development, and overview of public policies affecting older persons, families and service providers. Political administrative, advocacy and private sector involvements in employment, retirement, income security, health care, social services and housing of older persons. May include a service learning component. (AGNG 503 and POSC 503 are the same course.)
596083.prereqs: Prerequisite: AGNG 500 , POSC 309 or POSC 315 ; or classified graduate student status.

598361.title: Biopsychosocial Perspectives in Aging
598361.description: Biological, psychological and social concepts of aging upon which professional practice in gerontology is based.

596085.title: Public Organizational Theory and Behavior
596085.description: Management-oriented analysis of organizational behavior. Treatments of decision-making, leadership, communication, group dynamics and ethical aspects of organization. Applying theories of administration and systems management to public and volunteer programs and services. (POSC 526 and AGNG 526 are the same course).
596085.prereqs: Prerequisite: Public Administration or Gerontology graduate standing.

596086.title: Program Planning and Evaluation
596086.description: Comprehensive theories and methods for planning and evaluating health promotion programs. Techniques for collecting and analyzing quantitative and qualitative data. Skills for measuring effectiveness of health promotion programs. (PUBH 535 and AGNG 535 are the same course)
596086.prereqs: Prerequisite: Public Health or Aging Studies graduate standing.

598949.title: Advanced Topics in Aging
598949.description: Topics selected for in-depth study from one or more specialty areas within the field of aging. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 9 units. Upper-division undergraduates may enroll with permission of the instructor.

596082.title: Research Methods in Gerontology, Project Development
596082.description: Research processes and problems in gerontology; more detailed study of applied research, including program evaluation in the field of gerontology.Development of a project to conclude in AGNG 594 as a culminating experience.

598671.title: Research Methods in Gerontology, Completion of Master’s Project
598671.description: Culminating experience of MSG students. Utilize secondary data to engage in the scientific method to explore and analyze an original and individualized research question, completing all chapters of the capstone master's project.

596088.title: Gerontology Internship
596088.description: Supervised experience in organizations that serve older adults and their families. May be repeated once for credit. Requires classified status in M.S. in Gerontology program, and consent of instructor and Program Coordinator.

596089.title: Project
596089.description: Under the direction of a faculty member, a topic that integrates learning in the program with an applied area of student's interest will be selected; a major project on the topic will be developed and submitted. Requires classified status in the M.S. in Gerontology Program, and consent of instructor and Program Coordinator.

596090.title: Thesis
596090.description: Individual research under supervision, reported in a thesis and defended successfully in an oral examination conducted by a faculty thesis committee. Requires classified status in the M.S. in Gerontology degree program, and consent of instructor and Program Coordinator.

596091.title: Independent Study in Gerontology
596091.description: Individualized study with an instructor whose recognized interests are in the area of the planned study. Conferences with the instructor as necessary; work will culminate in one or more papers. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
596091.prereqs: Prerequisite: completion of M.S. in Gerontology core courses.

594955.title: Questioning America
594955.description: What is American culture? Introduction to multiple methods used to understand ideas of America and American culture; explore diverse techniques to investigate questions of power, belonging and everyday life.

598779.title: Explore Core: Migrant Lives
598779.description: Differing sociocultural experiences of different migrant groups. How immigration as a process impacts physical, cognitive and socioemotional development of migrants' children. Educational experiences of migrants and implications for schools and society. (CAS 131, AMST 131 and READ 131 are the same course)

598893.title: Explore Core: Fear and Fantasy
598893.description: Fear and fantasy through multiple disciplinary lenses and methods. The experience, representation and response to fear across cultures, generations and time periods. Use multidisciplinary approaches to understanding fear and fantasy, drawing from developmental psychology, art, popular culture, history and engineering. (AMST 132, ART 132, CAS 132 and EGME 132 are the same course)

594956.title: Introduction to American Studies
594956.description: With the concept of culture as a unifying principle, focus is on four separate time periods in order to provide the framework for an understanding of American civilization. Several different kinds of documents will be used to illustrate the nature and advantages of an interdisciplinary approach.

594957.title: Introduction to American Popular Culture
594957.description: Historical exploration of popular culture in America as it reflects and contributes to the search for meaning in everyday life. Heroes, myths of success, symbols of power, images of romance, consumerism, race and sexual identity.

594958.title: American Experiences
594958.description: American identities and beliefs, through a sampling of historical and contemporary voices from different groups of Americans. Similarities and differences in Americans? experiences based on class, race, ethnicity, gender, sexuality, region and other identities.

598287.title: Hollywood and America: Using Film as a Cultural Document
598287.description: Hollywood as a cultural institution. Concentrating on the films of selected periods, the course analyzes Hollywood's ability to create and transmit symbols and myths, and legitimize new values and patterns of behavior.

594959.title: Women in American Society
594959.description: Socio-cultural history of women and women's movements in American society. Emphasis on 19th and 20th centuries. Cultural models of American womanhood - maternal, domestic, sexual, social - their development and recent changes.

597763.title: American Immigrant Cultures
597763.description: Investigates American immigrant communities, both historical and contemporary, to better understand how their experiences helped shape the meaning of being American. Explores immigrant cultures through literature, music, film, oral history and photographs using interdisciplinary methods.

598780.title: Science and Modern America
598780.description: Interdisciplinary analysis of the relationship between science and culture in the American past and present. Topics include questions of trust, ethics, objectivity, power and identity in developing scientific knowledge in health and medicine, the environment, and technology.

594960.title: The American Dream
594960.description: Interdisciplinary analysis, in settings both historical and contemporary, of the myth and reality surrounding the notion of America as a land of unparalleled and unlimited possibilities, especially in the achievement of personal material success.

598288.title: American Culture Through Spectator Sports
598288.description: Shifting meaning of organized sports in changing American society. Includes analysis of sports rituals, symbols and heroes. Focus is on the cultural significance of amateur and professional football, baseball and basketball.

594961.title: Seminar in Theory and Method of American Studies
594961.description: Understanding and appreciation of methodology, theories of society and images of humanity as they affect American studies contributions to scholarship. Fulfills the course requirement of the university upper-division baccalaureate writing requirement for American Studies majors.
594961.prereqs: Prerequisites: AMST 201, one AMST 300-level GE course.

594962.title: Prejudice and American Culture
594962.description: Concepts and methods of American culture studies as tools for better understanding the origins and appeal of intolerance, past and present. Particular focus on racism, ethnic and religious bias, sexism  and homophobia.

597762.title: Disability and American Culture
597762.description: Changing meaning, history and experience of disability in American culture through scholarly readings, memoir, film, photography and other cultural documents. Disability in relation to identity, stigma, discrimination, media representations, intersectionality, gender and sexuality, work, genetic testing, and design.

594963.title: California Cultures
594963.description: Who can claim to be Californian? The ideals and realities of what it means to be Californian; investigating how various identities ? of race, class, gender, sexuality, region and generation ? have interacted in California?s cultures, past and present.

594964.title: Proseminar in American Studies
594964.description: Relationship between theory and application. Analytic readings and research. Check the class schedule for topics being considered. May be repeated once for credit with different topic.
594964.prereqs: Prerequisites: AMST 201 , one AMST 300-level G.E. course; or graduate standing.

598622.title: Creative Work in American Studies
598622.description: Cultivate a creative mentality in American Studies. Explore non-academic representations of cultural research and how to communicate interdisciplinary knowledge using creative forms. Historical fiction, graphic novels, musical expression, documentary film, podcasting, material culture, personal narrative.
598622.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

598446.title: Americans and Nature
598446.description: Shifting attitudes toward the natural environment among a range of Americans over time, from native inhabitants and early colonists to rural and urban dwellers today. Agrarian expansion, industrialization, transcendentalism, tourism, humans' roles in "natural" disasters and history of environmental activism.
598446.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

598289.title: Images of Crime and Violence in American Culture
598289.description: Cultural analysis of meanings ascribed to law and order, authority, violence and punishment in the American past and present. Examined in selected symbols, images, traditions and realities.
598289.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

598291.title: Gaming and American Culture
598291.description: Development and significance of outdoor, board and video gaming in America. Literary works, films, television shows, advertisements, manuals and material artifacts to understand how gaming has addressed larger social tensions and shaped American identity and culture.
598291.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

598292.title: Consumer Culture
598292.description: Consumerism in America from the Boston Tea Party to today from an interdisciplinary perspective, using literature, music, clothing, advertisements and consumer-based social movements to analyze the power of consumer culture.
598292.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

598286.title: Women, Race, and Ethnicity in American Culture
598286.description: Diversity of women's experiences, including historical and contemporary analysis of groups such as Black American, Asian American, Latina, Arab American and Indigenous women. Course materials include autobiography, fiction, visual and popular arts, and feminist cultural criticism.
598286.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

594965.title: The Shifting Role and Image of the American Male
594965.description: Effect of economic, social, political and cultural changes on American males. Emphasizes 19th and 20th centuries.
594965.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

598293.title: Southern California Culture: A Study of American Regionalism
598293.description: A focus on Orange County's diverse history and culture.
598293.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

597727.title: Food and American Culture
597727.description: Food and identities in America from the colonial era to the present, including explorations of American ethnic food,  industrialization of food and contemporary food movements.
597727.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

594966.title: Love in America
594966.description: Changes in the emotional lives of American men and women from the 17th century to the present. Enduring and innovative views on the nature of love and the cultural forces that shape its legitimate and illegitimate expression.
594966.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

594967.title: Childhood and Family in American Culture
594967.description: Historical and contemporary culture study of childhood and family in America. The idea of childhood, changing concepts of child-rearing, growing up in the American past, the impact of modernization, mother and home as dominant cultural symbols.
594967.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

598294.title: American Communities
598294.description: Interdisciplinary exploration of community and its role in American culture. Examines a diverse array of current and historical communities. What constitutes community, how we study it, how communities vary, and what draws people into and away from them.
598294.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598623.title: Americans at Work
598623.description: Explores a range of occupations, from factory worker to investment banker, nanny to drug dealer, mortician to exotic dancer. Considers the meaning work holds for those who perform it and the structures, cultures, and histories of particular occupations.

598457.title: American Monsters
598457.description: Interdisciplinary study of the monster in American culture. Monsters in historical context as reflection of fears and anxieties surrounding nature, science, gender, race, community, the body. Images of monstrosity in film, literature, folklore, television, performance art, youth culture.
598457.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

594968.title: American Minds: Images of Sickness and Health
594968.description: Cultural changes in American images of the healthy mind. Medical and legal views of insanity, Freud's impact on American thought, literary treatments of madness and psychological themes in American popular culture.
594968.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598295.title: Picturing America: Photography and Culture
598295.description: The cultural work of American photography, examining how photographs ? from the extraordinary to everyday variety ? can be used to study American identities, beliefs, narratives and values.
598295.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598296.title: Television and American Culture
598296.description: American television as an interactive form of cultural expression, both product and producer of cultural knowledge. Structure and content of television genres, and social-historical context of television's development and use, audience response, habits and environments of viewing.
598296.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598297.title: American Placemaking
598297.description: How Americans have shaped and been shaped by their spaces. Topics include how spaces become places, how space and race construct each other, how inequality has been built into our cultural landscapes and the impact of place on American culture.
598297.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598298.title: Cold War and American Culture
598298.description: The Cold War's impact on American society and culture. Nuclear fear, McCarthyism, gender roles, family life, material culture and the impact of containment, brinksmanship and detente.
598298.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598433.title: Race and American Popular Culture
598433.description: Using popular culture as a lens, examines theater, music and film, and asks: how has popular culture contributed to the social construction of race and ethnicity; how has it challenged and transformed racial and ethnic stereotypes?
598433.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598440.title: American Popular Culture and the World
598440.description: Historical and contemporary study of American popular culture in a global context. Transnational influences on U.S. popular culture and impact of American culture around the world. Youth culture, film, music, sports, TV, literature, material culture.
598440.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598299.title: Frontiers and Borderlands in American Culture
598299.description: How ideas about frontiers, borders and ?the West? have contributed to American identities and experiences. Topics include popular culture, politics, immigration, gender, racial formation and attitudes toward wilderness.
598299.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598463.title: Fashion in American Culture
598463.description: Cultural politics of fashion in America. Uses of interdisciplinary sources, including material culture, visual arts, legal codes, protests, advertising, and popular culture to study the diverse meanings of fashion in the past and present U.S.
598463.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598746.title: American Nightlife
598746.description: Development of nightlife in American society and culture. Topics include the meaning of night, evening labor, prohibition, gender roles, sexuality, race, material culture, ballroom culture, music, cinema and urban cultures.
598746.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

598462.title: Technology and American Culture
598462.description: Relationship between technology and culture in America from industrialization to the present. How technologies, such as the steam engine, automobile, atomic bomb and computer have both been shaped by larger cultural ideas, institutions, values and processes in America.
598462.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598300.title: Bohemians and Beats: Cultural Radicalism in America
598300.description: Ideas, activities and legacies of the creators of a "countercultural" tradition in the 19th and 20th centuries. Their critique of modern civilization, as well as their projects for self-transformation, social change and cultural renewal.
598300.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598301.title: The Culture of the American South
598301.description: Distinctive cultural patterns in the American South, past and present. Southern concepts of work and leisure; race and gender roles; political and religious controversies; literature and folklore; and the South as portrayed in the media.
598301.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

594969.title: Sexual Orientations and American Culture
594969.description: Cultural construction of the very idea of a sexual orientation. Shifting meanings of erotic attraction and involvement in America, especially regarding people of the same sex, from the colonial period to the present.
594969.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598451.title: Race, Sex and American Urban Culture
598451.description: Major urban spaces at key moments in the 19th and 20th centuries; ways that anxieties about race, gender, youth and sexuality have come to be identified with urban spaces and modern city life.
598451.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598747.title: Digital America
598747.description: Examines practices of digital participation in American culture from the 1960s to the present. Advanced study (in historical context) of the cultural, social, and political impact of personal electronic and digital communications devices, the internet, social media, and applications.
598747.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

598464.title: Internship in American Studies
598464.description: Learning experience for undergraduate majors or minors at any public or private institute to which an American Studies major is related. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units, only 3 of which may be applied to American Studies upper-division electives.

594970.title: Independent Study
594970.description: Supervised research projects in American Studies to be taken with the consent of instructor and department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

594971.title: Theory and Methods
594971.description: The American Studies movement. Its conceptual and methodological development. The way this development was affected by and in turn reflected larger trends in the culture itself.

594972.title: Seminar: Selected Topics
594972.description: A particular problem or topic as a case study in the use of interdisciplinary methods in American studies. May be repeated once for credit with different topic.

598061.title: Graduate Internship in American Studies
598061.description: Learning experience at any public or private institution to which an American Studies major is related.

594973.title: American Studies Teaching Tutorial
594973.description: Preparation for community college or university teaching. Small group discussion, lecture-discussion, examinations and teaching strategies. Enrollment requires approval of American Studies graduate coordinator. Course may be repeated for credit, but may only count once on a graduate study plan.

594974.title: Thesis
594974.description: Writing of a thesis based on original research and its analysis and evaluation. Requires consent of graduate coordinator.

594975.title: Independent Graduate Research
594975.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of graduate coordinator.

594976.title: Non-Western Cultures and the Western Tradition
594976.description: Changing views of people, nature and culture in Western civilization as related to the impact of non-Western influences, including the use and interpretation of data on non-Western peoples and cultures.

594977.title: Introduction to Biological Anthropology
594977.description: Humans as biological organisms from an evolutionary perspective. Concepts, methods, findings and issues in the study of the Order primates, including the relationships among fossil monkeys, apes and humans, and the significance of genetic diversity in modern populations.

594978.title: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology
594978.description: Nature of culture and its significance. Similarities and difference in human cultures. Analyses of family, economy, subsistence, religion, art and other aspects of culture in diverse societies. Central problems of cultural comparison and interpretation.

594979.title: Introduction to Archaeology
594979.description: Relationship of archaeology, culture history and process, field methods and analysis of archaeological data; uses and abuses of archaeology.

594980.title: Introduction to Anthropology
594980.description: Introduction to basic aspects of anthropology's sub-fields (biological anthropology, archaeological anthropology, cultural anthropology, and linguistic anthropology), and to an anthropological view of the world, which is grounded in a respect for cultural differences.

607257.title: Urban Agroecology
607257.description: Explore the principles of agroecology and apply them in an urban farm setting as part of a Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE).

594981.title: Language and Culture
594981.description: Language in the context of culture. The symbolic nature of language, speech as performance, non-verbal communication, gendered speech and bias in language. Language acquisition, language change and loss, and factors leading to the invention of writing.

598304.title: Primate Behavior
598304.description: Anthropological study of the behavior of primates, including monkeys and apes with data collection in the wild and the laboratory; review and discussion of behavioral characteristics that are part of the primate heritage of humankind.
598304.prereqs: Prerequisites: ANTH 101, ANTH 102, PSYC 101 or GE Area 5A or 5B.

598950.title: Introduction to Museum Studies
598950.description: History, principles and development of art and design, natural history and anthropology, science, historic houses, botanical gardens, zoos and children?s museums. Subjects include scope of museum history, collections, conservation, exhibition, interpretation, engagement, service, careers and professional practices in museums.

594982.title: Traditional Cultures of the World
594982.description: Comparative, worldwide survey of traditional, selected and well-studied ways of life using ethnographic writings and films. Examines diverse ways of life, with an emphasis on small-scale societies.

594983.title: Anthropology of Religion
594983.description: Beliefs and practices in the full human variation of religious phenomena, with an emphasis on primitive religions. Forms, functions, structures, symbolism, and history and evolution of religious systems. (ANTH 305 and RLST 305 are the same course.)

594984.title: Culture and Art
594984.description: Explores different types of creative expression and arts within the cultural context of diverse societies, including such forms as painting, weaving, stories, myths, music, dance, masks, body decoration and sculpture, among others.

594985.title: Culture and Aging: Anthropological Gerontology
594985.description: Anthropological discourse on diverse cultural conceptions of aging as they relate to gender, class, ethnic and religious categories. Cross-cultural comparison of culturally patterned time-table of life-cycle and age-grades for understanding the universals and variability in human aging.

594986.title: Urban Anthropology
594986.description: Cross-cultural investigation of similarities and differences in urbanism with an emphasis on current theoretical and methodological perspectives in the study of social and cultural forms and processes in urban populations.

594987.title: Culture and Communication
594987.description: How meanings are created, exchanged and interpreted in both traditional and modern cultures through language, myth and religion, art and architecture, and other means of communication.

594988.title: Psychological Anthropology
594988.description: Relationship of culture to the individual. Child-training in non-western cultures. Survey of concepts, studies and research techniques in psychological anthropology.

594989.title: Culture and Nutrition
594989.description: Interrelationships among human nutrition, basic food resources, individual development and socio-cultural organization; includes assessment of student's nutritional status, beliefs and practices relative to other cultures.

594990.title: Anthropology of Sex and Gender
594990.description: Human sex and gender roles in cross-cultural perspective and the role that gender plays in human social organization. Topics covered include cultural construction of gender; homosexuality, rights of women, evolution and gender. (ANTH 316 and GSS 316 are the same course.)

594991.title: Peoples of Native North America
594991.description: Native peoples of North America; origins, languages, culture areas, cultural history; the impact of European contacts.
594991.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A; for anthropology majors, GE Area 4A or any ANTH course in GE Area 4A.

598305.title: Human Behavioral Ecology
598305.description: Examines human biological and cultural diversity through an analysis of comparative socioecology using modern evolutionary theory. Topics covered include reproduction and marriage, the family, childhood, population growth and conservation. Computer labs utilizing eHRAF.

594992.title: Peoples of Central and South America
594992.description: Cultural survey of South America. Representative cultural areas before and after contacts with Western countries.

594993.title: Origins of Civilizations
594993.description: Development of civilization in the Old and New Worlds in primary centers such as Mesopotamia, Egypt, the Indus Valley, China, Mesoamerica and Peru, and secondary centers such as the Aegean and Europe.
594993.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A; for anthropology majors, GE Area 4A or any ANTH course in GE Area 4A.

594994.title: Peoples of the Caribbean
594994.description: Various ethnic groups of the Caribbean, focusing on the description and interpretation of African, European, Asian and Amerindian cultural elements.

594995.title: Gender in Cross-Cultural Perspectives
594995.description: Cross-cultural comparison of beliefs, values, and expectations related to gender roles in diverse societies. Changes in social definitions and perspectives of gender in the contemporary world.

594997.title: Peoples of Asia
594997.description: Asian civilizations and cultural traditions: personality configurations in different culture areas; structure of Asian civilizations; and peasant, tribal and ethnic groups of Asia.

594998.title: Anthropology and Health
594998.description: Uses an evolutionary, comparative and cross-cultural perspective to understand the process and conception of health in different times, places and societies. Topics include: evolutionary medicine, health beliefs, health ecology, culture and health. Computer labs utilizing eHRAF.

594999.title: Human Osteology
594999.description: Techniques in basic identification of human skeletal remains. Aging, sexing, racing and stature reconstruction. For those interested in archaeology, hominid evolution and/or forensic science. (2 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory)

595000.title: Sex, Evolution and Human Nature
595000.description: Evolutionary theory and human evolution; the primate origins of humanity, the evolution of human nature, and the evolutionary foundations of human behavior and cognition.
595000.prereqs: Prerequisite: ANTH 101 or GE Area 5A or 5B.

595001.title: Archaeology and Cultures of Pacific Islands
595001.description: Indigenous peoples, cultures and archaeology of Pacific Islands, including Tahiti, Hawaii and Australia. Forces and processes contributing to social change in island communities and contemporary problems being faced by them.

595002.title: Culture and Education
595002.description: Transmission of values, implicit cultural assumptions and the patterning of education in cross-cultural perspective. American culture and development problems.

598475.title: Archaeology of North America
598475.description: Change, development and diversity of adaptations of North American Indian cultures prior to European colonization. Uses archaeological data to describe and explain long-term processes of cultural change during ancient times in North America.
598475.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A; for anthropology majors, GE Area 4A or any ANTH course in GE Area 4A.

595005.title: Ethnographic Field Methods
595005.description: Anthropological field research by students on various problems using participant observation techniques.
595005.prereqs: Prerequisites: ANTH 102 and six additional units of anthropology.

595006.title: Museum Science
595006.description: Methods, principles and techniques used in natural history, and small scientific and historical museums. Scope of exhibit and research collections, care and repair of specimens, acquisitions, storage and preparation of presentations in anthropological, historical, biological and paleontological museums.
595006.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B or 4A; or graduate standing.

595007.title: Archaeological Fieldwork
595007.description: Excavation of a local archaeological site. Archaeological mapping, photography and recording. Laboratory methods of cataloging, preservation, description and interpretation of archaeological materials. Saturday field sessions. May be repeated once for credit as an elective. (1 hour lecture, 6 hours laboratory)

598108.title: Juvenile Justice Administration
598108.description: Definitions of delinquency and the related responses of the interested institutions (police, courts and correction); the juvenile court (past and present), and prevention and correction programs (practicing and proposed).

598153.title: Victims of Crime
598153.description: Nature and extent of victimization in the population, risk factors and theories of victimization, consequences of victimization, types of victimization, as well as the social, political, and criminal justice system reaction and response to victims.

595657.title: Theories of Crime and Delinquency
595657.description: Historical foundations and development of criminological theories to explain criminal behavior. Implications for criminal justice policy and practice.

595658.title: Criminal Justice Research Methodology
595658.description: Introduction to basic techniques in criminal justice research; focus on literature review, correlation/causation, research design and sampling techniques. Read research reports and critically analyze research study methodology.

595659.title: Complexities in Corrections
595659.description: Overview of the history and philosophies of corrections, emphasizing current trends and populations, policies and practices for adult correctional systems. The experience of individuals, from intake to reentry and its impacts on communities and society.

598137.title: White-Collar Crime
598137.description: The scope and harms of white-collar crime. Case studies of violations committed by corporations, professionals and government agencies and assess the causes, prevention, prosecution, and sentencing of white-collar offenders.

598649.title: Comparative and International Criminal Justice Systems
598649.description: Cross-national comparison of the policing, judicial and correctional systems of the United States to those of different nations from the common, civil, socialist and religious legal traditions.

598749.title: Immigration and Crime
598749.description: Analyzes the involvement of immigrants in crime through empirical studies and discusses the implications this has for public opinion and policy-governance.

598109.title: Sex, Crime and Culture
598109.description: Rationale for law's concern with sexual conduct, developed via discussion of selected offenses and offenders. Lectures and guest speakers also present opposing perspectives regarding the role of law enforcement, courts and correction, research and reform.

595660.title: Race, Inequality and the Criminal Justice System
595660.description: Historical and current issues that contribute to the overrepresentation of racial/ethnic individuals in criminal justice system. Utilizes current research, theory and practice with an intersectional approach to promote effective polices that lead to greater equality across individuals and communities.

598782.title: Peer Mentors in Criminal Justice
598782.description: Support and educational development for students serving as criminal justice peer mentors. Peer mentors serve as peer advisers and mentors, assisting students with the transition to the Criminal Justice department and campus community.

598558.title: The Criminal Court Experience
598558.description: Transitioning from the academic world to the legal profession by observing the criminal courtroom in action and shadowing a member of the California judiciary.

598327.title: Capital Punishment
598327.description: Issues relating to the use of capital punishment in the U.S., and arguments in support of and opposition to the death penalty. (CRJU 404 and POSC 404 are the same course.)
598327.prereqs: Prerequisites: POSC 100 , POSC 300 or HONR 201B ; junior standing or above; or graduate standing.

595661.title: Criminal Justice Policy
595661.description: Evolving purposes and practices associated with the development of criminal justice policies, principally in the U.S. Particular topics, such as sentencing legislation, illustrate the development, adoption and impact of public policy on criminal justice systems.
595661.prereqs: Prerequisites: CRJU 300 , CRJU 330 ; or graduate standing.

595662.title: Crime and Popular Culture
595662.description: How the prevalence of crime and violence in popular culture reflects on contemporary society. Materials and readings argue that images of crime are not only entertaining, they also perform deep social and political functions.

598750.title: Restorative Justice
598750.description: Provides introductory knowledge and applications of restorative justice. Topics include values inherent in restorative justice, the purpose of restorative justice, various types of restorative justice, and the theoretical and practical underpinnings of restorative justice.

597779.title: Policing the City
597779.description: Methods used by police to control crime and promote social order in inner city areas. Various issues from multiple perspectives (residents, merchants, customers, organizations and other users of public space).
597779.prereqs: Prerequisites: CRJU 300 , CRJU 315 ; or graduate standing.

598706.title: Mass Murder
598706.description: Incidence and prevalence of mass murder. Examine offender characteristics, theories and typologies. Threat assessment and prevention issues.
598706.prereqs: Prerequisites: junior or senior standing; criminal justice major or minor; or graduate standing.

597753.title: Drugs and Crime
597753.description: Issues in licit and illicit substance use and the criminal justice system within historical and contemporary contexts. The theoretical and empirical relationship between drugs and crime; drug treatment approaches, and drug control policies.

595663.title: Human Resources Management
595663.description: Civil service and the merit system; recruitment procedures and examinations; position classification, salary structures, retirement plans, in-service training, employee organizations and personnel supervision. Examples and cases from the criminal justice field. Emphasizes themes and topics from criminal justice. (POSC 422 and CRJU 422 are the same course.)

598328.title: Women and Crime
598328.description: Women as criminals and victims, gender differences in criminal behavior and the role of women as professionals in the criminal justice system. (CRJU 430 and GSS 430 are the same course.)

595664.title: Civil Disobedience and Social Justice
595664.description: The violation of law as protest. Definitions and types of disobedience and the policing and punishment of dissent. Analysis of protest as a strategy for social justice. (CRJU 435 and POSC 435 are the same course.)
595664.prereqs: Prerequisites: for CRJU 435 - CRJU 100 , CRJU 300 ; or graduate standing. For POSC 435 - POSC 100 ; or graduate standing.

595665.title: Correctional Rehabilitation
595665.description: Theories and techniques of correctional treatment. Current state of correctional rehabilitation with a focus on the What Works! literature and the value of proper programmatic evaluation and correctional classification.
595665.prereqs: Prerequisites: CRJU 300 , CRJU 345 ; or graduate standing.

595666.title: Gangs and the Criminal Justice System
595666.description: Causal factors of, and legal solutions to, gang-related crime in the U.S. Relevance of sociological, psychological, economic and educational deviance theories to justice intervention strategies.

598129.title: Crime and Justice at the U.S.-Mexico Border
598129.description: How crime occurs and the extent to which justice is rendered at the U.S.-Mexico border.

595667.title: Crime Analysis
595667.description: Crime analysis function within the law enforcement organization; how to develop, implement and operate a crime analysis unit, and discuss the nexus between crime analysis, field and investigative operations, and administrative bureaus.
595667.prereqs: Prerequisites: CRJU 100 , CRJU 300 , CRJU 340 ; or graduate standing.

595668.title: Law, Punishment and Justice
595668.description: Theoretical scholarship in criminal justice is increasingly concerned with law in relation to delivery of justice and practices of punishment. Examines the rule of law, questions whether justice is different from law and reviews the role punishment plays.

595669.title: Moot Court: Legal Practicum
595669.description: Open to undergraduates only. Prepares students for competition. Legal research, writing, court strategies and oral argument; civil liberties law, cases and adjudication; appellate court review and amicus brief reading and writing. May be repeated for a maximum of 12 units. (POSC 471 and CRJU 471 are the same course.)

598544.title: Civil Liberties
598544.description: Constitutional rights and liberties as found in the Bill of Rights and the 14th Amendment, with particular attention to free speech, religious freedom, the right to bear arms, cruel and unusual punishment, and sexual privacy. (POSC 474 and CRJU 474 are the same course.)
598544.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

595671.title: Topics in Administration of Justice: A Seminar
595671.description: Current social, legal and practical problems confronting police, courts and corrections. Variable topic class with specific subjects to be announced each semester. May be repeated with different topics up to a maximum of 9 units.

597743.title: Mock Trial: Legal Practicum II
597743.description: Highly participatory seminar introduces students to legal research, legal writing, trial strategies and litigation techniques; criminal and civil law and procedure, cases and adjudication; public speaking. (POSC 477 and CRJU 477 are the same course).

598550.title: Animals, Law and Society
598550.description: Behavioral and legal complexities of human-animal relationships. Individual and institutional harms to animals, the link between animal abuse and criminal violence, humane law enforcement and the challenge of securing justice for animals.
598550.prereqs: Prerequisites: CRJU 300 , ENGL 301 ; or graduate standing.

595672.title: Courtroom Evidence
595672.description: Rules of evidence in the context of a criminal trial in a California court. Rules, their application and rationale. Lecture, discussion and simulated courtroom situations.

595654.title: Criminal Law: Substantive
595654.description: History and evolution of criminal law from common law origins to present. Elements of crime, criminal offenses and defenses. Apply basic legal analysis.

595673.title: Search, Seizure and Interrogation I
595673.description: Analyze laws that apply in common street search-and-seizure and interrogation situations in California; how they have evolved, and what developments are anticipated.

595674.title: Search, Seizure and Interrogation II
595674.description: Analyze laws that apply in some search-and-seizure and interrogation situations, such as those involving the border patrol and college officials.

598707.title: Technology and Criminal Justice Rights
598707.description: Fundamental criminal defense rights of the Fourth Amendment and Fifth Amendment in the context of a variety of technological advances. Technology's impact on the rights against unreasonable searches and seizures and the privilege against self-incrimination.

598563.title: Applied Policy Research
598563.description: Conduct independent research, under faculty supervision, on policy-related issues proposed by community partners, students and faculty. Research topics will vary each semester, but will be based within criminal justice, political science and/or public administration. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires instructor approval, by application and faculty referral. (CRJU 491 and POSC 491 are the same course.)
598563.prereqs: Prerequisites: for CRJU 491 - CRJU 300 , CRJU 300 , CRJU 340 . For POSC 491 - POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; POSC 321 ; or POSC 407 .

595675.title: Prelaw Internship
595675.description: Acquaints students with the legal profession. A supervised working commitment of eight hours weekly with an assigned individual or organization. May be repeated once for credit. (POSC 492 and CRJU 492 are the same course.)
595675.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

595676.title: Internships
595676.description: Criminal justice professions; eight to 20 hours per week as a supervised intern in a public agency or related organization. In addition to the job experience, interns meet in a weekly three-hour seminar. May be repeated once for credit. Requires consent of instructor.

595677.title: Independent Study
595677.description: Student selects an individual research project, either library or field. Conferences with adviser as necessary, culminating in one or more papers. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of adviser.
595677.prereqs: Prerequisite: minimum 12 units of Criminal Justice.

597561.title: Introduction to Dance
597561.description: Historical and contemporary dance forms. Experiences in various dance forms such as ballet, modern, jazz, folk, ethnic. Recommended for non-majors.

597562.title: Ballet I
597562.description: Fundamental structure and technique of beginning classical ballet. May be taken for credit for a maximum of eight units. (2 hours activity per unit)

597563.title: Contemporary Dance Practices I
597563.description: Fundamental structure and technique of beginning modern and/or contemporary dance styles. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 8 units. (2 hours activity per unit)

597564.title: Dance Improvisation
597564.description: Theory and practice of improvisation in movement. Practical use of improvisation in expressing imagery, developing choreographic concepts and enhancing performance. (4 hours activity)
597564.prereqs: Prerequisite: Dance major or Musical Theatre major.

597565.title: Jazz I
597565.description: Modern jazz dance techniques and basic jazz choreography. May be taken for credit for a maximum of four units. (4 hours activity)

597566.title: Tap Dance I
597566.description: Structure and technique of tap dance and tap choreography. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 4 units. (4 hours activity)

598868.title: Experiential Anatomy
598868.description: Human anatomy and the body/mind connection for musicians, dancers, actors, athletes and/or anyone looking to feel integrated with their body. Efficient kinesthetic principles that will enhance ability, injury prevention and understanding of embodiment and the lived body.

597567.title: Ballet II
597567.description: Intermediate level technique of classical Ballet. May be taken for credit for a maximum of 4 units. (2 hours activity per unit)

598907.title: Classical Pointe
598907.description: Theory and technique for intermediate pointe work, building strength and control in the pointe technique. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. Requires audition and assessment by the instructor on readiness for pointe prior to enrollment.
598907.prereqs: Prerequisite: DANC 212 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

597568.title: Contemporary. Dance Practices II
597568.description: Intermediate-level technique of contemporary and modern dance styles. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 8 units. (2 hours activity per unit)

598826.title: Yoga and Mindfulness for Performing Artists
598826.description: Introduction to yoga and mindfulness principles to performing artists, with the intent to apply these principles into daily life and careers. Strategies to work with thoughts and emotions, while developing mind-body awareness. (DANC 225 and THTR 225 are the same course.)
598826.prereqs: Prerequisites: sophomore standing or above; Dance or Theatre major.

597569.title: Rhythmic Analysis
597569.description: Musical form and structure as it pertains to dance and choreography; musically notating dance rhythms and percussion accompaniment.

597570.title: Jazz II
597570.description: Intermediate level skills in jazz technique and choreography. May be repeated for a maximum of four units. Requires consented placement test. (4 hours activity)

597571.title: Tap Dance II
597571.description: Intermediate skills in tap technique and choreography. May be repeated for up to four units. Requires consented placement test. (2 hours activity per unit)

603111.title: Dance Styles from Hip Hop Culture
603111.description: Historical approach to dance styles from hip hop culture detailing the socio-political and economic environment from which they emerged alongside the physical techniques. Breaking, popping, locking, funk, tutting, lyrical and the evolution of each.

597572.title: Dance and Cultural Diversity
597572.description: Impact of various dance forms, from primitive time to modern, on diverse cultures. Contributions of immigrants, minorities and women to dance as a personal, social and cultural expression.

597573.title: Ballet III
