597573.description: Classical ballet technique at the second stage of the intermediate level. Complex combinations. Elements of technique and theory. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. (2 hours activity per unit)

597574.title: Contemporary Dance Practices III
597574.description: Contemporary and/or modern dance technique at an advanced intermediate level. Technical theory with emphasis on more complex combinations. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 8 units. (2 hours activity per unit)

597575.title: Dance Composition
597575.description: Choreography and forms of beginning dance composition. Final project required. (6 hours activity)
597575.prereqs: Prerequisites: Dance major; DANC 126 , DANC 226 , DANC 312 , DANC 322 ; junior standing or above.

597576.title: Dance Composition
597576.description: Choreography and forms of intermediate dance composition. Final project required. (6 hours activity)

597577.title: Forces and Figures in Dance
597577.description: Dance history from primitive to contemporary times, including historical eras, famous dancers, choreographers and companies.

598329.title: Dance Theory and Criticism
598329.description: Dance theory and philosophy, choreographic styles, published reviews, critique writing. Fulfills the course requirement for the university upper-division baccalaureate writing requirement for dance majors.

603118.title: Mindful Conditioning for Performers
603118.description: Principles of mindfulness and conditioning as they relate to performers. In-class and outside assignments; create routines. May include, but not limited to breathing techniques, meditation techniques, cardio routines, GYROKINESIS(r), Pilates, yoga and journaling.

597578.title: Dance for Musical Theatre
597578.description: Musical theatre dance techniques. Ensemble work and individual approaches to style, synthesizing and building upon the foundations of ballet, jazz, modern and lyrical dance. May be repeated once for credit. (6 hours activity)
597578.prereqs: Prerequisite: Dance major or Musical Theatre major.

598010.title: African American Concert Dance History
598010.description: Production of African derived dance from within American culture. Consideration of the history of dance artists' biographic and critical theory literature from diverse media. Includes a lab involving choreography and performance of major African American concert dance forms. (DANC 371 and AFAM 371 are the same course)

597579.title: Dance Kinesiology
597579.description: Structural aspects of the human body and factors that affect movement in dance.
597579.prereqs: Prerequisites: Dance majors; DANC 126 , DANC 212 , DANC 222 .

597580.title: Ballet IV
597580.description: Stylization and performance of the advanced level of classical ballet. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 9 units. (6 hours activity)

597581.title: Contemporary Dance Practices IV
597581.description: Advanced level skills in contemporary and/or modern dance. Emphasize individual techniques. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 9 units.

597582.title: Advanced Dance Composition
597582.description: Elements and forms in dance composition. Choreographing dances of concert quality. (6 hours activity)

597583.title: Dance Pedagogy
597583.description: Philosophies, techniques and methods for developing progressions in dance instruction.

597584.title: Creative Dance for Children
597584.description: Methods and materials for teaching creative dance to children.

597585.title: Performance
597585.description: Performing in stage or camera productions. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 10 units. (more than 6 hours activity).  (THTR 478A and DANC 478A are the same course.)

597586.title: Repertory and Performance Techniques
597586.description: Broadens understanding of the history, theory and practice of concert dance performance. Emphasizes learning repertory and exploring performance techniques. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. Requires audition. (4 hours activity)

597587.title: Production and Performance Projects in Dance
597587.description: Projects that culminate in production or performance. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units.
597587.prereqs: Prerequisites: Dance major; junior or senior standing.

597588.title: Independent Study
597588.description: Undergraduate research projects. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units.
597588.prereqs: Prerequisites: Dance major; junior or senior standing.

598056.title: Analytical College Writing
598056.description: Students will learn to express ideas effectively in well-developed, focused essays that support arguments with relevant and adequate evidence, and use the style and conventions of standard academic prose. Restricted to Early Start students.

598057.title: Analytical College Writing Workshop
598057.description: With tutorial, computer, and classroom activities, serves as the corequisite of ESE 100. As such, seeks to improve students' ability to compose analytical college essays. Restricted to Early Start students.

598266.title: Preparatory College Writing
598266.description: Practice and instruction in college-level writing. Writing, revision, grammar, rhetorical and research skills necessary for success in ENGL 101. Enrollment determined by appropriate placement assessment. (ENGL 101P and ESE 101P are the same course.)

598960.title: Mathematics For Liberal Arts Supplement
598960.description: Order of operations, calculator functions, fractions, percent, linear equations, inequalities, quadratics, exponential and logarithmic functions, sequences and series. Degree credit not awarded.

598058.title: Intermediate Algebra Preparation
598058.description: Absolute values and inequalities, exponents, solving equations, linear functions. Satisfies the early Start requirement, but does not advance a student in their remediation requirements. Degree credit is not awarded for this course. Offered online only.
598058.prereqs: Prerequisite: First-time freshmen who are required by Early Start Program to begin remediation during first summer term.

598961.title: Elementary Statistics Supplement
598961.description: Order of operations, mathematical expressions and functions. Conversion between fractions, proportions, decimals, percentages and probabilities. Average rate of change, equation of a line and intersection of two lines. Mathematical and statistical word problems. Data entry and use of statistical software. (MATH 20S and ESM 20S are the same course.)

598541.title: Mathematics for Liberal Arts Students
598541.description: Survey of traditional and contemporary topics in mathematics, such as elementary logic, counting techniques, probability, statistics, and the mathematics of the social sciences. For non-science majors.
598541.prereqs: For students who require a support course: Corequisite: MATH 10S / ESM 10S .

598645.title: College Algebra (A)
598645.description: First semester of a two-semester sequence for students planning to take calculus who are not MATH/QR ready. Linear and quadratic equations with additional focus on foundation-level mathematics to support algebraic properties of linear and quadratic functions, graphs and applications. (MATH 115A and ESM 115A are the same course).

598646.title: College Algebra (B)
598646.description: Second of a two-semester sequence for students planning to take calculus who are not MATH/QR ready. Equations, inequalities and systems of equations. Properties of functions, including polynomial functions, rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, with and their properties and applications. (MATH 115B and ESM 115B are the same course.)
598646.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 115A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598542.title: Elementary Statistics
598542.description: Explore and analyze data with real-world applications. Design surveys and experiments. Graphical and numerical summaries. Correlation, regression and analysis of contingency tables. Confidence intervals and hypothesis testing via simulation and using normal, t, chi-squared distributions.
598542.prereqs: For students who require a support course: Corequisite: MATH 20S / ESM 20S .

595678.title: The Economic Environment
595678.description: Application of economics to the problems of unemployment and inflation, the distribution of income, competition and monopoly, the role of government in the economy, other policy issues. Not open to pre-business, business administration majors or minors, economics majors or minors or international business majors.

595679.title: Principles of Microeconomics
595679.description: Principles of individual consumer and producer decision-making in various market structures, the price system, market performance and government policy.

595680.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
595680.description: Principles of macroeconomics analysis and policy, unemployment and inflation, financial institutions, international trade, economic growth, comparative systems.

598690.title: Economics, Causality, and Analytics
598690.description: Modern economic analysis, which centers around causal inference - how X causes Y. How economists and social scientists identify causal effects without experiments, how to diagram causality and how to implement casual methods using R.
598690.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 2A; ECON 100, ECON 201 or ECON 202.

598330.title: Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis
598330.description: Rational decision-making behavior of consumers and firms, price and output determination in markets. Primarily for economics majors, but open to all students who qualify. May not receive credit for both ECON 310 and ECON 315
598330.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 201 , ECON 202 , MATH 130 / MATH 135 / MATH 150A ; or completion of an Associate Degree for Transfer (ADT) in Business or Economics.

598331.title: Intermediate Business Microeconomics
598331.description: Business decisions in alternative market structures with special emphasis on problem solving in a business context using economic concepts and methods. Not open to economics majors. May not receive credit for both ECON 310 and ECON 315.
598331.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 201 , ECON 202 , MATH 130 / MATH 135 / MATH 150A ; or completion of an Associate Degree for Transfer (ADT) in Business or Economics. Corequisites: BUAD 301 , ISDS 361A .

598332.title: Intermediate Macroeconomic Analysis
598332.description: Macroeconomic analysis of policy and events in the short and long run, and of the open economy. Sources and interpretation of macroeconomic data. May not receive credit for both ECON 320 and ECON 325.
598332.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 201 , ECON 202 ; MATH 135 , MATH 130 or MATH 150A . Corequisites: BUAD 301 , ISDS 361A .

598845.title: Intermediate Macroeconomic Theory
598845.description: Macroeconomic theory and models of national income, employment, prices, fiscal and monetary policy, and the open economy. Analysis of business cycles and long run economic growth. May not receive credit for both ECON 320 and ECON 325.
598845.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 201 , ECON 202 ; MATH 130 , MATH 135 or MATH 150A . Not for Business Admin majors.Corequisites: BUAD 301 , ISDS 361A .

595681.title: Comparative Economic Systems
595681.description: Alternative economic systems; their theoretical foundations, actual economic institutions, and achievements and failures. Contrast between socialist and capitalist systems.

595682.title: Economies of the Pacific Rim
595682.description: Dimensions of industrialization, agriculture, investment, human resources and trade in economies of the Far East (including Japan and China), India and related nations of the Pacific Rim.

595683.title: Economic Development: Analysis and Case Studies
595683.description: Processes of economic growth with references to developing areas. Capital formation, resource allocation, relation to the world economy, economic planning and institutional factors, with case studies.

595684.title: Economics of Latin America and the Caribbean
595684.description: Regional economic problems within an international context: dependence, industrialization and the international corporation; agriculture; regional cooperation; inflation; trade and debt problems.

595685.title: The International Economy
595685.description: Theory, practice and institutions of the international economy. International trade and investment, effects of trade policies, trade blocs, balance of payments, foreign exchange markets, short-run and long-run determinants of exchange rates.

595686.title: Economies of the Middle East
595686.description: Economic circumstances and challenges in the Middle East. Topics include population and education, dependence on oil exports, state control of the economy, and the potential for economic growth and stability in the region.

595687.title: Economic Research Methods
595687.description: Basics of applied economic research. How to access existing economic knowledge, locate and compile economic data, and analyze economic problems using theory and quantitative methods.

595688.title: American Economic History
595688.description: Development of American economic institutions; economic problems, economic growth and economic welfare.

595689.title: Economics of Gender and Work
595689.description: Economic analysis of demographic trends and changing gender roles and experiences in paid and unpaid work, education, earnings and market discrimination using economic theory. International comparisons. (ECON 355 and GSS 355 are the same course.)
595689.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 4A, junior or senior standing.

603097.title: Economic Inequality in the U.S.
603097.description: Why inequality exists and why it matters using an economic lens. Discuss increases in economic inequality in the United States and government policies aimed at reversing this trend with a focus on economic concepts and data literacy.

595690.title: Urban Economics
595690.description: Theory and analysis of the urban economy, urban economic problems and policy.
595690.prereqs: Prerequisite: ECON 100 or ECON 201 (not CBE pre-major or undeclared).

595691.title: Environmental Economics
595691.description: Economic analysis of environmental problems and related issues: externalities, property rights, social costs and benefits, user cost, rent and decision making under uncertainty.

595692.title: Industrial Organization
595692.description: Business organization, conduct and performance; rationale and impact of public policy on business and business activities, including the regulated industries, sick industries and antitrust policy.

595693.title: International Trade
595693.description: Theories of international trade. Gains from trade, effects of tariff and non-tariff barriers, and conduct of commercial policy. Balance of payments, the theories of exchange rate determination and other international economic issues.

595694.title: Labor Economics
595694.description: Labor supply and demand, labor force participation, employment, unemployment, human capital, wage differentials, disadvantaged labor market groups, discrimination and wage-related income transfers.

595695.title: Law and Economics
595695.description: Economic analysis of the common law - property, contract and tort - focusing on the use of microeconomic theory to study the economic efficiency characteristics and effects of these laws. Analyze specific legal cases.

595696.title: Economics of Health
595696.description: Application of economic reasoning to the analyses of health-related issues, markets, practice, education, research and policy within social and political contexts.

595697.title: Benefit Cost and Microeconomic Policy Analysis
595697.description: Application of economic models to public policy. Cost-Benefit analysis of public projects. Estimation of benefits and costs in a market economy. Concepts of economic welfare, efficiency, and equity. Applications to selected policy areas.

595698.title: Public Finance
595698.description: Government finance at the federal, state and local levels; impact of taxation and spending on resource allocation, income distribution, stabilization and growth.

595699.title: Behavioral Economics
595699.description: Integrates insights from psychology into economic models. Review evidence of violations of standard economic assumptions, learn theories that can explain those violations and apply them to real-world examples.

598588.title: Economics of the Education System
598588.description: Use the tools of economics to study the educational system of the United States and other developed countries. Largely a literature class; will read heavily from the published empirical work. ECON 440 is recommended.

595700.title: Money and Banking
595700.description: Money supply process and impact of monetary policy on economic activity.

595701.title: Monetary and Fiscal Policy
595701.description: Techniques of monetary and fiscal policy and their relative roles in promoting economic stability and growth.

595702.title: International Macroeconomics and Growth
595702.description: Macroeconomic analysis of the open economy: impact of stabilization policies in a global economy, role of the balance of payments, international monetary system and growth in less developed countries.
595702.prereqs: Prerequisite: ECON 320 or ECON 325 or ECON 521.

595703.title: The Less Developed Countries and the World Economy
595703.description: Development and underdevelopment in the poorer countries in the context of a changing international economic order. Neo-classical and political economy approaches. Includes case studies from Asia, Africa and Latin America.
595703.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 310 , ECON 315 or ECON 515 ; ECON 320 , ECON 325 or ECON 521 .

595704.title: Introduction to Econometrics
595704.description: Economic measurement: specification and estimation of econometric models; statistical methods in economic research.

595705.title: Introduction to Mathematical Economics
595705.description: Economic theory from microeconomics and macroeconomics. Content varies; constrained optimization problems and rational decision-making.
595705.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 310 , ECON 315 or ECON 515 ; MATH 135 , MATH 130 or MATH 150A ; not CBE pre-major.

607228.title: Data Science for Economics and Policy Analysis
607228.description: Hands-on introduction to employing big data to solve economic and social problems. Studies modern applied economic approaches for quantitative social science research and policy analysis. Real-world projects develop skills for all steps in the data science pipeline.
607228.prereqs: Prerequisite: ISDS 361A or a comparable probability and statistics class, such as, but not limited to, SOCI 303, PSYC 300 and ECON 100 or ECON 201 or ECON 202; or ISDS 513 with graduate standing; or Economics graduate standing.

595706.title: History of Economic Thought
595706.description: Major schools of thought and of leading individual economists as they influenced economic thought and policy.
595706.prereqs: Prerequisite: ECON 100 ; or ECON 201 , ECON 202 ; not CBE pre-major. Corequisite: BUAD 301 .

595707.title: Natural Resource Economics
595707.description: Concepts and principles in the application of economics to issues in natural resource economics. Issues will include uncertainty and risk in investment, depletion over time, cartelization, the role of technological innovation and government intervention related to fuels, water, land, etc.
595707.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 310 , ECON 315 or ECON 515 ; not CBE pre-major; or graduate standing.

595708.title: Economics Capstone
595708.description: Taken in the last semester of studies. Students demonstrate proficiency in economic theory and quantitative methods and the ability to apply those to economic issues, including analyzing news reports, summarizing scholarly journal articles, writing policy and/or conducting original research.
595708.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 310, ECON 325, ECON 340; ECON 440, ISDS 361B or a 400-level Economics elective.

595709.title: Internship
595709.description: Planned and supervised work experience. Credit/No Credit only. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of the department internship adviser and one semester in residence at the university.
595709.prereqs: Prerequisites: at least junior standing and 2.5 GPA; Economics major - BUAD 301, ISDS 361A, and ECON 310, ECON 320 or ECON 325; International Business major and Business major - ECON 202, ECON 335, ISDS 361A.

597813.title: Tutorial
597813.description: Learn through teaching (tutoring) other students enrolled in principles and intermediate economics courses. Consult "Student-to-Student Tutorials" in this catalog for more information. May not be used to satisfy the elective requirements for the major or concentration in business economics. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Credit/No Credit only. Requires consent of department chair.
597813.prereqs: Prerequisites: senior standing; 3.0 GPA; Economics major or concentration; BUAD 301, ECON 310; ECON 320 or ECON 325.

595710.title: Independent Study
595710.description: Directed independent inquiry. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Not open to students on academic probation. Requires consent of department chair.
595710.prereqs: Prerequisites: senior standing; Economics major or concentration; BUAD 301, ECON 310; ECON 320 or ECON 325.

595711.title: Advanced Microeconomics
595711.description: Advanced treatment of decision-making by individuals and firms. Optimal resource allocation in partial and general equilibrium contexts. Topics include choice and preferences, duality, utility maximization, profit maximization, risk and uncertainty, information economics, and market power.
595711.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 310 , ECON 441 ; Economics graduate standing.

595712.title: Advanced Macroeconomics
595712.description: Advanced treatment of  long run economic growth models. Short run economic fluctuations and business cycle models. General equilibrium models. Dynamic inter-temporal optimization. Theories of consumption and saving. Models of unemployment and inflation. Monetary and fiscal policy.
595712.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 320 or ECON 325, ECON 441; or Economics graduate standing.

595713.title: Advanced Microeconometrics: Causality and Policy Evaluation
595713.description: Advanced estimation techniques of microeconomic data and panel data. Treatment Effects. Sample selection. Instrumental variables estimation. Limited dependent variable models. Use of econometric and statistical computer softwares.

595714.title: Advanced Macroeconometrics: Time Series and Forecasting
595714.description: Advanced estimation techniques of macroeconomic data. Economic forecasting. Time series econometrics. Stationarity and unit roots. Deterministic and stochastic processes. Vector Autoregressive Analysis. Macroeconomic applications. Use of econometric and statistical computer softwares.
595714.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 440 , ECON 441 ; Economics graduate standing.

595716.title: Microeconomic Perspective for Managers
595716.description: Behavior of demand-side consumers and supply side producers. Market structures, such as perfect competition, monopoly and oligopoly. Features of firm's organizational architecture. Game theory. Pricing strategies. Uncertainty and risk. Economics of information.
595716.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 135 ; or graduate standing except M.A. in Economics students.

595717.title: Macroeconomic Perspective for Managers
595717.description: National income, inflation and unemployment. Short run economic fluctuations and business cycles. Monetary and fiscal policy. The financial system and financial crises. Open economy, the exchange rate and the trade balance. Macroeconomic policy making. Economic forecasting using macroeconomic indicators. Not open to Economics graduate students or students with credit for ECON 320 or ECON 325.
595717.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE graduate (not Economics or pre-MBA) standing.

595718.title: Seminar in Financial Economics
595718.description: Valuation or corporate liabilities and other securities. Economic decision-making under uncertainty and asset pricing theories are analyzed rigorously. Other topics may include optimal capital structure, the market for corporate control, or macroeconomics aspects of finance. (FIN 528 and ECON 528 are the same course.)
595718.prereqs: Prerequisites: Economics graduate major - ECON 310, ECON 440, and ECON 320 or ECON 325; MBA major - ECON 515 or ECON 521, and ISDS 361A or ISDS 513.

598199.title: Seminar in Monetary Economics
598199.description: Advanced treatment of monetary policy issues. Topics may include the relevance of monetary policy, new Keynesian Economics, monetary policy shocks, price rigidities, optimal monetary policy, and monetary policy design.
598199.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 310, ECON 320 or ECON 325; or graduate standing and not pre-MBA.

595719.title: Seminar in International Economics
595719.description: Advanced treatment of macro or micro international economic issues. Topics may include international trade, trade policy, international finance, currency value, exchange rate regimes, macroeconomics of an open economy, international business cycles, offshoring and foreign direct investment, and globalization issues.
595719.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 310, ECON 320 or ECON 325; or graduate standing and not pre-MBA.

598559.title: Topics in Game Theory
598559.description: Advanced treatment of topics in game theory. Topics may include dynamic games and static games. Games of complete information and games of incomplete information. Nash Equilibrium. Auctions. Evolutionary Economics.
598559.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 310 , ECON 441 ; CBE graduate standing (not pre-MBA).

597827.title: Seminar in Development Economics
597827.description: Advanced treatment of macro or micro economic determinants of economic prosperity. Topics may include institutions, geography, culture, globalization, governance, conflict, inequality, corruption. Appropriate techniques used to address the core questions in the field of the deep determinants of economic development.
597827.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 310, ECON 320 or ECON 325; or graduate standing and not pre-MBA.

598589.title: Seminar in Environmental and Natural Resource Economics
598589.description: Environmental economics and natural resource economics topics, which may include market failures, public goods, environmental goods, policies for pollution, renewable and non-renewable resources, land and sustainability.
598589.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 310, ECON 320 or ECON 325; or graduate standing and not pre-MBA.

607229.title: Introduction to Machine Learning for Economic and Policy Analysis
607229.description: Hands-on introduction to the machine learning tools used in applied economic and policy analysis. Provides links between classical econometrics and deep learning. Real-world projects provide experience in applying neural networks and large-language models in causal analysis.
607229.prereqs: Prerequisite: ECON 442 or permission of the instructor.

595720.title: Seminar in Economic Analysis
595720.description: Special topics in microeconomic and macroeconomic analysis. Different topics in various microeconomic and macroeconomic fields.
595720.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 310, ECON 320 or ECON 325; or graduate standing and not pre-MBA.

595721.title: Current Research in Economics
595721.description: Read, present and replicate scholarly research published in peer-reviewed journals covering a variety of topics in economics. Receive guidance as to research methodology, composing a research paper and professional presentation. Attendance at departmental research seminars required.
595721.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 502 , ECON 503 ; ECON 504 or ECON 505 .

595722.title: Thesis Research
595722.description: Selection and approval of topic; outline; methodology; literature survey; data collection and analysis; presentation of results. Award of the grade is contingent upon the completion and acceptance of the thesis.
595722.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 502 , ECON 503 , ECON 504 ; Economics graduate standing. Pre- or corequisite: ECON 505 .

595723.title: Independent Graduate Research
595723.description: Directed advanced independent inquiry. May not be repeated for credit. Not open to students on academic notice. Requires consent of instructor, Department Chair, and the Graduate Studies Committee.
595723.prereqs: Prerequisites: ECON 502 , ECON 503 ; ECON 504 or ECON 505 ; Economics graduate standing.

597829.title: Induction Orientation for the Clear Administrative Services Credential Program (CASC)
597829.description: The Clear Administrative Services Credential Program is a job-embedded induction program providing candidates with opportunities to widen their expertise in school leadership. The Individualized Induction Plan (IIP) goals and actions provide for a significant "application-of-knowledge" component. A post-master's credential course. Students must have completed their Preliminary Administrative Services Credential. California requires administrators to begin their Clear Credential program within 120 days of starting in their position. Credit/No Credit only.

597830.title: Individualized Induction Planning for the Clear Administrative Services Credential Program (CASC)
597830.description: The second course in the EDAD 501 content series, this course focuses on the design and planning of the Individualized Induction Plan (IIP) as well content on organizational and instructional leadership.

598771.title: Individualized Induction Implementation for Clear Administrative Services Credential Program (CASC)
598771.description: Third course in the Clear Administrative Services Credential Program. Implement Individualized Induction Plan goals and actions to demonstrate advanced administrative skills.

598772.title: Individualized Induction Assessment for the Clear Administrative Services Credential Program (CASC)
598772.description: Fourth course in the content series for the Clear Administrative Services Credential. Focus on the assessment component of the Individualized Induction Plan.
598772.prereqs: Prerequisites: EDAD 501A , EDAD 501B , EDAD 501C . Corequisite: EDAD 502 .

598773.title: Clear Administrative Services Credential Program (CASC): Coaching
598773.description: A job-embedded induction program providing opportunities to widen expertise in school leadership. The supervisory coaching component taken with either the EDAD 501 content series or in conjunction with the EDD curriculum. Satisfies the coaching requirement for students working on their CASC.
598773.prereqs: Corequisite: EDAD 501A , EDAD 501B , EDAD 501C or EDAD 501D .

598531.title: Organizational Leadership and Management A
598531.description: Introduces organizational frameworks to understand schools and  leaders' roles in bringing about change in schools. Techniques used to guide, motivate, delegate, build consensus and lead others in the achievement of goals and vision.
598531.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Administrative Services Credential student or M.S. Educational Administration graduate standing.

598568.title: Organizational Leadership and Management B
598568.description: Use organizational theory and leadership studies to understand and bring about change in schools. Organization, structure and cultural context of schools, and study techniques used to develop, build consensus, lead others and implement shared vision and goals.

595724.title: P-12 Instructional Leadership and Assessment A
595724.description: Approaches for advocating, nurturing and sustaining a school culture and instructional program conducive to student learning and professional growth.
595724.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Administrative Services Credential student or M.S. Educational Administration graduate standing.

595725.title: Instructional Leadership in Higher Education
595725.description: Instructional leadership in higher educational settings and the role of the student development educator in advocating, nurturing and sustaining a culture that supports student learning and development.

595726.title: Instructional Leadership and Assessment B
595726.description: Use data and inquiry methods to assess students' learning and instructional practices. Apply data analysis to determine interventions and assess impact.
595726.prereqs: Prerequisites: Preliminary Credential student or M.S. Educational Administration graduate standing; EDAD 505A with a “B” (3.0) or better.

595727.title: History and Function of Community Colleges
595727.description: Overview of American and California community colleges, including  history, administration, and contemporary issues such as student development and learning outcomes, student diversity, access and equity.

595728.title: History and Philosophy of Higher Education
595728.description: Evolution of U.S. higher education, considering the diversity of the system, internal and external influences, and the evolution and development of student affairs and student learners.

595729.title: College Student Characteristics and Cultures
595729.description: Students in postsecondary education in the United States. Major demographic groups (race, class, ethnicity, age, ability, sexual orientation, gender, etc.) and their experiences with access, equity, campus cultures and retention at two- and four-year institutions.

595730.title: Student Learning and Development
595730.description: Student development theory in college, considering traditional and non-traditional students and learning outcomes. Theoretical assumptions and the practical application of theory to diverse student learners and the role of theory in student affairs practice.

595731.title: Diversity Access and Equity
595731.description: Diversity, access, equity, multiculturalism, pluralism as concepts in education. Understanding of these concepts and their applications to student affairs/higher education from a historical lens.

598333.title: Political Leadership
598333.description: Education policies and implementation strategies that influence policymaking and advance the community's understanding of education policy and its impact on student learning. The role of leaders in advocating for students in policy implementation and advocacy.
598333.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Administrative Services Credential student or M.S. Educational Administration graduate standing.

595735.title: Community Engagement for School Leaders
595735.description: Role of the school leader in engaging community and family stakeholders to transform schools and communities. Identifying and incorporating community and familial needs/resources in the vision of the school. Leadership, reflective practice, human relations, school leader's role in community outreach.
595735.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Administrative Services Credential student or M.S. Educational Administration graduate standing.

598334.title: Fieldwork
598334.description: Directed fieldwork in administrative areas in school. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
598334.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Administrative Services Credential student or M.S. Educational Administration graduate standing.

595736.title: Higher Ed Fieldwork
595736.description: At least 200 hours at two different sites demonstrating competence in applying theory to practice, assessment, evaluation, and program design and implementation, supervised by an approved educational leader who provides feedback for learning and growth as a student affairs educator/leader. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

597831.title: Foundations of Leadership through Equity in P-12 Schools
597831.description: This course will introduce conceptual underpinnings of program and examine theoretical frameworks and research methods that help school leaders promote just and equitable education for all students.

595737.title: Professional Seminar in Higher Education
595737.description: Application of technology for effective communication, verbal and written, and individual and group interactions on-line and face to face. Applying computers to work in student affairs/higher education settings.

595738.title: Directed Study in Educational Research
595738.description: Research under direction of a faculty member or principal investigator. Requires completing specified "deliverables" or outcomes. Develop intended learning outcomes and describe the methods for attaining each within the context of independent study, providing specific deliverables. Requires consent of program director or graduate advisor.

598335.title: Project
598335.description: Design and carry out an authentic research project at fieldwork school site. Connections between theory and evidence-based practice. Builds on EDAD 505A and extends learning from directed EDAD 567 fieldwork administrative experiences.
598335.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Administrative Services Credential student or M.S. Educational Administration graduate standing.

595739.title: Independent Graduate Research
595739.description: Independent inquiry for qualified students. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of instructor.

595740.title: Organizational Theory and Challenges for Instructional Leadership
595740.description: Organizational theories and their application to the role of educational leaders. Theories from leadership and management literatures, which predicate the conceptual development of the role of educational leadership. Implications of these theories for effective performance as educational leaders.

595742.title: Methods of Research: Qualitatively Based Methods
595742.description: Developing knowledge, dispositions and critical thinking skills necessary for conducting field research. Applying these skills to design and implement applied research projects that create knowledge for solving dilemmas related to educational leadership.

595744.title: Applications of Research: Forecasting and Planning
595744.description: Theories and methods that accurately forecast the impact of social, economic, political, cultural, academic and demographic trends as they affect educational institutions. How these indicators can be used to engage effective planning.

595745.title: Applications of Research: Collection and Analysis of Assessment Data
595745.description: Methods of system-level data collection and analysis of outcomes of education. Complexity and efficacy of using various types of data for making judgments at the system level about the effectiveness of instruction across classrooms and schools.

598887.title: Introduction to Methodology and Methods
598887.description: Introduction to methodological paradigms, research design concepts and data collection methods.

598852.title: Advanced Methodology
598852.description: Develop and plan methodology and data collection methods for dissertation study/project. Complete a written draft of the dissertation's methodology chapter.

598888.title: Dissertation Data Analysis
598888.description: Learn, use and apply multiple analytic approaches to analyze and work with data, which will be specific to each student and will apply toward the dissertation research.

595747.title: Inquiry 1
595747.description: Methods of conducting research using a mixed-methods orientation. Acquiring knowledge, dispositions and critical thinking skills necessary to understand educational research and descriptive statistical applications. Philosophical and epistemological foundations of educational research.

595748.title: Inquiry II
595748.description: Practical, philosophical and ethical considerations for data collection and analysis using quantitative, qualitative and mixed methods research designs. Significant quantitative and qualitative lab components utilizing quantitative and qualitative software.

595749.title: Inquiry III
595749.description: Applying the philosophical and epistemological foundations of educational research to the design of a formal research project. Draws upon educational research and the methods using a mixed-methods orientation that includes quantitative and qualitative perspectives.

595750.title: Ethical and Legal Dimensions of Instructional Leadership
595750.description: Concepts of ethics (e.g., self-interest, free will, social responsibility, duty) as the basis for legal standards (protection of individual rights, fair treatment, equality of opportunity, duty of care, public trust) through the study of education case law.

595751.title: Leadership of Curricular and Instructional Practices
595751.description: Current issues in curriculum design and implementation. Forces affecting the curriculum; curriculum continuity and articulation; content trends in the subject areas; appropriate curriculum for students from diverse backgrounds; curriculum censorship; and effective instructional leadership for school curriculum improvement.

595752.title: Higher Education, Community College Systems, Structures, and Cultures
595752.description: Higher education, from Egyptian Era to the diversity of current postsecondary instructions, philosophies and orientations. Organizational development and structures of higher educational systems and the impact of faculty, student and administrative cultures on higher education leaders.

595753.title: Human Dimensions of Educational Change
595753.description: Issues associated with change. Change as a sociopolitical process; sources and purpose of change; coping with multiple reform efforts; decision-making processes; reform implementation; problems of resistance to change in curriculum and instruction; and change as a continuous process.

595754.title: Resource Management and Development
595754.description: Practical applications and skills for college resource management in personnel, structures, facilities, technologies, finances, programs and services. Optimizing resources through management and creative leadership that encourage and support collaboration across divisions.

595755.title: Social Contexts of Education Politics, Policy and Governance
595755.description: Topics relevant to instructional leadership and educational policy cycles. Policy-making process, role of values and interest groups, policy analysis, equality of educational opportunity, how policy efforts are reshaped and systemic reform. Policy issues, including high-stakes testing, curricular mandates and accountability.

595756.title: Student Learning and Development
595756.description: Student development and learning theories based on cognitive, psychosocial, typology and person-environment perspectives. Role of faculty and others in the collaborative development and implementation of responsive curricula and co-curricula at two- and four-year institutions.

595757.title: Transforming Teaching and Education through Resource Optimization
595757.description: Perspectives on how optimizing resources can transform education through a multidisciplinary approach. Identifying economic, social and political resources; innovative ways to develop new streams of resources and policies and procedures that increase highly productive ways to use resources.

595758.title: Integrative Seminar in Higher Education/Community College Issues
595758.description: Current issues in higher education/community colleges from local to global perspectives, reinforcing a multilens view of higher educational studies. Opportunities for interactions with experts and to engage in questions/challenges and data-driven solution-focused discussions.

595759.title: Epistemology, History and Structure of Contemporary Education
595759.description: Epistemological and historical trends that have shaped the structure of contemporary education. Influence of major schools of thought, including rationalism, empiricism, pragmatism, behaviorism and constructivism; and how modern education structure, curriculum and pedagogy have been influenced by these various perspectives.

595760.title: Leadership for Change and Collaboration
595760.description: Research on leadership and organizational change in higher education, multicultural organizational development, forecasting, planning and change analyzed. Community relations needed to develop programs responsive to workforce and community needs. Educational codes, laws, policies and practices impacting higher education.
595760.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to the program; EDD 600 .

595761.title: Linking Research to Problems of Practice
595761.description: Identifying complex problems of educational practice appropriate for doctoral research. Small-group instruction provides coaching that enables students to initiate the research cycle by linking research to problems of practices.

595762.title: Connecting Research Questions to Scholarship in the Discipline
595762.description: Assists in writing a critical review of the professional literature pertaining to the identified research problem.

595763.title: Written Qualifying Examination
595763.description: Preparation for the EDD Qualifying Examination, a prerequisite for advancing to candidacy in the doctoral program.

595764.title: Refining Research Questions
595764.description: Further refine research questions or hypotheses, select the research method to investigate the research question, design a research study that specifies methods to be implemented for data collection and analysis.
595764.prereqs: Prerequisites: Ed.D. standing; EDD 670A , EDD 670B , EDD 670C ; passing EDD Qualifying Examination.

595765.title: Proposal Defense Preparation
595765.description: Assists in writing a defensible dissertation research proposal reflecting high quality scholarship.
595765.prereqs: Prerequisites: Ed.D. standing; EDD 670A , EDD 670B , EDD 670C ; passing EDD Qualifying Examination.

595766.title: IRB Approval and Proposal Defense
595766.description: Obtain CSUF IRB approval and submit a revised and completed dissertation research proposal in preparation for the dissertation proposal defense.
595766.prereqs: Prerequisites: Ed.D. standing; EDD 670A , EDD 670B , EDD 670C , EDD 670D , EDD 670E ; passing EDD Qualifying Examination.

598889.title: Research Writing Support
598889.description: Strengthens scholarly writing skills, focusing on paraphrasing, synthesizing sources and organizing a small-scale literature review.

597839.title: Seminar in Educational Research Design and Implementation
597839.description: Assists in designing, completing and defending a scholarly dissertation research study. Develop intended measurable outcomes and establish methods, timetables and specific deliverables for the completion of those outcomes in consultation with the course instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 12 units. Requires consent of program director or graduate advisor.

595767.title: Dissertation Research
595767.description: Individual research on a dissertation. Conferences with a faculty adviser and committee members, culminating in the publication of a dissertation. May be repeated for a maximum of 12 units.

595768.title: Independent Study
595768.description: Independent doctoral level inquiry for qualified students.

595008.title: Analytical Methods in Archaeology
595008.description: Employing physical data collecting techniques (e.g., photographic, paleomagnetic) in the field, and analyzing artifact collections and data from previous field operations in the laboratory. May be repeated once for credit as an elective. (1 hour lecture, 6 hours laboratory)

595009.title: Descriptive Linguistics
595009.description: Sounds (phonology), forms and meanings (morphology), and syntax of languages. Examples and problem-solving in various languages. (LING 406 and ANTH 406 are the same course.)

597773.title: The Anthropology of Human Rights
597773.description: Introduction to the study of human rights from anthropological and interdisciplinary perspectives. Examine human rights issues and specific cases of human rights abuses within the context of international and ethno-specific domains.

598624.title: Global Ethnographies of Food
598624.description: Ethnographic approach to global food systems. Production, circulation and consumption of food; emphasizing the cultural politics of food as it relates to local identity and notions of global citizenship.
598624.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 4A or ANTH 102 or graduate standing

595010.title: Economic Anthropology
595010.description: Ethnology and ethnography of economic life, principally in non-Western societies; operation of systems of production and distribution within diverse cultural contexts.

595011.title: Anthropology of Tourism
595011.description: Tourism and travel as cultural practices. Domestic and international tourism; perspective of hosts and travelers; global economy and tourism; souvenirs, artifacts and symbolic landscapes; tourism as pilgrimage.

595012.title: Anthropological Linguistics
595012.description: Nature and functions of language; language structure and change; classification of languages; use of linguistic evidence in anthropology. (ANTH 416 and LING 416 are the same course.)

595014.title: Visual Anthropology
595014.description: Development of the field of visual anthropology and the changing and diverse approaches to the use of visual media in representing and interpreting other cultures.

598704.title: Archaeology of South America
598704.description: Development of South American cultures over a 13,000-year time span based on archaeological and interdisciplinary evidence. Follows a temporal and regional approach to the prehistory of South American cultures; includes Indigenous, post-contact and other postcolonial South American archaeologies.

598625.title: Mass Media Cross-Culturally
598625.description: Media and popular culture in a variety of cultural and national contexts. The centrality of mass media to contemporary life, and the need for anthropology to explore its analytical and practical significance.
598625.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 4A or ANTH 102 or graduate standing

595003.title: The Ancient Maya
595003.description: Archaeology and ethnohistory of the Maya area of Southern Mesoamerica. Problems of initial settlement of the area and the rise and dynamics of ancient Maya civilization.

595004.title: The Aztecs and Their Predecessors
595004.description: Archaeological survey of principal Mesoamerica pre-Columbian cultures north and west of the Maya area. Aztecs and their predecessors, religion, art, architecture, intellectual achievements and the Olmec heritage.

598197.title: Lithic Analysis
598197.description: Teaches students about key theoretical and methodological facets of prehistoric lithic (stone) artifact analysis. Through readings, discussions, and lab practicums students will learn how archaeological lithic analysts infer pertinent technological, behavioral, and social information about the past.

598705.title: Bioarchaeology
598705.description: Scientific study of human remains from archaeological sites. How bioarchaeologists generate and solve research questions about past human lives, populations and societies. Professional and ethical standards in research design in bioarchaeology. Contemporary ethical issues.
598705.prereqs: Prerequisite: ANTH 101 , ANTH 102 or ANTH 103 ; or graduate standing.

598474.title: Settlement Patterns
598474.description: Introduction to settlement pattern studies in archaeology. Dispersion of aggregates and households within communities, and communities within regions, as a way to study political, social and economic organization in past societies.

598502.title: Anthropology of Death and Mortuary Practices
598502.description: Cultural practices relating to death. Burial practices, believes about the afterlife and memorializing the dead in diverse cultural contexts, both contemporary and ancient. Integrate archaeological, linguistic, cultural and biological data in a holistic approach.
598502.prereqs: Prerequisites: ANTH 102, GE Area 3B, GE Area 4A or graduate standing.

595015.title: Human Variation
595015.description: Processes underlying and the theories for the existence of the present variation between and within human populations. Genetics of human populations and the significance of racial classifications. (2 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory)
595015.prereqs: Prerequisites: ANTH 343 ; ANTH 301 , ANTH 322 or ANTH 344 .

595017.title: Advanced Topics in Human Osteology
595017.description: Analytical methods stressing morphological examination of human bone in a laboratory setting (determination of human, prehistoric; analysis of fragmented and commingled remains; basic identification and report writing; pathological conditions). For those interested in archaeology, hominid evolution and/or forensic science.
595017.prereqs: Prerequisites: ANTH 343 ; ANTH 301 , ANTH 322 or ANTH 344 .

598238.title: Forensic Anthropology
598238.description: Forensic Anthropology and associated techniques and skills. Work with human remains to estimate age, determine sex, ancestry, stature and any other evidence relevant to forensic studies.

595018.title: Quantitative Methods in Anthropology
595018.description: Develops skills and knowledge in the application of quantitative methods in anthropological research. Integrated approach to research design, data collection, data management and data analysis through hands-on training.
595018.prereqs: Prerequisites: Anthropology major or minor, junior or senior standing.

595019.title: Advanced Evolutionary Anthropology
595019.description: Uses life history theory to examine the evolutionary ecology of human behavior. Human life course, resource acquisition, parenting and fertility. Computer labs utilizing eHRAF. (ANTH 451 and BIOL 451 are the same course.)

595021.title: Human Evolutionary Anatomy
595021.description: Uses an evolutionary framework to conduct an in-depth and detailed examination of the structure and function of human anatomical systems, their interaction, and their evolutionary histories and how those histories affect health in modern populations.

595022.title: Primate Conservation
595022.description: Uses behavioral ecology and life history theory to understand issues surrounding conservation of non human primates. Develop theoretical background crucial to understanding the population dynamics and ecological principles driving primate conservation strategies.

598306.title: Behavioral Observation
598306.description: Preparation to conduct advanced behavioral observation research from an anthropological perspective. Research design, data collection techniques, ethical and other considerations unique to varied data collection settings, computerized resources and literature resources. Incorporates service learning.

598449.title: Sustainable Urban Food Systems
598449.description: This course develops students' skills and knowledge in the natural, social, and economic environment. Students will learn an integrated approach to understanding urban ecosystems and food security through sustainable urban agriculture.

598476.title: Cultural Resource Management
598476.description: Current professional and ethical responsibilities of archaeologists in Cultural Resource Management (CRM). Review local, state and federal legislation affecting the protection and preservation of archaeological sites and other cultural resources.

598499.title: California Archaeology
598499.description: Evolution and development of native California Indian tribes over a 13,000-year time span are based on archaeological and anthropological data. Follows a temporal and regional approach in covering prehistory, ethnography and early history of native California cultures.

598498.title: Archaeofaunal Analysis
598498.description: Method, theory and lab work in analyses of archaeofaunal remains recovered from archaeological sites and reconstruction of prehistoric subsistence patterns and paleoenvironments based on faunal remains. Vertebrate skeletal identification, taphonomy, subsistence studies and quantification.

598626.title: Los Angeles/Mumbai: Cinematic City Cross-Culturally
598626.description: The relationship between cinema and contemporary urban life and the interconnections between city life, cityscapes and cinematic representations of Los Angeles and Mumbai, cities that are home to two of the largest film industries in the world.
598626.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 4A or ANTH 102 or graduate standing

598855.title: Anthropology of Race and Media in the United States
598855.description: Depictions of race and ethnicity in media and popular culture in the U.S., focusing on historical, cultural, socio-economic, political and transnational contexts of racial representations. Considers historical and contemporary examples from theater, film, television, advertising, music and digital media.
598855.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or graduate standing.

598477.title: Archaeological Investigations
598477.description: Methodology and practice of archaeological fieldwork. May be repeated for credit. (1 hour lecture, 6 hours laboratory)

595023.title: History of Anthropology
595023.description: Principal contributions of anthropologists 1850-1950; evolutionary, diffusionist, historical, particularist, configurationalist, and culture and personality approaches in anthropology.

595024.title: Contemporary Anthropology
595024.description: Anthropologists from 1950 to present; neoevolutionist, sociological, structuralist, psychological and symbolic approaches.

598506.title: Globalization and Culture Change
598506.description: Interrelations between global, cultural and social processes that affect culture change, including transnationalism, migration, technology, media (including social media), tourism, development and other factors related to globalization. Anthropological contributions to theory and practice through selected examples in applied anthropology.
598506.prereqs: Prerequisites: ANTH 102, GE Area 3B, GE Area 4A or graduate standing.

597754.title: Anthropology of Digital Media
597754.description: Digital media practices, social media, cultural production and practices. Ethnographic analysis of culture formation in virtual worlds; cultural variations in the use of digital media; social media and identity; the use of media in social and political activism.
597754.prereqs: Prerequisites: ANTH 102, GE Area 3B, GE Area 4A or graduate standing.

595025.title: Undergraduate Seminar in Anthropology
595025.description: Topics in anthropology. May be repeated once for credit with a different topic.
595025.prereqs: Prerequisites: ANTH 101 , ANTH 102 , ANTH 103 ; or graduate standing.

595026.title: Internship in Anthropology
595026.description: Career opportunities. On-the-job training under faculty supervision in museum, industry or governmental service. One or more papers required. May be repeated once for credit.
595026.prereqs: Prerequisites: 18 upper-division units in anthropology or related fields.

595027.title: Museum Practicum
595027.description: Practical experience in museum operations, using the facilities of the Anthropology Museum. Exhibit preparation, membership and funding operations, catalogue preparation and outreach activities. May be repeated once for credit.

595028.title: Independent Study
595028.description: Individual research project involving either library or fieldwork. Conferences with the adviser as necessary. Results in one or more papers. May be repeated for a maximum of six units. Requires consent of adviser.

598307.title: Seminar: Selected Topics in Anthropology
598307.description: The chosen topic and a general outline of the seminar are circulated prior to registration. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

595029.title: Grammatical Analysis
595029.description: Word formation in a variety of languages with emphasis on the terminology used to describe morphological representation on various levels; problem solving of selected language data. (LING 507 and ANTH 507 are the same course.)

595030.title: Research Design in Anthropology
595030.description: Introduction to anthropological research. Develop skills in designing a research project; literature search and review; applying quantitative, qualitative and mixed methods; understanding ethical considerations in anthropology; identifying funding opportunities; proposal preparation; and oral presentation.

598308.title: Theory and Method in Evolutionary Anthropology
598308.description: Basic theoretical positions and methodological spectrum in evolutionary anthropology.

598478.title: Theory and Method in Archaeology
598478.description: Basic theoretical positions and methodological spectrum in archaeological anthropology. Requires instructor permission.
598478.prereqs: Prerequisite: senior standing; or graduate standing.

598309.title: Theory and Method in Cultural/Linguistic Anthropology
598309.description: Basic theoretical positions and methodological spectrum in cultural and linguistic anthropology.

595031.title: Project
595031.description: Complete a project derived from original field or laboratory research, and/or from library study. Project could also be a museum exhibit, field report or other project. A copy of the approved written component of the project must be filed in the department through the department graduate program adviser. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of project adviser.

595032.title: Thesis
595032.description: Complete a thesis derived from original field or laboratory research, and/or from library study. A copy of the approved thesis must be submitted to the department through the department graduate program adviser, and a copy of the thesis must be approved by the University Graduate Studies Office for submission to the bookstore for binding and microfilming. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of thesis adviser.

595033.title: Independent Graduate Research
595033.description: Individual research involving fieldwork, laboratory, or library study, and conferences with a project adviser as necessary, and resulting in one or more papers. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of adviser.

596756.title: Fundamental Arabic-A
596756.description: Introduction to essentials of Modern Standard Arabic vocabulary and structures. Basic reading, writing, and conversational skills using culturally appropriate language. Conducted primarily in Arabic.

596757.title: Fundamental Arabic-B
596757.description: Continuation of systematic introduction of fundamental vocabulary and grammatical structures of Modern Standard Arabic. Sustained development of reading, writing and speaking skills with a focus on culture. Conducted primarily in Arabic.

596758.title: Intermediate Arabic-A
596758.description: Instruction in listening and reading comprehension, and oral and writing practice, in Arabic based on cultural and literary materials, with further development in vocabulary and grammar. Conducted primarily in Arabic.

596759.title: Directed Study
596759.description: Supervised research projects in Arabic language, literature, culture, linguistics or business, to be taken with consent of instructor and department chair. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units.

595034.title: Introduction to Art
595034.description: Historical and contemporary art forms of painting, sculpture, architecture and design. Field trips required. Not open to art majors for credit except by permission of Art Department. (3 hours lecture)

595035.title: Two-Dimensional Design
595035.description: Art concepts, aesthetic elements and materials of two-dimensional design and visual organization. (6 hours activity)

595036.title: Three-Dimensional Design
595036.description: Art concepts, aesthetic elements and materials of three-dimensional design and spatial organization. (6 hours activity)

595037.title: Beginning Ceramics
595037.description: Form as related to ceramic materials, tools and processes. Kiln loading and firing, hand building, wheel throwing and raku. (9 hours laboratory)

595038.title: Beginning Ceramics
595038.description: Form as related to ceramics. Glaze batching and its application, and the presentation of ceramic technique. (9 hours laboratory)

595039.title: Beginning Drawing
595039.description: Traditional and contemporary use of drawing materials integrated with visual experiences and art concepts. (6 hours activity)

595040.title: Beginning Painting
595040.description: Traditional and contemporary use of painting materials integrated with visual experiences and art concepts. (6 hours activity)

595041.title: Life Drawing
595041.description: Drawing the live model. (6 hours activity)

595042.title: Descriptive Drawing
595042.description: Descriptive drawing, rendering techniques and theories representing forms of nature. (6 hours activity)

598894.title: Explore Core: Fear and Fantasy
598894.description: Fear and fantasy through multiple disciplinary lenses and methods. The experience, representation and response to fear across cultures, generations and time periods. Use multidisciplinary approaches to understanding fear and fantasy, drawing from developmental psychology, art, popular culture, history and engineering. (AMST 132, ART 132, CAS 132 and EGME 132 are the same course)

595043.title: Art and Civilization
595043.description: Ideas, forms and styles of the visual arts as they developed in various cultures from prehistoric time to the present. (3 hours lecture)

595044.title: Art and Civilization
595044.description: Ideas, forms and styles of the visual arts as they developed in various cultures from prehistoric time to the present. (3 hours lecture)

595045.title: Beginning Crafts
595045.description: Traditional and contemporary concepts and processes with emphasis on design principles in the development of aesthetic forms based on function. (6 hours activity)

595046.title: Beginning Crafts
595046.description: Development of esthetic forms based on function, with emphasis on design principles and the creative use of hand tools and power equipment. (6 hours activity)

595047.title: Drawing and Painting (Experimental Methods and Materials)
595047.description: Traditional and contemporary concepts. Image-making using various materials and approaches (representation and abstraction). (6 hours activity)

595048.title: Drawing and Painting (Experimental Methods and Materials)
595048.description: Traditional and contemporary concepts. Image-making using various materials and approaches (representation and abstraction). (6 hours activity)

595049.title: Beginning Sculpture
595049.description: Creative use of wood and metal, power equipment and hand tools. (6 hours activity)

595050.title: Beginning Sculpture
595050.description: Creative use of wood and metal, power equipment and hand tools. (6 hours activity)

598865.title: Life Drawing for Animation
598865.description: Continuing study of the human figure. Develops animation student's skills of drawing from observation.

595051.title: Lettering and Typography
595051.description: History, design and use of letter forms; the rendering and use of hand-lettered forms. (6 hours activity)

595052.title: Lettering and Typography
595052.description: History, design and use of letter forms; techniques for rough and comprehensive layouts and introduction to computer graphics. (6 hours activity)

595053.title: Typography into Graphic Design
595053.description: Technology and its application to typographic and graphic design solutions. Conceptual understanding of current technology as medium and tool in the creative process. (6 hours activity)

595054.title: Introduction to Glass
595054.description: A survey of glass working techniques in glass blowing, hot glass casting, kiln forming, and cold fabrication.

595055.title: Photo Visual Concepts
595055.description: Introductory photography course for art majors. Includes the study of photographic vision and design, visual conceptualization and examination of the qualities of light through the use of instant and automatic cameras. (6 hours activity)

598571.title: Principles of Animation
598571.description: Foundational principles and practices of character animation, including mechanics of movement, animation problems and acting, taught using 2D Digital animation tools or pencil/paper.

598572.title: Principles of Traditional Animation
598572.description: Foundational principles and practices of character animation, including mechanics of movement, animation problems and acting, taught using pencil/paper.

597939.title: Principles of Animation
597939.description: Foundational principles and practices of character animation including, mechanics of movement, animation problems and acting. May be taught using pencil/paper, 2D Digital or 3D Digital tools (see notes in class schedule). May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
597939.prereqs: Prerequisites: ART 103 , ART 104 , ART 117 . Corequisite: ART 217 .

595056.title: Introduction to 3D Computer Animation
595056.description: Fundamentals of 3D digital animation production. Introduction to the Maya interface and tools necessary to create 3D assets and explore animation principles. (6 hours activity)

598573.title: Introduction to 3D Modeling
598573.description: Fundamentals of 3D modeling through content creation of props, environments and characters specific to game engines and animation production workflows.

598574.title: Introduction to 3D Animation
598574.description: Fundamentals of 3D animation exploring the 12 principles of animation for both keyframe computer animation production workflows and integration into game engines.
598574.prereqs: Prerequisites: ART 103 , ART 104 , ART 107A , ART 107B . Corequisite: ART 117 .

595057.title: Perspective Drawing
595057.description: Introduction to linear perspective systems used to develop and place natural and fabricated forms in space on a two-dimensional surface. Integrated with methods and techniques of rendering light, shadow and reflection on varied subject matter including the human figure. (6 hours activity)

595058.title: Writing in the Visual Arts
595058.description: Principles, practices and objectives of writing in the visual arts. Includes descriptive, analytical and expressive essays; project and grant proposals; artist's statements; resumes; and professional correspondence. Satisfies the classroom portion of the upper-division writing requirements for art majors.

595061.title: Advanced Ceramics
595061.description: Traditional and contemporary use of ceramic methods, materials and concepts. (6 hours activity)

595062.title: Advanced Ceramics
595062.description: Traditional and contemporary use of ceramic methods, materials and concepts. (6 hours activity)

595063.title: Drawing and Painting
595063.description: Concepts, materials and activities in drawing and painting, emphasizing individual skills, ideas, and expression. (6 hours activity)

598479.title: Drawing and Painting
598479.description: Concepts, materials and activities in drawing and painting, emphasizing individual skills, ideas, and expression. (6 hours activity)

595064.title: Watercolor
595064.description: Watercolor media related to varied subject matter and design applications. Includes field trip activity. Provides skills and concepts useful for school art programs. (6 hours activity)

597704.title: Watercolor
597704.description: Watercolor media related to varied subject matter and design applications. Includes field trip activity. Provides skills and concepts useful for school art programs. (6 hours activity)

595065.title: Foundations of Modern Art
595065.description: History of painting and sculpture from the French Revolution to the end of the 19th century.
595065.prereqs: Prerequisite: junior, senior or postbaccalaureate standing.

595066.title: Modern Art
595066.description: The history of painting, graphic arts and sculpture from late 19th century to World War II.

595067.title: Jewelry
595067.description: Designing and creating jewelry. (6 hours activity)

595068.title: Jewelry
595068.description: Designing and creating jewelry. (6 hours activity)

598228.title: Metalsmithing
598228.description: Metal forming processes such as forging, raising and construction for jewelers, animators, and 3-D object makers. Research in contemporary and historical metal forms, body armor and 3-D Art. Required for the Jewelry and Metalsmithing concentration and open to all concentrations as an Upper Division Elective.

598227.title: Metalsmithing
598227.description: Intermediate-level study of the theories and processes of metal forming, fabrication, forging, raising, construction. Research in contemporary and historical metalsmithing and 3-D metal forms. Required for the Jewelry and Metalsmithing concentration; open to all concentrations as an upper-division elective.

595069.title: Sculpture
595069.description: Sculptural materials and processes. (6 hours activity)

595070.title: Sculpture
595070.description: Sculptural materials and processes. (6 hours activity)

595071.title: Life Studies, Drawing
595071.description: Drawing from the live model. Observation and anatomy. Concepts and techniques in drawing the figure. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. (6 hours activity)

595072.title: Life Studies, Painting
595072.description: Painting from the live model. Observation, structure and color. Concepts and techniques in painting the figure. (6 hours activity)

594896.title: Financial Accounting
594896.description: Accounting concepts and techniques essential to the administration of a business enterprise: analyzing and recording financial transactions; accounting valuation and allocation practices; preparation, analysis and interpretation of financial statements; international accounting issues.

594897.title: Managerial Accounting
594897.description: Introduction to managerial accounting; product costing; budgetary control and responsibility accounting; analysis and techniques for aiding management planning and control decisions; basic income tax concepts for planning business transactions.
594897.prereqs: Prerequisite: ACCT 201A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

594898.title: Intermediate Accounting
594898.description: Accounting theory; preparation of income statements, balance sheets, and statements of cash flows and comprehensive income; IFRS (International Financial Reporting Standards); present value concepts; assets, revenue recognition and investments.
594898.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 201B ; completion of all lower-division Business Administration core courses all with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: BUAD 301 .

594899.title: Intermediate Accounting
594899.description: Accounting theory; IFRS (International Financial Reporting Standards); present value concepts; liabilities and stockholders' equity; pensions; leases; earnings per share; financial statement analysis; accounting changes and error analysis; accounting for income taxes and statement of cash flows.
594899.prereqs: Prerequisites: CBE undergraduate standing (not CBE premajor) - ACCT 301A , BUAD 301 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or CBE graduate standing (not M.A. Economics).

594900.title: Cost Accounting
594900.description: Accounting information for management of manufacturing and service enterprises; cost records; cost behavior and allocation; product costing and inventory valuation; flexible budgeting; standard costs; responsibility accounting; cost planning and control; and operating decision analysis.
594900.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 201B ; completion of all lower-division Business Administration core courses with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: BUAD 301 .

594901.title: Accounting Information Systems
594901.description: Organization and implementation of information technology for the collection, organization and presentation of accounting information with an emphasis on enterprise resource planning systems.
594901.prereqs: Prerequisites: CBE undergraduate standing (not CBE premajor) - completion of all lower-division Business Administration core courses with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: BUAD 301 ; or CBE graduate standing (not M.A. Economics).

594902.title: Concepts of Federal Income Tax Accounting
594902.description: Federal tax system, federal income taxation relating to federal tax system, federal income taxation relating to individuals, corporations, partnerships and fiduciaries. Federal estate and gift taxes.
594902.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 201B ; completion of all lower-division Business Administration core courses all with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: BUAD 301 .

594903.title: Advanced Accounting
594903.description: Business combinations; meaning, usefulness and methodology of consolidated financial statements; investments and additional advanced topics; consolidated financial statements for overseas units of U.S.-based multinational companies; translations of foreign currencies, derivatives.
594903.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 301B with a “C” (2.0) or better; BUAD 301 ; or CBE graduate standing (not pre-MBA).

594904.title: Auditing
594904.description: Auditing standards and procedures used by financial and operational auditors. Management information and computer systems, internal control, audit evidence, professional responsibilities and legal liabilities, standards of reporting financial information.
594904.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 301B , ACCT 307 all with “C” (2.0) or better; BUAD 301 ; or CBE graduate standing (not pre-MBA).

594905.title: Accounting for Governmental and Nonprofit Entities
594905.description: Fund accounting as applied to governmental and nonprofit entities; state and federal governments, municipalities, hospitals and universities. Budgets, tax levies, revenues and appropriations, expenditures and encumbrances, various types of funds and accounting statements.
594905.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 301B with a “C” (2.0) or better; BUAD 301 .

598689.title: Emerging Technologies in Accounting
598689.description: Learning and applying (in the field of accounting) technologies that will become a cornerstone for success, such as Robotic Process Automation using UIPath, as well as data extraction using Microsoft Power Query.
598689.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 301A , ACCT 301B , all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or Accounting graduate standing.

594906.title: Forensic Accounting and Fraud Examination
594906.description: Methods to prevent and detect fraud. Current cases dealing with accounting fraud and appropriate methods to prevent or detect fraudulent behavior.
594906.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 307 , ACCT 301B with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598587.title: Accounting Data Analytics
598587.description: Data analytics as it pertains to accounting professionals. Three major areas that comprise analytics are Data Reporting, Data Visualization and Predictive Analytics. Uses emerging technology to show the practice of data analytics in the real world.
598587.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 301A , ACCT 301B , ACCT 302 , ACCT 307 all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

594907.title: Taxation of Business Entities
594907.description: Additional tax knowledge on tax research, corporate taxation, partnership taxation, S Corps, transfer taxation, gift taxes and accounting for income tax. Other topics, such as SALT, may be included.
594907.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 308 with a “C” (2.0) or better; BUAD 301 .
