598148.title: Accounting Ethics for Professionals
598148.description: The philosophy and behavioral and economic theories of ethics, and the role of ethics in accounting and other professions in which accountants work. Ethics regulations.
598148.prereqs: Prerequisite: ACCT 301B ; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

607226.title: Accounting for Environmental, Social and Corporate Governance
607226.description: Fundamental concepts of ESG (environmental, social and governance) reporting.
607226.prereqs: Prerequisite: ACCT 301B with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

594908.title: Advanced Cost Accounting
594908.description: Advanced topics in accounting: strategic profitability analysis; cost allocation and resources; quality and Just-In Time Inventory; and investment decisions and management control.
594908.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 302 , ISDS 361A all with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: ISDS 361B .

594909.title: Internal Audit and Control
594909.description: Professional standards and procedures used by internal auditors. Planning, performing, communicating risk based assurance and consulting engagements. Advanced topics in control; governance, risk management, fraud and information technology. Requires departmental permission for non-Accounting undergraduate majors and all graduate students.

594910.title: Valuation Concepts and Topics for Accountants
594910.description: Conceptual framework for valuation. Students will apply the framework in a number of settings they are likely to encounter as accounting professionals (i.e., fair value of financial assets, goodwill impairment).
594910.prereqs: Prerequisite: ACCT 301B with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

594911.title: Seminar in Financial Statement Analysis
594911.description: Analysis of demand and supply forces underlying the provision of financial statements; distributional, cross-sectional and time series properties of financial statement numbers; financial decision-making processes and the uses of financial statement information for decision making.
594911.prereqs: Prerequisite: ACCT 301B with a “C” (2.0) or better.

594912.title: Financial Controls for Entrepreneurs
594912.description: Accounting system design for new ventures, including budgeting, purchasing, collections, payroll taxes, safeguards against error and embezzlement, financial reports, cash management and banking relationships. Casework, research and fieldwork with selected local businesses. Not applicable for graduate degree credit.

594913.title: Internship
594913.description: Planned and supervised work experience. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Letter grade or credit/no credit. Requires consent of the department internship adviser and one semester in residence at the university.
594913.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 301A , ACCT 302 , BUAD 301 all with a “C” (2.0) or better; Business Administration Accounting concentration major; minimum 2.5 GPA; or graduate standing.

594914.title: Independent Study
594914.description: Open to qualified undergraduate students desiring to pursue directed independent inquiry. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Not open to students on academic probation. Requires permission of department chair.
594914.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 301B , BUAD 301 all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

594915.title: Accounting Theory and Professional Research
594915.description: Provides an analytical framework for managerial decision-making using accounting information. Explore solutions to professional accounting problems by researching the FASB Codification.
594915.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 301B ; CBE graduate standing (not pre-MBA).

594916.title: Seminar in Accounting Data Analytics
594916.description: Introduction to data extraction, analytic and data visualization tools used in business today, and techniques for Big Data analyses. Hands-on experience with several key tools used to transform raw data into actionable knowledge.

598731.title: Advanced Accounting Analytics and Technology
598731.description: Gain in-depth knowledge of a number of widely used data analytics tools. Case studies will allow students to apply data analytics tools to solve real-life accounting and auditing problems.

594917.title: Seminar in Auditing
594917.description: Auditing theory and practices; professional ethics; auditing standards; Securities and Exchange Commission and stock exchange regulations; auditor's legal liability; statement trends and techniques.
594917.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 402 ; CBE graduate (no pre-MBA) standing.

594918.title: Seminar in Professional Accounting Communications
594918.description: Compilation and composition of accounting reports and client presentations relating to accountants' working papers, client engagement letters, management advisory reports and prospectuses.

594919.title: Seminar in Accounting Information Systems
594919.description: Case studies of computer-based accounting systems used by organizations such as universities, banks, industrial corporations and CPA firms. Accounting information, reports, and internal controls.

594920.title: Seminar in Tax Planning
594920.description: Substantive provisions of federal law; tax planning from a corporate viewpoint; case studies of the effect of federal tax law on business decisions.
594920.prereqs: Prerequisite: ACCT 308 ; or (not pre-MBA) graduate standing.

594921.title: Financial Accounting
594921.description: Accumulation, organization and interpretation of financial and quantitative data relevant to the activities of corporate business enterprises; analysis of financial reports; current regulatory reporting requirements with attention to business ethics and an understanding of global reporting issues.

594922.title: Seminar in Managerial Accounting
594922.description: Design and develop cost accounting systems; contemporary cost management concepts; measurement, analysis and use of accounting information for management decisions with attention to current ethical, global and environmental issues. Measurement, analysis and use of information contained in standard and various cost systems for industry sectors.

594923.title: Advanced Management Accounting and Controls
594923.description: Integrative aspects of accounting, financial and quantitative data for managerial decision-making; long-term, short-term profit planning; budgetary control; cost analysis; financial analysis and planning; taxation; and transfer pricing.
594923.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 302 or ACCT 511 ; not pre-MBA.

597821.title: Corporate Governance and External Reporting
597821.description: Institutional knowledge on internal and external corporate governance mechanisms and the SEC regulation of financial reporting. How to prepare SEC filings and learn about how corporate governance influences firm performance.
597821.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 301B ; CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

597822.title: Seminar in Taxation of Corporations and Shareholders - Corp 1
597822.description: Federal Taxation relating to corporations including accounting methods, business deductions, selection of tax year, organization, distribution, liquidation, redemption and reorganization of/from the corporate entity.
597822.prereqs: Prerequisite: ACCT 308 ; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA or MS Taxation) standing.

597938.title: Tax Research, Practice and Procedures
597938.description: Methodology of tax research, including case studies; the management of a tax practice; administration procedures governing tax controversies; rights and obligations of taxpayers and tax practitioners. Requires basic knowledge of US Federal Income Tax.

594924.title: Seminar in Taxation of Corporations and Shareholders Corp. II
594924.description: Federal taxation relating to corporations; organizing, distributions, liquidations and reorganizations.
594924.prereqs: Prerequisite: ACCT 308 ; or (not pre-MBA) graduate standing.

594925.title: Seminar in Taxation of Property and M&A Transactions
594925.description: Concepts, rules and issues with regard to the taxation of transactions involving different types of property. Taxation of property transactions when a buyer acquires another company.
594925.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 308 ; CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

594926.title: Seminar in Taxation of International Business Operations
594926.description: Federal taxation relating to U.S. citizens and corporations with foreign source income and of foreign persons with U.S. source income; planning for foreign operations.
594926.prereqs: Prerequisite: ACCT 308 ; or (not pre-MBA) graduate standing.

594927.title: Seminar in Estate, Gift, Inheritance Taxes and Estate Planning
594927.description: Federal and California death taxes and the planning of personal estates.
594927.prereqs: Prerequisite: ACCT 308 ; or (not pre-MBA) graduate standing.

594928.title: Seminar in State and Local Taxation
594928.description: Application of interstate income allocations; multi-state tax compact; separate apportionment accounting; foreign country sourced income. California taxes as applied to businesses and individuals.
594928.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 308 ; CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

594929.title: Seminar in Taxation of Employee Compensation
594929.description: Federal taxation relating to employee compensation including pensions and profit sharing, stock options, ESOPs, IRAs, Keoghs, maximum tax 5-year averaging, death benefits, group term life, etc.

594930.title: Seminar in Taxation of Flow-Through Entities
594930.description: Federal taxation relating to partnerships, estates, trusts and other special entities.
594930.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 308 ; CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598732.title: Accounting for Income Taxes (ASC 740)
598732.description: Key provisions of Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) 740, Income Taxes. ASC 740 addresses how companies should account for and report the effects of taxes based on income.
598732.prereqs: Prerequisite: ACCT 308 ; or CBE graduate standing (not pre-MBA).

594931.title: Seminar in Taxation of S Corporations, LLCs and LLPs
594931.description: Tax consequences of electing and operating as a Subchapter S Corporation, including entity level taxes, distributions and computation of basis. Terminating the S Corporation election and liquidations.
594931.prereqs: Prerequisite: ACCT 308 ; or (not pre-MBA) graduate standing.

598884.title: Tax Accounting Methods
598884.description: Concepts governing timing of recognition of income and deductions for income tax purposes. Differences between GAAP and income tax accounting for all taxpayers.

607227.title: Internship
607227.description: A supervised experience in which relevant business principles are applied in an internship setting. Allows students to discuss their experience and integrate theory with practice.

594932.title: Accounting Capstone - Professional Research Project
594932.description: Culminating intellectual experience to use knowledge learned. Solve complex accounting problems using analytic tools applied to real world data with guidance from faculty and professionals.

594933.title: Independent Graduate Research
594933.description: May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. Not open to students on academic notice. Requires approval of department chair and associate dean.

594934.title: Introduction to Ethnic Studies
594934.description: Perspectives through which people of color have come to see themselves in terms of their own heroes, cultures and contributions to the societies in which they live and the world in general. (AFAM 101, ASAM 101, and CHIC 101 are the same course)

598743.title: Critical Race Theory
598743.description: How race, sexuality, ethnicity, gender, disability and class influence the law, using a critical race theory lens. An extension of Critical Legal Theory, formed in the 1980s, to explore how racism and structural inequality are institutionalized within the legal system.

594935.title: Introduction to African American Studies
594935.description: Introduction to key texts and topics in African American Studies. Interdisciplinary exploration of social conditions, political engagement, intellectual production and cultural contributions of African Americans.

598790.title: Introduction to Black Creative Expression
598790.description: Introduction to Black originators and innovators of art forms, such as performing, literary and visual. Critical responses to art forms in both historical and contemporary contexts. Understand trends in creativity and imagination that cross expressive forms in Black communities.

594936.title: Survey of American History with Emphasis on Ethnic Minorities
594936.description: Survey of American history from prehistoric times (before 1492) to the present with special emphasis on the role of race and ethnicity. (HIST 190, AFAM 190, ASAM 190 and CHIC 190 are the same course.)

598236.title: Introduction to Multi-Ethnic Literatures of the U.S.
598236.description: Introducing multi-ethnic literatures of the U. S., the course considers texts within their cultural, historical, and socio-political contexts. Relates multi-ethnic literature to the creative and performing arts. Themes covered may include diaspora, migration, memory, history, citizenship, and/or ethnic identities. (CHIC 250, AFAM 250, ASAM 250 and ENGL 250 are the same course.)

598791.title: Black Lives Matter Creative and Critical Ideas
598791.description: Black Lives Matter movement origins, controversies and legacies. Creative and critical responses to social activism in communities of color. Engaging critical debates around over-policing, anti-black racism and bias.

598053.title: Introduction to African American History
598053.description: Introduction to key events, individuals, institutions and experiences that shaped the history and culture of Africans and their descendants from their arrival in North America in 1619 to the present.

594937.title: African American Food Culture
594937.description: Dynamic relationship between African Americans, food culture and food in the U.S. from their earliest beginnings; focusing on the socio-historical, creative, economic and geographic manifestations of the relationship between food culture, identity and wellness.

594938.title: Black Families in America
594938.description: Issues of race, class, gender, sexuality and identity within African American families. Topics will include: black single mothers and welfare, prisons, black middle class families and residential housing, black youth and activism, and LGBT family formations. (AFAM 304 and SOCI 304 are the same course.)

594939.title: Research and Writing in Ethnic Studies
594939.description: Introduction to research and writing in ethnic studies. Issues of research in ethnic studies (e.g., quantitative v. qualitative analysis, reliability/validity) and specific methods of research (e.g., archives, interviews, oral history). Extensive writing. A "C" (2.0) or better is required to satisfy the upper-division writing requirement. (ASAM 307, AFAM 307 and CHIC 307 are the same course.)

594940.title: Black Men in America
594940.description: The diverse and conflicting representations and theories of black masculinity in the U.S. and abroad. Explores tensions between representations and social, economic, and political realities of black men. Analyzes contemporary issues of black masculinities and the post-racial imaginary.

594941.title: Black Women in America
594941.description: Issues in the study of black women in America, including social, political, economic and intellectual development. Historical and contemporary issues as they affect black American women. (AFAM 310 and GSS 310 are the same course.)

594942.title: Race and Relationships
594942.description: How race, ethnicity, gender and class matter in everyday society, emphasizing intrapersonal relationships, racial socialization and the effects of this racial socialization in people's lives.

594943.title: Pan-African Dance and Movement
594943.description: Theory and practice of movement of African and Haitian peoples. Movement (dance) as quasi-language in perpetuating the life style of African cultures and cultures of African descent.

594944.title: Black Political Thought
594944.description: The black American intellectual from slavery to contemporary times, emphasizing black contributions to American political and social thought, as well as their contributions in America's social development.

594945.title: Activism, Engagement and Professional Development
594945.description: Planning and community development trends in minority communities in urban, suburban and rural areas. Theoretical perspectives and practices embraced by grassroots planners. Public and private sector approaches. Topics include neighborhood planning, community development, economic development and grassroots organizing.

594946.title: Black Psychology
594946.description: Uses psychological principles and practices to guide students' comprehension of life as an African American. Introduction to a holistic perspective that expands ways of conceptualizing psychology from an African American world view.  (AFAM 322 and PSYC 322 are the same course.)

594947.title: Introduction to African American Literature
594947.description: Literary contributions by major black American authors. Contemporary black writers and the recurring themes of protest and quest for identity. Not available for graduate degree credit. (AFAM 324 and ENGL 324 are the same course.)

594948.title: African American Religions and Spirituality
594948.description: African-American belief systems and denominations. Folk beliefs among Blacks, African-American religious groups and the role of the Black Church in politics and social change in the Black community. (AFAM 325 and RLST 325 are the same course.)

594949.title: History of Racism
594949.description: Historical roots and current expressions of racism. How racism manifests itself through individual, social, political, economic and religious institutions and proposes methods of combating it.

594950.title: African American Music Appreciation
594950.description: Black music in America; the sociological conditions that help produce various forms of black music. (AFAM 356 and MUS 356 are the same course)

594951.title: Blacks in the Performing Arts
594951.description: African-American culture through the performing arts. Blacks in the entertainment industry as a means of understanding and revealing important aspects of African-American culture. (AFAM 357, MUS 357 and THTR 357 are the same course.)

598815.title: Black Recreation and Leisure
598815.description: African American recreation and leisure in the U.S., connections between play and work in the context of racial segregation and discrimination. The settings for commercial leisure, activities, social relations and ideas behind fairly well-known environments.

598797.title: Black Environmentalism
598797.description: Environmental racism, crises and justice issues for communities of color. Origins of Black environmentalism, slavery, Jim Crow segregation and impact on the relationship between African Americans with nature and the environment. Creative expressions of Black environmentalism.

598437.title: Development of African American Children and Youth
598437.description: Understanding cognitive and socio-emotional development of African American children and youth is facilitated through comprehensive examinations of significant African and African American cultural and historical experiences. (CAS 370 and AFAM 370 are the same course.)

598009.title: African American Concert Dance History
598009.description: Production of African derived dance from within American culture. Consideration of the history of dance artists' biographic and critical theory literature from diverse media. Includes a lab involving choreography and performance of major African American concert dance forms. (DANC 371 and AFAM 371 are the same course)

597725.title: Hip Hop Culture
597725.description: Origins and influences of hip hop on culture, fashion, movies, television, advertising, attitude, music, dancing and slang among African Americans. Impact of the hip hop culture phenomenon on American and global societies.

598778.title: Black Latinx Identity
598778.description: The relationship between Blackness and Latin American identity formation and social movements of Black-identified Latino/a/x people. Will pay particular attention to slavery within the United States, Caribbean and Latin America; racial classification laws and social movements.

594952.title: Black Representations in Film
594952.description: Critical study of black images in motion pictures, past and present. The tension between historical Black consciousness, authenticity, imitation and alternative adaptations.

598834.title: The Black Athlete
598834.description: The collective experiences of the Black athlete in America. Interrelationship among race, class, gender, politics and sport. Topics include: the historical construction of the Black athlete; the media and Black athletes; sports and social mobility; politics and sport.

598217.title: Language and Power in African American Culture
598217.description: Language use within the African American community. Topics include language history, dialect vs. language, communicative practices, language in education policy, language and ideology, and language attitudes. (ENGL 410 and AFAM 410 are the same course.)
598217.prereqs: Prerequisite: Fulfill Upper Division Writing Requirement.

598620.title: Black LGBT Experience
598620.description: Focuses on the experiences of Black (LGBT) lesbians, gay, bisexual, and transgender people to explore the multiple and intersecting social forces that have shaped their place, or lack thereof, in U.S. society.

598026.title: African American History: 1619 to 1863
598026.description: Key events, individuals, institutions and experiences that shaped the history and culture of Africans and their descendants in North America from the 17th century to the American Civil War (AFAM 476A and HIST 476A are the same course).
598026.prereqs: Prerequisite: AFAM 107 , AFAM 190 , AFAM 280 or HIST 170A .

598744.title: African Americans since 1863
598744.description: African Americans as historical actors from 1863 to the present, including responses to segregation and disfranchisement, participation in the Great Migration, and the movement for civil rights (HIST 476B and AFAM 476B are the same course).
598744.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598031.title: American Immigration History
598031.description: History of American immigration in a global context. Changes and continuities in the political, cultural, and economic contexts that generated the movement of diverse peoples and structured their experiences of integration within the U.S. (HIST 477C, AFAM 477C, ASAM 477C and CHIC 477C are the same course.)
598031.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

597726.title: Tutorial
597726.description: May be taken for credit for a maximum of three units.

594954.title: Independent Study
594954.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires acceptance of the subject by department chair and instructor directing the study.

598426.title: Introduction to Aging Studies
598426.description: Multidisciplinary overview of: characteristics, strengths and problems of older persons; diversity in aging process involving gender, race, ethnicity, subculture; services to older adults; gerontology as an academic discipline and a field of practice. (AGNG 133, SOCI 133, PUBH 133, HUSR 133 and PSYC 133 are the same course.)

598745.title: Discovering My Roots: Genealogy, Family, History
598745.description: The meanings and forms of family in world history by engaging the methods and practices of history research: theoretical literature, genealogy databases, oral histories, personal digital archives, family history rooms. Produce substantive research on own families. (HIST 202 and AGNG 202 are the same course).

598022.title: California Gold: Diversity and Aging
598022.description: California serves as a microcosm for studying diversity and aging. Course considers race/ethnicity, gender, disability, income, sexual orientation and religion among aging Californians. Highlights discrimination, racism and current/future needs and support services in the context of current events.

603102.title: Advanced Writing with a Focus on Aging
603102.description: Academic intensive writing in an aging studies context. Read, think, write and revise using current aging text and journal articles in written and oral formats. Assignments involve organizing complex ideas, with feedback provided throughout the course for revision.
603102.prereqs: Prerequisite: ENGL 101 with a “C-” (1.7) or better.

598947.title: Aging Science: Theoretical Foundations and Applications
598947.description: Exposure to scientific research on aging in medicine, science, technology, engineering and math (MSTEM) to prepare students for advanced learning and possible careers in one of these fields. Biopsychosocial issues related to aging within MSTEM.

598948.title: Aging Science: Methods and Data Analysis
598948.description: Aging-specific research methodology/analytical strategies applied to medicine, science, technology, engineering and math (MSTEM). Essential, in-depth training in study design, methodology, data entry, data analysis and ethics as they pertain to translational aging science.

598360.title: Aging and Dementia
598360.description: Physiological, psychological, social, economic aspects of dementia; its impact on the individual, family and society, with an emphasis on Alzheimer's disease.
598360.prereqs: Prerequisite: junior, senior or graduate standing.

596079.title: Successful Aging and Gerotechnology
596079.description: Gerotechnology is the study of technology and aging. The impact of computer and Internet, devices for sensory impairments, telehealth, smart home, automobile and transportation innovation on older adults, caregivers and society.
596079.prereqs: Prerequisites: SOCI 133/AGNG 133; GE Area 1A, 1B, 1C; or classified graduate standing.

598483.title: Applied Health Promotion in Aging Populations
598483.description: Promotion/risk reduction program content, development, implementation and evaluation. Topics include weight control, stress management, substance abuse, physical fitness and accident prevention. (PUBH 450 and AGNG 450 are the same course.)
598483.prereqs: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 ; junior or senior standing; or Kinesiology or Sociology major; or Public Health or Gerontology minor; or graduate standing.

598973.title: Aging Science:  Research Evaluation and Implementation
598973.description: Applying critical thinking skills to aging-related research content relevant to medicine, science, technology, engineering and math (MSTEM). Evaluate gerontological source material, apply theory, synthesize information and write a comprehensive literature review on a selected aging-related topic.

598974.title: Aging Science:  Communication and Dissemination
598974.description: Communicating and disseminating aging-related research as it applies to the fields of medicine, science, technology, engineering and math (MSTEM). Communicate and present research in multiple formats to academic and non-academic audiences, including older adults.

598621.title: Gerontology Undergraduate Internship
598621.description: Integration of professional and academic experience through internships with external employers (120-150 hours of fieldwork). Supervised experience in organizations that serve older adults and their families, and written reflections on these experiences. Requires consent of instructor and Program Coordinator.

596081.title: Applied Gerontology
596081.description: Introduction to professional practice of Gerontology. Applying biopsychosocial content and theoretical models, research and ethics in practice, career path exploration and networking, and developing leadership skills and resources.

597854.title: Health and Safety in Early Childhood
597854.description: Preventive measures for childcare professionals to promote safe, healthy environment at home, play, or group care. Prepares individuals who supervise and care for young children to recognize, differentiate and respond to common safety hazards, illness and injuries.

595413.title: Observations in Early Childhood Settings
595413.description: Introduces the appropriate application and limits of a variety of observation methods for use with young children and in early childhood settings; several assessment tools will be studied. Hands-on observations will focus on children, interactions, and environments.

598667.title: Responsive Care and Practices for Infants and Toddlers
598667.description: Overview of development among infants and toddlers. Introduces the practice of caring for and teaching of infants and toddlers in group settings. Infant and toddler child care services, emphasizing developmentally appropriate practices.

598014.title: Introduction to Early Childhood Curriculum
598014.description: Appropriate curriculum and environments for infants and young children, including supporting development through guidance, play, observation and assessment. Development of language and literacy, social skills and emotions, art and creativity, math and science.

595414.title: Elements of Effective Professional Communication
595414.description: Communication norms and standards in child and adolescent studies. Fosters written and oral communication skills to support students' professional development and their ethical and effective work with diverse children, adolescents and families. Meets upper-division writing requirement for CAS majors.
595414.prereqs: Prerequisites: Child and Adolescent Development major or minor; sophomore, junior or senior standing.

595415.title: Inquiry and Methodology in Development
595415.description: Frameworks and methods for conducting and consuming empirical research on the development of children from diverse backgrounds. Introduces scientific method, including developing research questions/hypotheses, surveying, sampling and interpreting statistics. Read, analyze and synthesize research studies retrieved from library databases.
595415.prereqs: Prerequisites: Child and Adolescent Development major or minor; sophomore, junior or senior standing. Pre- or corequisite: CAS 300 .

607238.title: Cultural Competence in Developmental Contexts
607238.description: Knowledge, skills and values that promote cultural competence in developmental contexts. Theories, topics and practices focused on issues of inequality, racism, culture and the strengths of historically minoritized children, adolescents and families.

595416.title: Advanced Assessment in Early Childhood
595416.description: Covers advanced assessment in early childhood. Combines knowledge of child development and commonly used practices to understand the conceptual and operational definition of observation and assessment strategies as relevant to establishing quality programs for young children.
595416.prereqs: Prerequisites: Child and Adolescent Development major or minor; CAS 250 , CAS 300 , CAS 301 all with a “C” (2.0) or better. Pre- or corequisite: CAS 325A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595417.title: Assessing and Observing Development
595417.description: Purposes, methods, ethics and implications associated with assessing and observing children and adolescents from diverse populations, including use of standardized measures of development and learning. Selection of methods and measures. Appropriate interpretation of data.
595417.prereqs: Prerequisites: Child and Adolescent Development major or minor; CAS 300 , CAS 301 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595418.title: Human Growth and Development
595418.description: Biological/physical, socio-emotional and cognitive development across the lifespan.

595419.title: Child Development
595419.description: Major concepts, principles, theories and research related to cognitive, linguistic, social, emotional and physical development from birth through adolescence; emphasizes developmentally appropriate practices.

595420.title: Advanced Study of Infant and Toddler Development
595420.description: Normative and atypical physical, social, emotional and cognitive development for children from birth to three years of age. Child development theories, research strategies and environmental, biological, and cultural influences on the development of young children.
595420.prereqs: Pre- or corequisite: CAS 325A ; or prerequisite: CAS 221 .

595421.title: Preschool-Age Development
595421.description: Normative and atypical physical, social, emotional and cognitive development for children 3-6 years of age and implications on child care services provided for preschool-aged children with an emphasis on developmentally appropriate practices.

595422.title: Conception Through Age 8
595422.description: Biological, psychological, cultural and environmental influences on children?s physical, cognitive and socioemotional development from conception through age 8. Enhance understanding of developmental research and theories that support cultural competence. Apply knowledge to promote optimal development of children.
595422.prereqs: Prerequisites: Child and Adolescent Development major or minor; CAS 101 , CAS 201 , CAS 300 , CAS 301 all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595423.title: Age 9 Through Adolescence
595423.description: Biological, psychological, cultural and environmental influences on physical, cognitive and socioemotional development from age 9 through adolescence. Enhanced understanding of developmental research and theories that support cultural competence. Apply knowledge to promote optimal development of older children and adolescents.
595423.prereqs: Prerequisites: Child and Adolescent Development major or minor; CAS 201 , CAS 300 , CAS 301 , CAS 325A all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595424.title: Optimizing Development of School Age Children
595424.description: Conditions that impact and facilitate development during middle childhood. These include external (e.g., appropriate support and empowerment across various contexts) and internal assets (e.g., social competence and commitment to learning). Highlights strategies that promote development.

595425.title: Optimizing Development During Adolescence
595425.description: Conditions that impact and facilitate development during adolescence including external (e.g., appropriate support and empowerment across various contexts) and internal assets (e.g., self concept, commitment to learning). Strategies that promote development.

607270.title: Child Life Theory and Practice
607270.description: Theory and techniques employed to reduce negative effects of stressful or traumatic life events and situations on the development of infants, children, youth and their families in health care and other settings.
607270.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 4A; CAS 101 , CAS 312 or CAS 315 ; or department approved equivalent.

595426.title: Adolescence and Early Adulthood
595426.description: Human development during and following adolescence. Community resources and services for adolescents and their families. Consequences of adolescent experiences for later development.

595427.title: Parenting Today
595427.description: Goals and patterns of parenting in context of contemporary, multicultural society; identifies changing demands of parenting infants, children and adolescents; summarizes current scholarly research on relation of parenting practices to child development outcomes.

595428.title: Working with Parents of Young Children
595428.description: Responsibilities and influences of diverse family systems from the transition to parenting through children completing primary grades. Effective collaboration and communication with parents during early childhood years with the goal of optimizing children's development.
595428.prereqs: Prerequisite: Child and Adolescent Studies major or minor.

595429.title: Child and Adolescent Development in Diverse Family Contexts
595429.description: Patterns and processes of child/adolescent development within families of various cultural/ethnic/social contexts. Identifies multiple theoretical and disciplinary perspectives in studying child and family developmental processes, as well as summarizing the current related scholarly literature.

595430.title: Advanced Study in Preschool Development
595430.description: Builds on previous foundation classes to explore current issues in child development from age 2 to 6 years. Explores implications for development across the physical, socio-emotional and cognitive domains in the context of diverse families and society.

595431.title: Numeracy and Science in Early Childhood
595431.description: Theory and research on children's scientific inquiry and numeracy development. Integrates science and mathematics in early childhood settings through interdisciplinary thematic units.
595431.prereqs: Prerequisite: CAS 325A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595432.title: Learning and Motivation in Early Childhood
595432.description: Building on the foundation developmental classes, this class examines theory and research on children's learning, cognition and motivation with an emphasis on practical applications in early childhood settings. Developmental norms, individual and cultural variations, and curricular strategies.
595432.prereqs: Prerequisite: CAS 325A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595433.title: Adolescents and the Media
595433.description: Summarizes current social, cultural and behavioral research on adolescents and mass media. How teens use, learn, are depicted in, and shape cultural meaning from exposure to television and other electronic media.

595434.title: Adolescent Pregnancy and Parenting
595434.description: Reviews current knowledge base on adolescent pregnancy and the developmental implications for parent and child. Social, educational and health implications of early parenting, and articulates the resources, skills and supports needed to foster success in parenting.

595435.title: Development of African American Children and Youth
595435.description: Understanding cognitive and socio-emotional development of African American children and youth is facilitated through comprehensive examinations of significant African and African American cultural and historical experiences. (CAS 370 and AFAM 370 are the same course.)

595436.title: Adolescent Identity
595436.description: Adolescent identity within the context of soci-emotional, physical, and cognitive development. Sociocultural factors (e.g., ethnicity, peers, family) that influence individual and group identities.

595437.title: Adolescent Sexuality and Intimate Relationships
595437.description: Current trends, potential risks, and opportunities associated with adolescents' involvement in sexual and intimate relationships from a normative developmental perspective. Socio-ecological contexts (e.g., families, peers, culture) of adolescents' sexual and relational attitudes/behaviors are a central focus.

598209.title: Leadership Seminar in Early Childhood
598209.description: Capstone course examining leadership, assessment and funding for early childhood programs. Prepares students to use their knowledge of data, theory and literature to promote the well-being of young children and families through advocacy, fundraising and professional activities.

595438.title: Introductory Practicum in Child and Adolescent Studies
595438.description: Minimum 60 hours of supervised practicum experience in agencies, institutions and organizations serving children, adolescents and/or their families. Analyze experience in relation to developmental theory, professional development skills, cultural competence and developmentally appropriate practice.
595438.prereqs: Prerequisites: Child and Adolescent Development major or minor; CAS 101 , CAS 201 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598211.title: Peer Mentoring Academy for Student Success
598211.description: Scholarly, self-reflective work to develop and use advanced communication skills as a Child and Adolescent Studies major peer student mentor under faculty supervision. Requires 35 out-of-class hours on peer mentoring and professional activities.
598211.prereqs: Prerequisites: Child and Adolescent Studies major; junior standing or above.

598196.title: Practicum in Transitional Early Childhood Education
598196.description: Minimum 60 hours of supervised practicum experience in licensed early childhood education settings or school districts; working directly with children in pre-kindergarten, transitional kindergarten or kindergarten. Advanced analysis related to developmental theory, cultural competence and developmentally appropriate practice.

595439.title: Practicum Seminar in Early Care and Education
595439.description: Minimum 60 hours of supervised practicum experience in licensed early childhood education settings, working directly with very young children (infants through age 5). Advanced analysis in relation to developmental theory, cultural competence and developmentally appropriate practice.

595440.title: Practicum in Development in School Settings
595440.description: Minimum 60 hours of supervised practicum experience in elementary school settings serving K-6th grade students, working directly in a classroom. Advanced analysis in relation to California Academic Content Standards, developmental theory, cultural competence and developmentally appropriate practice.

595441.title: Practicum Seminar in Adolescent and Youth Services
595441.description: Classroom analysis of field experience focusing on linkages between theory and practice, and skills and techniques of adolescent development/youth services professionals.
595441.prereqs: Prerequisites: Child and Adolescent Development major or minor; CAS 394 , CAS 325A ; or CAS 140 , CAS 325A ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: CAS 484L .

595442.title: Practicum in Adolescent and Youth Services
595442.description: Supervised field experience in agencies, institutions and organizations serving adolescents and families. Minimum of 4 hours per week for a total of 60 hours required for the semester. Credit/No Credit grade option only. May be repeated for a maximum of 2 units.

595443.title: Senior Seminar in Child and Adolescent Development
595443.description: Integrating and applying knowledge, competencies and skills acquired in prerequisite courses to a specific developmental topic (varies by section), including considerations related to biological, psychological, social and cultural factors.
595443.prereqs: Prerequisites: Child and Adolescent Development major or minor; CAS 305 or CAS 310 ; CAS 325B ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595444.title: Practicum in Youth and Families in Community Settings
595444.description: Minimum 60 hours of supervised practicum experience in licensed agencies, institutions or organizations that support children, adolescents (up to early 20s) or their families. Analyze experience in relation to developmental theory, professional development skills, cultural competence and developmentally appropriate practice.

595445.title: Student-to-Student Tutorial
595445.description: Work on student-to-student tutorial and related tasks under the direction of a Child and Adolescent Studies faculty member. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Only 3 units may be taken in a single semester. Requires consent of instructor.

595446.title: Independent Study
595446.description: Individual research project, either library or field, under the direction of a Child and Adolescent Studies faculty member. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 units. Only 6 units may be taken in a single semester.

595305.title: Survey of Chemistry
595305.description: The fundamental principles of chemistry; atomic and molecular structure and the application of these principles to contemporary problems. For the non-science major. One year of high school algebra recommended.

595306.title: Survey of Chemistry Laboratory
595306.description: Experiments chosen to develop laboratory techniques; chemical principles and their application to environmental and societal problems. (3 hours laboratory)

595308.title: Survey of the Molecules of Life
595308.description: An introduction to the biochemical processes of life, including metabolism, development and disease. Recent scientific advances are discussed with emphasis placed on AIDS, cancer, diabetes and cloning. Scientific methods and ethical issues in scientific research are examined.

595309.title: Nutrition and Health
595309.description: The basics of nutrition; diet, food additives, vitamins, hormones, drugs, disease and related biochemical topics. Current controversies, popular practices, fads and fallacies. For the non-science major.

595310.title: Introductory General Chemistry
595310.description: Chemistry at the basic level. For students with limited background in math and chemistry who plan to take additional chemistry or other science courses. Does not fulfill chemistry requirements for majors or minors in the physical or biological sciences. (3 hours lecture)

595311.title: General Chemistry
595311.description: For majors and minors in the physical and biological sciences. The principles of chemistry: stoichiometry, acids, bases, redox reactions, gas laws, solid and liquid states, changes of state, modern atomic concepts, periodicity and chemical bonding. Laboratory: elementary syntheses, spectroscopy and volumetric quantitative analysis. (3 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory, 2 hours activity)
595311.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 115 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or pass the chemistry placement examination.

595312.title: General Chemistry
595312.description: For majors and minors in the physical and biological sciences, chemical thermodynamics, chemical equilibrium (gaseous, aqueous, acid-base, solubility and complexation), elementary electrochemistry and chemical kinetics. Laboratory: quantitative and qualitative analysis and elementary physical chemistry; some qualitative analysis. (3 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory).
595312.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 120A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

597806.title: Chemistry for Engineers
597806.description: Fundamental concepts of chemistry for engineering students. Atomic structure, periodic table, stoichiometry, states of matter, chemical bonding, new materials, solutions, thermodynamics, reaction rates, equilibrium, electrochemistry, polymers and nuclear reactions.
597806.prereqs: Corequisite: MATH 125 or MATH 150A; or MATH 115, MATH 116: or MATH 115B, MATH 116.

595313.title: General Chemistry B Lecture
595313.description: For students who do not need a second semester of general chemistry lab. Chemical thermodynamics, chemical equilibrium (gaseous, aqueous, acid-base, solubility and complexion), elementary electrochemistry and chemical kinetics. Not open to students with credit in CHEM 120B.
595313.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 120A or CHEM 123 ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595314.title: Orientation to Chemistry and Biochemistry
595314.description: Resources, opportunities and careers available in chemistry and biochemistry. Focus on successful strategies to complete the major and enter the chemistry/biochemistry workforce. Credit/No Credit only..
595314.prereqs: Prerequisite: Chemistry or Biochemistry undergraduate standing.

595315.title: Chemistry for Nursing and Allied Health Professionals
595315.description: Fundamental concepts of general, organic and biochemistry and their applications to the health sciences. Meets requirement for pre-nursing curriculum and can be applied to other allied health majors. High school math and one year of high school chemistry, or a passing score on the placement test for general chemistry, or completion of introductory general chemistry (CHEM 100, CHEM 100L) with a "C" (2.0) or better strongly advised. (3 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory)

595316.title: Directed Study
595316.description: Research in chemistry under the supervision of a chemistry department faculty member. Credit/no credit only. May be repeated once for credit. Does not count towards major. (3 hours laboratory per unit)

595317.title: Organic Chemistry
595317.description: Properties and reactions of aliphatic and aromatic compounds, theories of structure and reaction mechanisms. For the non-chemistry majors, or B.A. in Chemistry, B.S. in Chemistry or B.S. in Biochemistry majors.
595317.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 120B with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: CHEM 306A .

595318.title: Organic Chemistry
595318.description: Properties and reactions of aliphatic and aromatic compounds, theories of structure, and reaction mechanisms. For non-chemistry majors, or B.A. in Chemistry, B.S. in Chemistry or B.S. in Biochemistry majors.
595318.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 301A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595322.title: Organic Chemistry Laboratory
595322.description: Techniques for synthesis, isolation and characterization of typical aliphatic and aromatic compounds, with applications of instrumental and spectroscopic methods. (1 hour discussion, 3 hours laboratory)
595322.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 120B with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: CHEM 301A.

595323.title: Organic Chemistry Laboratory
595323.description: Continuation of CHEM 306A for the B.A. and B.S. in chemistry major. (6 hours laboratory)
595323.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 301A , CHEM 306A ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: CHEM 301B .

595324.title: Nutrition and Disease
595324.description: Relationship between nutrients and disease, with an emphasis on cancer, atherosclerosis and infectious illness. Dietary factors that modify and/or contribute to the disease process from the viewpoints of physiology, biochemistry and immunology. Not applicable to the major.

595325.title: Environmental Pollution and Its Solutions: Air Pollution
595325.description: Human pollution of the Earth's atmosphere and means to ameliorate this pollution. Historical examples, current cases and future prospects. (3 hours lecture/discussion for 5 weeks)

595326.title: Environmental Pollution and Its Solutions: Water Pollution
595326.description: Human pollution of the Earth's aqueous environment and means to ameliorate this pollution. Historical examples, current cases and future prospects. (3 hours lecture/discussion for 5 weeks)

595327.title: Environmental Pollution and Its Solutions: Land Pollution
595327.description: Human pollution of the Earth's terrestrial environment and means to ameliorate this pollution. Historical examples, current cases and future prospects. (3 hours lecture/discussion for 5 weeks)

595328.title: Theory of Quantitative Chemistry
595328.description: Modern analytical chemistry; aqueous and non-aqueous equilibrium calculations, electrochemistry, spectrometry and contemporary separation methods with emphasis on chromatography. PHYS 226 strongly recommended.
595328.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 120B with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595329.title: Quantitative Chemistry Laboratory
595329.description: Modern analytical chemistry laboratory: polyprotic acids, liquid chromatography, electrochemistry, absorption spectroscopy (ultraviolet/visible, infrared, atomic). (1 hour lecture, 3 hours laboratory)
595329.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 315 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595330.title: Inorganic Chemistry
595330.description: The chemistry of the main group elements and an introduction to transition metal chemistry.
595330.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 315 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595331.title: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
595331.description: Experiments in chemical synthesis, instrumental analysis and physical chemistry. Laboratory training and written presentation of theory, data and results. (1 hour lecture, 6 hours laboratory).
595331.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 316 , CHEM 371A ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: CHEM 371B .

595332.title: Introduction to Physical Chemistry
595332.description: Thermodynamics and kinetics; properties of gases and solutions; molecular structure and energies and application to spectroscopic techniques; liquids, phase equilibria, thermodynamics of multicomponent systems with application to the life sciences.
595332.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 150B , CHEM 301B ; PHYS 212 or PHYS 226 ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595333.title: Introduction to Physical Chemistry
595333.description: Thermodynamics and kinetics; properties of gases and solutions; molecular structure and energies and application to spectroscopic techniques; liquids, phase equilibria, thermodynamics of multicomponent systems with application to the life sciences.
595333.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 150B , CHEM 301B ; PHYS 212 or PHYS 226 ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595334.title: Physical Chemistry
595334.description: Thermodynamics, solutions, chemical and phase equilibria, electrochemistry, transport phenomena, introduction to atomic and molecular structure, rotation and vibration spectroscopy, statistical mechanics and kinetics.
595334.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 250A , PHYS 226 , CHEM 301B ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595335.title: Physical Chemistry
595335.description: Thermodynamics, solutions, chemical and phase equilibria, electrochemistry, transport phenomena, introduction to atomic and molecular structure, rotation and vibration spectroscopy, statistical mechanics, and kinetics.
595335.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 250A , PHYS 226 , CHEM 301B ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595336.title: Undergraduate Research
595336.description: Independent research in chemistry or biochemistry under the guidance of a department faculty member. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 units. Does not count towards major. Requires one semester of experience working in a research laboratory. (3 hours per week per unit).
595336.prereqs: Prerequisite: completion of one upper-division Chemistry course.

597808.title: Computational Chemistry
597808.description: Introduction to fundamental theory of molecular electronic structure, modern methods and techniques of computational chemistry; understanding calculated properties and accuracy; predicting structural, spectroscopic, thermodynamic, and kinetic data of chemical systems; solving chemical problems using molecular computation.
597808.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 361A or CHEM 371A with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing. Corequisite: CHEM 361B or CHEM 371B .

595337.title: Instrumental Analysis - Optical Spectroscopy
595337.description: UV/visible, infrared, atomic absorption, flame emission. Students wishing an ACS certified degree must take three units of CHEM 411 courses. (1 hour lecture, 3 hours laboratory for 5 weeks)
595337.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 315 , CHEM 316 ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing. Corequisite: CHEM 361B or CHEM 371B .

595338.title: Instrumental Analysis - Magnetic Resonance
595338.description: Nuclear magnetic resonance, electron spin resonance. Students wishing an ACS certified degree must take three units of CHEM 411 courses. (1 hour lecture, 3 hours laboratory for 5 weeks)
595338.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 301B , CHEM 306A ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595339.title: Instrumental Analysis - Separations
595339.description: High performance liquid chromatography, gas chromatography. Students wishing an ACS certified degree must take 3 units of CHEM 411 courses. (1 hour lecture, 3 hours laboratory for 5 weeks)
595339.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 315 , CHEM 316 ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595340.title: Electrochemistry
595340.description: Voltammetry, amperometry, electrodes. ACS-certified degrees require three units of CHEM 411 courses. (1 hour lecture, 3 hours laboratory for 5 weeks)
595340.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 315 , CHEM 316 ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595341.title: Instrumental Analysis - Mass spectrometry
595341.description: Conventional magnetic sector, quadruple, Fourier transform, tandem, and time-of-flight; hyphenated techniques including gas chromatography (GC-MS), liquid chromatography (LC-MS). Students wishing an ACS certified degree must take three units of CHEM 411 courses. (1 hour lecture, 3 hours laboratory for 5 weeks)
595341.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 315 , CHEM 316 ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

598902.title: Introduction to Materials Chemistry
598902.description: Materials chemistry is a multidisciplinary field that studies the technologically important stuff all around us, from bridges to plastics to cell phone components. The performance, properties, structure and processing of materials from a chemistry perspective.

595342.title: Biological Chemistry
595342.description: Biochemistry designed for biology majors and pre-health profession careers. Major areas of biochemistry, including intermediary metabolism and compounds of biochemical interest. Applying biochemistry and the biochemical foundation of health science.
595342.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 301B with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595343.title: General Biochemistry Laboratory
595343.description: Chemistry and metabolism of carbohydrates, nucleic acids and proteins; techniques of enzyme isolation and characterization; DNA isolation and manipulation; research methods. (6 hours laboratory)
595343.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 306A, CHEM 316; CHEM 421 or CHEM 423A: all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595344.title: General Biochemistry
595344.description: For biochemistry majors. Structural chemistry and function of biomolecules, bioenergetics and intermediary metabolism.
595344.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 301B with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: CHEM 315 .

595345.title: General Biochemistry
595345.description: For biochemistry majors; structural chemistry and function of biomolecules, central and secondary metabolism; photosynthesis; nucleic acid biochemistry.
595345.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 423A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595346.title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
595346.description: Bonding, structure and reactivity of transition and lanthanide elements. Molecular orbital and ligand field theory, classical metal complexes and organometallic chemistry of the transition elements.
595346.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 325 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

598019.title: Medicinal Chemistry
598019.description: Concepts and practices of modern medicinal chemistry focusing on drug discovery, design, and development. Case studies on successful drugs.
598019.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 301B with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

598642.title: Bioorganic Chemistry
598642.description: The interface of biology and organic chemistry, focusing on biological processes. Study chemical reactions and mechanisms to understand how nature creates complex molecules with specific biological roles.
598642.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 301B with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595347.title: Advanced Organic Chemistry
595347.description: Theoretical and physical aspects of organic chemistry. Modern concepts of structure, and reaction mechanisms.
595347.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 301B with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595349.title: Atmospheric Chemistry
595349.description: Chemistry and photochemistry of the troposphere and stratosphere, both natural and polluted. Includes fundamental reaction kinetics and mechanisms, monitoring techniques, smog chamber, field and modeling studies.
595349.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 315 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595350.title: Environmental Biochemistry
595350.description: Effects of current agricultural, industrial and mechanical practices on the composition, metabolism and health of soil, plants, animals and man, from a biochemical perspective; mechanism of action and degradation of common agricultural chemicals and industrial pollutants.
595350.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 301B with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

598643.title: Green Chemistry
598643.description: Introduction to the principles of green chemistry. The role of chemists in developing the knowledge and tools for society to meet the basic needs for energy, clean water, and food and to protect human health and the environment.
598643.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 301B with a “C” (2.0) or better; junior or senior standing.

595351.title: Nutritional Biochemistry
595351.description: Nutrition, metabolism and excretion of carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, major minerals and trace elements from a biochemical perspective. Relevant variations in dietary practices related to life stages and specific illnesses.
595351.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 421 or CHEM 423A with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

598644.title: Medicinal Chemistry Laboratory
598644.description: Introduction to medical chemistry research, focusing on organic synthesis, enzymatic assays and molecular modeling to discover novel therapeutic agents.
598644.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 429 with a “C” (2.0) or better; junior or senior standing.

595352.title: Advances in Biotechnology Lab
595352.description: First semester explores biotechnology techniques for DNA cloning and analysis: restriction enzyme action, DNA sequencing, sequence analysis by computer, plasmid cloning, genomic library production and screening, and DNA probe hybridization. (1 hour lecture/discussion, 6 hours laboratory) (BIOL 472A and CHEM 472A are the same course.)
595352.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 ; BIOL 309 , CHEM 421 or CHEM 423A ; both with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595353.title: Advances in Biotechnology Laboratory
595353.description: Second semester exploring biotechnology techniques for gene product analysis: DNA sequencing, site-directed mutagenesis, predicting amino acid changes, protein overproduction, enzyme function assays, protein identification/preparation by gel techniques, immunoblotting. (1 hour discussion, 6 hours laboratory) (CHEM 472B and BIOL 472B are the same course.)
595353.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 421 or CHEM 423A with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

598318.title: Introduction to Bioinformatics
598318.description: A research-based, problem-solving experience using the tools and algorithms of molecular and computational biology to analyze genetic and protein sequences retrieved from appropriate databases. (2 hours lecture, 3 hours computer laboratory) (BIOL 473 and CHEM 473 are the same course.) (BIOL 473 and CHEM 473 are the same course.)
598318.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 309 , BIOL 303 , BIOL 325 or CHEM 423A with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595354.title: Topics in Contemporary Chemistry
595354.description: Research seminar dealing with topics of current interest in chemistry, such as photochemistry, biochemistry, analytical chemistry and organometallic chemistry. Credit/no credit only. Not applicable toward master's degree. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units.
595354.prereqs: Corequisite: CHEM 295 , CHEM 395 , CHEM 495 , CHEM 499 , CHEM 598 or CHEM 599 .

595355.title: MARC Proseminar
595355.description: Intended to increase the contact of MARC Fellows with minority scientists of national repute who will present seminars. Fellows will read and discuss relevant primary literature, attend the seminars, and meet with speakers before and after the seminars. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 units. Requires selection as a MARC Fellow. (BIOL 480M, CHEM 480M and PSYC 480M are the same course.)

595357.title: Topics in Contemporary Chemistry
595357.description: Special lecture topics of current interest in chemistry. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 6 units. (1 hour lecture per unit)
595357.prereqs: Prerequisite: junior, senior or graduate standing.

595358.title: Internship in Chemistry and Biochemistry
595358.description: Internship in chemistry. Work on projects in industrial, governmental or medical laboratories. May count as career breadth requirement units for chemistry majors or substituted for CHEM 495, with permission. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Does not count toward M.S. degree.
595358.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 301B , CHEM 315 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598210.title: Sustainability Projects
598210.description: Interdisciplinary teams work on real world problems related to sustainability on campus or in the community. (ENST 492 and CHEM 492 are the same course.)

595359.title: Senior Research
595359.description: Methods of chemical research through a research project under the supervision of a department faculty. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Only 6 units may apply toward B.A. or B.S. degree. (6 hours per week per unit)
595359.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 301B , CHEM 315 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595879.title: Introduction to Asian Literature
595879.description: Selected translations of Arabic, Persian, Indian, Chinese or Japanese literature. (CPLT 380 and ENGL 380 are the same course)

595880.title: African Literature
595880.description: African literature written in the English language; the fiction, poetry and drama of the new nations. (ENGL 381 and CPLT 381 are the same course.)

595881.title: Topics in Asian Literature
595881.description: Specific topics will vary from semester to semester. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 6 units.

598857.title: The European Novel
598857.description: Survey of the modern European novel (excluding England and Ireland) from the 19th century to the present. All texts in English translation. (CPTL 384 and ENGL 384 are the same course)

597755.title: Reading Food in Literature
597755.description: Representation of food in literature and its meaning and significance. (ENGL 388 and CPLT 388 are the same course.)

595882.title: Medieval Literature
595882.description: Readings in modern English translation from the medieval literature of England and the continent from St. Augustine to Sir Thomas Malory. (ENGL 450 and CPLT 450 are the same course.)
595882.prereqs: Prerequisite: an upper-division literature course; or graduate standing.

595883.title: Literature of the Renaissance
595883.description: The Renaissance as a literary movement, from Erasmus to Montaigne and Cervantes.
595883.prereqs: Prerequisite: an upper-division literature course; or graduate standing.

598903.title: Postcolonial Literature
598903.description: Survey of literature from the formerly colonized world, emphasizing Anglophone literatures of Africa, the Caribbean, South Asia and Ireland, from 1950 to the present. (ENGL 471 and CPLT 471 are the same course.)
598903.prereqs: Prerequisite: an upper-division literature course; or graduate standing.

598975.title: Translating World Literature
598975.description: Examine texts in translation that shape a contemporary view of the world. Address two central related questions: how does translation shape the formation of so-called world literature?; and what is the worldview present in a translation?
598975.prereqs: Prerequisite: an upper-division literature course; or graduate standing.

595884.title: Independent Study
595884.description: May be repeated for  a maximum of 6 units.

595886.title: Independent Study
595886.description: Research projects in areas of specialization beyond regularly offered coursework. Oral and written reports. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

595580.title: Introduction to Programming
595580.description: Introduction to the concepts underlying all computer programming: design and execution of programs; sequential nature of programs; use of assignment, control and input/output statements to accomplish desired tasks; design and use of functions. Structured and object-oriented methodologies. (1.5 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory)

598931.title: Introduction to Programming Lecture
598931.description: Introduction computer science and computer programming, including designing programs; sequential execution; variables, assignment and arithmetic; control flow, Boolean logic, selection and loops; input/output; functions; debugging; practical applications; and development methodologies. (50-minute lecture)

598932.title: Introduction to Programming Lab
598932.description: Introduction to computer science and computer programming, including designing programs; sequential execution; variables, assignment and arithmetic; control flow, Boolean logic, selection and loops; input/output; functions; debugging; practical applications; and development methodologies. (110-minute lecture)

595581.title: Object-Oriented Programming
595581.description: The object-oriented programming paradigm: classes, member functions, interfaces, inheritance, polymorphism, and exceptions. Design practices including encapsulation, decoupling, and documentation. Pointers/references and memory management. Recursion. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours activity)
595581.prereqs: Prerequisite: CPSC 120 or passing score on Computer Science Placement Exam.

598933.title: Object Oriented Programming Lecture
598933.description: The object-oriented programming paradigm, including classes, objects, member variables and functions; exceptions, inheritance, templates, encapsulation, decoupling and class design best practices. Advanced program design, including iterators, operator overloading, recursion and dynamic memory allocation (50-minute lecture).
598933.prereqs: Prerequisite: CPSC 120 ; or CPSC 120A and CPSC 120L ; or passing score on Computer Science Placement Exam. Corerquisite: CPSC 121L .

598934.title: Object-Oriented Programming Lab
598934.description: Apply object-oriented programming concepts, including classes, objects, member variables and functions; exceptions, inheritance, templates, encapsulation, decoupling and class design best practices. Advanced program design, including iterators, operator overloading, recursion and dynamic memory allocation (110-minute lecture).
598934.prereqs: Prerequisite: CPSC 120 ; or CPSC 120A and CPSC 120L ; or passing score on Computer Science Placement Exam. Corequisite: CPSC 121A .

595582.title: Data Structures
595582.description: Classical data structures: vector, linked list, stack, queue, binary search tree, and graph representations. Worst-case analysis, amortized analysis, and big-O notation. Object-oriented and recursive implementation of data structures. Self-resizing vectors and self-balancing trees. Empirical performance measurement.
595582.prereqs: Prerequisite: CPSC 121A, CPSC 121L; or CPSC 121; or sufficient score on the Computer Science Placement Exam.

597899.title: C Programming
597899.description: Systems programming in the C language, including its syntax and semantics; essential idioms; important parts of the C11 and POSIX C APIs; security issues; and notable extensions libraries.

595583.title: Java Programming
595583.description: Characteristics of Java: portable, robust, secure, object-oriented, high performance; using the Java environment; server administration; types, expressions and control flow; classes, interfaces and packages; threads; exceptions; class libraries; Java for the Internet; tools, the Java Virtual machine. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours lab per week)

595584.title: Visual C# Programming
595584.description: Characteristics of C#, object-oriented design concepts, control structures, methods, arrays, classes, objects, inheritance, polymorphism, exception handling, graphical user interfaces, multithreading, characters, strings, files, streams. Rudiments of the Unified Modeling Language Software development assignments. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours laboratory)

597889.title: Python Programming
597889.description: Concepts of computing, domain-specific problem solving with computing technologies. Methodologies, tools and the application development process. Variables, expressions, control flow, functions, standard libraries, packages, data structures, files, modularization, integration. Develop functional applications. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours lab per week)

598830.title: Swift Programming
598830.description: Introduction to Swift, a programming language primarily used to develop software for Apple operating systems. Introduces skills to learn a new programming language. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours lab per week)

595585.title: Computer Organization and Assembly Language
595585.description: Digital logic and architecture of a computer system, machine level representation of data, memory system organization, structure of low-level computer languages. Machine, assembly, and macro language programming. Principles of assembler operation, input-output programming, interrupt/exception handling. Laboratory programming assignments. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours laboratory)
595585.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 131 ; MATH 170A or MATH 280 ; or graduate standing.

597901.title: Cybersecurity Foundations and Principles
597901.description: Security goals, security systems, access controls, networks and security, integrity, cryptography fundamentals, authentication. Attacks: software, network, website; management considerations, security standards in government and industry; security issues in requirements, architecture, design, implementation, testing, operation, maintenance, acquisition and services.
597901.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science major/minor or Computer Engineering student.

595586.title: Workshop in UNIX
595586.description: Workshop in the use of the UNIX operating system. (2 hours activity)
595586.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 121 or EGME 205 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595587.title: Applied Artificial Intelligence
595587.description: Concepts of Artificial Intelligence, application software and open-source projects. Understanding AI capabilities, AI applications, their impact and ethical issues. Identifying domain-specific problems and solving them with AI technologies and related open-source projects.

595588.title: Programming Lab Practicum
595588.description: Intensive programming covering concepts learned in lower-division courses. Procedural and object oriented design, documentation, arrays, classes, file input/output, recursion, pointers, dynamic variables, data and file structures.
595588.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 131 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598324.title: The Computer Impact
598324.description: The effects of computers on society. Unanticipated consequences of computing technology for individuals, organizations, and institutions. Personal responsibility and legal ramifications. May not be applied toward Computer Science major requirements.
598324.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 2A; junior or senior standing.

595590.title: Professional Ethics in Computing
595590.description: Ethics and moral philosophy as applied to software and digital artifacts. Notions of rights, responsibilities, property, ownership, privacy, security, and professional ethics. Security obligations. Intellectual propertystatutes, licenses, and their terms. Oral and written reports are required.
595590.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 131 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595591.title: Compilers and Languages
595591.description: Basic concepts of programming languages and principles of translation. Topics include history of programming languages, various programming paradigms, language design issues and criteria, design of compilers for modern programming languages.
595591.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 131 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595592.title: File Structures and Database Systems
595592.description: Fundamental theories and design of database systems, the Structured Query Language (SQL), basic concepts and techniques of data organization in secondary storage. Topics include introduction to database systems, ER model, relational model, index structures and hashing techniques.
595592.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 131 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595593.title: Algorithm Engineering
595593.description: Algorithm design using classical patterns: exhaustive search, divide and conquer, randomization, hashing, reduction, dynamic programming, and the greedy method. Asymptotic and experimental efficiency analysis. NP-completeness and decidability. Implementing algorithms to solve practical problems.
595593.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 131 , MATH 170A , MATH 150A ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598204.title: Web Front-End Engineering
598204.description: Concepts and architecture of interactive web applications, including markup, stylesheets and behavior. Functional and object-oriented aspects of JavaScript. Model-view design patterns, templates and frameworks. Client-side technologies for asynchronous events, real-time interaction and access to back-end web services.

598325.title: Operating Systems Concepts
598325.description: Resource management, memory organization, input/output, control process synchronization and other concepts as related to the objectives of multi-user operating systems.
598325.prereqs: Prerequisite: CPSC 131 , CPSC 240 ; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

597890.title: Cryptography
597890.description: Introduction to cryptography and steganography. Encryption, cryptographic hashing, certificates, and signatures. Classical, symmetric-key, and public-key ciphers. Block modes of operation. Cryptanalysis including exhaustive search, man-in-the-middle, and birthday attacks. Programing projects involving implementation of cryptographic systems.
597890.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 170B , CPSC 131 , CPSC 253 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598326.title: Foundations of Software Engineering
598326.description: Basic concepts, principles, methods, techniques and practices of software engineering. All aspects of the software engineering fields. Use Computer-Aided Software Engineering (CASE) tools.
598326.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 131 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598662.title: Introduction to Data Science and Big Data
598662.description: Techniques for data preparation, exploratory analysis, statistical modeling, machine learning and visualization. Methods for analyzing different types of data, such as natural language and time-series, from emerging applications, including Internet-of-Things. Big data platforms. Projects with real-world data.
598662.prereqs: Prerequisites: Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Data Science minor; or Computer Science or Computer engineering graduate standing; CPSC 223P or CPSC 131.

595594.title: Introduction to Game Design and Production
