595594.description: Current and future technologies and market trends in game design and production. Game technologies, basic building tools for games and the process of game design, development and production.
595594.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 121A, CPSC 121L; GE Area 2A; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

597891.title: Mobile Device Application Programming
597891.description: Introduction to developing applications for mobile devices, including but not limited to runtime environments, development tools and debugging tools used in creating applications for mobile devices. Use emulators in lab. Students must provide their own mobile devices.
597891.prereqs: Prerequisite: CPSC 131 or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598885.title: Mobile Device Application Programming for Android
598885.description: Introduction to developing applications for Android mobile devices, including but not limited to runtime environments, development tools and debugging tools used in creating applications for mobile devices. Use emulators in lab. Students must provide own mobile devices.

595595.title: Database and Applications
595595.description: Database design and application development techniques for a real world system. System analysis, requirement specifications, conceptual modeling, logic design, physical design and web interface development. Develop projects using contemporary database management system and web-based application development platform.
595595.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 332 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

597902.title: Theory of Computation
597902.description: Introduction to the theory of computation. Automata theory; finite state machines, context free grammars, and Turing machines; hierarchy of formal language classes. Computability theory and undecidable problems. Time complexity; P and NP-complete problems. Applications to software design and security.
597902.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 121A and CPSC 121L , or MATH 320 ; MATH 170B or MATH 280 ; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595596.title: Computer System Architecture
595596.description: Computer performance, price/performance, instruction set design and examples. Processor design, pipelining, memory hierarchy design and input/output subsystems.
595596.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 240 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595603.title: Web Back-End Engineering
595603.description: Design and architecture of large-scale web applications. Techniques for scalability, session management and load balancing. Dependency injection, application tiers, message queues, web services and REST architecture. Caching and eventual consistency. Data models, partitioning and replication in relational and non-relational databases.
595603.prereqs: Prerequisite: CPSC 332 or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

597904.title: Cloud Computing and Security
597904.description: Cloud computing and cloud security, distributed computing, computer clusters, grid computing, virtual machines and virtualization, cloud computing platforms and deployment models, cloud programming and software environments, vulnerabilities and risks of cloud computing, cloud infrastructure protection, data privacy and protection.
597904.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 351 , CPSC 253 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598694.title: Web Security
598694.description: Concepts of web application security. Web security mechanisms, including authentication, access control and protecting sensitive data. Common vulnerabilities, including code and SQL attacks, cross-site scripting and cross-site request forgery. Implement hands-on web application security mechanisms and security testing.
598694.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 351 or CPSC 253 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

597900.title: Network Security Fundamentals
597900.description: Learn about vulnerabilities of network protocols, attacks targeting confidentiality, integrity and availability of data transmitted across networks, and methods for diagnosing and closing security gaps through hands-on exercises.
597900.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 351 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598602.title: Malware Analysis
598602.description: Introduction to principles and practices of malware analysis. Topics include static and dynamic code analysis, data decoding, analysis tools, debugging, shellcode analysis, reverse engineering of stealthy malware and written presentation of analysis results.
598602.prereqs: Prerequisite: CPSC 351 or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598695.title: Blockchain Technologies
598695.description: Digital assets as a medium of exchange to secure financial transactions; decentralized and distributed ledgers that record verifiable transactions; smart contracts and Ethereum; Bitcoin mechanics and mining; the cryptocurrency ecosystem; blockchain mechanics and applications.
598695.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 351 , CPSC 352 or CPSC 253 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595597.title: Software Design
595597.description: Concepts of software modeling, software process and some tools. Object-oriented analysis and design and Unified process. Some computer-aided software engineering (CASE) tools will be recommended to use for doing homework assignments.
595597.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 362 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595598.title: Software Testing
595598.description: Software testing techniques, reporting problems effectively and planning testing projects. Students apply what they learned throughout the course to a sample application that is either commercially available or under development.
595598.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 362 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595599.title: Software Architecture
595599.description: Basic principles and practices of software design and architecture. High-level design, software architecture, documenting software architecture, software and architecture evaluation, software product lines and some considerations beyond software architecture.
595599.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 362 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595600.title: Software Process
595600.description: Practical guidance for improving the software development process. How to establish, maintain and improve software processes. Exposure to agile processes, ISO 12207 and CMMI.
595600.prereqs: Prerequisite: CPSC 362 or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595601.title: Computer Communications
595601.description: Introduction to digital data communications. Terminology, networks and their components, common-carrier services, telecommunication facilities, terminals, error control, multiplexing and concentration techniques.
595601.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 351 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595602.title: Parallel and Distributed Computing
595602.description: Concepts of distributed computing; distributed memory and shared memory architectures; parallel programming techniques; inter-process communication and synchronization; programming for parallel architectures such as multi-core and GPU platforms; project involving distributed application development.
595602.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 351 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598224.title: Introduction to High Performance Computing
598224.description: Introduction to the concepts of high-performance computing and the paradigms of parallel programming in a high level programming language, design and implementation of parallel algorithms on distributed memory, machine learning techniques on large data sets, implementation of parallel algorithms.
598224.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 351 Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595604.title: Artificial Intelligence
595604.description: Using computers to simulate human intelligence. Production systems, pattern recognition, problem solving, searching game trees, knowledge representation and logical reasoning. Programming in AI environments.
595604.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 335 , MATH 338 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595605.title: Introduction to Machine Learning
595605.description: Design, implement and analyze machine learning algorithms, including supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms. Methods to address uncertainty. Projects with real-world data.
595605.prereqs: Prerequisites: Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Data Science minor; or Computer Science or Computer engineering graduate standing. CPSC 375, MATH 237 or CPSC 335; MATH 338, PSYC 201, PUBH 349, ISDS 361A or EGEC 323.

595606.title: Principles of Computer Graphics
595606.description: Examine and analyze computer graphics, software structures, display processor organization, graphical input/output devices, display files. Algorithmic techniques for clipping, windowing, character generation and viewpoint transformation.
595606.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 131 , MATH 150B , MATH 170B , junior or senior standing; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595607.title: Computational Bioinformatics
595607.description: Algorithmic approaches to biological problems. Specific topics include motif finding, genome rearrangement, DNA sequence comparison, sequence alignment, DNA sequencing, repeat finding and gene expression analysis.
595607.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 131 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595608.title: Game Programming
595608.description: Survey of data structures and algorithms used for real-time rendering and computer game programming. Build upon existing mathematics and programming knowledge to create interactive graphics programs.
595608.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 386 , CPSC 484 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

607232.title: Computational Epidemiology
607232.description: Applying computational methods to problems in the field of epidemiology. Developing computational tools for modeling, simulating, predicting and visualizing the spread of diseases, using techniques from different areas of computer science.
607232.prereqs: Prerequisite: CPSC 223P; undergraduate major/minor in Computer Science, Biology, Mathematics or Public Health; or graduate standing.

607233.title: Natural Language Processing
607233.description: Concepts of natural language, natural language processing, understanding and generation. Designing and building various language models using computational approaches to solve common natural language problems, as well as other real-world problems.
607233.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 170B; MATH 338; CPSC 131 or CPSC 375; Computer Science or Computer Engineering major or minor; or Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598725.title: Undergraduate Seminar in Computer Science
598725.description: Review of foundational computer science theories and principles, real-world application development methods and processes, and industry practices. Survey of modern computing technologies. Research methods. Identification of research or practical application problems. Writing and presenting a proposal for a capstone project.
598725.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 362 , junior or senior standing, Computer Science major.

598726.title: Senior Capstone Project in Computer Science
598726.description: A computer science research or real-world level of application development project. Business communication. Presenting the results to a wide range of audiences. Demonstrating the culminating experience of the practicum in computer science. Writing a final project report and technical documents such as user manuals, installation guides, feasibility study reports.

595610.title: Independent Study
595610.description: Special topic in computer science, selected in consultation with and completed under the supervision of instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 units of Undergraduate credit and 6 units of Graduate credit. Requires approval by the Computer Science chair.

598603.title: Mobile Computing
598603.description: Wireless systems and communication fundamentals; IoT protocols for wireless software development; sensor network systems; techniques for native and cross-platform mobile application development; mobile connectivity; integration of mobile applications with cloud services. CPSC 471 recommended.

595611.title: Advanced Database Management
595611.description: Implementation techniques for query analysis, data allocation, concurrency control, data structures and distributed databases. New database models and recent developments in database technology. Student projects directed to specific design problems. CPSC 431 recommended.
595611.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598604.title: Applied Algorithms
598604.description: Primer on data structures and algorithms applicable to software development and professional meetings. Lists, queues, search trees and hashing. Sorting and searching. Graph structures, traversal, paths and spanning. Design methods: asymptotic analysis, greedy methods, divide and conquer, and dynamic programming. CPSC 121 recommended.
598604.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598605.title: Advanced Algorithms
598605.description: Design and analysis of sophisticated algorithms and data structures. Lower, tight and pseudo-polynomial bounds. Randomization, approximation and special-purpose data structures. Algorithmic frameworks, such as maximum flow and linear programming. CPSC 335 recommended.
598605.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595612.title: Systems and Software Standards and Requirements
595612.description: SESC framework and the IEEE Software Engineering Standards. Establishing the following standards: Software Life Cycle Processes, Work Product Standards, Process Standards, Requirement Analysis and Management and System Integration. Introduces CMMI framework; discuss number of practical lessons. CPSC 362 recommended.
595612.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595613.title: Software Verification and Validation
595613.description: Theory and practice of software verification and validation (V&V), including software integrity levels, minimum V&V tasks, walkthroughs, inspections and clean room. Topics include: white-box and black-box testing, boundary value analysis, equivalence class partitioning, unit testing, functional testing and test plans. CPSC 362 recommended.
595613.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595614.title: Software Maintenance
595614.description: Theory and practice of maintaining large-scale software. Maintenance framework, process, measures, and process management. Topics include fundamentals of software change and its implications, maintenance process models, reusability for maintenance, reverse engineering, maintenance testing, software configuration management and tools in maintenance. CPSC 362 recommended.
595614.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595615.title: Advanced Software Process
595615.description: Advanced guidance for defining and improving the software development process. Concepts of software maturity framework, principles of process improvement and software process assessment. Current topics such as CMMI and SCAMPI. CPSC 362 recommended.
595615.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595616.title: Software Design and Architecture
595616.description: Advanced software design and architecture principles focusing a software engineering approach to the development process. Topics include architecture business cycle, quality attributes, attribute-driven design method, architectural styles, design patterns, software product lines and component-based design. CPSC 362 recommended.
595616.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595617.title: Modern Software Management
595617.description: Modern project management methodologies and techniques. Software development process. Planning, estimating, organizing, directing, monitoring, controlling software projects and managing risks. Other related software management issues, such as infrastructure, quality software development, project and product metrics and external factors. CPSC 362 recommended.
595617.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595618.title: Software Measurement
595618.description: Current software measurement practices. Topics include:  establishing an effective software metrics program; measuring software product, project and process; applying Statistical Process Control and other statistical techniques. High maturity concepts defined in CMMI model will be discussed. Stresses a practitioner-based approach. CPSC 362 recommended.
595618.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595619.title: Professional, Ethical and Legal Issues for Software Engineers
595619.description: Professional, legal and ethical issues pertaining to software engineering. Topics include professional codes of ethics, intellectual property laws, computer privacy and human-computer interaction. Relevant regulatory documents and their applications. CPSC 362 recommended.
595619.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598606.title: Web Application Frameworks
598606.description: Examine and compare current patterns and models for modern web application development. Analyze front- and back-end web framework design and architecture. Emerging web technologies and current research. CPSC 449 recommended.
598606.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595620.title: Operating Systems Design
595620.description: Design and evaluation techniques for controlling automatic resource allocation, providing efficient programming environments and appropriate user access to the system, and sharing the problem solving facilities. CPSC 351 recommended.
595620.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598569.title: Cyber Forensics
598569.description: Introduction to principles and practices of cyber forensics. Topics include: developing an investigative capability; legal and IT requirements; forensic tools; incident response; live forensic investigations; seizure of digital information; operating system boot processes; and investigation of network traffic. CPSC 456 recommended.
598569.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595621.title: Advanced Computer Networking
595621.description: System-oriented view of computer network design, protocol implementation, networking, high-speed networking, network management, computer network performance issues. CPSC 471 recommended.
595621.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

598767.title: Advanced Blockchain Technologies
598767.description: A holistic experience for different types of blockchain development. The ins and outs of blockchain and Ethereum from a developer perspective, along with smart contract security and best practices.
598767.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 459 or CPSC 352 ; Computer Science, Computer Engineering or Integrated B.S.-M.S. Computer Engineering major/minor; or Computer Science, Computer Engineering or Integrated B.S.-M.S. Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595622.title: Advanced Computer Graphics
595622.description: Three-dimensional: reflection models, shading techniques, rendering process, parametric representation, ray tracing, radiosity, texture, anti-aliasing, animation, color science. CPSC 484 recommended.
595622.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595623.title: Knowledge Representation and Reasoning
595623.description: A field of artificial intelligence representing information about the world in a form that a computer system can use to solve complex tasks. Representing knowledge symbolically for automated reasoning; inference algorithms; logic programming; Semantic Web; reasoning under uncertainty; Requires project. CPSC 481 recommended.
595623.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595624.title: Neural Networks, Deep Learning, and Reinforcement Learning
595624.description: Principles of artificial neural networks, designing network architectures, implementations and applications. Principles of reinforcement learning, frameworks, designing solutions, implementations and applications. Principles of deep learning and applications.
595624.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595625.title: Seminar in Computer Science
595625.description: Research methods in computer science. Current technology trends and research topics. Verification of computer science theories and principles. Identification of practical application development and/or research problems. Presentations on selected topics and problems. Writing a proposal for a capstone graduate project.

595626.title: Project
595626.description: Conduct a computer science research or development project proposed in the selected topic, complete it, write a final project report, and present the results in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the master's degree. Classified graduate standing and approval of the computer science graduate adviser are required to enroll.

595627.title: Thesis
595627.description: Requires approval of the Computer Science graduate adviser.
595627.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 589 ; Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595628.title: Independent Graduate Research
595628.description: Special topic in computer science, selected in consultation with and completed under supervision of a full-time faculty member. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. CPSC 589 recommended. Requires approval of Computer Science department chair.
595628.prereqs: Prerequisite: Computer Science or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

597745.title: Myths and Realities of Crime and Justice
597745.description: The myths and misperceptions of crime, law and justice. The role of moral panics and the media in shaping perceptions of crime.

607259.title: Concepts of Criminal Law
607259.description: Basic concepts of substantive and procedural criminal law. Introduction to the philosophy of law, definition and classification of crime, and the constitutional provisions related to search, seizure, interrogation, the nature of acceptable evidence and the trial process.

595652.title: Foundations of Criminal Justice
595652.description: Overview and analysis of the components of the criminal justice system; emphasizing the historical and contemporary aspects of law, policing, courts and corrections.

607260.title: Introduction to Criminal Courts
607260.description: Structure, operation and function of the U.S. criminal courts. Emphasizes pretrial and trial procedure, as well as the organizational roles, key players and behaviors within the court system.

595653.title: Controlling Crime
595653.description: Crime control and prevention. Common criminal justice tactics, such as imprisonment, capital punishment, camera surveillance, electronic monitoring, restorative justice, and situational crime prevention.

598952.title: Introduction to Criminalistics
598952.description: Introduction to the basic concepts and methods of criminalistics, crime scene investigation and the legal issues surrounding the use of physical evidence in the judicial process.

595655.title: Police and Society
595655.description: Critical overview of local policing from a historical and contemporary lens. Organizational structure, law and practices, including discretion, use of force and police-public interactions in a diverse society.

598419.title: Introduction to Public Administration
598419.description: Introduces public administration through current trends and problems of public sector agencies in such areas as organization behavior, public budgeting, personnel, planning and policy making. Examples and cases from the Criminal Justice field. (POSC 320 and CRJU 320 are the same course.)

595656.title: Leadership for Public Service
595656.description: Conceptions of leadership as applied in governmental and nonprofit sectors. Types of leaders; tools for leaders; leadership in public policy-making settings. Includes student project and extend leadership concepts; participation in CSUF Student Leadership Institute or similar activity. (POSC 322 and CRJU 322 are the same course.)
595656.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 , POSC 200 or GE Area 4A.

595486.title: Earthquake Engineering
595486.description: Principles of seismic analysis and design for structural and non-structural elements based on current building codes. Earthquake motions, response spectra, energy absorption capacity of materials and structural components, earthquake-resistant building systems.

597989.title: Advanced Topics in Reinforced Concrete Design
597989.description: Analysis and design of reinforced concrete structural members subjected to seismic loading. Detailing considerations for ductility in reinforced concrete. Lateral load resisting systems for concrete structures. Use of computer software for simplified analysis. Use of latest building codes and standards.

598504.title: Advanced Topics in Structural Steel Design
598504.description: Analyze and design structural steel members for seismic loading and structural stability. Advanced design topics include composite construction, plate girders, plastic analysis, connections and ductile lateral force resisting systems. Use contemporary computer software, building codes and design specifications.

595489.title: Groundwater and Seepage
595489.description: Satellite systems, link analysis, propagation effects, SNR/CNR calculations, modulation schemes, TDMA, FDMA and CDMA techniques.

597986.title: Advanced Soil Mechanics
597986.description: Behavior of soil on fully and partially saturated conditions, consolidation of soil, shear strength of soil for fully and partially saturated conditions, shear strength of soil for earthquake loading.

597982.title: Slope Stability and Retaining Structures
597982.description: Static and seismic stability analysis of slopes; calculation of earth pressures retaining structures; design of retaining wall, sheet pile, and braced excavation system for static and seismic loading.

597714.title: Advanced Foundation Engineering
597714.description: Design foundations for earthquake loading and problematic soils; pile and caisson design, ground surface subsidence, slope stability and stabilization; designing anchored bulkheads and dam sections.

597940.title: Geotechnical Earthquake Engineering
597940.description: Dynamic loading of soils, effect of liquefaction, ground response analysis, soil-structure interaction, and in-depth design and behavior of foundation structures due to earthquake loading.

598663.title: Advanced Soil Characterization Methods
598663.description: Determine engineering properties for various applications using analyses of static and cyclic simple shear, static and cyclic triaxial, and bender element data and in-situ data, including that from cone penetration and vane shear tests.

595488.title: Advanced Construction Methods and Techniques
595488.description: Advanced technologies in the construction of building, highway, bridge, dam structures and building materials and systems, such as concrete, steel, masonry and diverse methods and techniques.
595488.prereqs: Prerequisite: EGCE 350 or Civil Engineering graduate standing.

595476.title: Construction Methods and Equipment for Heavy Construction Engineering
595476.description: Methods and equipment for construction foundations, highways, airfields, bridges, ports, harbors, dams, nuclear power plants and industrial facilities. Quality control and construction failures.
595476.prereqs: Prerequisite: EGCE 350 or Civil Engineering graduate standing.

595490.title: Preconstruction Design Evaluation
595490.description: Cost benefit, preconstruction scheduling, and constructability modifications in design, specifications and construction methods. Value Engineering.
595490.prereqs: Prerequisite: EGCE 350 or Civil Engineering graduate standing.

597931.title: Cost Estimating and Bidding Strategy
597931.description: Management and cost control of large capital projects. Capital cost estimation, value prediction and control, cost and schedule control and management of mega projects.
597931.prereqs: Prerequisite: EGCE 350 or Civil Engineering graduate standing.

598802.title: Construction Procurement Management
598802.description: Concepts and techniques for construction contract and procurement management; PMBOK procurement process; project evaluation, planning, financing, contracting, negotiation and procurement execution.
598802.prereqs: Prerequisite: EGCE 350 or Civil Engineering graduate standing.

597934.title: Fate and Transport of Chemicals in the Environment
597934.description: Principles of thermodynamics, reaction kinetics, mass balance, energy balance, reactor design, and unit operations in environmental engineering applications; fate and transport of chemicals in the environment.

597935.title: Hydraulics and Hydrology for Environmental Engineers
597935.description: Fluid mechanics, hydraulics, and hydrology principles, applications and design for environmental engineers.

597936.title: Water Supply, Treatment and System Design
597936.description: Stepwise development and process design equipment selection, economic evaluation, green technologies, and operating guidelines for water treatment.

597937.title: Environmental Engineering Practices and Project Management
597937.description: Environmental impact analysis and assessment, regulatory framework, and environmental issues. Budget, schedule, and management of environmental engineering projects.

597705.title: Surface Water Pollution and Control
597705.description: Sources, quality and quantity of storm water runoff, best management practices (BMPs), system design of structural BMPs, green technologies, design for wastewater discharge into rivers, lakes and oceans.
597705.prereqs: Prerequisite: EGCE 431 ; or Environmental Engineering graduate standing.

595484.title: Solid Waste Management, System Design and Sustainability
595484.description: Industrial waste treatment and disposal, waste minimization, process selection, control, green technologies and resource recovery. Design of liners, gas and leachtate collection and removal systems in landfills.
595484.prereqs: Prerequisite: EGCE 431 ; or Environmental Engineering graduate standing.

595473.title: Remediation of Contaminated Soil and Groundwater
595473.description: Site assessment, green technologies, design for soil remediation systems and design for groundwater remediation systems.

595474.title: Wastewater Treatment and Water Reclamation
595474.description: Principles of anoxic, aerobic and anaerobic biological processes and treatment. Stepwise development and process design equipment selection, economic evaluation, green technologies and operating guidelines for wastewater treatment.

597706.title: Air Pollution Control Engineering
597706.description: Sources and impacts of air pollutants, methods of sampling and analysis, air dispersion modeling, control techniques and system design for common air pollutants, climate changes, green technologies and greenhouse emission control.
597706.prereqs: Prerequisite: EGCE 370 ; or Environmental Engineering graduate standing.

597707.title: Graduate Projects
597707.description: A systematic approach to conducting research and in-depth study of an applied topic within the civil and environmental engineering disciplines.

597932.title: Thesis
597932.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units (three units per semester). Requires classified graduate status and formal approval of Civil Engineering Graduate Committee, graduate adviser and department head.

597717.title: Independent Graduate Research
597717.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires classified graduate status and formal approval of Civil Engineering Graduate Committee, graduate adviser and department head.

596236.title: Introduction to Phonetics
596236.description: Analysis and description of speech at the segmental and suprasegmental levels. Practice using the International Phonetic Alphabet for broad and narrow transcription. Overview of speech production.

596237.title: Introduction to Communicative Disorders
596237.description: Broad overview of disorders of communication, including classification and prevalence. Educational and training requirements for speech-language pathology and audiology, professional settings and opportunities, ethical considerations, clinical observations.

598591.title: Introduction to Research in Communication Sciences and Disorders
598591.description: Understanding and using professional literature in communication sciences and disorders and using that literature to generate a formal research paper. A passing grade fulfills the course requirement of the university upper-division baccalaureate writing requirement for communicative disorders majors.

596238.title: Introduction to Sign Language
596238.description: Overview of the deaf experience and the options for communication in the deaf community. Use of American Sign Language and finger spelling at the introductory level.

598533.title: Biology of Human Communication
598533.description: Biology and evolution of speech and language. Speech production, evolution and development; speech perception; language, hemispheric specialization, clinical studies; current methods in neurolinguistics; and plasticity and aging.

598534.title: Speech/Language Development
598534.description: Normal acquisition of phonology, morphology, semantics, syntax and pragmatics in children. Biological, cognitive and social bases of language acquisition. Meets the requirements for specialized preparation to serve as a teacher of exceptional children. (COMD 307 and LING 307 are the same course.)

596255.title: The Anatomy and Physiology of Speech and Hearing
596255.description: Anatomy and physiology of the speech and hearing mechanism. Processes of respiration, phonation, articulation-resonance and hearing.

596256.title: Communication and Aging
596256.description: Communicative changes found in older adults, including normal and pathologic changes in the physiological and behavioral aspects. Diagnosis, rehabilitative strategies, social implications and health care systems.

596257.title: Speech and Hearing Science
596257.description: Physiology and acoustics of speech production, including voice, resonance and individual speech segments. Instrumentation for the acoustic and perceptual analysis of speech.

596258.title: Child Language and Phonological Disorders
596258.description: Language and phonological disorders in children. Speech/language profiles of special populations and contemporary approaches to assessment and intervention. Practice analyzing child speech/language samples.

596260.title: Communication Development/Disorders in Children from Culturally/Linguistically/Diverse Backgrounds
596260.description: Speech-language development in children from culturally and linguistically diverse (CLD) dialect and language backgrounds, differentiating normal language and dialect differences from disorder, and current clinical procedures for assessing and treating speech and language disorders in CLD child populations.
596260.prereqs: Prerequisites: COMD 241 , COMD 242 , COMD 307 , COMD 352 ; or graduate standing.

596270.title: Audiology and Audiometry
596270.description: Characteristics of hearing disorders, including etiologies and risk factors. Methods and procedures used in assessing the auditory system including current topics of interest. Partially fulfills the requirements for state audiometrist certificate.

596271.title: Aural Rehabilitation
596271.description: Effects of hearing loss on speech and language. Treatment of hearing disorders, including amplification and aural rehabilitation. Role of the audiologist and speech-language pathologist in the management of hearing disorders.

596272.title: Voice and Craniofacial Disorders
596272.description: Disorders of voice; disorders of articulation and resonance caused by orofacial pathology. Anatomical and physiological bases, assessment, diagnosis, management and interdisciplinary aspects.
596272.prereqs: Prerequisites: COMD 241 , COMD 242 , COMD 344 ; or graduate standing.

596273.title: Neurology and Neurogenic Communicative Disorders
596273.description: Anatomy and physiology of the nervous system as they relate to speech, language, hearing and swallowing. Clinical characteristics of neurogenic language disorders, apraxia of speech and dysarthria. Contemporary approaches to assessment and treatment. Lecture, demonstration and clinical observations.
596273.prereqs: Prerequisites: COMD 241 , COMD 242 , COMD 307 , COMD 344 ; or graduate standing.

596274.title: Fluency Disorders
596274.description: Theories of development and remission of stuttering, constitutional and environmental risk factors. Clinical characteristics of stuttering. Contemporary approaches to assessment and treatment. Lecture, demonstration, clinical observations and exercises.
596274.prereqs: Prerequisites: COMD 241 , COMD 242 , COMD 307 , COMD 344 ; or graduate standing.

596275.title: Clinical Methods and Procedures
596275.description: General principles and procedures for assessment and treatment of individuals with communicative disorders. Lecture, demonstration, clinical observations and supervised clinical experience.
596275.prereqs: Prerequisites: COMD 241 , COMD 242 , COMD 307 , COMD 344 , COMD 352 ; COMD 472 , COMD 474 or COMD 475 ; or graduate standing.

598592.title: Counseling in Communication Disorders
598592.description: Introduces counseling skills to address the impact of communication disorders on individuals and their families. Explores counseling approaches that maximize treatment outcomes. Includes in-class activities, team research, hands-on service-learning, field trips, community outreach, lectures and guest talks.

598660.title: Internship in Communication Sciences and Disorders
598660.description: Minimum of 120 hours of supervised fieldwork at a CICE-approved internship site. Practical application of academic knowledge within the field of Communication Sciences and Disorders via experience in a clinical or professional setting.

598593.title: Independent Study
598593.description: Open to upper-division students in speech communication only with signed consent form from department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

598594.title: Research in Communication Sciences and Disorders
598594.description: Research design and methods used in descriptive and experimental research in communication sciences and disorders.

596282.title: Seminar in Speech-Language Pathology
596282.description: Introduction to requirements for the M.A. degree in communicative disorders, including the requirement for demonstrating knowledge-based and skill-based competencies. Students start a portfolio for documentation of competencies and demonstrate a number of competencies within this course. Credit/no credit only.

596290.title: Neurologic and Clinical Aspects of Speech, Language and Cognition
596290.description: Neuroanatomy as it relates to speech, language and cognition; the neuropsychological bases of consciousness, attention, sensation, perception, higher mental functions, language and motor speech; emphasis on assessment, diagnosis, prognosis and management of neurogenic communicative disorders.

596291.title: Seminar in Dysphagia
596291.description: Theory and clinical aspects of dysphagia. Physiology of normal swallow, etiologies of dysphagia, clinical and instrumental assessment, diagnosis and management.
596291.prereqs: Prerequisites: COMD 542 , Communicative Disorders graduate standing.

596292.title: Seminar in Neurogenic Speech, Language and Cognitive Disorders
596292.description: Theory and clinical aspects of neurogenic speech, language and cognitive disorders. Standardized and informal assessment, differential diagnosis, prognosis and management, including evaluation of the validity of clinical practice guidelines through the analysis of published research.
596292.prereqs: Prerequisites: COMD 542 , Communicative Disorders graduate standing.

596269.title: Clinical Practicum: Speech and Language Disorders in Children
596269.description: Supervised experience in the assessment and treatment of children with speech and language disorders. Weekly individual and group conferences. Approximately 25-40 clinical clock hours. May be repeated for credit. Requires approved Clinical Practicum Plan.
596269.prereqs: Prerequisite: Communicative Disorders graduate standing, COMD 404 . Corequisites: COMD 574 , COMD 577 .

596293.title: Seminar: Cultural, Linguistic, and Global Issues in Communication Sciences and Disorders
596293.description: Culturally responsive research-to-practice considerations for individuals and families from diverse cultural-linguistic and global communities. Case study reviews with applied assessment, treatment, instruction and counseling/consultation activities across lifespan involving varied communication disorders and differences.
596293.prereqs: Prerequisite: Communicative Disorders graduate standing, COMD 404.

596294.title: Clinical Practicum: Speech and Language Disorders in Adults
596294.description: Supervised experience in assessing and treating adults with speech and language disorders. Weekly individual and group conferences. Approximately 25-40 clinical clock hours. May be repeated for credit. Requires approved Clinical Practicum Plan.
596294.prereqs: Prerequisite: Communicative Disorders graduate standing, COMD 404 . Corequisite: COMD 542 .

598595.title: Specialty Clinic
598595.description: Supervised/specialized clinical experiences that address the needs of: adults seeking gender-affirming voice and communication modifications, using evidence-based practices; or children and adults who require aided augmentative alternative communication (AAC) systems to support ldaily communication.
598595.prereqs: Prerequisite: COMD 404; COMD 548 (ACC Clinic) or COMD 558A (GCC Clinic); Corequisite: COMD 573 (GCC Clinic) or COMD 576 (AAC Clinic).

596295.title: Advanced Clinical Practicum: Communicative Disorders
596295.description: Advanced clinical practice under supervision with children and/or adults. Off-campus program in hospitals, clinics and other rehabilitation facilities. Approximately 150 clinical clock hours. Requires approved Clinical Practicum Plan.
596295.prereqs: Prerequisites: Communicative Disorders graduate standing, COMD 404, COMD 543, COMD 548, COMD 558A; Pre- or corequisite: COMD 544.

598536.title: Advanced Clinical Practicum: Communicative Disorders
598536.description: Advanced clinical practice, under supervision with children and/or adults. Off-campus program in hospitals, clinics and other rehabilitation facilities. Approximately 50 clinical clock hours per unit. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 units. Requires approved Clinical Practicum Plan.
598536.prereqs: Prerequisites: COMD 548 , COMD 543 , COMD 558A , COMD 571 , COMD 573 , COMD 574 , COMD 576 , COMD 577 ; Communicative Disorder graduate standing.

596296.title: Autism Spectrum Disorders in Speech-Language Pathology
596296.description: Communication disorders in children with autism spectrum disorders (current theories, diagnostic process, co-occurring conditions, the role of speech-language pathologists in multi-disciplinary approaches to assessment and intervention planning, critical review of relevant research).
596296.prereqs: Prerequisites: COMD 577 , Communicative Disorders graduate standing.

598800.title: Audiology and Aural Rehabilitation Practicum
598800.description: Clinical education experience necessary to help meet ASHA's academic and clinical education requirement of knowledge and skill acquisition (KASA) in the areas of hearing, identification of hearing loss and aural rehabilitation. Requires approved clinical practicum plan. Students accrue five to 10 clock hours from hearing screenings.
598800.prereqs: Prerequisites: Communicative Disorders graduate standing, COMD 404, COMD 461, COMD 465.

596297.title: Seminar in Fluency Disorders
596297.description: Reading assignments, seminars, lectures and case reviews to enable students to develop a framework for understanding the etiology and maintenance of stuttering and to develop their own approaches to assessment and treatment. Requires approved Individual Student Schedule.

596298.title: Seminar in Voice Disorders
596298.description: Review classification of voice disorders (perceptually); examine instrumental assessment of such disorders (acoustically); and emphasize a comprehensive physiological, perceptual and acoustic work-up of individual cases. Requires approved Individual Student Schedule.

596299.title: Seminar in Phonological Disorders
596299.description: Develop critical thinking and analytical skills related to current issues in linguistic theories on the assessment and treatment of phonological disorders in children. Requires approved Individual Student Schedule.

596300.title: Seminar in Augmentative and Alternative Communication
596300.description: Historical service delivery approaches; symbol sets and systems; assessment and management strategies for persons with severe physical and speech impairments; advocacy approaches for the disabled.

596301.title: Seminar in Child Language Disorders
596301.description: Principles of language assessment and intervention based upon psycho-linguistic theory and current research on language disordered children. Develop critical thinking and analytical skills related to the assessment and treatment of language disorders in children. Requires approved Individual Student Schedule.

596277.title: Public School Practicum in Communicative Disorders
596277.description: Meets the directed teaching requirements for the Speech-Language Pathology Services Credential. Approximately 100-150 clinical clock hours. Requires approved Clinical Practicum Plan and application approved prior to semester of practicum.
596277.prereqs: Prerequisites: Communicative Disorders graduate standing, COMD 404, COMD 548, COMD 558A, COMD 574, COMD 577; Pre- or corequisite: COMD 564, COMD 576; Corequisite: COMD 590.

598535.title: Seminar: Speech and Hearing Service in Schools
598535.description: Problems and challenges unique to the student clinician in organizing and managing the speech and hearing program in the school. Clinician's role; planning, scheduling, case finding, treatment program reporting and other responsibilities.
598535.prereqs: Prerequisites: Communicative Disorders graduate standing. Corequisite: COMD 589A .

598596.title: Independent Graduate Research
598596.description: Open to graduate students only with signed consent from department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

595491.title: Writing for Mass Media
595491.description: Principles and practices of writing for major types of mass communications media. Content, organization, conciseness and clarity. All Fullerton campus lectures online, laboratory in classroom. Requires typing ability. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours laboratory)
595491.prereqs: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595492.title: Digital Reporting and Writing
595492.description: Develop expertise in news reporting and writing for print, web and social media. Introduction to ethical and legal concerns for journalists; changing concepts of news; and data journalism. Pitch stories for publication by the Daily Titan.

595493.title: Digital Reporting and Production
595493.description: Develop expertise in news reporting and production for digital platforms, emphasizing visual storytelling and production. News content contribution to student media.

595494.title: Mass Communication in Modern Society
595494.description: Internet, newspapers, magazines, film, radio and television; their significance as social instruments and economic entities in modern society.

595495.title: Visual Communication
595495.description: Social and cultural analysis of the meaning, production and consumption of visual information in a modern media society. Still, moving, television, graphic design, cartoon and computer images will be analyzed in terms of technical, commercial and cultural considerations. Must earn a "C" or better to pass the course.

595496.title: Writing for the Entertainment Industry
595496.description: Theory and principles of writing for the entertainment industry. Requires typing ability. (2 hours discussion, 1 hour activity)
595496.prereqs: Prerequisites: ENGL 101 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598225.title: Spanish Language TV News
598225.description: Produce the Spanish-language television news program Al DIa. Emphasize news gathering, writing, shooting and editing packages for television and web. Impact of Spanish-language media and changing demographics in the United States. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units

595497.title: Mass Media Ethics
595497.description: Moral and professional conduct within various communications contexts. Examine cases involved with advertising, broadcast journalism, film, photojournalism, print journalism, public relations, television and the World Wide Web.

595498.title: Mass Media and Diversity
595498.description: Analyzes the representations of marginalized groups in mass media and popular culture. Evaluates gender, race, sexuality, religion, and other identities. Designed to make students more critical producers and consumers of the media.

595499.title: Digital Foundations
595499.description: Develop ability to create and evaluate multimedia content. Preparation for digital portfolio graduation requirement.

595500.title: Visual Reporting
595500.description: Image creation for publication in print and/or screen media. Convergence of the basic principles and practices of digital photography, digital imaging, graphic design and web page production for journalism-based visual problem solving.
595500.prereqs: Prerequisite: COMM 317 with a “C” or better; or Art major.

595501.title: Studio Photography
595501.description: Creative and effective use of images in print and/or screen publications within advertising, public relations, entertainment studies and other commercial, persuasive communication contexts.
595501.prereqs: Prerequisite: COMM 317 with a “C” or better; or Art major.

597718.title: Multimedia Journalism
597718.description: Study online journalism models and basic multimedia design while conducting in-the-field reporting projects that combine audio, photo, video, graphic and print elements to tell compelling journalistic stories.
597718.prereqs: Prerequisite: COMM 201 , COMM 202 , all with a “C” (2.0) or better; Communications major or Journalism minor.

595520.title: Global Media
595520.description: Major mass communication systems, both democratic and totalitarian, and the means by which news and propaganda are conveyed internationally. The role of media in the process of globalization.

595502.title: News Literacy
595502.description: Provides a foundation in news literacy: using critical thinking skills to judge the reliability and credibility of information reports, whether via print, television, radio or Internet. Read and deconstruct a variety of news stories to determine their level of transparency and trustworthiness.

595503.title: Social Media, Editing and Design
595503.description: Digital and print news editing: social media practices; copy improvement; headline writing; news photos and captions; online news production and management; design and typography principles; law and ethics. (2 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory)

595504.title: Mass Media Effects
595504.description: The role mass media communications play in all human activity with heavy emphasis on the effects of mass media on the political, social and economic fabric of America.

595505.title: Feature Article Writing
595505.description: Nonfiction writing for newspapers and magazines; sources, methods and markets.
595505.prereqs: Prerequisite: COMM 101 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595506.title: Public Affairs Reporting
595506.description: Reporting public interest news such as courts, education, finance, government, police and urban problems. COMM 407 recommended.
595506.prereqs: Prerequisite: COMM 201 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598691.title: Sports Broadcast Journalism
598691.description: Develop expertise in sports reporting, anchoring and producing for television sports programs. Produce Titan Sports in the studio and a live athletic event on campus. Opportunities to learn play-by-play and sideline reporting.

598692.title: Politics in the Mediasphere
598692.description: Examines the collective political ecology of the world's media, including newspapers, magazines, television, radio, film, advertising, press releases, political websites, blogs and social media in view of the current political climate and campaigns.

595507.title: Principles of Entertainment and Tourism Communications
595507.description: Structure and commercial functions of the entertainment and tourism industries. The central role of communication in industry technologies and professional practices. Career opportunities associated with these fields.
595507.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A. Corequisite: Communications major - COMM 233 or COMM 317.

595508.title: Principles of Advertising
595508.description: Overview of the advertising industry and its specializations. Contemporary functions, strategies, media, ethics and technology, as well as the role of integrated marketing communication.
595508.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A. Corequisite: Communications major - COMM 233 or COMM 317.

598322.title: Writing for the Advertising Industry
598322.description: Develop persuasive communication skills essential for success within the advertising industry. Write strategic advertising copy for various target audiences across multiple platforms. Must earn a "C" (2.0) or better to continue taking advertising courses.

595509.title: Advertising Media
595509.description: Plan, execute and control advertising media programs. Basic data and characteristics of the media. Buying and selling process, techniques and methods in media planning process. Audience measurement and media analysis.

595510.title: Advertising Creative Strategy and Execution I
595510.description: Writing copy and layout advertisements, based on study of sales appeals, attention factors and illustrations. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours activity)

595511.title: Principles and Ethics of Public Relations
595511.description: Social, behavioral, psychological, ethical, economic and political foundations of public relations, and the theories of public relations as a communications discipline.
595511.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A. Corequisite: Communications major - COMM 233 or COMM 317.

595512.title: Public Relations Writing I
595512.description: Communications analysis, writing for business, industry and nonprofit organizations. Creating effective forms of public relations communication. Requires typing ability.
595512.prereqs: Prerequisites: COMM 101 , COMM 361 , all with a “C” (2.0) or better; junior standing.

598527.title: Principles and Ethics of Journalism
598527.description: American journalism; newspapers and periodicals through radio, television and the internet; ideological, political, social and economic aspects.
598527.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A. Corequisite: Communications major - COMM 233 or COMM 317.

598515.title: Radio-Audio Operations
598515.description: Concepts and practices of radio station and audio broadcast operations, including programming, sales, promotion, traffic, billing, production, news, research and engineering. Work in traditional and online formats.

595513.title: TV News Production
595513.description: Writing, production and evaluation of television news. Discussion of TV reporting techniques and problems. Cover events and produce TV news in lab. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours lab)
595513.prereqs: Prerequisites: COMM 201 , COMM 202 , all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598126.title: Radio-Audio Entertainment
598126.description: Theory and application of commercial audio production, including broadcast and console operations, microphone techniques, digital editing and on-air procedures. Develop appreciation for high-quality sound and produce broadcast-quality audio entertainment projects.

598597.title: Radio-Audio News
598597.description: Writing, editing and reporting radio/digital news. Create journalistic stories from interviews and news events. Incorporate sound bites and insert music where appropriate. Emphasize accurate and concise content and ability to work on deadline. Completion of COMM 371 strongly recommended.

595073.title: Sculpting Life Forms
595073.description: Three-dimensional investigation of any life form, its characteristics and expressive possibilities. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. (6 hours activity)

607219.title: Digital Sculpting
607219.description: Digital three-dimensional investigation of natural and hard-surface forms, including the human figure and its anatomy, structure and expressiveness.

595074.title: Drawing and Painting the Head and Hands
595074.description: Construction and anatomy of the human head and hands, and their principal use in drawing, painting and illustration. (6 hours activity)

595075.title: History of Architecture Before the Modern Era
595075.description: Selected monuments from Stonehenge through the late Baroque. Interrelationship between patronage, style, function, structural principles and technological developments.
595075.prereqs: Prerequisite: ART 101 or ART 201A or ART 201B ; or junior or senior standing.

597928.title: History of Architecture: Renaissance through Beaux-Arts (1400-1900)
597928.description: Renaissance through Beaux-Arts architecture. History, patronage, style, function structural principles, technological developments and architectural terminology as they apply to 600-year survey of architecture.
597928.prereqs: Prerequisite: ART 101 , ART 201A or ART 201B ; or junior or senior standing.

595076.title: Graphic Design
595076.description: Development and projection of ideas in relation to the technical, aesthetic and psychological aspects of advertising art. Intermediate use of computer graphics. (6 hours activity)

595077.title: Graphic Design
595077.description: Development and projection of ideas in relation to the technical, aesthetic and psychological aspects of advertising art. Intermediate use of computer graphics. (6 hours activity)

595078.title: Beginning Glass Casting
595078.description: Hot glass laboratory equipment and casting techniques. Introduction to hot pour, sand and kiln casting. (6 hours activity)

598230.title: Beginning Glassblowing
598230.description: Introduction to glassworking. Develop concepts and basic glassblowing skills in solid and blown glass.

598964.title: Digital Fabrication
598964.description: The possibilities and technologies of digital fabrication in the context of contemporary art practice. Additive and subtractive technologies, such as 3D printing and laser cutting, to create three-dimensional objects.

595079.title: Ceramic Sculpture
595079.description: Concepts, materials and investigation of sculptural forms, emphasizing individual growth. (6 hours activity)

595080.title: Ceramic Sculpture
595080.description: Concepts, materials and investigation of sculptural forms, emphasizing individual growth. (6 hours activity)

595081.title: Moldmaking and Cast Sculpture
595081.description: Theories and techniques of rigid and flexible moldmaking incorporated with both cold material and hot metal casting processes. Recommended for concentrations in Entertainment Art/Animation, Ceramics and Crafts; required for Sculpture majors. (9 hours laboratory)

598310.title: Animal and Wildlife Drawing
598310.description: Principles and practices of drawing animals, including construction, anatomy, texture, movement and expression. Fundamentals, historical information and critiques are covered in the classroom; field studies are conducted at various zoos and wildlife habitats. (6 hours activity)
598310.prereqs: Prerequisites: BFA major in Entertainment Art/Animation or Illustration; ART 107A , ART 117 .

595082.title: Creative Photography
595082.description: Photographic media as a personal expression. Historical attitudes and processes; new materials and contemporary aesthetic trends. Field trips required. (9 hours laboratory)

595083.title: Creative Photography
595083.description: Photographic medium as personal expression. Historical and contemporary aesthetic issues. Exploration of black and white, color and digital media. Field trips required. (9 hours laboratory)

598519.title: Creative Digital Photography
598519.description: Fine art digital photography course for art majors. Digital image-making as a personal fine art expression. Historical attitudes and processes, as well as new materials and contemporary aesthetic trends. (9 hours laboratory)

595084.title: Kinetic Sculpture
595084.description: Kinetic sculpture is sculpture in motion. Theory and practice of creating sculpture that uses both motorized and nonmotorized means of activation. History of the medium and basic fabrication techniques. (9 hours laboratory)

595085.title: Printmaking Etching
595085.description: Concept development, exploration and materials involved in printmaking techniques. Includes etching and aquatint. (9 hours laboratory)

595086.title: Artists’ Books
595086.description: Personal vision and concepts applied to the book form as art; the history and aesthetics of artists' books. (6 hours activity)

598863.title: Animation Preproduction
598863.description: The animation pre-production process, including the fundamentals of storyboarding, character and background design, layout, timing and the language of film. (6 hours activity)
598863.prereqs: Prerequisites: BFA major in Entertainment Art/Animation or Game Art, Animation and Immersive Media or Illustration; ART 253A or ART 255B with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598866.title: Animation Production
598866.description: Pitch and produce original animated short films with an entertaining, character driven story showcasing unique voices and perspectives. Soundtracks, dialogue and post-production. (6 hours activity)
598866.prereqs: Prerequisites: BFA major in Entertainment Art/Animation or Game Art, Animation and Immersive Media or Illustration; ART 353A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

607220.title: Visual Storytelling for Animation and Games
607220.description: Art direction for animation and games. Explore elements of visual storytelling to affect the emotional intensity of an audience through the study of visual components, including color, light, mood and tone. (6 hours activity)
607220.prereqs: Prerequisites: BFA major in Entertainment Art/Animation or Game Art, Animation and Immersive Media or Illustration; ART 217, ART 263, ART 253A or ART 255A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598727.title: 2D Character Animation
598727.description: Expand knowledge of the 12 principles of animation through studying and practicing 2D character animation techniques in a series of intermediate level exercises, focusing on character animation as a storytelling medium. (6 hours activity)
598727.prereqs: Prerequisites: BFA major in Entertainment Art/Animation or Game Art, Animation and Immersive Media or Illustration; ART 253A or ART 253T with a “C” (2.0) or better.

607221.title: 3D Character Animation
607221.description: Expand knowledge of the 12 principles of animation through studying and practicing 3D character animation techniques using keyframing and real-time motion-capture for game engines. (6 hours activity)
607221.prereqs: Prerequisites: BFA major in Entertainment Art/Animation or Game Art, Animation and Immersive Media; ART 255B with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598864.title: 3D Character Modeling
598864.description: Create character and prop content using intermediate-level organic and hard surface modeling and sculpting workflows specific to game engines and computer animation production.
598864.prereqs: Prerequisites: ART 255A ; Entertainment Art/Animation, Game Art, Animation and Immersive Media, or Illustration B.F.A. major.

598575.title: 3D Environment Modeling
598575.description: 3D environment art for games, immersive media and animation virtual production using intermediate level modeling, sculpting and procedural workflows both realistic and stylized.
598575.prereqs: Prerequisites: ART 255A ; Entertainment Art/Animation, Game Art, Animation and Immersive Media, or Illustration B.F.A. major.

598576.title: 3D Rigging and Animation
598576.description: Fundamentals of rigging characters and props for computer animation, games, and virtual production by integrating motion capture data with key-frame performances.
598576.prereqs: Prerequisites: ART 255A ; ART 255B ; Entertainment Art/Animation or Game Art, Animation and Immersive Media B.F.A. major.

595087.title: Woodcuts and Monotypes
595087.description: Woodcut and monotype as a means of personal expression. Traditional, as well as contemporary materials and trends. May be repeated once for credit. (6 hours activity)

595088.title: Illustration
595088.description: Story, book, magazine and film illustration. May be repeated once for credit. (6 hours activity)

595089.title: Illustration
595089.description: Computer aided illustration. May be repeated once for credit. (6 hours activity)

595090.title: Digital Narrative Illustration
595090.description: Narrative illustration using advanced digital painting programs and techniques. Theory of illustration concepts, composition and current trends in story illustration as it relates to digital media. May be repeated once for credit. (6 hours activity)

595091.title: Stained Glass
595091.description: Architectural and autonomous stained glass design and craftsmanship. (6 hours activity)

595092.title: Stained Glass/Kiln Working
595092.description: Flat glass fusing and slumping. Designs are fused together in kilns and slumped over or into molds to create sculptural relief and low vessel forms. (6 hours activity)

595093.title: Elements of Sequential Art
595093.description: Theory and practice of pictorial narrative in film story-board and graphic novel. Character and scenic design; story sketch, "breakdown" and production design. Considerations: plot, scene, exposition, transition and continuity. Individual and team projects. May be repeated once for credit. (6 hours activity)

595094.title: Cartooning and Caricature
595094.description: Principles and practices of cartooning and caricature construction, anatomy and expression. Historical overview of the field with an emphasis on professional applications and the impact of computer graphics. (6 hours activity)

595095.title: Art and Child Development
595095.description: Art concepts, materials and processes as they relate to child development. May include a service-learning component. (6 hours activity)

598840.title: Creative Thinking in the Studio Art Classroom
598840.description: Teaching creativity in the studio art classroom.
598840.prereqs: Prerequisite: ART 201A, ART 201B or GE Area 3A.

598841.title: Art and Social Justice
598841.description: Create art lessons and art projects to share with community partners via teaching experiences. Work directly with community to teach and create social justice service projects and public practice projects in alternative venues.

595096.title: History of Women Artists
595096.description: Study of art made by women in the context of major art historical developments from the 10th century to the present. Analysis of images of women and the evolution of gender stereotypes in art. (3 hours lecture)

595097.title: The Digital Studio
595097.description: Digital studio as a site for experimentation in image making and visual media expression. Computer applications for creating and manipulating images and media are fundamental for the contemporary visual artist. May be repeated once for credit. (6 hours laboratory)

595098.title: History of Contemporary Art
595098.description: Major art movements and aesthetic discourses grasping the shift from modern to contemporary. Artists' writings and including geographies outside the U.S. and Europe, concentrating on concepts that challenged our understanding of what is considered "art." ART 312 recommended.
595098.prereqs: Prerequisite: ART 201A or ART 201B ; or graduate standing.

595099.title: Seminar in Creative Photography
595099.description: Introduces studio art majors to photographic and media criticism and theory. Provides studio artists with the necessary theoretical background and context for creating and understanding their work in our current media culture. May be taken for credit for a maximum of nine units.

595100.title: Glass Blowing
595100.description: Advanced level; designing, analyzing and developing concepts to create contemporary glasswork. Exploring the material while expanding on technical skills and conceptual depth in glass. May be repeated once for credit. (6 hours activity)
595100.prereqs: Prerequisites: ART 103 , ART 104 ; or graduate standing.

595101.title: Glass Blowing
595101.description: Creating hand-blown glassware and sculpture from molten glass using traditional and contemporary tools and techniques. May be repeated once for credit. (6 hours activity)

595102.title: Renaissance Art
595102.description: Painting, sculpture and architecture from the late 13th to 16th centuries in Italy.

595103.title: Creative Photo Studio Projects
595103.description: Advanced technical class to perfect and refine photographic skills. Integrate technical skills with creative options. May be taken for credit for a maximum of nine units. (6 hours activity)

595104.title: Media Exploration for Teaching Art
595104.description: Art media used in secondary school art programs today, focusing on secondary levels. Materials for art curriculum and lesson planning. Two- and three-dimensional media in subject matter applications. (6 hours activity)
595104.prereqs: Prerequisites: ART 103 , ART 104 , ART 107A , ART 107B , ART 205A .

595105.title: Special Studies: Artists’ Books and Art
595105.description: Studio art course for advanced students who want to continue to explore the book form as it relates to their personal aesthetic goals. (6 hours activity)

595106.title: Exhibition Design
595106.description: Technical and aesthetic experience in problem-solving exhibition design concepts, evaluation and design analysis. Production of exhibitions in the University Art Gallery; their selection, design, installation, lighting and supportive interpretive material. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. (6 hours activity)
595106.prereqs: Prerequisites: 3 units upper-division art history, 3 units lower-division studio art; or graduate standing.

607222.title: Realtime Narrative Development
607222.description: Learn to work individually and in teams to create functional prototypes within an existing real-time engine. Use industry standard tools for rapid prototyping.

598577.title: Lighting and Look Development
598577.description: Cinematic approaches to lighting and material systems for virtual scenes that convey story, mood and atmosphere specific to workflows in ray-traced scenarios and game engines.

598578.title: 3D Team Production
598578.description: Original storytelling and content creation for immersive media, virtual production for animation, and game development in a diverse and collaborative setting.
598578.prereqs: Prerequisite: ART 355A , ART 355B , ART 355C ; Entertainment Art/Animation or Game Art, Animation and Immersive Media B.F.A. major. Corequisite: ART 455B .

598579.title: BFA Capstone: Game Art, Animation and Immersive Media
598579.description: Portfolio-building content creation and career path development focusing on game art, animation, immersive media (VR/AR/XR) and virtual production; emphasizing originality, design and communicating ideas with a high level of craftsmanship and storytelling.
598579.prereqs: Prerequisites: ART 355A , ART 355B , ART 355C ; Game Art, Animation and Immersive Media B.F.A. major. Corequisite: ART 479 .

598072.title: Art History of the Ancient Americas
598072.description: History of the art and architecture of select civilizations of ancient Mesoamerica and South America. (ART 459 and CHIC 459 are the same course.)

598842.title: American Art: From Puritanism to Pop
598842.description: American painting and sculpture from the 17th to the 20th centuries. The cultural, social, historical, racial and gender issues that influenced the development of art in the United States.
598842.prereqs: Prerequisite: ART 201A or ART 201B ; or graduate standing.

595108.title: Latin American Art History: 1400 - Present
595108.description: History of art and architecture of select regions and nations of Latin America, from Contact to present. Major monuments and art movements. (ART 462 and CHIC 462 are the same course)

598904.title: Modern and Contemporary Latin American Art
598904.description: Modern and contemporary Latin American art. Focus on key case studies to study art production in the region from the 1920s avant-gardes to activist art in the 21st century. ART 462 recommended.
598904.prereqs: Prerequisite: ART 201A or ART 201B ; or graduate standing.

595110.title: Art of Sub-Saharan Africa
595110.description: Art and architecture of sub-Saharan Africa from c. 300 BC to present. Relation between art and culture.

595111.title: Museum Education
595111.description: History of museum education, its philosophy and issues. Relationship with other museum departments, outreach programs, new technology. Events organization, writing interpretive materials, budgets and grants, conducting tours. Lectures, field trips and guest speakers.

595112.title: Photography and Social History
595112.description: Photography from ancient optical observations through 19th-century invention to 20th-century acceptance as an art form. Aesthetic movement and influential innovators. Lectures, slides and class discussion.

595114.title: Studio Expanded: Other Genre
595114.description: Various methods of expanding traditional studio approaches through the investigation of installation, performance and video art. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 12 units, but no more than 3 units in a single semester. (6 hours activity)

595115.title: Video Art and the Moving Image
595115.description: Contemporary and historic practices in video and the role time plays in moving image arts. Production and post-production fundamentals, including camera work, editing, audio recording, storytelling and relationships between images and sound.
595115.prereqs: Prerequisite: 6 units of lower-division studio art courses.

597703.title: Topics in Art History
597703.description: Detailed study of the work of individual artists, patronage in particular places, specific pictorial, sculptural and architectural programs or art history periods. May be repeated for credit with different topics for a maximum of 12 units.

595116.title: Seminar in Art History
595116.description: Study and evaluation in one area of art history and appreciation. May be repeated once for credit.

595117.title: Special Studies in Graphic Design
595117.description: Advanced use of computer graphics. Maximum of 12 units of credit (repeatable as upper-division electives), but no more than 3 units in a single semester without permission of instructor. (6 hours activity). ART 483E recommended.
595117.prereqs: Prerequisites: ART 323A , ART 323B ; or graduate standing.

595118.title: Visual Development and Background Painting
595118.description: Story concepts, research, design and media for rendering and painting background environments. Historical precedents, color theory, perspective, theatrical composition, painting and drawing media, and stylization for dramatic impact as it relates to visual development. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. (6 hours activity)
595118.prereqs: Prerequisite: 6 units from ART 363A , ART 363B , ART 367 , ART 353A , ART 353B or ART 373 .

595119.title: Special Studies in Illustration
595119.description: May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 12 units, but no more than 3 units in any one area in a single semester without permission of instructor. (6 hours activity)
595119.prereqs: Prerequisite: 6 units from ART 363A , ART 363B , ART 367 , ART 353A , ART 353B or ART 373 .

595121.title: Computer Assisted Graphics
595121.description: Theory and practice of design using the computer. Numerous applications of the computer through lecture demonstration, studio/laboratory experiences, guest speakers and field trips. Maximum of 12 units for credit (repeatable as upper division electives), but no more than 3 units in a single semester without permission of instructor. (6 hours activity)

595122.title: Design for Interactive Art
595122.description: Creating interactive art and design projects. Concentration in the advanced visual organization systems of art and design and how to apply those techniques to an interactive computer environment. May be repeated once for credit (as upper-division elective). (6 hours activity)

595123.title: Entertainment Graphics
595123.description: Structure, procedure and standards of the entertainment design field. Students will work on projects from a major entertainment design group, developing concepts and designs for comparison with professional solutions. May be repeated once for credit (as upper-division elective). (6 hours laboratory)
595123.prereqs: Prerequisites: ART 323A , ART 323B , ART 483E or graduate standing.
