595954.description: Historical development and schools of criticism. Individual offerings within this course number may deal with only one aspect of critical problems. May be repeated once for credit with a different topic.
595954.prereqs: Prerequisite: no postbac undeclared or credentials.

595955.title: Writing Theory and Practice for Teaching Associates
595955.description: Theory and practice of the composing process for the beginning college teacher of expository writing. Required of all English Department Teaching Associates during their first semester of teaching. Requires admission to the English Department Teaching Associate Program.

595957.title: Seminar: Topics in Rhetoric and Composition
595957.description: As appropriate to the specialized research of instructor, special topics on rhetoric and composition, including historical and theoretical approaches. May be repeated once with different topic.
595957.prereqs: Prerequisite: no postbac undeclared or credentials.

595958.title: Project/Comprehensive Exam
595958.description: Writing a master's project in literature, rhetoric and composition, or creative writing. Or,  prepare to take a comprehensive exam covering a predetermined area of focus. Requires prior departmental approval of project proposal or desired exam area of focus.

595959.title: Independent Graduate Research
595959.description: Research projects in areas of specialization beyond regularly offered coursework. Oral and written reports. May be repeated once for credit.

595960.title: Teaching English in the Secondary School
595960.description: Principles, methods and materials of teaching English in the secondary school. Students must earn a "B-" (2.7) or better to meet the requirements for earning a preliminary Single Subject credential.
595960.prereqs: Prerequisite: Teacher Education Credential Program in English student.

595961.title: First Semester Student Teaching
595961.description: Student teaching in the secondary school during the first semester of the teacher preparation program. Candidate plans and teaches assigned lessons during the last third of the semester.

595962.title: Second Semester Student Teaching
595962.description: Student teaching in the secondary school during the second semester of the teacher preparation program. Candidate has the same instructional hours of responsibility as the master teacher.

595963.title: Seminar in Secondary Teaching
595963.description: Teaching a single subject in secondary schools. Videotape analysis of teaching based on Teaching Performance Assessments. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit.

598554.title: Sustainability Projects
598554.description: Interdisciplinary teams work on real world problems related to sustainability on campus or in the community. (ENST 492 and CHEM 492 are the same course.)

595964.title: Environmental Issues and Approaches
595964.description: Interdisciplinary approaches to environmental problems and research methods. Prepare seminars and papers on research design for potential thesis topics. Meets graduate writing requirement.
595964.prereqs: Prerequisite: graduate standing in Environmental Studies.

595965.title: Environmental Evaluation and Protection
595965.description: Environmental parameters (water, air, solid wastes, noise, radiation, etc.). Techniques in monitoring and measurement; effect on human health; environmental quality standards and controls. Demonstrations and field trips.
595965.prereqs: Prerequisite: graduate standing in Environmental Studies.

595966.title: Environmental Research and Analysis
595966.description: Research methods used in the field of environmental studies. Research tools used in such areas as environmental field studies, environmental experiments, social environmental impacts, environmental attitudes and behavior and environmental trend analysis.
595966.prereqs: Prerequisite: graduate standing in Environmental Studies.

595968.title: Selected Topics in Environmental Problems
595968.description: Various environmental topics, contemporary or historic, that focus on problems (e.g., law, endangered habitats, planning, global environmental issues, etc.). Topic chosen and outline will be circulated prior to registration. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 18 units.
595968.prereqs: Prerequisite: graduate standing in Environmental Studies.

595969.title: Internship in Environmental Studies
595969.description: Field experience with a governmental or private agency.

595970.title: Project
595970.description: Planning, preparing and completing an acceptable, interdisciplinary project. Credit on submission of project and presentation of research findings in a poster session organized by the Environmental Studies Program. Requires classified status in Environmental Studies program and consent of project adviser and program coordinator.

595971.title: Thesis
595971.description: Planning, preparing and completing an acceptable, interdisciplinary thesis. Credit on submission of thesis. Requires classified status in Environmental Studies Program and consent of instructor and program coordinator.

595972.title: Independent Graduate Research
595972.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of instructor and program coordinator.

597905.title: Ethnic Studies Senior Seminar
597905.description: Senior capstone learning experience and seminar. Required course for Ethnic Studies majors (AFAM, ASAM, CHIC). Requires completion of core requirements for AFAM, ASAM or CHIC.

598629.title: Ethnic Studies Senior Seminar
598629.description: Senior capstone learning experience and seminar. Required course for Ethnic Studies majors (AFAM, ASAM, CHIC). Requires completion of core requirements for AFAM, ASAM or CHIC.

598630.title: Ethnic Studies Senior Seminar
598630.description: Senior capstone learning experience and seminar. Required course for Ethnic Studies majors (AFAM, ASAM, CHIC). Requires completion of core requirements for AFAM, ASAM or CHIC.

598345.title: Personal Financial Management
598345.description: Financial problems of the household in allocating resources and planning expenditures. Housing, insurance, installment buying, medical care, savings and investments. Special financial planning problems faced by minorities and women. May not be used to fulfill the concentration requirement in finance.

595973.title: Financial Management I
595973.description: Financial statement analysis. Interest rates and valuing cash flows (TVM; valuing stocks and bonds). Investment decision rules and capital budgeting. Risk and return (CAPM) and cost of capital.
595973.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 201A ; non-business student - GE Areas 1A, 1B. Corequisites: Business student - ISDS 361A , BUAD 301 ; non-business student - GE Area 2A.

595974.title: Financial Management II
595974.description: Brief review of valuing cash flows, risk/return and capital budgeting. Long-term financing, capital structure and payout policy, financial planning and forecasting, with a focus on firm valuation. Additional topics if time permits.

598925.title: General Principles of Professional Financial Planning
598925.description: Preparation for the Certified Financial Planner exam by addressing Sections B and H of the CFP(c) exam curriculum. Specific topics include the financial planning process, understanding personal financial statements, economic concepts and behavioral finance, among others.

598346.title: Working Capital Management and Computer Applications
598346.description: Analyze working capital management and policy, liquidity measurement, sources of financing for periods of cash deficits; manage accounts receivable and inventories; financial forecasting and short-term financing.

595975.title: Financial Analysis for Investors and Lenders
595975.description: Interpretation of financial statement from the perspective of the financial analyst and creditor. Economic meaning of financial statement data for the purpose of evaluating a company's financial performance.

595976.title: Introduction to Investments
595976.description: Institutional characteristics of securities markets, security valuation and trading methods, fundamental and technical analysis, selection and management of securities, role of the capital asset pricing model in investing, options and futures markets, portfolio analysis and mutual funds.

598656.title: Student Managed Investment Fund
598656.description: Manage a portfolio of stocks and bonds funded by an external or internal sponsor. Investment teams may compete against local universities for the opportunity to invest funds for a sponsor organization.

595977.title: Capital and Money Markets
595977.description: Capital and money markets in the American and international economies; markets for new corporate and government issues; secondary markets; use of derivative securities for hedging; factors influencing yields and security prices.
595977.prereqs: Prerequisites: not a CBE premajor or undecided/undeclared major; FIN 320 with a “D” (1.0) or better. Pre- or corequisite: FIN 321 .

595978.title: Real Estate Principles
595978.description: Real estate principles, practices and investment decisions. Equity investment, finance, legal aspects, practices, principles, property development, real estate administration in the public sector, real estate market analysis and valuation.

598347.title: Real Estate Finance
598347.description: Financial institutions and real estate credit. Sources and uses of capital (funds) in financing real estate transactions. Money and capital markets and their effect on credit availability. Mortgage mechanics and the workings of both primary and secondary markets.

598348.title: Real Estate Valuation
598348.description: Comprehensive coverage of the basic concepts and principles of real estate valuation. Use of the three approaches to valuation for the appraisal of both residential and income-producing properties. Role of valuation in real estate investment. Government regulation of appraisers.

598349.title: Real Estate Investment Analysis
598349.description: Alternative analytical techniques in evaluating real estate investments. Tax aspects, measurement of investment returns, application of computer models to investment decisions. Lecture, discussion and case analysis of major investment types - raw land, apartment houses, commercial and industrial uses.

595979.title: Principles of Risk Management and Insurance
595979.description: Analysis of the risk management process, introduction to property and liability insurance, employee benefits and financial planning. Overview of the insurance industry and insurance problems.
595979.prereqs: Corequisite: FIN 320 ; or junior standing or above.

598159.title: Insurance Company Operations
598159.description: Course surveys the overall structure and functions of insurance companies and reviews all major insurance company functional areas. It also examines the two major markets in which businesses and individuals may obtain insurance: admitted lines and non-admitted lines.

595980.title: International Business Finance
595980.description: Financing problems of the multinational business. International financial environment, taxation of foreign income, the cost of capital in international capital and money markets, problems of risk in foreign investments, and financial techniques for the operation of the multinational firm.

595981.title: Export-Import Financing
595981.description: Institutional arrangements, methods and techniques used to finance international trade. Government and financial institution services. Risk-return aspects of international sales, insurance needs, the use of letters of credit, international factoring, accounts receivable insurance and other financing techniques. Review of required export-import documentation.

597941.title: Global Risk Management and International Finance
597941.description: Loss control within the field of global insurance and risk management to provide knowledge for the practical application of international financial risk management principles techniques and methods utilized in multinational corporations and governmental organizations operations.

598968.title: Fundamentals of Cryptocurrencies
598968.description: The design of cryptocurrencies and how they function in practice, focusing on the following: cryptography; blockchain technology; crypto as currency; interaction with traditional capital markets; investments. (FIN 379 and ISDS 379 are the same course.)

598734.title: Property Management
598734.description: Real estate is managed at the property level by property managers, the asset level by asset managers and the portfolio level by portfolio managers. Key concepts across three levels of real estate management: property management, asset management and portfolio management.

598516.title: Retirement Planning
598516.description: Retirement savings and income planning from the perspective of a Certified Financial Planner - practitioner. Required in order to take the CFP(r) Certification Examination. Considerable discussion of federal legislation controlling retirement planning.

598517.title: Estate Planning
598517.description: Estate planning from the perspective of a Certified Financial Planner practitioner. Required in order to take the CFP(r) Certification Examination. Considerable discussion of federal legislation controlling estate planning.
598517.prereqs: Prerequisite: FIN 320 or FIN 360; or CBE graduate standing.

595982.title: Theory and Practice of Personal Financial Planning
595982.description: Developing, implementing and monitoring comprehensive personal financial plans. Risk management, investments, taxation, retirement and estate planning, professional practices
595982.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 308, FIN 340, FIN 360, FIN 408. Corequisite: FIN 409.

597826.title: Quantitative Theory of Interest
597826.description: The theory of interest in both finite and continuous time; the use of various annuity functions as a basis for reserving, valuation, pricing, duration, asset/liability management, amortization schedules and measurement of fund performance; term structure of interest rates.
597826.prereqs: Prerequisites: CBE (not pre-business) major FIN 320 or CBE graduate standing; other major MATH 106 or MATH 150B.

595983.title: Commercial Bank and Financial Institution Management
595983.description: Financial institution problem solutions. Major financial intermediaries and the decision-making problems they face. Regulation and its effect on management operations. Group problems and case studies.
595983.prereqs: Prerequisites: FIN 320 with a “D” (1.0) or better; not CBE pre-major or undeclared major; or CBE graduate standing (not pre-MBA). Corequisite: FIN 321 .

595984.title: Financial Forecasting and Budgeting
595984.description: Forecasting in financial management; profit planning and control process; goals, technical procedures and effects of budgeting; mechanics of forecasting and budgeting, follow-up and control.
595984.prereqs: Prerequisites: FIN 320 with a “D” (1.0) or better; not CBE pre-major or undeclared major; or CBE graduate standing (not pre-MBA). Corequisite: FIN 321 .

595985.title: Problems in Business Finance
595985.description: Group problems and case studies relating to estimation of funds requirements, long-term financial planning, evaluation of cash flows, financing acquisitions and mergers, capital budgeting and cost of capital. Team-building, leadership and computer-assisted presentation skills. Not applicable for graduate degree credit.

598432.title: Capital Markets and Fixed Income Analysis
598432.description: Fixed income markets, including the price dynamics and risk profiles of various fixed-income securities, derivatives, yields, duration, credit analysis of bonds, portfolio management strategies, calculating performance and identifying factors driving fixed-income returns.
598432.prereqs: Prerequisites: FIN 320 or FIN 517 ; not CBE pre-major or undecided/undeclared major; or CBE graduate standing and not pre-MBA. Corequisite: FIN 340 , FIN 342 or FIN 541 .

595986.title: Business Valuation, Mergers and Acquisitions
595986.description: Valuation, especially for mergers and acquisitions. Valuation methods and their application in mergers and acquisitions. May not receive credit for both FIN 440 and FIN 540.
595986.prereqs: Prerequisites: FIN 321 , not CBE pre-major or undeclared major; or FIN 517 , CBE graduate standing (not pre-MBA).

595987.title: Portfolio Management for Stocks and Bonds
595987.description: How to make evidence-based decisions for personal investing, or prepare for careers in financial planning or asset management. Topics include investment research methods, portfolio management techniques, financial statement analysis, cash flow forecasting and professional ethics.
595987.prereqs: Prerequisites: FIN 341 , ISDS 361A . Corequisite: FIN 340 or FIN 517 .

597990.title: Advanced Security Analysis for Bonds
597990.description: Integrate portfolio management techniques from FIN 442 with advanced analysis of fixed income securities to achieve a desired investment objective. Use market data platforms such as FactSet and Bloomberg to combine macroeconomics with company-specific factors to develop high-conviction investment recommendations.

603098.title: Advanced Security Analysis for Stocks
603098.description: Apply traditional and quantitative investment techniques to identify attractive equity securities. Create customized cash flow forecasts and discounted cash flow models to estimate intrinsic value. Employ option strategies, including covered calls and protective puts for risk management and income.

598350.title: Options and Futures
598350.description: Put and call options, option pricing theory and models. Financial futures pricing, hedging strategies and models. Institutional characteristics of futures trading. Options and futures on stock indices. Options on futures, theoretical relationship between options and futures.

598657.title: Real Estate Practice
598657.description: Professional aspects of real estate business, overview of the real estate industry, ethics, licensing, contracts, forms, disclosure documents, listing properties, handling offers, closing sales transactions; financing, escrow, title and taxation issues; and 1031 exchanges requirements for investment property.

598658.title: Legal Aspects of Real Estate
598658.description: Overview of early to modern legal principals and how they apply to real estate transactions ownership, title, escrow, brokerage, contracts, financing, landlord/tenant issues and government regulation.

595988.title: Real Estate Economics
595988.description: Factors and influences of urban growth and development. Economic factors and real estate supply and demand. Location theory and urban growth patterns. Public policy as a factor in real estate development. Analysis of real estate markets.

598351.title: Business Property and Liability Risk Management
598351.description: Duties and functions of a corporate risk manager, the major commercial property liability lines, including business income, general liability, commercial auto workers compensation, business owner insurance and operation of property liability insurers.
598351.prereqs: Prerequisite: FIN 320 or FIN 360 ; or graduate standing.

598352.title: Life and Health Insurance
598352.description: Analyze various types of life annuity and health insurance contracts, major employee benefit plans adopted by corporations, and the organization and management of life and health insurance companies.
598352.prereqs: Prerequisite: FIN 320 or FIN 360 ; or graduate standing.

598436.title: Professional Ethics, Corporate Compliance and Regulation
598436.description: How organizations can best assess and manage their exposure to legal, regulatory and ethical issues through corporate compliance programs.
598436.prereqs: Prerequisite: FIN 320 or FIN 360 ; or graduate standing.

598353.title: Insurance Marketing and Distribution Strategies
598353.description: Practices and procedures involved in insurance marketing and distribution. Analyzes insurance marketing environment, marketing strategies and product promotion; introduction to insurance distribution channels and sales force management.
598353.prereqs: Prerequisite: FIN 320 , FIN 360 or MKTG 351 ; or graduate standing.

598870.title: Data Analytics for Risk and Insurance
598870.description: Overview of the application of traditional and modern data analytics to risk management and property-casualty insurance. Data management, predictive modelling, traditional analysis techniques, modern analysis techniques, smart product technology and data analysis in underwriting. (ISDS 478 and FIN 478 are the same course.)

598969.title: Crypto Creation
598969.description: Create own cryptocurrency and non fungible tokens (NFT) using the Titan Crypto Ecosystem. Utilize the ecosystem?s blockchain to create nodes, Integrate APIs, design the interface, make the cryptocurrency legal and mint the cryptocurrency. (FIN 479 and ISDS 479 are the same course.)

595989.title: Internship
595989.description: A supervised experience where financial principles or methods are applied in a fieldwork setting. Mandatory class meetings for students to discuss their experience and integrate financial practice. Sections for other concentrations within the department will include application of relevant principles. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
595989.prereqs: Prerequisites: FIN 320 , 2.5 GPA; or graduate standing.

595990.title: Independent Study
595990.description: Open to undergraduate students desiring to pursue directed independent inquiry. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Not open to students on academic notice. Requires consent of department chair.

595991.title: Managerial Finance
595991.description: Modern theory and practice of financial management. Net present value and the time value of money. Basic principles of risk and return. Capital budgeting and forecasting. Capital structure and dividend theory. Firm valuation from a value-based management and corporate governance perspective.

595992.title: Seminar in Corporate Financial Management
595992.description: Analyze financial decision-making process through case studies and seminar presentations. Current financial theory and models. International applications.

595993.title: Seminar in Financial Economics
595993.description: Valuation or corporate liabilities and other securities. Economic decision-making under uncertainty and asset pricing theories are analyzed rigorously. Other topics may include optimal capital structure, the market for corporate control, or macroeconomics aspects of finance. (FIN 528 and ECON 528 are the same course.)
595993.prereqs: Prerequisites: Economics graduate major - ECON 310, ECON 440, and ECON 320 or ECON 325; MBA major - ECON 515 or ECON 521, and ISDS 361A or ISDS 513.

595994.title: Seminar in Financial Administration
595994.description: Optimal financing and asset administration; advanced techniques of capital budgeting; application of analytical methods to the administration of the finance function of the business firm.

595995.title: Seminar in Business Valuation, Mergers and Acquisitions
595995.description: Issues and techniques related to business valuation and mergers and acquisitions. May not receive credit for both FIN 440 and FIN 540.

595996.title: Seminar in Investment Management
595996.description: Problems of investment and portfolio management; concepts of risk evaluation and investment criteria; analysis of interest rate movements; investment valuation and timing; regulation and administrative problems of the industry. May not receive credit for both FIN 442 and FIN 541.

595998.title: Seminar in Real Estate Investment
595998.description: Problems of real estate investment; concepts of evaluation and investment criteria; analysis of real property values; real estate development and financing. Case studies.

595999.title: Corporate Risk Management and Insurance Seminar
595999.description: Managing risks that confront firms; how they are managed with diversification, capital structure, loss control, corporate governance, and how they are financed with commercial insurance contracts; analyzes market and instruments created to enable corporations to manage downside risks.

596000.title: Enterprise Risk Management (ERM)
596000.description: ERM framework with the integration of pure, financial, strategic and operational risks. Discusses seven building blocks for developing an ERM program. Legal and regulatory environment, technical tools and future prediction on ERM.

598354.title: Seminar in International Financial Management
598354.description: Financial problems of the multinational firm. International financing instruments, capital investment decisions and constraints on the profitability of multinational businesses.

596001.title: Project
596001.description: Directed independent inquiry. Not open to students on academic probation. Requires consent of instructor, approval by Department Chair.

596002.title: Independent Graduate Research
596002.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Not open to students on academic notice. Requires consent of instructor, approval by department chair and associate dean.
596002.prereqs: Prerequisites: FIN 517 ; CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

595823.title: The Teaching Experience: Exploration
595823.description: Exploring one's self in relation to other people in the schools, and an encounter with the teaching experience through fieldwork. Accompanying seminar helps extend observations and explore relevant issues. (2 hours fieldwork, 2 hours seminar). (EDSC 110, EDEL 110, SCED 110 and SPED 110  are the same course.)

595824.title: Introduction to Elementary Classroom Teaching
595824.description: Exploratory course with field assignments for those considering careers in schools, grades TK-8. Students taking this course to meet the prerequisite for either the Multiple Subject or the Special Education Credential Program must earn a "C-" or better. Fieldwork required.

595825.title: Cultural Pluralism in Elementary Schools
595825.description: Culture and cultural pluralism in grades TK-8. Examine one?s own beliefs and values; classroom practices and materials that promote equity; strategies for learning about students; history/traditions of cultural groups; and assess multicultural education programs. Students taking this course to meet the prerequisite for either the Multiple Subject or the Special Education Credential Program must earn a "C-" or better.

595826.title: Integrated Curriculum and Instruction in the Elementary School
595826.description: Additional study of elementary curriculum emphasizing language arts, integrated instruction across the curriculum and assessing learning outcomes. Must be taken for a letter grade if enrolled in the credential program. A "B" or better is required to pass the course.
595826.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to second semester of Multiple Subject Credential Program.

595827.title: Foundations in Elementary School Teaching
595827.description: Curriculum of the elementary school, instructional planning, principles of effective teaching, generic instructional strategies, classroom management and legal issues in education. Must be taken for a letter grade if enrolled in the credential program. A "B" or better is required to pass the course.
595827.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to Multiple Subject Credential Program.

595828.title: Language Arts and Reading Instruction in the Public Schools
595828.description: Overview of principles of reading instruction, elements of the language arts program including literature-based reading, content area reading, the role of phonics, emergent literacy and diagnosis of reading problems. Must be taken Credit/No Credit. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit.
595828.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to Multiple Subject Credential Program.

595829.title: Methods and Inquiry for Teaching English Learners
595829.description: Theoretical foundations, legal issues and school programs for the education of English learners. Assessment, materials, methods and strategies for English language development and learning across the curriculum for elementary school English learners. Must be taken Credit/No Credit. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of Credit.
595829.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to Multiple Subject Credential Program.

595830.title: Mathematics Curriculum and Instruction in Elementary School Teaching
595830.description: Instructional materials, learning styles, inquiry, concept learning, problem solving, various instructional strategies applied to teaching of mathematics. Must be taken Credit/No Credit. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit.
595830.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to Multiple Subject Credential Program.

595831.title: Science Curriculum and Instruction in Elementary School Teaching
595831.description: Instructional materials, learning styles, inquiry, concept learning, problem solving, various instructional strategies applied to the teaching of science. Must be taken Credit/No Credit. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit.
595831.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to Multiple Subject Credential Program.

595832.title: Social Studies Curriculum and Instruction in Elementary School Teaching
595832.description: Instructional materials, learning styles, inquiry, concept learning, problem solving, various instructional strategies applied to teaching social studies. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit.
595832.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to Multiple Subject Credential Program.

595833.title: Supervised Fieldwork in Elementary Teacher Education
595833.description: Students serve as teacher participants in an assigned elementary school classroom. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" or better is required to receive a grade of credit. May be repeated for a maximum of 2 units.
595833.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to Multiple Subject Credential Program; EDEL 315 or EDSC 310 , SPED 371 .

595834.title: Student Teaching in the Elementary School
595834.description: Participate in a regular elementary school teaching program for the full school day. Credit/ No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit. May be repeated for a maximum of 15 units.
595834.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to student teaching; EDEL 430 , EDEL 433 , EDEL 438 .

595835.title: Methods and Inquiry for Bilingual Teachers
595835.description: Prepares bilingual teacher candidates for teaching Spanish-speaking students. Program models for bilingual instruction, methods for teaching reading and content areas in bilingual settings, materials and assessment. Conducted in Spanish and English; 20 hours of fieldwork required. (EDEL 446 and EDSC 446 are the same course)

597840.title: Methods and Inquiry for Korean Bilingual Teachers
597840.description: Prepares bilingual teachers to teach Korean-speaking students. Program models for bilingual instruction and methods for teaching Korean language and content areas in bilingual settings. 10 hours of fieldwork in schools is required. (EDSC 446K and EDEL 446K are the same course). Requires Korean fluency and consent of Korean Bilingual Authorization coordinator.

597833.title: Methods and Inquiry for Vietnamese Bilingual Teachers
597833.description: Prepares bilingual teachers to teach Vietnamese-speaking students. Program models for bilingual instruction; methods for teaching Vietnamese language and content areas in bilingual settings. 10 hours of fieldwork in schools is required. Requires consent of Vietnamese Bilingual Authorization coordinator. (EDSC 446V and EDEL 446V are the same course).

595836.title: Visual and Performing Arts Methods: Art, Dance, Drama and Music
595836.description: Instructional materials, learning styles, integration and strategies as they apply to teaching the arts in elementary education. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit.
595836.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to Multiple Subject Credential Program.

595837.title: Community, School, and Classroom Issues
595837.description: Current issues of elementary school teaching, including classroom management, parent-teacher communication, school law and child abuse reporting. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit.
595837.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to Multiple Subject Credential Program; EDEL 315 or HCOM 307 , EDSC 310 and SPED 371 .

595838.title: P.E., Health and Mainstreaming Education
595838.description: Mainstreaming students with special needs, health education and physical education in elementary school settings. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit.
595838.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to Multiple Subject Credential Program.

595839.title: Teaching Performance Assessment Seminar
595839.description: Preparation for completing the California Teaching Performance Assessment (CalTPA) Cycle 2, which is required for a Preliminary Multiple Subject Teaching Credential. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive credit. May be repeated for a maximum of 2 units. Credit/No Credit only. Requires admission to student teaching.
595839.prereqs: Prerequisites: EDEL 430 , EDEL 433 , EDEL 434 , EDEL 435 , EDEL 438 .

595840.title: Teaching Performance Assessment Support: Assessing Learning and Culminating Teaching Experience
595840.description: TPA support within social studies or science for the Multiple Subject Credential program. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit. May be taken for credit for a maximum of two units. (EDEL 453B and SPED 453B are the same course.)
595840.prereqs: Prerequisites: EDEL 430 , EDEL 433 , EDEL 434 , EDEL 435 , EDEL 438 ; admission to student teaching.

595842.title: Independent Study
595842.description: Individual investigation under supervision of a faculty member. Only students of demonstrated capability and maturity will be approved. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
595842.prereqs: Prerequisite: senior, postbaccalaureate or graduate standing.

595843.title: Bilingual Multicultural Curriculum
595843.description: Culture and school curriculum, forces operating on the curriculum, the participants involved in curriculum building, modification of the curriculum to reflect multicultural contexts, and pedagogy and pluralism.

598336.title: New Teacher Induction, Assessment and Support, Year 1
598336.description: Preparation and professional development for new teachers in accordance with the California Standards for the Teaching Profession. (EDSC 502A, EDEL 502A, SPED 502A are the same course.)

595844.title: Pedagogy, Assessment and Support for New Teachers: Semester 1
595844.description: Formative assessment and professional development for new teachers via utilization of state-approved formative assessment system. Inquiry into teaching effectiveness including analyzing teaching and learning context and assessment. Requires participation in the Fullerton Teacher Induction Program. (EDEL 502E, EDSC 502E, SPED 502E are the same course.)

598448.title: Pedagogy, Assessment and Support for New Teachers: Semester 2
598448.description: Formative assessment and professional development for new teachers via utilization of state-approved formative assessment system. Inquiry into teaching effectiveness, including action research, review and reflection on teaching and learning. Requires participation in the Fullerton Teacher Induction Program. (EDEL 502F, EDSC 502F, and SPED 502F are the same course.)

598567.title: Pedagogy, Assessment and Support for New Teachers (Semester 3)
598567.description: Formative assessment and professional development for new teachers. Focus on inquiry into teaching effectiveness, including analysis of inquiry and assessment of teaching and learning. Requires participation in the Fullerton Teacher Induction Program. (EDSC 502G, EDEL 502G, SPED 502G are the same course.)

598279.title: Pedagogy, Assessment and Support for New Teachers (Semester 4)
598279.description: Formative assessment and professional development for new teachers. Focus on inquiry into teaching effectiveness, including analysis of inquiry and assessment of teaching and learning. Requires participation in the Fullerton Teacher Induction Program. (EDSC 502H, EDEL 502H, SPED 502H are the same course.)

595845.title: Survey of Educational Research
595845.description: Descriptive statistics and statistical inferences in educational research. Representative research papers. Principles of research design. Prepare papers using research findings.

595846.title: Level Two Technology Proficiencies for Teachers in TK-8 Schools
595846.description: Theoretical basis and strategies for improving teaching TK-8 students using multimedia and other technologies. Requires teaching credential.

595847.title: Technology and Problem Solving in Schools
595847.description: Software and web-based applications that promote problem-solving in schools. Research and discuss issues, implications of and implementation strategies for using technology to enhance students' problem-solving skills.
595847.prereqs: Prerequisites: Level 2 technology proficiency; teaching credential.

595848.title: Issues in the Instructional Design of Software for use in Schools
595848.description: Issues related to the instructional design of courseware designed specifically for classroom students. Learning principles, learner characteristics, instructional strategies, screen design, response analysis, feedback and interactivity.

595849.title: Multimedia Development and Instruction in the Classroom
595849.description: Application and instruction of computer-based instructional design principles in developing classroom software and multimedia projects. Planning and assessment, design principles and developing tools.

595850.title: Web Design for Instruction in Schools
595850.description: Design, develop and implement web pages and sites for instructional purposes. Issues surrounding using the World Wide Web for instruction. Fieldwork required.

595851.title: Distance Education Issues and Trends in Schools
595851.description: Issues and trends in distance education for teaching and learning in schools. Draws on research in K-12, higher education and corporate domains.

595853.title: Reading/Language Arts in the Early Childhood Curriculum
595853.description: Significant research, curriculum developments and materials, and current instructional strategies for promoting emergent literacy in children.

595854.title: Graduate Studies: Learning Theory for Classroom Use
595854.description: Major theoretical positions in planning and interpreting classroom practices. Educational research findings, implications for curriculum development and teaching practices.

595855.title: Graduate Studies in Elementary Education: Second Languages
595855.description: Significant research, curriculum developments and materials, and criteria for planning and improving second language programs, including those for English as a second language.

595856.title: Graduate Studies in Elementary Education: Integrated Language Arts
595856.description: Significant research, trends and problems in teaching the fundamental skills of communication; curriculum development and materials, and criteria for planning and improving integrated language arts programs.

595857.title: Graduate Studies in Elementary Education: Mathematics
595857.description: Significant research, curricular developments and materials, criteria for planning and improving mathematics programs and instruction.

595858.title: Graduate Studies in Elementary Education: Science
595858.description: Research and materials in science education and criteria for planning and improving science programs and instruction.

595859.title: Graduate Studies in Elementary Education: Social Studies
595859.description: Research developments and materials, criteria for planning and improving social studies programs, and current techniques of teaching.

595860.title: Curriculum Theory and Development
595860.description: School curriculum, including the forces operating on the curriculum and the participants involved in curriculum building. Process of curriculum building.

598340.title: Graduate Studies: Current Issues and Problems
598340.description: Problems and issues in elementary and secondary education, their causes and possible solutions. One or more sections may be offered in any online format.

595861.title: Teaching and Learning in the Early Childhood Classroom
595861.description: Applying significant research in the education of young children. Current instructional strategies and criteria for planning and improving programs in early childhood education.

595862.title: Culture and Education of Latino Students
595862.description: Impact of historical, social, political and economic forces on educational experiences for Latino students in the U.S., in particular, those of Mexican origin. Immigration, migration, language and culture with respect to educational attainment. Requires consent of Bilingual Authorization Coordinator. (EDEL 541 and EDSC 541 are the same course.)

597842.title: Culture and Education of Korean Students
597842.description: Korean culture, Korean-American history, the socioeconomic contexts of Korean immigration, and their contributions to the United States. Korean cultural values and their educational and social implications, bilingual education issues and teaching strategies. Requires Korean fluency and consent of Korean Bilingual Authorization coordinator. (EDSC 541K and EDEL 541K are the same course). Requires Korean fluency.

597845.title: Culture and Education of Vietnamese Students
597845.description: Vietnamese culture, Vietnamese-American history, the socioeconomic contexts of Vietnamese immigration and Vietnamese Americans' contributions to the United States. Vietnamese cultural values and their educational and social implications, bilingual education issues, and teaching strategies. Requires consent of Vietnamese Bilingual Authorization coordinator. (EDSC 541V and EDEL 541V are the same course).

595863.title: Current Issues and Problems in Bilingual-Bicultural Education
595863.description: Problems and issues in the development and implementation of bilingual-bicultural education.

597848.title: Elementary Graduate Seminar: Critical Arts Education with/in Urban Communities
597848.description: Critical arts practices with/in multilingual and multicultural communities. Issues pertinent to just, equitable and inclusive education through the arts. Applications for arts education curriculum integration, instructional strategies and assessment in both school and community settings.
597848.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to credential or master’s program.

595864.title: Social Studies, Science and Math in Early Childhood Education
595864.description: Current curriculum standards and instructional options in social studies, science and mathematics in early childhood education. Content, process skills and literature connections.

595866.title: Family, Community and Professional Partnership
595866.description: Value of educational partnerships between families, teachers and the community. Inquiry and the development of strategies to develop partnerships, address and overcome barriers, and sustain partnerships to enhance the education of children.

598069.title: Foundations of Education for Social Justice
598069.description: Educational practice and research within the framework of social justice. Analyze poverty, inequality and discrimination in society and schooling, while articulating the potential of education as an effective approach to social justice.

595868.title: Technology Professional Development in Schools
595868.description: Planning, implementing and evaluating technology professional development in schools. Writing grants, acting as a change agent and serving as a technology leader in a school. Fieldwork required.
595868.prereqs: Prerequisites: Level 2 technology proficiency; EDEL 522 , EDEL 523 .

595869.title: Culminating Project
595869.description: Preparing, evaluating, developing and presenting curriculum research proposals culminating in a graduate project.

595870.title: Research Project
595870.description: Individual research on an empirical project, with conferences with the instructor, culminating in a project. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Consent of instructor required.

595871.title: Thesis
595871.description: Individual research with conferences with the instructor, culminating in a thesis. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Requires consent of instructor.

595872.title: Independent Graduate Research
595872.description: Independent inquiry. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Requires one year of teaching experience.

595571.title: Digital Logic and Computer Structures
595571.description: Binary number system and arithmetic, computer codes, Boolean algebra, logic gates, K-map minimization, sequential circuits, memory devices, state diagram and table, computer architecture, memory, Arithmetic Logic Unit and control unit. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours laboratory)

595769.title: Electric Circuits
595769.description: Units; Ohm's and Kirchhoff's laws; mesh and nodal analysis, superposition; Thevenin and Norton theorems; RL and RC transients; phasors and steady state sinusoidal analysis; response as a function of frequency; current, voltage and power relationships; polyphase circuits.
595769.prereqs: Prerequisites: PHYS 226 , MATH 250A . Corequisite: CPSC 120 or EGME 205 .

595770.title: Electric Circuits Laboratory
595770.description: Simple resistive RL and RC circuits, electrical measurement techniques, verification of basic circuit laws through hard-wired breadboarding and CAD circuit simulation. (3 hours laboratory)

595771.title: Solving Engineering Problems Using MATLAB
595771.description: Formulating, solving, verifying and reporting engineering problems such as control, signal processing and communication systems and engineering, math and physics problems such as engineering/scientific computations and operations research using the MATLAB/SIMULINK program. (3 hours laboratory)

595772.title: Computer Logic and Architecture
595772.description: Logic design and organization of the major components of a computer, analysis and synthesis of combinational and sequential logics, analysis of the arithmetic, memory control and I/O units, concepts in computer control.

595773.title: Computer Logic and Architecture Lab
595773.description: Computer-Aided Design (CAD) of digital logic circuits, including decoders, multiplexes, adders and subtracters, counters, shift registers and Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) of a computer. After verifying the CAD design through simulation, the circuits are built on a protoboard. (3 hours laboratory)

598872.title: Microcontrollers
598872.description: Microcontrollers, microcontroller programming model and instruction set, assembler directives, writing and debugging microcontroller assembly language routines, microcontroller memory system, microcontroller communication systems. (1 hour lecture, 4 hours laboratory)

598873.title: Designing with VHDL
598873.description: Introduction to various modeling methods, timings, events, propagation delays and concurrency, the language constructs, data representations and formats, and physical attributes. (1 hour lecture, 2 hours laboratory)
598873.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 120 or CPSC 121 ; EGEC 180 or EGEC 245 .

595774.title: Electronics
595774.description: Characteristics and elementary applications of semiconductor diodes, field-effect transistors and bipolar-junction transistors and operational amplifiers; mid-frequency small-signal analysis and design of transistors.

595775.title: Electronics Laboratory
595775.description: Semiconductor diodes, transistors and elementary electronic circuits through hard-wired breadboarding, CAD electronic simulation and analysis. (3 hours laboratory)

598874.title: Engineering Analysis
598874.description: Fundamentals and engineering applications of Fourier transforms, Laplace transforms, complex analysis, vector analysis; engineering applications. (EGCE 308, EGEC 308, EGGN 308 and EGME 308 are the same course.)

595776.title: Network Analysis
595776.description: Performance of RLC circuits; complex frequency and the s-plane; frequency response and resonance; network topology; two-port network characterization; classical filter theory.
595776.prereqs: Prerequisites: EGEC 203 , EGGN 308 . Pre- or corequisite: EGEC 203L .

595777.title: Electronic Circuits
595777.description: Continuation of EGEC 303; analyzing and designing multistage and feedback amplifiers; frequency characteristics of amplifiers, frequency characteristics and stability of feedback amplifiers, differential amplifiers, design of IC circuit biasing, operational amplifiers and their applications.

595778.title: Electronic Circuits Lab
595778.description: Computer-Aided Design (CAD) of electronic circuits, including multi-stage feedback amplifiers; linear and integrated circuits; ADC and DAC and wireless design projects. After verifying the CAD design through simulation, the circuits are built on a protoboard. (3 hours laboratory)
595778.prereqs: Prerequisite: EGEC 303L . Pre- or corequisite: EGEC 310 .

595779.title: Field Theory and Transmission Lines
595779.description: Introduction to waves and phasors; analysis and design of transmission lines; electrostatics and magnetostatics; boundary value problems; Maxwell equations.

595780.title: Introduction to Electromechanics
595780.description: Electromagnetic fields and circuits; transformers, saturation effects. Simple electro-mechanical systems. Circuit models, terminal characteristics and applications of DC and AC machines.

595781.title: Power Laboratory
595781.description: Experiments in electromagnetic fields and circuits, transformers and electromechanical systems such as AC and DC machines (3 hours laboratory)
595781.prereqs: Prerequisite EGEC 303L . Pre- or corequisite: EGEC 313 .

595782.title: Engineering Probability and Statistics
595782.description: Set theory: axiomatic foundation of probability; random variables; probability distribution and density functions; joint, conditional and marginal distributions; expected values; distribution of functions of random variables; central limit theorem; estimation.

595572.title: Modeling and Simulation of Signals and Systems
595572.description: Modeling and simulation of physical systems, mathematical description of systems, transfer functions, poles and zeros, frequency response, continuous and discrete-time convolution, continuous and discrete Fourier transforms, Laplace and Z transforms, Fast Fourier Transforms, simulation using Matlab.

595573.title: Computer Design and Organization
595573.description: Computer system, central processing unit (CPU) organization and design, instruction set and addressing modes, microprogrammed control unit design, cache memory, internal memory, virtual memory, input/output interfacing, parallel processors, superscalar processors (2 hours lecture, 4 hours laboratory).
595573.prereqs: Prerequisite: EGEC 281 , EGEC 303 both with a “C-” (1.7) or better.

598875.title: Engineering Economics and Professionalism
598875.description: Development, evaluation and presentation of design alternatives for engineering systems and projects using principles of engineering economy and cost benefit analysis. Engineering profession, professional ethics and related topics. (Not available for use on graduate study plans.) (EGEC 401, EGCE 401, and EGME 401 are the same course.)
598875.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 150A ; Engineering or Computer Science major; junior or senior standing.

595783.title: Introduction to Microprocessors and Microcomputers
595783.description: Hardware and software concepts in microprocessors, processor family chips, system architecture, CPU, input/output devices, interrupts and DMA, memory (ROM, RAM), electrical and timing characteristics, assembly language programming.
595783.prereqs: Prerequisite: EGEC 245L , EGEC 280 ; or graduate standing.

595784.title: Design Applications with Microcontroller and FPGA
595784.description: Digital system application design using microcontrollers, FPGAs and CPLDs including programming hardware interfacing, A/D conversion, CLB, logic arrays, interconnections, testing and simulations.
595784.prereqs: Prerequisites: EGEC 245 , EGEC 245L , EGEC 280 ; or graduate standing.

595785.title: Introduction to Linear Systems
595785.description: Development of time and frequency domain models for physical systems. Linearization process and representation with block diagrams and signal flow graphs; discrete-time systems and digital signals including use of Z-transforms; stability theory of continuous and discrete time systems.

595786.title: Electro-Optical Systems
595786.description: Introduction to electro-optics; optical radiation characteristics and sources; geometrical and physical optics; lasers and electro-optical modulation; quantum and thermal optical radiation detectors; detector performance analysis; electro-optical systems modeling and analysis; application examples.

595787.title: Feedback Control Systems
595787.description: Feedback control system characteristics; stability in the frequency and time domains; analysis and design of continuous-time systems using root-locus, Bode and Nyquist plots, Nichols chart and applications.

595788.title: Introduction to Digital Filtering
595788.description: Discrete-time signals and systems; solution of difference equations; Fourier transform for a sequence; Z-transform; discrete Fourier transform; FIR and IIR realizations; design of digital filters.

595789.title: Microwave Engineering
595789.description: Essential fundamentals for radio frequency, wireless and microwave engineering. Wave propagation in cables, wave-guides and free space; impedance matching, standing wave ratios, impedance and scattering parameters.

598811.title: Implementation of Probabilistic Processes on Embedded Systems
598811.description: Continuous random variables, probability distributions and density functions, the law of large numbers, and the central limit theorem, sample mean and variance, estimating distributions, correlation, regression, and hypothesis testing implemented on Embedded Systems. (2 hrs lecture, 2 hrs laboratory)

595574.title: Advanced Electronics for Computer Engineers
595574.description: High-speed CMOS, biCMOS, CPLDs, FPGAs, A/D, D/A, transducers and optics; integration of these devices into complete systems. (2 hours lecture, 4 hours laboratory)
595574.prereqs: Prerequisite: EGEC 281 , EGEC 303 both with a “C-” (1.7) or better.

595790.title: Electronic Circuits
595790.description: Power amplifiers and tuned amplifiers; RF amplifiers; modulation and detection circuits; oscillators; and operational amplifier applications.

595791.title: Electronic Communication Systems
595791.description: Principles of amplitude, angular and pulse modulation, representative communication systems, the effects of noise on system performance.

595792.title: Digital Electronics
595792.description: RC circuits, attenuators, compensation and scope probe. Logic circuits: DTL, TTL, STTL, LSTTL and ECL. Fanout, noise-immunity, switching speed, power consumption, input-output characteristics. Design and analysis of MOS logic circuits; PMOS, NMOS and CMOS gates, flip-flops, shift registers and memory circuits.
595792.prereqs: Prerequisites: EGEC 245 , EGEC 303 ; or graduate standing.

597892.title: Advanced Digital Design using Verilog HDL
597892.description: Fundamentals of Verilog programming; behavioral modeling using Verilog; structural modeling using Verilog; RTL design using Verilog; Shannon's decomposition; FPGA architecture; Digital design, synthesis and implementation using FPGA.

597893.title: Introduction to Cyber-Physical Systems Security
597893.description: Hardware trojan detection; physical and invasive attacks; side-channel attacks; intellectual property piracy; circuit obfuscation; passive and active metering; physical unclonable functions; cryptographic algorithms; introduction to cyber-physical systems and IoT security; security threats and vulnerabilities in cyber-physical systems.
597893.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 223P , CPSC 240 ; or EGEC 281 ; or graduate standing.

595793.title: Digital Systems Design with FPGA
595793.description: Basic concepts and characteristics of digital systems, traditional logic design, LSI/VLSI logic design with VHDL, combinational and sequential logic, and their applications; timing and control, race conditions and noise, microcomputers, computer-aided programming, development systems, microcomputer system hardware design, input/output devices.

595575.title: Embedded Processor Interfacing
595575.description: Techniques of interfacing based on speed, timings, synchronization, interrupts, protocols, noise, and race conditions. Interfacing specifications of the processor data, address and control buses. (2 hours lecture, 4 hours laboratory)
595575.prereqs: Prerequisites: EGEC 280 , EGEC 381 , EGEC 441 , EGEC 440 , EGEC 451 , MATH 170A .

598812.title: Real-Time Operating Systems for Embedded Systems
598812.description: Fundamentals of Real-Time Operating Systems (RTOS) for embedded systems, including thread communication and synchronization, real-time scheduling, memory and process management, file systems and management, and commercially-available RTOS. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours laboratory)
598812.prereqs: Prerequisites: CPSC 131 , EGEC 280 ; or graduate standing.

595794.title: Microelectronics and Nano Devices
595794.description: Quantum mechanical principles, crystal structure, energy brand, carrier transport, carrier generation and recombination, p-n junction, bipolar transistor, MOSFET, MEFET and related devices, basic microwave and optoelectronic technology, crystal growth and fabrication, introduction to nano structure, nano devices and technology.
595794.prereqs: Prerequisites: EGEC 303 , EGEC 311 ; or graduate standing.

595576.title: Introduction to Logic Design in Nanotechnology
595576.description: Promising novel Nanoelectronic technologies and logic primitives for such technologies, applicable basic logic design technique, design models for spatial dimensions, applicable word-level data structures, multilevel circuit design, testability and observability, tolerance and reliable computing.
595576.prereqs: Prerequisite: EGEC 180 or EGEC 245 all with a “C-” (1.7) or better; or Computer Engineering graduate standing.

595795.title: Introduction to Cellular Mobile Communications Systems
595795.description: Introduction to wireless mobile telecommunications, description and analysis of cellular radio systems, co-channel interference reduction, channel capacity and digital cellular systems.

598876.title: Low Power Digital IC Design
598876.description: Importance of low power design; analysis of power dissipation in digital integrated circuits; circuit-level low-power techniques, logic-level low power techniques and system-level low power techniques.
598876.prereqs: Prerequisites: EGEC 180 or EGEC 245 ; EGEC 303 ; all with a “C-” (1.7) or better.

595577.title: Current Topics in Computer Engineering
595577.description: Topics of contemporary interest from the perspective of current research and development in computer engineering. Lectures by guest professionals.
595577.prereqs: Prerequisites: Engineering or Computer Science major; junior or senior standing.

595151.title: Ceramics
595151.description: Planning, development and evaluation of individual projects in ceramics, glass blowing and glass casting. May be taken for credit for a maximum of twelve units in each area but no more than three units in a single semester without permission of instructors. Requires classified standing. (6 hours activity)

595152.title: Glass Blowing
595152.description: Planning, developing and evaluating of individual projects in glass blowing. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 12 units, but no more than three units in a single semester without permission of instructors. Requires  classified standing. (9 hours laboratory)

595153.title: Glass Casting
595153.description: Planning, developing and evaluating individual projects in glass casting. May be repeated for a maximum of 12 units, but no more than three units in a single semester without permission of instructors. Requires classified standing. (9 hours laboratory)

595154.title: Jewelry
595154.description: Planning, development and evaluation of individual projects listed below. May be taken for credit for a maximum of twelve units in each area, but no more than three units in a single semester. Requires classified standing. (6 hours activity)

598203.title: Graduate Metals
598203.description: Graduate-level theories, processes and designing metal forms using varied techniques in smithing. Research in contemporary and historical metalsmithing and 3-D metal forms. Planning, developing and evaluating individual projects. May be repeated for a maximum of 12 units in each area, but no more than three units in a single semester. Requires classified standing. (6 hours activity)

595156.title: Graduate Problems in Sculpture
595156.description: Planning, developing and evaluating individual projects in sculpture. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 12 units in each area, but no more than 3 units in a single semester without permission of instructors. Requires classified standing. (6 hours activity).

595157.title: Graduate Problems in Sculpture
595157.description: Planning, developing and evaluating individual projects in sculpture. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 12 units in each area, but no more than 3 units in a single semester without permission of instructors. Requires classified standing. (6 hours activity).

595158.title: Graduate Seminar: Painting and Image Making
595158.description: Planning, development and evaluation of individual projects listed below. Maximum of 12 units in each area, but no more than three units in a single semester without permission of instructors.

595159.title: Graduate Studies: The Figure
595159.description: Planning, development and evaluation of individual projects listed below. Maximum of 12 units in each area, but no more than three units in a single semester without permission of instructors. (6 hours activity)

595160.title: Special Topics in Art
595160.description: Planning, development and evaluation of individual projects listed below. Maximum of 12 units in each area, but no more than three units in a single semester without permission of instructors.

595161.title: Printmaking
595161.description: Planning, developing and evaluating individual projects. May be repeated for a maximum of 12 units, but no more than three units in a single semester without permission of instructors.

595162.title: Graduate Problems in Creative Photography
595162.description: Planning, developing and evaluating individual projects in photography. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 12 units in each area, but no more than 3 units in a single semester without permission of instructors. Requires consent of instructor. (6 hours activity)

595163.title: Graduate Problems in Creative Photography
595163.description: Planning, developing and evaluating individual projects in photography. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 12 units in each area, but no more than 3 units in a single semester without permission of instructors. Requires consent of instructor. (6 hours activity)

595164.title: Graduate Problems: The Digital Studio
595164.description: Digital studio as a "site" for the experimentation in image making and visual media expression. Develop own projects creating and manipulating images and media through technology and computer software. May be repeated once for credit. (6 hours activity)

595165.title: Seminar on the Content and Method of Art History
595165.description: Methods of research, analysis and theories of art historical scholarship. May be repeated once for credit. ART 511 and ART 512 are both required to meet the graduate writing requirement.

595166.title: Seminar on Selected Topics in Art History
595166.description: Analysis and evaluation of specific works and their historical significance, including cultural, social and economic circumstances. May be repeated once for credit. ART 511 and ART 512 are both required to meet the graduate writing requirement. Requires appropriate upper-division Art course approved by instructor.

595167.title: Graduate Seminar in Creative Photography
595167.description: Expands and deepens  knowledge of photographic and media criticism and theory. Explores advanced theoretical topics and applies tools of criticism to better understand the creative process and artwork. May be repeated once for credit.

595168.title: Graduate Problems in Artists’ Books
595168.description: Investigation and application of principles of the book form to visual art and design, illustration, photography and printmaking media. Development of original works of art, which demonstrate competency in design, construction and fabrication of graduate quality visual books. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 12 units. (6 hours activity)

595169.title: Graduate Studies in Digital Narrative Illustration
595169.description: Narrative illustration using advanced digital painting programs and techniques. Theories of illustration and story illustration, to include concepts, composition, and current trends in digital media. May be repeated once for credit. Requires classified standing in illustration, drawing and painting.

595170.title: Graduate Studio Expanded: Other Genre
595170.description: All aspects of new genre work, including conceptual, historic and theoretical approaches. Studio disciplines that will be investigated are installation, performance art, video and public art. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 units.

595171.title: Graduate Video Art and the Moving Image
595171.description: Contemporary and historic practices in video and the role time plays in moving image arts. Production and post-production fundamentals, including camera work, editing, audio recording, storytelling and relationships between images and sound. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 units. (6 hours activity)

598518.title: Graphic and Interactive Design: Theory and Practice
598518.description: Forming philosophy, methodology and processes for higher education within graphic design field. Develop written and visual projects for basic, intermediate, and advance levels of graphic design undergraduate education. Taken with the chair or member of the graduate student's committee.
598518.prereqs: Prerequisite: MFA graphic design graduate standing.

595172.title: Project
595172.description: Develop and present a one-person project. Must be exhibited in a department graduate gallery. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires written consent of instructor and recommendation of the student's graduate committee.

595173.title: Thesis
595173.description: May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. Requires written consent of instructor and recommendation of the student's graduate committee.

595174.title: Independent Graduate Research
595174.description: Open to graduate students in art with consent of department chair and written consent of instructor. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units.

595175.title: Teaching Art in the K-12 Schools
595175.description: Objectives, methods and practices for teaching art in K-12 schools with an emphasis on secondary levels. Required before student teaching of majors in art for the Single Subject Teaching Credential.
595175.prereqs: Prerequisite: Teacher Education Credential Program in Art student.

598905.title: Externship in Single Subject Teaching
598905.description: Eight-week practicum (150 hours) fieldwork in single subject classrooms. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit. Students sign up for the appropriate departmental offering. Requires admission to the Single Subject Credential Program. May be repeated once for credit. (EDSC 449E, ARTE 449E, KNES 449E, MAED 449E, MUSE 449E, and THTR 449E are the same course.)
598905.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to Single Subject Credential Program.

598906.title: Second Semester Student Teaching
598906.description: A 450-hour practicum in a single subject in public schools. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit. Departmental course offerings are: ARTE 449I, EDSC 449I, KNES 449I, MAED 449I, MUSE 449I, THTR 449I.

595178.title: Seminar in K-12 Teaching
595178.description: Seminar in teaching a single subject in K-12 schools. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit.

595179.title: Introduction to Ethnic Studies
595179.description: Perspectives through which people of color have come to see themselves in terms of their own heroes, cultures and contributions to the societies in which they live and the world in general. (AFAM 101, ASAM 101, and CHIC 101 are the same course)

595180.title: Survey of American History with Emphasis on Ethnic Minorities
595180.description: Survey of American history from prehistoric times (before 1492) to the present with special emphasis on the role of race and ethnicity. (HIST 190, AFAM 190, ASAM 190 and CHIC 190 are the same course.)

595181.title: The History of Asian Pacific Americans
595181.description: Origins and evolution of Asian American communities and cultures, with an emphasis upon the southern California region, through selected books, oral histories, films, outside speakers and excursions. (HIST 201 and ASAM 201 are the same course.)

598792.title: Ideas, Imagination and Intersections in Ethnic Studies/Asian American Studies
598792.description: Understand contemporary Ethnic Studies/Asian American Studies by examining their roots and agency to imagine a society beyond our nation's historical legacies. Students consider their life experiences through core concepts, research and creative works, and intersectional topics and identities in ES/ASAM.

595182.title: Vietnamese Communities in the U.S.
595182.description: Historical and cultural overview of Vietnamese communities in the U.S., especially Orange County. The vital role of voluntary agencies, mutual assistance associations, and religious centers. Examines Vietnamese business, entertainment, family, education and hobbies.

595183.title: Civic Engagement Through Asian American and Pacific Islander Studies
595183.description: Service-learning course introducing purpose of AAPI Studies, opportunities to develop cultural competency while serving AAPI communities and structured critical reflection for determining life purpose. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 units.

598562.title: Introduction to Multi-Ethnic Literatures of the U.S.
598562.description: Introducing multi-ethnic literatures of the U. S., the course considers texts within their cultural, historical, and socio-political contexts. Relates multi-ethnic literature to the creative and performing arts. Themes covered may include diaspora, migration, memory, history, citizenship, and/or ethnic identities. (CHIC 250, AFAM 250, ASAM 250 and ENGL 250 are the same course.)

595184.title: Introduction to Asian Pacific American Studies
595184.description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the experiences of several Asian American groups. Addresses questions of cultural assimilation and cultural persistence, family and gender roles, and literary and popular culture representations.

598793.title: Community, Liberation and Action in Ethnic Studies/Asian American Studies
598793.description: Examine Asian American Studies' historical legacies, community formation and social movements to address issues impacting APIDA communities, e.g., justice, identity, oppression. Apply knowledge of activism, creativity and liberation to design, implement and evaluate transformative action projects.

595185.title: Research and Writing in Ethnic Studies
595185.description: Introduction to research and writing in ethnic studies. Issues of research in ethnic studies (e.g., quantitative v. qualitative analysis, reliability/validity) and specific methods of research (e.g., archives, interviews, oral history). Extensive writing. A "C" (2.0) or better is required to satisfy the upper-division writing requirement. (ASAM 307, AFAM 307 and CHIC 307 are the same course.)

595186.title: Asian American Women
595186.description: Interdisciplinary examination of Asian and Pacific Islander American women's experience. Compares and contrasts the experience of women from various parts of Asia and explores the social, cultural and political issues they face in the U.S. and abroad.
595186.prereqs: Prerequisite: sophomore, junior or senior standing.

598311.title: Asian Pacific American Cultural Studies
598311.description: Asian American life as portrayed through novels, short stories, plays, poetry, film, music, painting, dance and other expressive forms. Examines historical and contemporary works by a variety of Asian and Pacific Americans.

595188.title: Asian American Film and Video
595188.description: Introduction to major themes in Asian American film and video history and criticism. Asian American aesthetics, history and politics will be examined in areas of film and video direction, production, writing and acting.

595189.title: Asian American Literature
595189.description: Introduces early literary expressions of the Asian American experience. Readings include poetry, short stories, novels and autobiographies. Fundamental understanding of Asian American literary history and awareness of the cultural diversity in America. (ASAM 327 and ENGL 327 are the same course.)

595191.title: Asian Pacific American Families
595191.description: Asian Pacific American families have ranged from the seemingly solitary "bachelor" to the extended "clan." Explores these, and many other ways of being a "family," as it has been a basic part of Asian Pacific American history and culture.

595192.title: Asian Pacific American Identities
595192.description: Interdisciplinary explorations of the ways in which those of Pacific Islander, Southeast, South and East Asian descent have met the challenge of being American at the personal level. Social construction of racial/ethnic identities, cultural conflict, self-determination and personal growth.

595193.title: Asian American Psychology
595193.description: Major issues in the Asian American community from a psychosocial perspective, including ethnic identity development, generational conflicts, the "model minority" myth, interracial relationships, attitudes toward mental health services and alternative healing/therapeutic approaches. (ASAM 346 and PSYC 346 are the same course.)

595194.title: Multiple Heritage Asian American and Pacific Islanders
595194.description: Overview of the mixed heritage Asian American population in the U.S. Surveys the historical avenues that led to the United States and to inter-ethnic alliances. The many challenges this multi-ethnic population faces.

595195.title: Filipina/o American Experiences
595195.description: Introduction to Filipina/o American Studies, covering point of origin, immigration, legal barriers, economic struggles, civil rights and other current issues up to 1965.

598895.title: Contemporary Issues in Filipino America
598895.description: Social justice and community issues in Filipina/o American communities in the U.S. after 2000. Issues may include institutional racism, environmental justice, gendered labor, urban redevelopment and cultural representations.

595196.title: South Asian American Experiences
595196.description: Interdisciplinary course exploring the experiences of South Asian Americans originally from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh or Sri Lanka. Questions regarding influence of American culture on South Asian American identity, intergenerational concerns and cultural continuity, among others.

597776.title: Vietnamese American Experiences
597776.description: Cultural, economic, political, social and transnational experiences of Vietnamese Americans. Participation through oral history, field trips to Orange County's Little Saigon and projects involving the Vietnamese community.

595197.title: Korean American Experiences
595197.description: Historical events and contemporary issues, such as Korean American immigration, identity, inter-ethnic relations, gender issues, and entrepreneurship within the context of social, political and economic conditions of Korea and the United States.

595199.title: World War II Japanese American Evacuation
595199.description: World War II eviction and detention of people of Japanese ancestry in the United States, pivoting on the significance of this experience in the areas of civil and human rights, cross-cultural relations and international affairs. Not available for graduate degree credit. (HIST 382 and ASAM 382 are the same course.)
595199.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 4A; HIST 170B, HIST 180 or HIST 190.

597771.title: The Vietnam Wars
597771.description: Origins, conduct, consequences and legacies of the Vietnamese wars. (POSC 458 and ASAM 458 are the same course).
597771.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

598035.title: The Vietnam War from the Vietnamese Perspective
598035.description: The Vietnam War from various Vietnamese perspectives: historical, cultural and psychological; North vs. South; personal, regional, national and global; men and women; elite class and ordinary people. (HIST 464E and ASAM 464E are the same course)
598035.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A; or graduate standing.

598032.title: American Immigration History
598032.description: History of American immigration in a global context. Changes and continuities in the political, cultural, and economic contexts that generated the movement of diverse peoples and structured their experiences of integration within the U.S. (HIST 477C, AFAM 477C, ASAM 477C and CHIC 477C are the same course.)
598032.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

595201.title: Internship in Asian American Studies
595201.description: One hundred twenty (120) hours practical experience in some organization serving the Asian Pacific American community. Regular meetings with faculty advisor. May be repeated once for credit. Requires approval of supervising instructor(s).

595202.title: Student-to-Student Tutorials
595202.description: Consult "Student-to-Student Tutorials" in this catalog for a more complete course description. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 3 units. Requires approval of supervising instructor(s).

595203.title: Independent Study
