598373.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A, POSC 100 , HONR 201B or HIST 110B .

596146.title: The American Civil War
596146.description: History of the American Civil War. Both contemporary and current analyses of the war will be amplified by the use of films and slides.
596146.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B .

596147.title: World War I
596147.description: Explores military, cultural, social, economic, ecological, and political aspects of the war using film, literature and other sources.

596148.title: Teaching Premodern History
596148.description: For students intending to teach world history. Introduction to and critical analysis of the history and pedagogy of world history. The differential development of human societies across time and across the globe.

598117.title: Concepts in World History
598117.description: Designed primarily for students intending to teach world history. Introduction to various conceptual approaches to world history and the major themes of modern world history, including industrialization, imperialism, nationalism and globalization.

598378.title: Oral History - United States
598378.description: Utilize tape recorded interviews to document significant events in 20th-century history. Training in interviewing techniques, specific background research and equipment use, after which students conduct a number of tape-recorded interviews.
598378.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

598374.title: Introduction to Public History
598374.description: Applying history to activities outside of teaching and academic research. Archival work, historic preservation, exhibit interpretation, and historical research and writing in business, government and individual consulting.
598374.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A; or graduate standing.

598445.title: Practicum in Public History
598445.description: Hands-on experience in the field of public history. Working as a project team, students will contribute to a public history project in collaboration with a museum, historic site, agency, or organization in Southern California. Field work may be required. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
598445.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A; or graduate standing.

598473.title: Visual History
598473.description: Images are significant sources informing historians' understanding of the past. This course examines the ways historians use visual material such as photographs, paintings, public monuments, exhibitions, and film as sources for historical interpretation and public history practice.
598473.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3A, 3U, or 4A; or graduate standing.

597942.title: History and Editing
597942.description: Techniques of editing, book and photo layout and indexing. Focuses on oral history documents, but includes other historical and technical editing. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
597942.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 4A or HIST 110A ; or graduate standing.

596149.title: The Rise of the Atlantic World
596149.description: Main themes of the history of the Atlantic Basin, 1450-1700, including the discovery and conquest of the New World, Africans' contributions to the creation of the Atlantic world and the origins of the "plantation complex."

596150.title: Genocide and Ethnic Cleansing
596150.description: History of genocide and ethnic cleansing in a global context. Weekly readings and seminar discussions highlight questions of facial violence, victimhood, modernization, nation building, gender, class, and the politics of memory and denial.

596151.title: History of the Christian Church to the Reformation (1517)
596151.description: Christian Church from its origins in the apostolic preaching through the late Middle Ages and the beginning (1517) of the Reformation in both the East and West. (HIST 412A and RLST 412A are the same course.)
596151.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U, 4A, HIST 110A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596152.title: History of the Christian Church from the Reformation to the Present
596152.description: Western church as an institution from the Reformation (1517) to the present. Orthodoxy, Catholicism and Protestantism in historical perspective. (HIST 412B and RLST 412B are the same course.)
596152.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U, 4A, HIST 110A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596153.title: History of the Jews
596153.description: The Jewish people from the biblical period to the present. The literature of each period, as well as the relationships which exist between the Jewish communities and the societies in which they exist. (HIST 412C and RLST 412C are the same course.)
596153.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U, 4A, HIST 110A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

597760.title: The Ancient Near East
597760.description: Introduction to the history of the Ancient Near East, from the first cities and states (c. 3500-3000 B.C.E.) to the death of Alexander the Great (323 B.C.E.), focusing on the Assyrian and Persian Empires.
597760.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3A or 3B or HIST 110A or graduate standing.

596154.title: Early Greece: From Troy to Thermopylae
596154.description: Introduction to the history of early Greece (c.1400-479 BCE). Social, cultural, political and economic history, critically analyzed on the basis of primary sources; focusing on historical context of beginnings of ancient Greek poetry, philosophy, historiography and political organization.

598754.title: The Classical Greek World, 479-323 BCE
598754.description: The political, social, cultural, gender, religious and economic framework of the Classical Greek world (479-323 BCE) through critical analysis of primary sources.

598762.title: War and Society in Ancient Greece
598762.description: The dynamic relationship between the changing ways in which Archaic (800-500 BCE) and Classical (500-300 BCE) Greek societies were structured, and the ways in which the Greeks organized themselves for and conducted warfare.

596155.title: Roman Republic
596155.description: Roman social and political institutions under the republic.
596155.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 4A or HIST 110A; or graduate standing.

596156.title: Roman Empire
596156.description: Roman imperial institutions and culture with attention to the rise of Christianity. (HIST 417B and RLST 417B are the same course.)
596156.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 4A or HIST 110A; or graduate standing.

596157.title: The Byzantine Empire
596157.description: East Roman Empire from Constantine to the Ottoman conquest of 1453. Institutional aspects of Byzantine society: church, state, the economy, law and culture.
596157.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B or 3U or HIST 110A or 4A or HIST 110B or graduate standing.

596158.title: Medieval History, 300-1350
596158.description: Medieval civilizations - East European, West European and Islamic - from the decline of the Roman Empire to the beginning of the Hundred Year's War, with emphasis on cultural, intellectual and social history.
596158.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U or HIST 110A; or graduate standing.

596159.title: Ancient and Medieval Britain
596159.description: Britain from 5 B.C. to 1485. Constitutional, institutional and cultural aspects of Roman, Celtic, Anglo-Saxon, Norman and Plantagenet Britain.
596159.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U or HIST 110A; or graduate standing.

596160.title: The Renaissance
596160.description: Europe in the 14th and 15th centuries: development of humanism and capitalism in Italy and their impact on European culture; rise of Renaissance monarchies; the Renaissance papacy; Christian humanism; and Renaissance science and mysticism.
596160.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3A or 3B or HIST 110A or graduate standing.

596165.title: From the Defeat of Fascism to the Fall of Communism: Europe since 1945
596165.description: Survey of the cultural, political and economic history of Europe since 1945.

596166.title: Germany to Fall of the Nazis: Nation, Race, Sex and Empire
596166.description: German national unification, the rise of racial antisemitism, imperialism in Africa, World War I, fascism and antifascism, the sexual and cultural innovations of the Weimar Republic, and Nazi genocide during World War II. Focus on race, gender and empire.
596166.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596167.title: Tudor Stuart England
596167.description: England from the accession of Henry VII to the Glorious Revolution. Political, institutional, ecclesiastical and cultural aspects of the period of the Tudors and Stuarts.
596167.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B or 3U or 4A or graduate standing.

596168.title: History of Modern England and Great Britain
596168.description: Modern British history (Glorious Revolution to present). Achievement of constitutional monarchy, transition from agrarian to industrial society, establishment of political democracy and the rise and fall of socialism.
596168.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B or 3U or 4A or graduate standing.

596169.title: The Holocaust
596169.description: The history and origins, implementation and results of the European-wide programs of persecution and genocide carried out by Nazi Germany and their collaborators against the Jews during the period 1933-1945. (HIST 435A and RLST 435A are the same course.)
596169.prereqs: Prerequisite: HIST 110B or any modern European upper-division course.

596170.title: Fascism, 1918 - 1945
596170.description: Global phenomenon of fascism from its origins at the end of the 19th century to its "defeat" at the end of World War II, examining major and minor movements from a social, cultural, and political point of view.
596170.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

598220.title: The Spanish Civil War
598220.description: Causes of the Spanish Civil War and its consequences for Spaniards, Europeans, and the world at large. The ideological, social, political and international conflicts underpinning the Spanish Civil War.
598220.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596171.title: Cities in European Civilization, 1000-1915
596171.description: Urban history of Western Europe from the revival of urban life in the High Middle Ages through WWI, with a focus on urban social and cultural evolution.
596171.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3A, 3B, 4A or HIST 110A ; or graduate standing.

596172.title: Race, Ethnicity and Gender in Latin America: A History
596172.description: Issues of race, ethnicity and gender in Latin America from the 15th century to the present. Emphasizes Latin America's two largest countries, Brazil and Mexico.

596173.title: Cuban History Through Film
596173.description: History of Cuba through film. The camera as a window into Cuban society. Major themes, such as slavery, gender, Cuban-U.S. relations and the socialist revolution.

596174.title: Colonial Period of Latin America
596174.description: Latin America from its pre-Columbian origins to the era of the Wars of Independence. Ethnic, social, and cultural factors that characterized the colonial period.
596174.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596175.title: 19th-Century Latin America: Era of Nation Building
596175.description: Latin America during the 19th century (1810-1910) with emphasis on cultural and socio-political factors that were important in the creation of Latin American nations. Special focus on development of the Rio de la Plata, the Andean nations and Mexico.
596175.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596176.title: Latin America Since 1945
596176.description: Focuses on political, economic, cultural and social patterns in key Latin American nations from 1945 to the present. Not available for graduate degree credit.
596176.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596177.title: 20th-Century Brazil
596177.description: Social, economic, cultural and political history of Brazil, with particular emphasis on the period since World War II.
596177.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596178.title: History of Mexico pre-Columbian (pre 1521) through 1821
596178.description: History of Mexico from prior to the Spanish conquest of 1521 through the wars for Independence ending in 1821.
596178.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596179.title: History of Mexico from Independence (1821) to Modern Day
596179.description: Pivotal moments in modern Mexican history, including post-colonial nation building, Mexican-American War, Mexican Revolution of 1910, Chiapas Rebellion of the mid-1990s and 2000 elections.
596179.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596180.title: West Africa and the African Diaspora
596180.description: West African relationships with the African diaspora in the Americas. Issues of the origins of political conflict, economic exploitation, racism, gender, revolts and emancipation, Pan-Africanism and rights of African descendants since the 15th century.

596181.title: Southern Africa in the 20th Century
596181.description: Twentieth-century developments in the Union (Republic) of South Africa, Central Africa (the Rhodesias and Nyasaland) and Portuguese colonies; the political, economic and social ramifications of race relations.

596182.title: African History Since 1935
596182.description: Issues of European imperialism, settler cultures, racism and African consciousness, ethnic conflict, gender, nationalist and guerrilla liberation movements, Pan-Africanism, international relations and society development policies in Africa since 1935.

596183.title: The Chinese Diaspora
596183.description: History of Chinese migration from the 16th century to the present, focusing on the domestic and international situations that shaped the conditions for Chinese migration to different parts of the world.

596184.title: History of Ancient China
596184.description: Chinese history from ancient times to the middle of the 17th century; society, thought, economy and political institutions.
596184.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A, 3B, 3U or HIST 110A ; or graduate standing.

596187.title: History of Japan
596187.description: Social, political, and economic history of Japan until 1868, stressing the Tokugawa era.
596187.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U or HIST 110A; or graduate standing.

596188.title: History of Japan
596188.description: Rise of the modern Japanese state, Japanese imperialism and the postwar era.
596188.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596189.title: Themes in Korean History
596189.description: Chronological overview of Korean history, emphasizing the modern period. Thematic approach covers topics such as a state building, Confucianism, nationalism, the colonial period, the Korean War and reunification of the peninsula.
596189.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596190.title: History of Southeast Asia to 1800
596190.description: Development of Southeast Asian civilizations from the earliest times to 1800, including the classical and early modern era.
596190.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A; or graduate standing.

596191.title: History of Southeast Asia, 1800-present
596191.description: Development of Southeast Asian history from 1800 to the present, including the colonial, post-colonial and contemporary period.
596191.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A; or graduate standing.

596192.title: Early Vietnam
596192.description: History of Vietnam from the earliest times to c. 1800. Seeks to identify main issues in early history of Vietnam, trade origins of Vietnamese civilization and its implications on the formation of Vietnamese national identity and nationalism.
596192.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U or HIST 110A; or graduate standing.

596193.title: Modern Vietnam
596193.description: History of Vietnam since 1802. The French colonial experience, the Vietnamese struggle against the French from 1946 to 1954, and the American involvement in Vietnam.
596193.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A; or graduate standing.

598036.title: The Vietnam War from the Vietnamese Perspective
598036.description: The Vietnam War from various Vietnamese perspectives: historical, cultural and psychological; North vs. South; personal, regional, national and global; men and women; elite class and ordinary people. (HIST 464E and ASAM 464E are the same course)
598036.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A; or graduate standing.

596194.title: Islamic Civilization: Arab Era
596194.description: Arab predominance in the Middle East from the rise of Islam to the Mongol invasions of the 13th century. (HIST 466A and RLST 466A are the same course.)
596194.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U or HIST 110A; or graduate standing.

596195.title: Islamic Civilization: Imperial Age
596195.description: Mongol invasions of the Middle East and their effects. Ottoman Turkish, Safavid Persian and Moghul Empires to 1800. (HIST 466B and RLST 466B are the same course.)
596195.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U or HIST 110A; or graduate standing.

596196.title: The Middle East in the 19th Century
596196.description: Western penetration of the Middle East and the reaction to it, modernization, the growth of nationalist movements and revolutionary disturbances ending with World War I.
596196.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596197.title: Contemporary Middle East History
596197.description: Social, political and economic changes in the Middle East since World War I. The period after World War II and recent independence movements.
596197.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596198.title: Women and Gender in Middle East History
596198.description: History of women and gender relations in Middle Eastern society and culture from the period of late antiquity to the present.
596198.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or HIST 110B; or graduate standing.

596199.title: Making the Medieval Middle East
596199.description: Most important historical events, social transformations and historiographic issues that pertain to the rise of caliphal rule and the creation of medieval society in the Eastern Mediterranean.
596199.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U or HIST 110A; or graduate standing.

596200.title: American Colonial Civilization
596200.description: Creation and development of societies in English North America from 1492-1754; the emergence of economic, social and political patterns and structures in a maturing Anglo-American culture.

596201.title: The United States from Colony to Nation
596201.description: Social, economic, political and intellectual developments in late 18th-century America, the coming of the American Revolution, origins of American nationalism, social structure of the new nation and formation and ratification of the Constitution.

596202.title: United States, 1845-1877
596202.description: Mid-19th century U.S. society, politics and culture. Slavery, the sectional crisis, the Civil War and Reconstruction.
596202.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

596203.title: United States, 1876-1920
596203.description: Industrialization, urbanization and immigration. Reconstruction, the New South, and the West. Populist and Progressive reform movements. World War I and the Red Scare.

596204.title: United States, 1920-1960
596204.description: Major trends and conflicting values in domestic policies, national security policies, the economy, society and culture. Civil rights, civil liberties, parties and politics. Key historiographic controversies.
596204.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

596205.title: United States in the 1950s
596205.description: American society, politics and culture during the Cold War era. From World War II's end, the Cold War at home and abroad and America's involvement in the Vietnam War.
596205.prereqs: Prerequisites: HIST 170A , HIST 170B ; or HIST 180 and HIST 170A or HIST 170B ; or HIST 190 and HIST 170A or HIST 170B ; or HIST 180 or HIST 190 .

596206.title: United States Since 1960
596206.description: U.S. History from 1960 to present, interrelating foreign and domestic policy, economic, social and cultural trends, a study of U.S. history as it is being formed.
596206.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598755.title: African American History: 1619 to 1863
598755.description: Key events, individuals, institutions and experiences that shaped the history and culture of Africans and their descendants in North America from the 17th century to the American Civil War (AFAM 476A and HIST 476A are the same course).
598755.prereqs: Prerequisite: AFAM 107 , AFAM 190 , AFAM 280 or HIST 170A .

598176.title: African Americans since 1863
598176.description: African Americans as historical actors from 1863 to the present, including responses to segregation and disfranchisement, participation in the Great Migration, and the movement for civil rights (HIST 476B and AFAM 476B are the same course).
598176.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

596207.title: The Multiracial History of America
596207.description: History of race relations and racial ideas in the United States through the experiences of multiracial families, from prior to European colonization to the present day.
596207.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B or graduate standing.

596208.title: Native American History
596208.description: Role of Native Americans in American history. Focuses on religion, education, literature, commerce and museums to understand the interactions between Native Americans and Americans of other races and ethnicities within the context of wider historical trends.
596208.prereqs: Prerequisites: HIST 170A , HIST 170B , HIST 180 or HIST 190 .

598034.title: American Immigration History
598034.description: History of American immigration in a global context. Changes and continuities in the political, cultural, and economic contexts that generated the movement of diverse peoples and structured their experiences of integration within the U.S. (HIST 477C, AFAM 477C, ASAM 477C and CHIC 477C are the same course.)
598034.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4B, POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598375.title: The Urbanization of American Life
598375.description: Urban life in America; the colonial town, western town and the industrial city.
598375.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or 4B or graduate standing.

598444.title: U.S. Economic History to 1900
598444.description: Economic origins of the American colonies, economic causes of the Revolution, the market revolution of the early 1800s, the diverging regional developments in North and South, and industrialization and incorporation of America before 1900.
598444.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or 4B or graduate standing.

596211.title: United States Foreign Relations
596211.description: Relations from 1900 to the present. United States as a world power in the 20th century; the search for world order and the diplomacy of the atomic age.

596212.title: U.S. West and Borderlands
596212.description: History of the Western frontier and region of the U.S. and its borderlands from the 17th century to the present. The U.S. West as a dynamic space marked by conquest, frontier mythology, aridity, migrations and complex relations with federal power.
596212.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or 4B or graduate standing.

596213.title: History of California
596213.description: Political, economic and social history of California from the aboriginal inhabitants to the present; the development of contemporary institutions and the historical background of current issues.
596213.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A or 4B or graduate standing.

596214.title: The History of Orange County
596214.description: History of Orange County. Stresses the process of urbanization.

598376.title: United States Cultural History
598376.description: Cultural values, ideas and beliefs of American communities as expressed through a variety of media, including historical, literary, visual, material and aural sources.
598376.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3A, 3B, 4B, 4U,  POSC 100 or HONR 201B; or graduate standing.

598521.title: Senior Seminar in Historiography and Theory
598521.description: Precedes HIST 490T in the same topic. The historiography, methodology and analytical frameworks used in the particular topic's sub-field. Culminates in a research proposal to be used in 490T. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
598521.prereqs: Prerequisites: HIST 110A , HIST 110B ; or graduate standing.

596215.title: Senior Seminar
596215.description: Directed research seminar with class discussions applied to specific topics and areas as schedule and staff allow. Original research and writing. Required of all history majors. History majors must earn a "C" (2.0) or better. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 9 units.
596215.prereqs: Prerequisites: HIST 300A , HIST 300B ; or graduate standing.

596217.title: History Internship
596217.description: Offers work experience related to the history academic program or to areas of public and private employment where any liberal arts major is appropriate. May be repeated once for credit.

596218.title: Independent Study
596218.description: Open to advanced students in history with consent of department chair. May be repeated once for credit.

596219.title: Theory and History
596219.description: Seminar introducing philosophical issues in history as a humanistic social science, to epistemological considerations of the relationship of history to other disciplines and to new subdisciplines in history. Required for the M.A.

598317.title: Plants and Life
598317.description: Importance of plants in our lives, including plant domestication and the origin of agriculture. Why plants are fascinating organisms. No credit toward biological science major.

595226.title: Biology of Human Sexuality
595226.description: Biology of the human reproductive system, sexual differentiation, anatomy and physiology, sexual behaviors, procreation, contraception and sexually transmitted infections. No credit toward biological science major.

595227.title: Human Anatomy
595227.description: Systems approach to the structure and function of the human body. For biological science majors and related health sciences. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory)
595227.prereqs: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L , CHEM 120B with a “C” (2.0) or better. Other major - BIOL 251 or BIOL 252 , CHEM 120B with a “C” (2.0) or better; or BIOL 310 with a “B” (3.0) or better.

595228.title: General Human Physiology
595228.description: Fundamental mechanisms of human physiology. Integrating cellular and organ system functions, emphasizing regulatory processes. For biology majors and related health sciences. (3 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory).
595228.prereqs: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L , CHEM 120B ; Biochemistry major - BIOL 151 , BIOL 251 , CHEM 120B ; other major - BIOL 151 , BIOL 152 , BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598867.title: Scientific Communication Workshop
598867.description: Instruction and practice in written and oral scientific communication, including retrieval, citation and evaluation of relevant literature.
598867.prereqs: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251, BIOL 253L, BIOL 252, BIOL 254L, CHEM 120B, all with a “C” (2.0) or better; other major - junior or senior standing.

595229.title: Seminar in Biology Education
595229.description: For students interested in biology education/science education. Discuss major topics in biology education and conduct research. (3 hours lecture/discussion)
595229.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 302 , BIOL 303 , BIOL 309 , BIOL 314 or BIOL 325 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595230.title: Biogeography
595230.description: Evolutionary patterns and mechanisms of the distribution of plants and animals in the major habitats of the world. Current concepts and theories.
595230.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 314 or BIOL 325 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or Biology or Environmental Studies graduate standing.

595231.title: Computer Lab in Molecular Systematics
595231.description: Gain practical and theoretical experience with software-based methods in molecular systematics, with emphasis on Internet resources for molecular biologists, acquisition of gene protein sequences, multiple sequence alignment, PCR primer design, phylogenetic analysis and controversies in the field. (2 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory)
595231.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 303 , BIOL 309 , BIOL 314 or BIOL 325 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595232.title: Developmental Biology
595232.description: Molecular and cellular processes in embryonic development encompassing mechanisms of fertilization, cell and tissue interactions, morphogenesis, organogenesis and the regulation of gene expression.
595232.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 303 or BIOL 309 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or Biology graduate standing.

598216.title: Evolutionary Genetics
598216.description: Introduction to molecular genetic data analysis as commonly applied in the fields of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology. Classical population genetics through to the genomics era, focusing on conservation.
598216.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L , all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595234.title: Medical Genetics and Systems Biology
595234.description: Advances in genetics, genomics, proteomics and systems biology. Implications for the pharmaceutical industry, the clinic and for genetic counseling. Uses of biological arrays in diagnosing and treating diseases.
595234.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 302 , BIOL 309 , CHEM 421 or CHEM 423A with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595235.title: Principles of Gene Manipulation
595235.description: Current approaches to and applications of recombinant DNA technology. Principles behind construction of recombinant molecules including vectors and enzymes, introduction into organisms, selection, expression of cloned genes and impact of research on society.
595235.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 309 , CHEM 301B ; or CHEM 423A with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595236.title: Advances in Molecular Genetics
595236.description: Function of genetic material and informational macromolecules. Extensive analysis of recent scientific articles in molecular genetics illustrating mutagenesis, protein synthesis, protein structure and function, biogenesis of RNA molecules, regulation of gene expression and their relationship to important biological processes.
595236.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 309 , CHEM 301B ; or CHEM 423A with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595237.title: Microbial Genetics
595237.description: Perspective of genetics of microbial systems including background information, experimental methods, data interpretation, genetic analysis and applications to biotechnology.
595237.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 302 , BIOL 309 , CHEM 421 or CHEM 423A with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595238.title: Advances in Cell Biology
595238.description: Current topics in the cell biology of cell motility, cell multiplication and regulation, membranes and permeability, cell signaling, cell-to-cell contact and extracellular matrix, and cell differentiation using current journal articles.
595238.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 303 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595239.title: Advances in Cell Biology Lab
595239.description: Use of current techniques like fluorescence microscopy, immunolabeling, ion-sensitive dye ratiometry, image processing and 2-D and 3-D reconstruction to study problems in cell biology, cellular developmental biology and cellular neurobiology. (6 hours laboratory)
595239.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 303 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595240.title: Marine Ecology
595240.description: Ecology of planktonic, nektonic and benthic organisms; their communities and environments.
595240.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 314 or BIOL 325 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595241.title: Marine Ecology Laboratory
595241.description: Field and laboratory studies of planktonic, nektonic and benthic communities. (3 hours laboratory or field work; weekend field trips may be required)

595242.title: Coastal Ecology
595242.description: Ecology or coastal populations and communities emphasizing rocky intertidal or other marine or ocean-influenced habitats. Field and laboratory experiments and studies or ecological processes affecting species distributions and abundances. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory/field work; weekend field trips may be required)
595242.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 314 or BIOL 325 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or Biology or Environmental Studies graduate standing.

595243.title: Immunology
595243.description: Molecular, cellular and organismic nature of the immune process. Inflammation, phagocytosis, antigens, immunoglobulins and cell-mediated immune phenomena. Modern immunology techniques. (3 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory)
595243.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 ; BIOL 303 or BIOL 309 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595244.title: Molecular Virology
595244.description: Viral structure, strategies of replication and gene expression and host-virus interactions, emphasizing animal virus systems.
595244.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 302 , BIOL 303 , BIOL 309 or CHEM 421 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595245.title: Stem Cell Biology
595245.description: Historical context, principles, methodology, clinical impact on society and the individual, recent relevant scientific facts and progress, controversies and perspective of stem cell biology with a focus on applications to regenerative medicine and tissue engineering. BIOL 405 or BIOL 424 recommended.
595245.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 303 or BIOL 309 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595246.title: Biology of Cancer
595246.description: Cancer problem as a dilemma of biology. Clinical and epidemiological aspects. Current research. BIOL 424 is recommended.
595246.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 303 , BIOL 309 , BIOL 314 or BIOL 325 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595247.title: Techniques in Stem Cell Biology
595247.description: Introduction to cell-culture and stem cell laboratory research techniques; focus on advanced-level cell biology experiments, fundamental characteristics of stem cells and differentiation of government-approved human stem cell-lines into several phenotypes. (6 hours of laboratory and 1 hour of discussion per week.)
595247.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 ; BIOL 303 or BIOL 309 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595248.title: Advances in Microbiology
595248.description: Current topics in microbiology virulence mechanisms, antibiotics, host-bacterium interaction, mobile DNA elements, secretion systems, select agents, differentiation and development.
595248.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 302 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or Biology or Environmental Studies graduate standing.

598640.title: Advanced Microbiology Lab
598640.description: Provide knowledge and laboratory expertise to analyze scientific literature in microbiology, perform advanced microbiological techniques and conduct independent microbiology research.
598640.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 302 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595249.title: Advanced Applied Statistics
595249.description: Linear models, including mixed models, applied to experimental and field data from current research projects. Poisson and logistic regression. Model fitting and checking; use of permutation tests as needed. Presentation of results suitable for publication (3 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory)
595249.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 338 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595250.title: Public Health Microbiology
595250.description: Control and epidemiology of infectious diseases of public health importance, water and sewage microbiology. Control of current problems. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory)
595250.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 302 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595251.title: Plant Taxonomy
595251.description: Classification and evolution of vascular plants; emphasis on the flowering plants. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory or fieldwork; weekend field trips may be required.)
595251.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 325 , BIOL 340 or BIOL 345 with a “C” (2.0) or better, or graduate standing.

595252.title: Plant Ecology
595252.description: Community and population ecology of terrestrial plants. Environmental factors and plant distribution with emphasis on California vegetation. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory or fieldwork; weekend field trips may be required).
595252.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 314 , BIOL 325 or BIOL 345 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595253.title: Plant Physiological Ecology
595253.description: Fundamental mechanisms of plant physiological responses to the environment with primary emphasis on whole plants and ecosystems. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory; weekend field trips may be required.) BIOL 345 recommended.
595253.prereqs: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L ; other major - BIOL 151 , BIOL 152 , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595254.title: Plant Cell Physiology
595254.description: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of behavior, growth, transport processes and environmental responses in vascular plants. Plant cell development, nutrition, respiration, photosynthesis, hormones, photoperiodism and stress biology.
595254.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 , BIOL 309 , BIOL 325 , BIOL 345 , CHEM 421 or CHEM 423A with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595255.title: Marine Phycology
595255.description: Biological aspects of marine algae; comparative development, morphology, taxonomy, physiology and ecology. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory or fieldwork; weekend field trips may be required.)
595255.prereqs: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L ; other major - BIOL 151 , BIOL 152 , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595256.title: Plant Molecular Biology
595256.description: Genetic mechanisms in vascular plants controlling metabolism, growth, development and responses to biotic/abiotic environmental stresses. Molecular regulation of gene expression and transduction of internal and external signals.
595256.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 302 , BIOL 303 , BIOL 309 , BIOL 325 , BIOL 345 , CHEM 421 or CHEM 423A with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595257.title: Desert Ecology
595257.description: Adaptations, distributions and interactions of desert plants, animals and microbes, including the influences of environmental factors. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory of fieldwork; weekend field trips may be required)
595257.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 314 or BIOL 325 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595258.title: Conservation Biology
595258.description: Current topics involving theory, concepts and techniques in the conservation of biological diversity.
595258.prereqs: Prerequisite: “C” (2.0) or better in one of the following: BIOL 401 , BIOL 402 , BIOL 410 , BIOL 419 , BIOL 422 , BIOL 441 , BIOL 443 , BIOL 446 , BIOL 449 , BIOL 461 , BIOL 466 , BIOL 475 , BIOL 476 , BIOL 478 , BIOL 479 , BIOL 481 ; or graduate standing.

595259.title: Advanced Evolutionary Anthropology
595259.description: Uses life history theory to examine the evolutionary ecology of human behavior. Human life course, resource acquisition, parenting and fertility. Computer labs utilizing eHRAF. (ANTH 451 and BIOL 451 are the same course.)

598978.title: Global Change Biology
598978.description: How environmental change impacts life on our planet over many time periods, spatial scales, biological levels and across the tree of life. Weekend field trips may be required.
598978.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 325 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595260.title: Life Science Concepts
595260.description: Biological principles using science processes appropriate for elementary teachers. No credit for Biological Science major. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours activity)
595260.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 5B and 5C, or graduate standing (not Biology).

598760.title: Microscopy and Imaging in Biology
598760.description: Skills-based training in microscopy and imaging techniques. Theoretical and practical aspects of microscope use, fluorescent dyes and biosensors, image generation and analysis. Significant project-based experience. (6 hours laboratory)
598760.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 302 , BIOL 303 , BIOL 309 or BIOL 325 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595262.title: Marine Invertebrate Biology
595262.description: Evolution, classification, phylogeny, morphological and physiological adaptations of marine invertebrate animals. Dissect, identify and observe extant animals. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory or fieldwork; weekend field trips may be required)
595262.prereqs: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L ; other major - BIOL 151 , BIOL 152 , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595263.title: General Parasitology
595263.description: Survey of various animal parasites emphasizing the morphology, physiology, and genetics of human protozoans and helminthes. Vectors and common parasites of domestic animals.
595263.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 302 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595265.title: Behavioral Ecology
595265.description: Current problems in the evolution of animal behavior; the origin and maintenance of social systems and behavioral interactions of animals.
595265.prereqs: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L ; other major - BIOL 151 , BIOL 152 , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595266.title: Comparative Animal Physiology
595266.description: Comparative study of physiological and biochemical processes among representative animals. (3 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory, weekend field trips may be required)
595266.prereqs: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L , CHEM 120B ; other major- BIOL 151 , BIOL 152 , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L , CHEM 120B all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595267.title: Cellular Neurobiology
595267.description: Processes of cell communication, particularly in nervous systems. Molecular biology of neurons, model sensory and motor systems, and cellular basis for behavior.
595267.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 303 or BIOL 309 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595268.title: Advances in Biotechnology Lab
595268.description: First semester explores biotechnology techniques for DNA cloning and analysis: restriction enzyme action, DNA sequencing, sequence analysis by computer, plasmid cloning, genomic library production and screening, and DNA probe hybridization. (1 hour lecture/discussion, 6 hours laboratory) (BIOL 472A and CHEM 472A are the same course.)
595268.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 302 ; BIOL 309 , CHEM 421 or CHEM 423A ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595269.title: Advances in Biotechnology Laboratory
595269.description: Second semester exploring biotechnology techniques for gene product analysis: DNA sequencing, site-directed mutagenesis, predicting amino acid changes, protein overproduction, enzyme function assays, protein identification/preparation by gel techniques, immunoblotting. (1 hour discussion, 6 hours laboratory) (CHEM 472B and BIOL 472B are the same course.)
595269.prereqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 421 or CHEM 423A with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595270.title: Introduction to Bioinformatics
595270.description: A research-based, problem-solving experience using the tools and algorithms of molecular and computational biology to analyze genetic and protein sequences retrieved from appropriate databases. (2 hours lecture, 3 hours computer laboratory) (BIOL 473 and CHEM 473 are the same course.)
595270.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 309 , BIOL 303 , BIOL 325 or CHEM 423A with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595271.title: Ichthyology
595271.description: Systematics, evolution, morphology, physiology, ecology and behavior of fishes. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory/fieldwork; weekend field trips may be required.)
595271.prereqs: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L ; other major - BIOL 151 , BIOL 152 , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595272.title: Herpetology
595272.description: Biology, structure, physiology, ecology, distribution, identification, collection, evolution and behavior of amphibians and reptiles. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory or fieldwork; weekend field trips may be required.)
595272.prereqs: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L ; other major - BIOL 151 , BIOL 152 , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595273.title: Mammalogy
595273.description: Systematics, evolution, morphology, physiology, ecology and behavior of mammals. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory/fieldwork; weekend field trips may be required.)
595273.prereqs: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L ; other major - BIOL 151 , BIOL 152 , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595274.title: Ornithology
595274.description: Anatomy, physiology, evolution, behavior and ecology of birds. Laboratory and fieldwork in identification, anatomy, observational techniques and community composition. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory/fieldwork; weekend field trips may be required.)
595274.prereqs: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L ; other major - BIOL 151 , BIOL 152 , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595275.title: Advanced Topics in Undergraduate Biology
595275.description: Current topics, updating of concepts, recent advances and unification of the principles of biology. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
595275.prereqs: Prerequisites: lower-division Biology core courses with a “C” (2.0) or better.

597802.title: Stem Cell Proseminar
597802.description: Preparation for internship in stem cell research labs at the collaborating institutions through analyzing journal articles, presenting research projects, discussing stem cell techniques, and internship project proposal preparation and presentation. Requires acceptance into the CIRM Bridges to Stem Cell Research (BSCR) program.
597802.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 329 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

595276.title: Colloquium: Diverse Topics in Biology
595276.description: Diverse research topics and perspectives in the biological sciences, as presented invited speakers from other universities, governmental agencies, private organizations and industry, and by CSUF biologists. May be repeated once for credit.
595276.prereqs: Pre- or corequisite: at least one upper-division Biology course.

595277.title: SCERP Proseminar
595277.description: Increases the experience and skills of SCERP Scholars in working on problems in environmental biology. Discuss publications, and develop and present SCERP research. Offered Credit/No Credit only. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Not available for graduate degree credit. Selection as a Southern California Ecosystems Research Program (SCERP) Scholar is required.

595278.title: MARC Proseminar
595278.description: Intended to increase the contact of MARC Fellows with minority scientists of national repute who will present seminars. Fellows will read and discuss relevant primary literature, attend the seminars, and meet with speakers before and after the seminars. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 units. Requires selection as a MARC Fellow. (BIOL 480M, CHEM 480M and PSYC 480M are the same course.)

603106.title: U-RISE Proseminar
603106.description: For U-RISE program scholars. Present and discuss thesis projects, case studies, primary research articles and other research-related topics. Participants meet with invited speakers and attend their respective seminars. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 units. Requires acceptance into the Undergraduate Research Training Initiative for Student Enhancement (U-RISE) program; by permit only.
603106.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 101 or BIOL 151 completed with a grade of “C” (2.0) or better.

595280.title: Advances in Evolution and Ecology
595280.description: Current topics in evolutionary biology and ecology. Examine and analyze current literature relating to evolutionary biology, population, community and ecosystem ecology, behavioral ecology and evolutionary ecology.
595280.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 314 or BIOL 325 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or Biology or Environmental Studies graduate standing.

595281.title: Capstone Studies in Biology
595281.description: Individualized practical experience related to the study of biology or pursuit of a biology career that reflects paradigms of the discipline. Application and integration of biological concepts and skills through library research, applied projects or community service activities. Not available for graduate degree credit.

598821.title: Evolutionary Genomics and Aging
598821.description: Compare and contrast theories of aging. Analyze experimental and theoretical literature on aging. Evolutionary genomics of aging. Cover concepts through student-led discussions.
598821.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 325 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

598979.title: Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases
598979.description: Issues related to human pathogens, clinical microbiology techniques, pathogenicity mechanisms, infectious disease epidemiology, and traditional and novel treatments to combat challenging-to-treat microorganisms. (1 hour lecture, 6 hours laboratory)
598979.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L ; or graduate standing.

598641.title: Biology Study Abroad
598641.description: Advanced topics in biology for graduate and undergraduate students. Includes laboratory experience; topics may vary. Only offered as part of CSUF Study Abroad Programs. May be repeated once for credit.
598641.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

595282.title: Biological Internship
595282.description: Biological, ecological and health-related fields. Ninety (90) hours of practical experience in student's chosen field of interest with public or private agencies or businesses. May not be repeated for credit. (1 hour lecture/discussion, 6 hours laboratory work experience)
595282.prereqs: Prerequisites: successful completion of 90 units, including BIOL 302 , BIOL 303 , BIOL 309 , BIOL 317 , BIOL 325 or BIOL 345 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

597809.title: Stem Cell Biology Internship
597809.description: For BSCR Scholars who are completing their internship in a stem cell laboratory at a collaborating institution. BSCR Scholars are required to make significant progress towards a stem cell project approved by their Internship mentor. Must be repeated for a total of 6 units. Requires acceptance into the Bridges to Stem Cell Research (BSCR) program.
597809.prereqs: Prerequisites: BIOL 329 , BIOL 427 , BIOL 429 , BIOL 480C , BIOL 499L , all with a “C” or better. Must be a Bridges to Stem Cell Research scholar.

595283.title: Biology Tutorials
595283.description: Supervised experience in biological science teaching through tutoring or assisting in a laboratory or field class. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. No credit toward biological science major.
595283.prereqs: Prerequisite: completion of Biology lower-division core.

595284.title: Senior Thesis
595284.description: Thesis committee must approve research plan at least two semesters prior to enrollment in this course. Requires preparation, presentation and defense of a formal thesis. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. (BIOL 498 and CHEM 498 are the same course.)

595285.title: Independent Laboratory Study
595285.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of instructor with whom the student wishes to pursue independent laboratory study in biology.

595286.title: Professional Aspects of Biology
595286.description: Discussions concerning research protocol, scientific methodology and communication techniques. Ethics and social responsibilities of professional biologists. (1 hour discussion) BIOL 500A and BIOL 500B are both required to meet the graduate writing requirement.
595286.prereqs: Prerequisite: Biology graduate standing. Corequisite: BIOL 500B .

595287.title: Professional Aspects of Biology
595287.description: Individualized project work and experiences in scientific writing. Required of all students upon admission to the graduate program. (3 hours project work) BIOL 500A and BIOL 500B are both required to meet the graduate writing requirement.
595287.prereqs: Prerequisite: Biology graduate standing. Corequisite: BIOL 500A .

595288.title: Professional Aspects of Biology: Teaching Effectiveness
595288.description: Professional development in the scholarship of teaching biology in higher education. Biology education research, pedagogy, instructional design and assessment to prepare for biology laboratory and classroom instruction.

595289.title: Seminar in Cellular and Molecular Biology and Physiology
595289.description: Selected advanced topics. May be repeated for credit.

595290.title: Seminar in Ecological and Organismic Biology
595290.description: Selected advanced topics. May be repeated for credit.
595290.prereqs: Prerequisite: Biology or Environmental Studies graduate standing.

595291.title: Seminar in Microbiology
595291.description: Selected advanced topics. May be repeated for credit.

595292.title: Advanced Topics in Graduate Biology
595292.description: Current research topics, experimental design and problem solving in biological systems. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 units; only 1 unit may be used on a graduate study plan.

595293.title: Biology Colloquium
595293.description: Series of scholarly presentations that provide diverse research topics and perspectives in the biological sciences. Scientific presentations by biologists from CSUF and other universities, industries, governmental agencies or private organizations. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units.
595293.prereqs: Prerequisite: Biology or Environmental Studies graduate standing.

595294.title: Project
595294.description: Planning, preparing and completing an applied master's degree project. Credit only for completed written project report and oral presentation both of which must be formally approved by the master's program committee. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. (Not acceptable for research-based thesis master's degree programs.)

595295.title: Thesis
595295.description: Open to graduate students with consent of instructor with whom the student is conducting graduate thesis research. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

595296.title: Independent Graduate Research
595296.description: Open to graduate students with consent of graduate faculty with whom the student wishes to pursue independent study in biology. A maximum of 6 units may be used on a graduate study plan. May be repeated for a maximum of 12 units.

598901.title: Foundations for College Success and Lifelong Learning
598901.description: Knowledge, skills and attitudes necessary to succeed as an undergraduate student. Builds a foundation for life-long learning and creates self-meaning in a global society. Designed for exploring majors, with a focus on longitudinal learning, self-validation and social integration.

598804.title: Explore Core: Teens in Trouble
598804.description: Teens in trouble through multiple lenses. The physiological and environmental conditions that impact adolescents. How societies interpret and react to teens in trouble. Apply holistic knowledge to developing personal and/or economic well-being and promoting societal responsibilities to youth. (CAS 130, BIOL 130, BUAD 130, and HIST 130 are the same course)

595297.title: Business Writing
595297.description: Core communication practices: routing business correspondence, positive, informative, negative and persuasive messages. Introduction to research and job application process.
595297.prereqs: Prerequisite: ENGL 101 with a “C-” (1.7) or better.

595298.title: Understanding Business
595298.description: Nature, dimensions and forms of business and the role of entrepreneurship in business creation and growth. Development of an understanding of contemporary business issues, including an introduction to major business functions.

598062.title: Professional and Career Development
598062.description: Develop and practice skills, conceptual understanding, and self-assessment in interpersonal relationship, critical thinking, diversity management, leadership and team building. Introduce tools and build skills for career exploration and planning.
598062.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Areas 1A, 1B; projected sophomore or junior standing (includes in-progress units).

595299.title: Advanced Business Communication
595299.description: Expands knowledge of business communication and develops written and oral communication skills. Study a variety of business cases that understand the function of communication in the modern business world. Analyze real-life business problems and determine when and how to communicate corporate decisions to employees, business partners and the public.
595299.prereqs: Prerequisites: BUAD 201 with a “C” (2.0) or better, ENGL 101 ; or CBE minor, junior standing (not CBE pre-major or undeclared).

595300.title: Entertainment Money Management
595300.description: How entertainment, tourism and hospitality firms make money: overview of existing and evolving income generation models in the various industry sectors.
595300.prereqs: Prerequisites: ACCT 201A or BUAD 210 ; MGMT 365 ; no Pre-Business majors.

598512.title: Starting and Managing a Professional Practice/Small Business
598512.description: Introduces the fundamentals of starting and managing a professional practice or small business. The class targets non-business majors who have an interest in starting their own professional practice or small business after graduation.
598512.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 1A; junior standing; or graduate standing.

595301.title: Internship
595301.description: Planned and supervised work experience. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Credit/No Credit grading only. Requires consent of the instructor and semester in residence at the university.
595301.prereqs: Prerequisites: Business Administration major; junior standing; 2.5 GPA.

595302.title: Independent Study
595302.description: Open to qualified students desiring to pursue directed independent inquiry. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Not open to students on academic notice.

595303.title: Managerial Communications
595303.description: Investigates the entire process of case studies and formal reports. Analyze management communication problems, apply writing strategies and deliver executive presentations.

598733.title: Executive Communication
598733.description: Develop advanced interpersonal, critical thinking and business writing skills. Work effectively in teams, develop listening skills, prepare case analyses, and build stronger written and oral communication skills.

595304.title: Business Strategy Capstone
595304.description: Tools of strategic management and their application in a business environment. Integrates business functional areas and tools by means of a business consulting project. Fulfills the terminal requirement for the MBA degree. Must be taken in the program's final semester during which students can enroll in a maximum of nine units, including a maximum of one core course.

598740.title: Foundations for Success in CAS and College
598740.description: Introduction to the field of child and adolescent studies for CAS majors as they enter college. Explores developmental concepts and applications to success in college, life, and career. Builds connections with CAS community and campus resources during the transition to college.
598740.prereqs: Prerequisite: Child and Adolescent Studies major and freshman or sophomore standing.

595407.title: Introduction to Child and Adolescent Development
595407.description: Overview and practical application of major developmental concepts from birth to adolescence within different biological, familial, social and cultural contexts.

598813.title: Explore Core: Teens in Trouble
598813.description: Teens in trouble through multiple lenses. The physiological and environmental conditions that impact adolescents. How societies interpret and react to teens in trouble. Apply holistic knowledge to developing personal and/or economic well-being and promoting societal responsibilities to youth. (CAS 130, BIOL 130, BUAD 130, and HIST 130 are the same course)

598777.title: Explore Core: Migrant Lives
598777.description: Differing sociocultural experiences of different migrant groups. How immigration as a process impacts physical, cognitive and socioemotional development of migrants' children. Educational experiences of migrants and implications for schools and society. (CAS 131, AMST 131 and READ 131 are the same course)

598896.title: Explore Core: Fear and Fantasy
598896.description: Fear and fantasy through multiple disciplinary lenses and methods. The experience, representation and response to fear across cultures, generations and time periods. Use multidisciplinary approaches to understanding fear and fantasy, drawing from developmental psychology, art, popular culture, history and engineering. (AMST 132, ART 132, CAS 132 and EGME 132 are the same course)

595408.title: Introduction to Early Childhood
595408.description: Learn about and plan developmentally appropriate activities in early childhood settings for children ages 0-8 and their families.

595410.title: Intermediate Seminar in Early Childhood
595410.description: Builds on an introductory practicum as students learn about and plan developmentally appropriate activities in early childhood settings for children ages 0-8 and their families. Minimum four hours of fieldwork per week for a total of 60 hours required for the semester.

595412.title: Child, Family, and Community
595412.description: Relationships between child, family and community members; interaction among systems; influences of gender, abilities, language, culture, race, ethnicity, socio-economic status and political factors; impact of bias and sterotyping; community resources and culturally competent practices to support families.

598972.title: Cybersecurity for Business
598972.description: Organizational and technological issues of cybersecurity, including cyber threats against enterprises and methods of protecting assets from threats. Operational, managerial and technical countermeasures utilized by organizations to safeguard confidentiality, integrity and availability.

596360.title: Business Databases: Design and Processing
596360.description: Internet and multi-user databases; accessing Web servers; data warehouse, structured query language, client-server database systems and programming; object-oriented databases.
596360.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE graduate (not Economics or pre-MBA) standing.

596361.title: Data Warehousing and Foundations of Business Intelligence
596361.description: Basic concepts, architectures and development strategies of data warehousing, issues in managing data as organizational assets and its potentials for competitive advantages in dynamic business environments.
596361.prereqs: Prerequisites: ISDS 552 , ISDS 555 ; CBE graduate (not Economics or pre-MBA) standing.

596362.title: Issues in Business Information Technology
596362.description: Advanced concepts of global networks, advanced communications design and management, global information security and privacy, global communications protocol and applications to industry, government and commercial sectors.

596363.title: Advanced Software Development with Web Applications
596363.description: This course focuses on advanced software development with web applications using Python. Topics include python basics, web scraping, application program interface, and building your own web applications.

598724.title: Advanced Regression Analysis for Business Applications
598724.description: Apply regression to develop prediction models for a variety of business decision problems using real case studies and examples. Data issues, appropriate use of statistical software, and various aspects and extensions of linear regression models for different data types.

598028.title: Business Data Transformation
598028.description: ETL/ELT aspects of business data analysis. Relational and multidimensional data extraction from local and remote sources, designing ETL processes, querying multidimensional cubes, dimension and time-based hierarchies, and adding calculated members.

598029.title: Data Mining for Business Appl
598029.description: Fundamentals of data mining. Association, classification, clustering, decision trees, statistical modeling and visualization. Motivation for the applications of data mining techniques. Introduction to business analytics and case studies. Use of data mining software suites on data sets.
598029.prereqs: Prerequisite: ISDS 540 or equivalent course in Statistics.

596366.title: Seminar in Information Systems Implementation
596366.description: Integrates the development concepts of project management, analysis, design and implementation with telecommunications, database design, programming, testing and system integration issues. Develop information systems from concept to completion through individual and team effort. Requires projects. Individual project will fulfill the terminal degree requirement. To be taken in the last semester or with completion of at least seven ISDS courses in the program.
596366.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE graduate (not Economics or pre-MBA) standing.

596367.title: Independent Graduate Research
596367.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Not open to students on academic notice. Requires consent of department chair and associate dean.

596811.title: Fundamental Italian-A
596811.description: Develop listening and reading comprehension, speaking and writing, and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level with a focus on oral expression. Introduction to Italian customs, culture and civilization. Conducted primarily in Italian.

596812.title: Fundamental Italian-B
596812.description: Continued development of listening and reading comprehension, speaking and writing, and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level with an emphasis on oral expression. Further study of Italian customs, culture and civilization. Conducted primarily in Italian.

596813.title: Japanese Conversation for Beginners
596813.description: Introduction to spoken Japanese, with emphasis on vocabulary development at the beginning levels. For students who would like to learn conversational Japanese without having to learn the writing system.

596814.title: Fundamental Japanese-A
596814.description: Develop listening and reading comprehension, speaking, writing, and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level in Japanese. Introduction to Japanese customs, culture and civilization.

596815.title: Fundamental Japanese-B
596815.description: Continued development of listening and reading comprehension, speaking, writing, and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level in Japanese. Further study of Japanese customs, culture and civilization.

596816.title: Intermediate Japanese-A
596816.description: Develop listening and reading comprehension, and oral and written proficiency in Japanese based on cultural and literary materials. Review and introduce grammar. Conducted primarily in Japanese.
596816.prereqs: Prerequisite: JAPN 102 . Pre- or corequisite: JAPN 213 .

596817.title: Intermediate Japanese-B
596817.description: Continued development of listening and reading comprehension, and oral and written proficiency in Japanese based on cultural and literary materials. Review and introduce grammar. Conducted primarily in Japanese.
596817.prereqs: Prerequisites: JAPN 203 , JAPN 213 . Pre- or corequisite: JAPN 214 .

598756.title: Japanese Cultural Conversation and Composition A
598756.description: Subjects related to Japanese culture. Helps develop Japanese oral and written proficiency through discussions, oral and written reviews, and essays. Conducted primarily in Japanese.
598756.prereqs: Prerequisite: JAPN 102 . Pre- or corequisite: JAPN 203 .

597739.title: Japanese Cultural Conversation and Composition B
597739.description: Topics related to Japanese culture. Helps further develop Japanese oral and written proficiency through discussions, oral and written reviews, and essays. Conducted in Japanese.
597739.prereqs: Prerequisites: JAPN 203 , JAPN 213 . Pre- or corequisite: JAPN 204 .

596818.title: Directed Study
596818.description: Supervised study projects in Japanese language or literature. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of instructor and department chair.

596819.title: Advanced Japanese-A
596819.description: Practice in four skills of advanced Japanese, emphasizing reading comprehension in the context of contemporary concerns. Conducted in Japanese.

596820.title: Advanced Japanese-B
596820.description: Practice in four skills of advanced Japanese, emphasizing reading comprehension in the context of contemporary concerns. Conducted in Japanese.

596821.title: Advanced Spoken Japanese
596821.description: Spoken aspect of advanced Japanese through dialogues, discussions and oral presentations in the context of contemporary concerns. Conducted in Japanese.

596822.title: Advanced Grammar and Composition
596822.description: Helps achieve an advanced level of written expression in Japanese and cultural awareness through reading and writing on various topics. Further develop writing skills in Japanese using "kyoiku-kanji" with accurate grammar. May be repeated once for credit.

596823.title: Japanese for Business
596823.description: The practical vocabulary and structure of business language, as well as the cultural background of business procedures in the Japanese business world. Conducted in Japanese.

596824.title: Japanese for International Business
596824.description: Vocabulary and language structures for Japanese in the international business world and related economic situations. Comprehension of business terminology through conversation, reading and writing. Conducted in Japanese.

598387.title: Introduction to Japanese Civilization
598387.description: Readings and lectures in Japanese literature, arts and institutions from earliest history to 1868, to develop insights into Japanese culture while strengthening facility in the language. Conducted primarily in Japanese.

598388.title: Modern Japan
598388.description: Readings and lectures in Japanese literature, arts and institutions from 1868 to the present, to develop insights into Japanese culture while strengthening facility in the language. Conducted primarily in Japanese.

598565.title: Japanese Culture and Language Through Manga
598565.description: Develop cultural knowledge, plus reading, writing, speaking and listening skills in formal and informal Japanese through reading and discussing manga works (graphic novels, comic books). Conducted primarily in Japanese.
598565.prereqs: Prerequisite: JAPN 305 , JAPN 306 , JAPN 307 , JAPN 308 , JAPN 310 or JAPN 311 .

598389.title: Introduction to Japanese Literature
598389.description: Introduction to literary forms and concepts of literary techniques. Analysis and interpretation of various texts. Conducted primarily in Japanese.
598389.prereqs: Prerequisites: JAPN 305, JAPN 306, JAPN 307, JAPN 308, JAPN 310 or JAPN 311; GE Area 3B.

596825.title: Japanese Culture and Society: Anime
596825.description: Japanese culture and society, as well as multicultural analysis of global issues as reflected in Japanese animated films. Conducted in English.

598131.title: Advanced Writing on Current Issues
598131.description: Current Japanese topics with the goals of developing academic writing and broadening cultural awareness from a humanistic perspective. Conducted in Japanese.

596826.title: Medieval Japanese Literature
596826.description: Masterpieces of Japanese literature from eighth to 16th centuries and their relationship to cultural, historical and intellectual developments in these eras. Conducted primarily in Japanese.
596826.prereqs: Prerequisite: JAPN 305 , JAPN 306 , JAPN 307 , JAPN 308 , JAPN 310 , JAPN 311 or JAPN 375 .

596827.title: Modern and Contemporary Japanese Literature
596827.description: Literary use of language, cultural production, reading and critical evaluation of literary works. Reading excerpts of modern Japanese literature on various topics. Conducted primarily in Japanese.
596827.prereqs: Prerequisite: JAPN 305 , JAPN 306 , JAPN 307 , JAPN 308 , JAPN 310 , JAPN 311 or JAPN 375 .

598390.title: Japanese Culture and Society in Film
598390.description: Development of modern Japanese culture and society using film that reflects important Japanese cultural and social concepts, and ways of looking at and dealing with the world. Conducted primarily in Japanese.
598390.prereqs: Prerequisite: JAPN 305 , JAPN 306 , JAPN 307 or JAPN 308 ; or graduate standing.

596828.title: Introduction to Japanese Linguistics
596828.description: Analytical procedures of general linguistics as applied to phonological, semantic, morphological, syntactic and discourse aspects of Japanese. Conducted primarily in Japanese.

596829.title: Japanese Language and Society
596829.description: Introduces the methodology for analyzing the Japanese language in its social dimension. Major dialectal areas in Japan and their linguistic characteristics, social class and language, and language and gender. Conducted primarily in Japanese.
596829.prereqs: Prerequisites: JAPN 305 , JAPN 306 , JAPN 307 or JAPN 308 ; JAPN 466 .

596830.title: Japanese-English Contrastive Analysis
596830.description: Contrastive analysis of phonological, lexical, syntactic and discourse aspects of Japanese and English. Conducted primarily in Japanese.
596830.prereqs: Prerequisites: JAPN 306 and JAPN 466 (may be taken concurrently).

596831.title: Senior Seminar: Variable Topics in Japanese
596831.description: Research and discussion of a cultural, literary or linguistic theme. Subject varies and is announced in the class schedule. May be repeated once for credit with different topic. Conducted primarily in Japanese.
596831.prereqs: Prerequisites: JAPN 305 or JAPN 306 ; at least one 400-level JAPN course; or graduate standing.

596832.title: Independent Study
596832.description: Supervised projects in Japanese language or literature to be taken with consent of instructor and department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596377.title: Physical Conditioning
596377.description: Performance courses are instructional. Beginning, intermediate and advanced sections are offered for most performance courses. Students who already possess proficiency in an activity should consider the course chosen from the standpoint of the level of skill development that may be encountered, standards of proficiency expected and their own ability level. Initial assessment and determination will be made by the course instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

598891.title: Personal Fitness and Wellness Through Physical Activity
598891.description: Practical and theoretical exploration of components and benefits of physical fitness and movement as they relate to overall health and wellness.

596378.title: Beginning Jogging
596378.description: Performance courses are instructional. Beginning, intermediate and advanced sections are offered for most performance courses. Students who already possess proficiency in an activity should consider the course chosen from the standpoint of the level of skill development that may be encountered, standards of proficiency expected and their own ability level. Initial assessment and determination will be made by the course instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596379.description: Performance courses are instructional. Beginning, intermediate and advanced sections are offered for most performance courses. Initial assessment and determination will be made by the course instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

598943.title: Aqua Fit
598943.description: A variety of aerobic conditioning activities in the water and on the pool deck. Activities include intervals, circuits, muscle and core exercises, games and other workouts.  Incorporate flotation equipment for buoyancy and water resistance. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

598668.title: Aquatic Adaptation
598668.description: Provide non-swimmers with basic water-comfort skills. Identified non-swimmers (self or by instructor) are those who may be uncomfortable in the water or have never received formal swim instruction.

596380.title: Beginning Swimming
596380.description: Performance courses are instructional. Beginning, intermediate and advanced sections are offered for most performance courses. Students who already possess proficiency in an activity should consider the course chosen from the standpoint of the level of skill development that may be encountered, standards of proficiency expected and their own ability level. Initial assessment and determination will be made by the course instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units..
