596396.description: Performance courses are instructional. Beginning, intermediate and advanced sections are offered for most performance courses. Students who already possess proficiency in an activity should consider the course chosen from the standpoint of the level of skill development that may be encountered, standards of proficiency expected and their own ability level. Initial assessment and determination will be made by the course instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

598944.title: Beginning Pickleball
598944.description: Fast-paced, self-officiated net game with similarities to tennis, badminton, table tennis and racquetball. Rules, strategies, technique, preparation for play, plus extensive active practice and play with two, three or four people.

596397.title: Aerobic Exercise and Weight Control
596397.description: Performance courses are instructional. Beginning, intermediate and advanced sections are offered for most performance courses. Students who already possess proficiency in an activity should consider the course chosen from the standpoint of the level of skill development that may be encountered, standards of proficiency expected and their own ability level. Initial assessment and determination will be made by the course instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596398.title: Cardio Kick-Boxing
596398.description: Performance courses are instructional. Beginning, intermediate and advanced sections are offered for most performance courses. Students who already possess proficiency in an activity should consider the course chosen from the standpoint of the level of skill development that may be encountered, standards of proficiency expected and their own ability level. Initial assessment and determination will be made by the course instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596416.title: Intercollegiate Cross Country
596416.description: An intercollegiate activity in individual or team sports in an educational setting under the direction of a coach. May be repeated for a maximum of 20 units.

597857.title: Intercollegiate Men’s Golf
597857.description: An intercollegiate activity in individual or team sports in an educational setting under the direction of a coach. May be repeated for a maximum of 20 units.

598612.title: Intercollegiate Women’s Golf
598612.description: An intercollegiate activity in individual or team sports in an educational setting under the direction of a coach. May be repeated for a maximum of 20 units.

596417.title: Intercollegiate Track-Field
596417.description: An intercollegiate activity in individual or team sports in an educational setting under the direction of a coach. May be repeated for a maximum of 20 units.

596418.title: Intercollegiate Women’s Tennis
596418.description: An intercollegiate activity in individual or team sports in an educational setting under the direction of a coach. May be repeated for a maximum of 20 units.

597850.title: Intercollegiate Men’s Basketball
597850.description: An intercollegiate activity in individual or team sports in an educational setting under the direction of a coach. May be repeated for a maximum of 20 units.

598613.title: Intercollegiate Women’s Basketball
598613.description: An intercollegiate activity in individual or team sports in an educational setting under the direction of a coach. May be repeated for a maximum of 20 units.

596419.title: Intercollegiate Men’s Baseball
596419.description: An intercollegiate activity in individual or team sports in an educational setting under the direction of a coach. May be repeated for a maximum of 20 units.

598392.title: Intercollegiate Men’s Soccer
598392.description: An intercollegiate activity in individual or team sports in an educational setting under the direction of a coach. May be repeated for a maximum of 20 units.

597851.title: Intercollegiate Women’s Soccer
597851.description: An intercollegiate activity in individual or team sports in an educational setting under the direction of a coach. May be repeated for a maximum of 20 units.

603100.title: Women’s Intercollegiate Water Polo
603100.description: Training for and competing in NCAA-regulated water polo games. Conditioning, practice, water polo-specific strength training, pre-season preparation, between-games recovery, leadership skill development, league and tournament games. May be repeated for credit. Requires consent of coach.

596420.title: Intercollegiate Women’s Volleyball
596420.description: An intercollegiate activity in individual or team sports in an educational setting under the direction of a coach. May be repeated for a maximum of 20 units.

596421.title: Intercollegiate Women’s Softball
596421.description: An intercollegiate activity in individual or team sports in an educational setting under the direction of a coach. May be repeated for a maximum of 20 units. Credit/No Credit only.

596422.title: Integrated Human Anatomy and Physiology A
596422.description: Integrated introduction to human anatomy and physiology. Structure and function of the musculoskeletal, nervous and cardiorespiratory systems. For nursing majors and students interested in allied health professions; no credit toward Biological Science major. (3 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory) (KNES 191A and BIOL 191A are the same course).
596422.prereqs: Prerequisites: sophomore, junior or senior standing; minimum 3.0 GPA; minimum 30 units completed except for Nursing majors.

596423.title: Integrated Human Anatomy and Physiology B
596423.description: Second semester of integrated concepts in human anatomy and physiology for nursing, allied health and kinesiology majors. Nutrition, water and ion balance, and homeostatic regulation by the digestive, renal, cardio-respiratory, endocrine, nervous systems. No credit toward biological science major. (3 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory) (BIOL 191B and KNES 191B are the same course.)
596423.prereqs: Prerequisite: BIOL 191A / KNES 191A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596424.title: Introduction to Kinesiology
596424.description: Study of human movement, including its role in daily life, its place in higher education and professional career opportunities in areas related to sport, movement, exercise and fitness. Multiple ways of knowing and studying human movement with a focus on the subdisciplines within kinesiology.

597849.title: CPR, Automated External Defibrillator and First Aid
597849.description: Provides knowledge and skills necessary to respond to injuries and sudden illnesses in the community. Successful completion provides American Red Cross certifications in infant, child and adult Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR), Automated External Defibrillator (AED) and standard first aid. Credit/No Credit only. (PUBH 203 and KNES 203 are the same course)

596425.title: Medical Terminology
596425.description: Introduction to medical terminology using word building (roots, suffixes, prefixes, spelling, and pronunciation) as they relate to anatomical structure and function. Additional topics include medical terminology related to pharmacology, abnormal conditions, surgical procedures, and diagnosis and treatment of medical conditions. (KNES 205 and NURS 205 are the same course.)

596426.title: Human Anatomy and Physiology
596426.description: Introduction to human anatomy and physiology concepts as they apply to physical activity, sport and exercise. Structure and function of the skeleto-neuromuscular and cardio-respiratory systems relative to human movement. Preparation for KNES 360, KNES 361, KNES 348, KNES 371 and major in Health Science. No credit toward biological science major. (BIOL 210 and KNES 210 are the same course.)

596427.title: Basic Scuba
596427.description: Skin and scuba diving, theory of diving, safety procedures and ocean environment. Open Water Basic Scuba Certification earned with successful completion. Requires ability to swim 200 yards; float or tread water for 10 minutes.

596429.title: Teaching Team Sports
596429.description: Team sport history, skills, rules, progressions and sport-specific teaching strategies to promote active participation and experiential learning. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours activity)

596430.title: Teaching Nontraditional Team Sports
596430.description: Nontraditional sports history, skills, rules, progressions and sport-specific teaching strategies to promote active participation and experiential learning. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours activity)

597724.title: Seminar in Rhetorical Theory and Criticism
597724.description: Rhetorical theories and critical methods. Major figures and schools of thought from Classical to contemporary era.
597724.prereqs: Prerequisite: HCOM 330 or HCOM 432 ; or graduate standing.

596288.title: Seminar in Argumentation and Persuasion
596288.description: Leading theories and empirical research on argumentation and persuasion. Strategies of effective advocacy and compliance-gaining. Laboratory research and applied settings. Ethical issues related to argumentation and persuasion.
596288.prereqs: Prerequisite: HCOM 332 or HCOM 334 ; or admission to the graduate program.

596289.title: Seminar in Communication and Rhetorical Theory
596289.description: Analyze rhetorical and communication theories. Comparisons and contrasts of the epistemological bases of empirical and humanistic inquiry. A "B" (3.0) or better is required for credit in the Communication Studies M.A.

598365.title: Directed Graduate Research
598365.description: Individual research study, under the supervision of the chair of the student's advisory committee.

598366.title: Thesis
598366.description: The selection, investigation and written presentation of a selected problem in the field of speech.

596302.title: Thesis
596302.description: The selection, investigation and written presentation of a selected problem in the field of speech.

596303.title: Thesis
596303.description: The selection, investigation and written presentation of a selected problem in the field of speech.

598367.title: Independent Graduate Research
598367.description: Open to graduate students only with signed consent from department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

597855.title: Introduction to Aging Studies
597855.description: Multidisciplinary overview of: characteristics, strengths and problems of older persons; diversity in aging process involving gender, race, ethnicity, subculture; services to older adults; gerontology as an academic discipline and a field of practice. (AGNG 133, SOCI 133, PUBH 133, HUSR 133 and PSYC 133 are the same course.)

596304.title: Introduction to Human Services
596304.description: Origin and scope of human services, including theoretical frameworks, the functions and activities of human services organizations, and the roles and related skills of human services workers.

596305.title: Character and Conflict
596305.description: Experiential, theme-oriented class exploring life choices in the struggle for personal autonomy. Body image, sex roles, love, sexuality, intimacy, marriage, loneliness, death, meaning and values. Credit/No Credit only. Requires consent of instructor at first class meeting.
596305.prereqs: Prerequisite: sophomore, junior or senior standing; or second BA, postbaccalaureate undeclared or postbaccalaureate certificate; or graduate standing.

596306.title: Case Management
596306.description: Principles and critical issues in case management, along with various models of service delivery. Special attention given to the diverse populations utilizing case management systems. Collaborative and interagency services.

596307.title: Research and Data Management in Human Services
596307.description: Basic research and assessment skills appropriate to the delivery of human services. Introductory skills relating to library search techniques, evaluation of research articles, computer-based data analysis, tracking client progress and implications for human services.

596308.title: Human Services for Immigrants and Refugees
596308.description: U.S. immigration policy for newcomers. Stressors and cultural influences on coping behaviors, and culturally sensitive models of human service delivery emphasizing Southeast Asian, Latino and Soviet immigrants and refugees.
596308.prereqs: Pre- or corequisite: HUSR 201 or AFAM 311 .

596309.title: Leadership Skills and Personal Development
596309.description: Leadership concepts and skills, including psychological process, conflict resolution, counseling and human service skills. Becoming aware of personal leadership styles; maintaining vitality through physical and mental health. (HUSR 350 and COUN 350 are the same course).

596310.title: Theories and Techniques of Counseling
596310.description: Contemporary theories and techniques of counseling. The counseling process, comparison of various theoretical approaches, introduction to professional and ethical issues. (HUSR 380 and COUN 380 are the same course.)
596310.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 4A, junior or senior standing.

596311.title: Program Design and Proposal Writing
596311.description: Techniques of program design, budgeting and staffing of human service programs; proposal writing and fund development methods; survey of needs assessment procedures.
596311.prereqs: Prerequisites: HUSR 315 ; HUSR 396 , HUSR 490 or EDEL 315 .

598379.title: Practicum Seminar
598379.description: Participation at an approved agency conducting appropriate human service duties. Discussions related to: functions and structures of human services agencies; interrelationships with community services; the role of the human services worker; ethical, legal and professional issues.

598508.title: Peer Mentoring for HUSR Student Success
598508.description: Develop mentorship skills through seminar learning and serving as a peer mentor to other students. Enhance communication, cultural competency, leadership, motivation, goal achievement, personal management and student success skills. Learn about barriers to and resources for college student success.

596312.title: Ethical and Professional Issues in Human Services
596312.description: Ethical, legal and professional issues facing the human services worker. Designed to teach a process of ethical decision-making and to increase awareness of the complexities in practice.

596313.title: Crisis Intervention for Para-Professionals
596313.description: Emphasis on theories and techniques of short-term intervention and referral procedures addressing societal crises including suicide, cultural, developmental, loss, veterans, PTSD, community disaster, IPV, child abuse, sexual assault/rape, sexuality, bullying, substance misuse, gun violence, the pandemic, and social media issues.

596314.title: Human Services Delivery to Communities
596314.description: Identifying the human service needs of varied community groups and focuses on the utilization of this knowledge about those groups in order to develop effective service delivery strategies.

596315.title: Gerontology in Human Services
596315.description: Gerontology and human services practice and policy, focusing on historical developments and content of key social, legislative and governmental programs designed for older adults, including the Social Security Act, Older Americans Act and Medicare.

596316.title: Treatment Issues in Drug Addiction
596316.description: Treatment issues and theoretical models involved in treating drug dependencies. Specific effects of different drug classifications; understanding drug cultures; women, children and elderly addiction; co-dependency and enabling.

596317.title: Group Process and Membership
596317.description: Didactic and experiential overview of stages of group development, impact of members on group identity, group member and leader issues. Survey various counseling groups. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Credit/No Credit only.

596318.title: Human Services Management
596318.description: Issues in administration and management of human services in community agencies. Assessing client needs, designing human service delivery systems, program budgeting, marketing strategies, accountability and improving program management.
596318.prereqs: Prerequisite: junior or senior standing. Pre- or corequisite: HUSR 201 .

596319.title: Contemporary Issues in the Human Services
596319.description: Systematic study and theory, research findings and intervention strategies related to contemporary issues faced by paraprofessional human service workers. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 9 units.

596320.title: Child Abuse and the Human Services
596320.description: Introduction to types and symptoms of abuse, assessment techniques, legal and ethical issues, family dynamics pertaining to children, adolescents and adults abused as children. Networking and referral, utilizing community resources and prevention.

596321.title: Physiological Effects of Alcohol and Other Drugs
596321.description: Pharmacological actions of drugs of abuse and how these relate to the physiological, psychological and behavioral effects of such drugs. Properties of recreational, "street" drugs and of prescription drugs that lead to abuse and/or dependence are covered. Not available for use on a graduate study plan.

596322.title: Drug Abuse Prevention and Early Intervention
596322.description: History, theories and models in the drug prevention field. Theoretical foundations and conceptual frameworks that have been used in the field will be presented. Major research and evaluation outcomes on the effectiveness of prevention strategies. Not available for use on a graduate study plan.

596323.title: Dynamics of Substance Abuse Treatment in Families
596323.description: Explore and apply methods of assisting significant others, organizations and communities to understand, treat and prevent substance abuse and dependence. Students develop practice strategies that will prepare them to deliver services at the micro, meso and macro levels. Not available for use on a graduate study plan.

596324.title: Co-Occurring Disorders: Assessment, Treatment and Referral
596324.description: Concepts, definitions and features of co-occurring mental disorders and substance-related disorders in individuals seen in human services settings; includes screening, assessment, case management and service delivery for such individuals. Not applicable to graduate degree requirements.

596326.title: Persons with Disabilities and Human Services Community Support Systems
596326.description: A diversity model approach to human service practice for persons with disabilities. Societal and professional stereotypes; disability culture; disability groupings; guidelines for practice with persons with disabilities; systems and community supports for persons with disabilities.

596328.title: Theory and Practice of Group Counseling
596328.description: Critical evaluation of 10 contemporary theoretical approaches to group counseling, as well as issues in group work. Applying theories and techniques to actual group situations.

598814.title: Integrating Acting and Psychodrama Exercises in Human Services
598814.description: Introduction to basic acting and psychodrama techniques designed to encourage self-awareness and promote growth and healing in future clients. Integrates acting exercises into counseling theories and techniques that challenge established behavioral and psychological patterns.

596327.title: Human Services Delivery to Latinos
596327.description: Theory, research findings and intervention strategies related to contemporary issues faced by paraprofessional human service workers in dealing with Latino populations. How to best deliver services in mental health, social welfare, and educational agencies.

596329.title: Evaluation of Human Services Programs
596329.description: Making program objectives measurable; determining appropriate methodology and techniques to evaluate effectiveness, efficiency and process variables; practical problems of program evaluation.

596330.title: Human Services Policy and Practice
596330.description: Relationship between policy and practice. Problem of inequities and inequalities in the distribution of resources through social policies and social welfare programs. How policy impacts service delivery to disenfranchised groups.
596330.prereqs: Prerequisite: junior or senior standing. Pre- or corequisite: HUSR 201 .

596331.title: Case Analysis and Intervention Techniques
596331.description: Psychodynamic principles of evaluation, diagnosis and intervention; techniques of counseling appropriate to diverse populations; application of a psychoanalytic perspective to the diagnostic categories of the DSM.
596331.prereqs: Prerequisite: HUSR 380 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596332.title: Practicum in Group Leadership
596332.description: Supervised experience as a group leader. Approaches and techniques of group leadership. May be used as a substitute for HUSR 396, HUSR 495 or HUSR 496 with coordinator approval. May be repeated for a maximum of six units. Human Services majors and minors must earn a "C" (2.0) or better.

598610.title: HHD Peer Mentoring Academy
598610.description: New and experienced mentors will explore interdisciplinary mentorship with peer mentor service. Expand knowledge of resources to overcome barriers to college success. Enhance communication, cultural competency, leadership, motivational, goal achievement, personal management and student success skills. Requires recommendation to continue a second semester of mentorship by 399 instructor.
598610.prereqs: Prerequisite: CAS 399 , HUSR 399 , PUBH 399 , KNES 399 or NURS 399 .

596333.title: Fieldwork Seminar
596333.description: Students participate in 120 hours of service at an approved agency, 8 hours per week. Classroom analysis of agency experience focusing on skills and techniques of human service workers and organizational analysis.

596334.title: Internship Seminar
596334.description: Supervised internship in a community service agency in area of specialization. Seminar consists of group supervision and discussion of cases. Letter grade only. Internship experience consisting of 120 hours with a minimum of 8 hours per week during the semester.

596335.title: Independent Study
596335.description: Individual research project, either library or field, under the direction of a faculty member. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units; only three units in one semester. Requires approval of coordinator, consent of instructor.

598267.title: Leadership in Human Services Capstone Course
598267.description: Requires an original capstone project demonstrating the culmination of knowledge gained in the program and independent thinking. Identify a leadership need within an identified agency and develop a strategic plan addressing that need.

607261.title: Careers in Humanities and Social Sciences: Passage to the Future
607261.description: Core values and skills of the humanities and social sciences as they relate to a variety of different professions. Reflect on personal strengths and passions, how they align with different careers and how they lead to meaningful professions.

598819.title: Politics, Culture, and History of Washington, D.C.
598819.description: The politics, history and culture of Washington, D.C., emphasizing the importance of the political and cultural geography of the city's historic and diverse neighborhoods. Uses literature, art and music to illuminate these neighborhoods and its racial history.

597731.title: Life and Culture Abroad
597731.description: Interdisciplinary course providing a broad background to culture and civilization abroad. Social, historical and cultural approach to contemporary societies abroad. Examines traditions and institutions to help understand the 21st century way of life abroad. Related field trips. (Course only offered as part of CSUF Study Abroad Programs.) May be repeated once for credit.

597709.title: Humanities Internship
597709.description: Supervised internship requiring course project and 120 hours (3 units) or 240 hours (6 units).

597710.title: Social Sciences Internship
597710.description: Supervised internship requiring course project and 120 hours (3 units) or 240 hours (6 units).

597711.title: Independent Study
597711.description: Independent research project in humanities or social sciences. May be repeated once for credit with different content. No more than three units may be taken in any one semester.

607262.title: Cultures in Global Context
607262.description: Interdisciplinary graduate seminar on social, historical and cultural approaches to studying contemporary societies abroad. Examines traditions and institutions to help understand 21st-century ways of life in global context. Related field trips. (Only offered as part of CSUF Study Abroad/Away Programs.)

597712.title: Independent Graduate Research
597712.description: May be repeated once for credit with different content. No more than three units may be taken in any one semester. Requires consent of home department graduate advisor.

598833.title: Design and Development of Multimedia for Learning
598833.description: Designing and developing multimedia-based instruction, including video and interactive tutorials. Introduces instructional design concepts and processes, learning theories, multimedia design principles, related trends and issues, and practical applications of multimedia-based learning in a variety of contexts.

598890.title: Emerging Technologies for Learning
598890.description: This course will focus on the use and theoretical basis of a variety of emerging technologies for learning. Introduces trends and issues in emerging technologies, online teaching, usability and accessibility, and lesson plan design utilizing technology.

596368.title: Foundations of Instructional Design and Digital Authoring Tools
596368.description: Understanding operating systems, hardware and networking environments to develop instructional tools and products using a multimedia authoring tool.

596369.title: Research Practices in Instructional Design and Technology
596369.description: Terms and accepted procedures in qualitative and quantitative inquiry as they apply to instructional design and technology. Conduct controlled portions of IDT research and prepare preliminary proposals for larger projects. Requires completion of orientation program for M.S. in Instructional Design and Technology (IDT).

596370.title: Instructional Design 1: Issues in ELearning and the Design Process
596370.description: Systematic design of instructional courseware, including analysis, media selection, design, development and evaluation. Learning principles, learner characteristics, instructional strategies, screen design, response analysis, feedback and interactivity.

596371.title: Learning Theories for Postsecondary and Adult Instructional Settings
596371.description: Behavioral, cognitive, constructionist learning theories, related concepts and their implications for designing instruction. Develop critical thinking about desirable cognitive outcomes when designing educational experiences.

596372.title: Instructional Design 2: Advanced Issues in Implementation, Management and Program Evaluation
596372.description: Applying computer-based instructional design principles to develop new methods and materials for technology-based instruction. Computer-based instruction, project management, planning, assessment, design principles and development tools. Design multimedia courseware.

596373.title: Instructional Strategies and Universal Design Issues in Learning Environments
596373.description: Training in instructional strategies for Pre-K through adulthood. Current research on instructional strategies and assistive technologies in a variety of instructional contexts.

598383.title: Systematic Approaches to Digital Design and Development
598383.description: Design, develop and implement digital media for instructional purposes. Issues surrounding using digital media for instruction. Requires successfully completing Midpoint Symposium.

596374.title: Trends, Emerging Technologies and Issues in Instructional Design
596374.description: Theoretical basis, issues and strategies for improving teaching and learning through the use of emerging technologies.

596375.title: Practicum in Instructional Design and Technology
596375.description: Strategies for effectively implementing and evaluating instructional design and technology to improve learning; includes significant field work assignments in work-related settings. Requires consent of Program Coordinator.

596376.title: Project
596376.description: Individual research on an empirical project, with conferences with the instructor, culminating in a project. Requires consent of Program Coordinator.

596336.title: Introduction to Programming
596336.description: Structured programming principle; object-oriented programming principles; using GUI objects; handling events; processing files and streams.

596337.title: Principles of Information Systems
596337.description: How business professionals can leverage Information Systems (IS) through planning, oversight and management. Understanding the implications of IS, learning to identify and evaluate potential opportunities to employ IS, understanding the role of IS as a major facilitator of the fundamental business activities and learning to manage IS projects.

596338.title: Business Analytics I
596338.description: Statistical data analysis and inference techniques within the context of business analytics. Selecting statistical tools that are appropriate for a given application. Develop a high level of proficiency in Microsoft Excel. Minimum 2.5 GPA required for online section registration.
596338.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 130 , MATH 135 or MATH 150A with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: BUAD 301 . Business Data Analytics minor prerequisites: MATH 130 , MATH 135 or MATH 150A with a “C” (2.0) or better. Or CBE graduate standing.

596339.title: Business Analytics II
596339.description: Advanced concepts and applications of business analytics. Developing analytical thinking, applying business analytics solutions, and communicating insights based on the solutions to decision makers in an organization.
596339.prereqs: Prerequisite: ISDS 361A , 2.5 cumulative GPA for online section registration.

596340.title: C++ For Business Applications
596340.description: C++ syntax, structured programming, table handling, design standards, object oriented programming.

598735.title: Python for Business Analytics
598735.description: Introduction to core Python programming basics, including data types, control structures, algorithm development and program design with functions. Data/information processing techniques and how to glean insights from data under the context of business applications.

598970.title: Fundamentals of Cryptocurrencies
598970.description: The design of cryptocurrencies and how they function in practice, focusing on the following: cryptography; blockchain technology; crypto as currency; interaction with traditional capital markets; investments. (FIN 379 and ISDS 379 are the same course.)

596341.title: Database Management Systems
596341.description: Essential concepts, principles and methods for analysis, design and implementation of database management systems; covers theory and practice; emphasis the relational model; examines issues and problems associated with developing single and multiple user applications both today and in the future; project required.
596341.prereqs: Prerequisite: BUAD 301 ; ISDS 361A for Business Data Analytics minor.

596342.title: Systems Analysis and Design
596342.description: Systems analysis and design for business information systems; systems development methodologies; managing changes to system parameters; systems process and data models; case tool types and their use; structured vs. object oriented analysis and design.

596343.title: Business Telecommunications for Information System Design
596343.description: Essential concepts for developing a data communication architecture to support information systems for a business enterprise. Requires group project to design a LAN.
596343.prereqs: Prerequisites: BUAD 301 , ISDS 309 . Pre- or corequisite: ISDS 406 .

596344.title: Business Applications using Web Technologies
596344.description: Contemporary issues in the design and development of integrated, graphical user interface-based business applications.

598384.title: Principles of Business Intelligence
598384.description: Principles and procedures related to the design and use of expert systems and decision support systems principles in management decision making; development of expert systems using shells.
598384.prereqs: Prerequisites: ISDS 402 with a “C” (2.0) or better; CBE undergraduate major or Information Systems minor; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596345.title: Privacy and Security
596345.description: Security and privacy problems associated with the use of computer systems; ways to minimize risks and losses.
596345.prereqs: Prerequisites: CBE undergraduate or graduate standing; Management Information Systems or Information Systems minor - ISDS 402 or ISDS 309 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598736.title: Pricing Analytics and Revenue Management
598736.description: Provides analytical tools; a conceptual framework deals with how prices are set in organizations. Learn to apply advanced analytics to earn incremental revenue through the efficient use of resources and science-based pricing methods.
598736.prereqs: Prerequisites: ISDS 361B , ISDS 514 or ECON 440 ; ECON 310 , ECON 315 or ECON 515 .

596346.title: Integrated Enterprise Information Systems
596346.description: Application programming fundamentals for ERP systems; accessing and management of ERP database tables and external files; layout design and data extraction for advanced output; testing, debugging and analysis tools; security issues in an ERP system.

596347.title: Business Modeling Using Spreadsheets
596347.description: Use Microsoft Excel to implement business models. Excel will be used to effectively organize, analyze and present information. Examples include operations, production, marketing and finance. Macros, goal seek, solver, simulation and data tables.

596348.title: Marketing Analytics: Decision-Making in the Information Age
596348.description: Applying analysis and modeling techniques to a broad range of marketing decision making domains. (MKTG 443 and ISDS 443 are the same course.)
596348.prereqs: Prerequisites: ISDS 361A , MKTG 351 ; not CBE pre-major or undeclared; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

597823.title: Social Media Marketing and Analytics
597823.description: Theoretical concepts and practical skills used by organizations in developing social media marketing strategies and in generating and utilizing analytics. Create social media content and produce actionable analytics from the social media content. (MKTG 444 and ISDS 444 are the same course.)
597823.prereqs: Prerequisites: MKTG 353 , ISDS 361A (not CBE pre-major or undeclared); graduate student (not pre-MBA) - ISDS 513 or ISDS 540 (prerequisite) and MKTG 519 (corequisite).

596349.title: Senior Project: Information Systems Development
596349.description: Integrates information systems development concepts of analysis, design and implementation. Develop an information system from concept to completion. Individual and team effort.

596351.title: Data Mining for Managers
596351.description: Fundamentals of data mining. Topics may include association, classification, clustering, decision trees, statistical modeling, and visualization. Motivation for the applications of data mining techniques. Use of data mining software suites on data sets.
596351.prereqs: Prerequisites: ISDS 361A , ISDS 361B with a  “C” (2.0) or better, BUAD 301 ; not CBE pre-major or undeclared major; or CBE graduate standing (not pre-MBA); Business Data Analytics minor - ISDS 361A , ISDS 361B with a  “C” (2.0) or better.

596350.title: Applied Business Forecasting
596350.description: Forecasting methods applied to problems in business and industry; practical multiple regression models with computer solutions; basic techniques in time-series analysis of trend, cyclical and seasonal components; correlation of time-series and forecasting with the computer.

598871.title: Data Analytics for Risk and Insurance
598871.description: Overview of the application of traditional and modern data analytics to risk management and property-casualty insurance. Data management, predictive modelling, traditional analysis techniques, modern analysis techniques, smart product technology and data analysis in underwriting. (ISDS 478 and FIN 478 are the same course.)

598971.title: Crypto Creation
598971.description: Create own cryptocurrency and non fungible tokens (NFT) using the Titan Crypto Ecosystem. Utilize the ecosystem?s blockchain to create nodes, Integrate APIs, design the interface, make the cryptocurrency legal and mint the cryptocurrency. (FIN 479 and ISDS 479 are the same course.)

596352.title: Internship
596352.description: Planned and supervised work experience. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Credit/No Credit or 3-unit Letter Grade option. Only 3-unit Letter Grade option will fulfill practicum requirement. Consent of department internship adviser needed.
596352.prereqs: Prerequisites: Management Science concentration - ISDS 361A , ISDS 361B ; Management Information Systems concentration - ISDS 309 , ISDS 402 ; at least junior standing; 2.5 GPA.

596353.title: Independent Study
596353.description: Open to qualified students desiring to pursue directed independent inquiry. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Not open to students on academic notice. Requires approval by the Department Chair.

597814.title: Programming Concepts for Information Technology
597814.description: Application programming fundamentals for information technology systems; structured and object-oriented programming, accessing and management of database tables and external files; layout design and data extraction for advanced output; testing, debugging and analysis tools.

598385.title: Statistical Analysis
598385.description: Basic probability and descriptive statistics; sampling techniques; estimation and hypothesis testing; simple and multiple regression, correlation analysis; computer packages and other optional topics.

596354.title: Decision Models for Business and Economics
596354.description: Linear programming; inventory; PERT-CPM; queuing; computer simulation; time-series forecasting; and other optional topics.
596354.prereqs: Prerequisites: ISDS 361A , ISDS 513 or ISDS 540 ; CBE graduate (not Economics) standing.

596356.title: Forecasting for Analytical Decision Making
596356.description: Time series analysis. Trend, cyclical and seasonal components. Statistical decision theory. Fundamental principles of experimental design; interaction. Software packages.
596356.prereqs: Prerequisites: ISDS 514 ; CBE graduate (not Economics or pre-MBA) standing.

598469.title: Statistics for Data Science
598469.description: Quantitative analysis and data visualization in R programming, random variables and probability distributions, sampling distributions, confidence intervals and testing hypotheses, p-value and significance level, regression analysis to measure relationships and ANOVA to analyze designed experiments.

598012.title: Marketing Analytics for Managers
598012.description: Organizations are increasingly becoming data-driven and are actively seeking managers with knowledge and experience in data analysis and marketing analytics. Focuses on the integrative application of various marketing analytics techniques to solve typical business problems. (ISDS 543 and MKTG 543 are the same course).

598386.title: Telecommunications and Business Networks
598386.description: Developing data communication architecture for a business enterprise. Transmission media, speed, efficiency, protocols, security in a variety of network architectures, such as LAN, WAN, VPN, leading to "state of the art" wireless networks. Technical implications of doing business on the Internet.
598386.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE graduate (not Economics or pre-MBA) standing.

596357.title: Info Resources and IT Project Management
596357.description: Expanding role of information systems in the overall strategy and management of organizations is examined. Topics include strategic value of information systems, management of the information systems development and procurement process, E-commerce, and integrated enterprise systems.
596357.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE graduate (not Economics or pre-MBA) standing.

596358.title: Systems Analysis, Design and Development
596358.description: Systems analysis and design concepts, life cycle and prototyping; planning and managing projects; systems evaluation, selection and development. Interface design with controls, object-oriented design concepts and tools, including the use cases and UML.
596358.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE graduate (not Economics or pre-MBA) standing.

596359.title: Electronic Commerce: Analysis and Evaluation
596359.description: Electronic commerce. Understanding the technical infrastructure, which enables E-commerce. Organizational challenge for developing an appropriate business model for emergence of the electronic business. Social economical impact of electronic commerce.
596359.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE graduate (not Economics or pre-MBA) standing.

596220.title: Seminar in Public History
596220.description: Seminar in sources, themes, writing and formats used by historians working outside the classroom. Content will vary with instructor and will emphasize applying historical methods to various sectors of community history. Alternative to HIST 572/HIST 522 requirement for M.A. Required for M.A. students pursuing the Public History Emphasis.

596221.title: Directed Readings Seminar in Fields of European History
596221.description: Literature that has been important in different fields of European history. May be repeated once with different topic. Requires 3-unit upper-division course in the sub-field of the offering.

596222.title: Seminar in European History
596222.description: Utilize primary sources in writing research papers on European History. May be repeated once for credit with different sub-field.

597748.title: Directed Readings Seminar in Fields of Non-Western History
597748.description: Variable topics reading seminar designed to offer a comprehensive background in "non-Western" history.

598241.title: Seminar in Non-Western History
598241.description: Variable topics research seminar designed to explore non-Western history through a primary source-based research paper. Topics include: Nation Formation in Latin America; and Africa from Colony to Nation.

596223.title: Directed Readings Seminar in World and Comparative History
596223.description: Variable topics reading seminar designed to offer a comprehensive background in the literature of world and comparative history. May be repeated once for credit with different topic. Requires 3-unit upper-division course in world history.

596224.title: Seminar in World and Comparative History
596224.description: Variable topics research seminar designed to explore world and comparative history through a primary source based research paper. May be repeated once for credit with different topic.

596225.title: Directed Readings Seminar in Fields of American History
596225.description: Literature that has been important or influential in specific fields of American history. May be repeated once for credit with different topic. Requires 3-unit upper-division course in sub-field of the offering.

596226.title: Seminar in American History
596226.description: Utilize primary sources in writing research papers on American History. May be repeated once for credit with different topic.

596227.title: Graduate Internship in History
596227.description: Professional-level internship in historical work. Usually precedes HIST 597, Project and constitutes research phase of main graduate exercise, as well as preparation for post-graduate career. May be repeated once for credit. Requires classified graduate status.

596228.title: History Project
596228.description: Editing a significant body of primary source materials, including a critical and interpretive introduction, as well as appropriate reference and explanatory notes. Foreign sources will normally be translated into English. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596229.title: Thesis
596229.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596230.title: Independent Graduate Research
596230.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of department chair.

598052.title: Introduction to Learning and Thinking in Science and Math
598052.description: Knowledge, skills and attitudes necessary for success as a science and mathematics student and life-long learner. Significant reading, writing, and collaborative learning activities emphasizing quantitative reasoning.

607235.title: Understanding Disability: A Path to Inclusive Education
607235.description: Introduction to principles, policies and practices associated with inclusive education. The intersection of disability and education with critical discussions, case studies and practical applications, examining the historical, cultural and societal contexts that shape inclusive education practices.

598878.title: Structural and Institutional Bias in Schools
598878.description: Some of the ways power and bias perpetuate broader systems of oppression and systemic injustice in education. Critically examine traditional practices in K-12 schools and consider ways to foster just, equitable, inclusive and anti-bias conditions in education. For urban learning majors only.

598879.title: Curriculum as a Lever of Change
598879.description: Curriculum materials, including textbooks and classroom resources, represent a powerful lever for education reform. Investigate just, equitable and inclusive issues of justice in urban schools through the lens of the curriculum.

598880.title: Living, Learning and Translanguaging Across Identities in Schools
598880.description: How personal and social identities intersect to create different modes of privilege and/or oppression. From micro and personal self-evaluation to macro analysis, students build tools to interrupt series of -isms (racism, sexism, classism) and build just, equitable and inclusive education.

598881.title: Urban School Policy and Practice
598881.description: Urban education policy centered on social justice and democracy. Engage with theories to explore the development of urban schooling through the social, historical and political shaping of education policy in the United States.
598881.prereqs: Prerequisite: AFAM 103 with a “B-” (2.7) or better.

598882.title: Just, Equitable, and Inclusive Classrooms
598882.description: Strategies providing a just, equitable and inclusive education to all students. Concludes with a culminating project to be presented at a symposium.

598635.title: Introduction to University Honors Colloquium
598635.description: Required of University Honors students. Introduction to the University Honors Program.

597678.title: Honors Seminar in Critical Thinking
597678.description: Seminar for first-year Honors Program students. Developing critical thinking skills. Interpretation, analysis, criticism and advocacy of ideas encountered in designated Honors Program activities.

597679.title: Honors Seminar in Oral Communication
597679.description: Seminar for first-year Honors Program students, emphasizing oral communication skills. Construction, presentation and critical analysis of oral presentations related to the ideas encountered in designated Honors Program activities. Instruction in effective oral communication and critical thinking.

598636.title: Being Scholarly and Creative in an Interdisciplinary World
598636.description: Required of all University Honors students. Interdisciplinary consideration of academic research and creative activities.
598636.prereqs: Prerequisites: University Honors program student; HONR 100 .

597680.title: Honors Seminar: American Institutions and Values to 1877
597680.description: Critically examines the historical development and political culture of American institutions and values from Colonial history to the Reconstruction era. The interaction, conflict and cooperation of diverse groups, with specific attention to race, ethnicity, gender and class.

597681.title: Honors Seminar: American Institutions and Values since 1877
597681.description: Critically examines the development of American institutions and values from Reconstruction to present day, with particular reference to California government and politics. The interaction, conflict and cooperation of diverse groups with specific attention to race, ethnicity, gender and class.

597682.title: Honors Seminar: World Civilizations to 1500
597682.description: Integrative, holistic introductory survey of the historical development of civilization within a global context. Impact of Western institutions and ideas upon non-Western societies and cultures and the influence of non-Western cultures and peoples upon Western societies and cultures.

597683.title: Honors Seminar: World Civilizations since 1500
597683.description: Integrative, holistic introductory survey of the historical development of civilization within a global context. Impact of Western institutions and ideas upon non-Western societies and cultures and the influence of non-Western cultures and peoples upon Western societies and cultures.

598637.title: Honors Proposal Colloquium
598637.description: Prepare proposal for the Senior Honors Project and submit to an appropriate faculty mentor. Required of all University Honors Students.
598637.prereqs: Prerequisite: University Honors program student. Pre- or corequisite: HONR 200

597684.title: Junior Honors Colloquium
597684.description: Required of all junior honors students. Interdisciplinary examination of selected topics. Guest lecturers from the university and community.
597684.prereqs: Prerequisites: enrollment in the University Honors Program, junior standing.

597685.title: Junior Honors Colloquium
597685.description: Required of all junior honors students. Orientation to advanced research and creative activity, including the senior honors project.
597685.prereqs: Prerequisites: enrollment in the University Honors Program, junior standing.

598883.title: Honors Seminar: Contemporary Issues in California Government and Politics
598883.description: California state and local government institutions and politics, including direct democracy and current policies. The role of California state and local government in the Federal system. How the state's history and diversity lead to challenges for public policy.

597686.title: Honors Seminar in Natural Science and Mathematics
597686.description: Interdisciplinary seminar examining selected topics in natural science and mathematics.
597686.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 5A, 5B or 2A;  University Honors Program Students.

597687.title: Honors Seminar in Arts and Humanities
597687.description: Interdisciplinary seminar examining selected topics in arts and humanities.
597687.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 3A or 3B; University Honors Program Students.

597688.title: Honors Seminar in Social Sciences
597688.description: Interdisciplinary seminar examining selected topics in social sciences.
597688.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 4A; University Honors Program Students.

597689.title: Honors Seminar in Lifelong Learning
597689.description: Interdisciplinary seminar examining selected topics in lifelong learning.
597689.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 1A, 1B or 1C; University Honors Program Students.

597690.title: Honors Seminar: Evolution and Creation
597690.description: Interdisciplinary study of evolutionary biology's impact on culture in the context of religious doctrines of creation. Evolutionary theory and religious and philosophical reactions to it from Darwin to the present, including relevant educational and legal contexts.
597690.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 5A, 5B or 2A;  University Honors Program Students.

597691.title: Honors Seminar: Women in American Society
597691.description: Socio-cultural history of women and women's movements in American society. Cultural models of American womanhood - maternal, domestic, sexual, social - and their development and recent changes.
597691.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 4A; University Honors Program Students.

598638.title: Senior Honors Colloquium
598638.description: Interdisciplinary dialogue, presentation and evaluation of the senior honors project.

597692.title: Senior Honors Colloquium I
597692.description: Required of all senior honors students. Preparation for advanced academic and professional study: Senior honors project and the graduate and professional school admission process.
597692.prereqs: Prerequisites: HONR 300B , University Honors Program student.

597693.title: Senior Honors Colloquium II
597693.description: Required of all senior honors students. Presentation and evaluation of senior honors projects.
597693.prereqs: Prerequisites: HONR 400A , University Honors Program student.

597694.title: Senior Honors Project
597694.description: Supervised individual research or creative activity. Work toward completing an honors project, which is required in order to graduate with University Honors. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
597694.prereqs: Prerequisites: enrollment in the University Honors Program, senior standing.

597695.title: Honors Independent Study
597695.description: Study of special topic(s) in consultation with and completed under the supervision of a member of the honors faculty, or other faculty upon approval of the director of the Honors Program. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units.
597695.prereqs: Prerequisites: enrollment in the University Honors Program; junior or senior standing.

596231.title: Introduction to Human Communication
596231.description: Theory and practice of interpersonal communication. Practice in the development of skills for improving the quality of communication is required.

596232.title: Public Speaking
596232.description: Theory and presentation of public speeches, including an analysis of determinants of comprehension and attitude formation; selection and organization of speech materials, development of delivery skills and evaluation of message effectiveness. Student presentations required. Participation in research projects.

598808.title: Communicating for Professional Success
598808.description: Introduction to the social science of communication studies as a practical tool for everyday living and professional success. Key communication concepts, methods and theories to empower students to navigate their individual, interpersonal, intercultural, organizational and computer-mediated contexts.

596233.title: Forensics
596233.description: Investigation and practice in the background, format procedures and evaluation criteria of the various forensic events. Students must participate in at least two intercollegiate speech tournaments. May be repeated once for credit. (More than 6 hours of class work for each unit of credit)

596234.title: Interpersonal Conflict Management
596234.description: Nature, causes and structure of interpersonal conflict; communication strategies exhibited in conflict; and intervention principles for conflict management. Conflict management theory is applied to conflicts within marriages, small groups, organizations and intercultural relationships.

596235.title: Essentials of Argumentation
596235.description: Methods of critical inquiry and advocacy. Identify fallacies in reasoning, testing evidence and evidence sources; advancing a reasoned position; and defend and refute arguments. Analysis and evaluation of oral and written arguments.

598362.title: Introduction to Research in Speech Communication
598362.description: Understanding and using professional literature in speech communication and using that literature to generate a formal research paper. A passing grade fulfills the course requirement of the university upper division baccalaureate writing requirement for communication studies majors and communicative disorders majors.

598206.title: Introduction to Communication Theory
598206.description: Theories and competencies in interpersonal, small group, public, organizational and intercultural communication. Variations in communication processes across contexts are investigated.

598162.title: Digital Media Literacy
598162.description: Introduces literacies necessary for thriving in a digital age. Develop, practice and self-evaluate digital literacy. Learn to effectively, ethically, and mindfully use digital media for communication and wellbeing. Topics include participation, collective intelligence, attention, networking, and ethics.

598526.title: Introduction to Communication and Critical/Cultural Studies
598526.description: Introduction to critical/cultural studies of communication. Canonical theoretical texts and primary methods and areas of study. Culture and representation as sites of personal, social and cultural identities. Vocabulary and tools applicable to furthering progressive social, economic and political change.

598363.title: Quantitative Research Methods
598363.description: Current perspectives in empirical research methodology in the discipline of Communication Studies. Experimental designs, common statistical tests and the use of the computer as a research tool.

597995.title: Sexual Communication
597995.description: The role of communication in human sexuality and the role communication plays in all stages of sexual encounters and sexual development. Interpersonal communication, but includes mediated messages.

596239.title: Interpersonal Communication Theory
596239.description: Behavioral and humanistic approaches to theories of interpersonal communication. Functions of communication that influence interpersonal relationships, including communicator characteristics, information exchange, situational demands and interpersonal evaluations.

598065.title: Social Media and Communication
598065.description: Social media across communication contexts. Interaction among social media, communication and culture. Analyze and evaluate contemporary social media and practices. Requires basic familiarity with social media technologies.
598065.prereqs: Prerequisites: HCOM 100 or GE Area 1C; GE Area 4A.

596240.title: Family Communication
596240.description: Research and theory in family communication. Role of communication in courtship, family satisfaction, family conflict and family dysfunction, with emphasis on marital, parent-child sibling and intergenerational family relationships.

596241.title: Intercultural Communication
596241.description: Communication problems that result when members of different cultures communicate. How interpersonal communication can overcome differences in cultures' perceptions of communication's functionality, value orientations, nonverbal behavior, language, epistemologies and rhetorics.

598140.title: Latina/o Intercultural Communication
598140.description: Explores the intersection of communication and the Latina/o community, including cultural identity or what it means to be Hispanic. Communication between Latinas/os and other cultures are examined from historical, contemporary, political contexts, among a variety of other settings. Requires consent of instructor. (HCOM 321 and CHIC 321 are the same course.)

596242.title: Communicating in Teams and Groups
596242.description: Applying communication theories and behavioral research findings as they relate to small groups and teams. Communication facilitation among individuals in task realization, including interpersonal needs, leadership, norms, roles, verbal and nonverbal messages, and group systems and procedures.

596243.title: Interviewing: Principles and Practices
596243.description: Principles and practices of interviewing processes. Consideration of appraisal, counseling, employment, exit, journalistic, persuasive and survey types of interviews. Case analyses, simulations and community fieldwork required.

596244.title: Organizational Communication Dynamics
596244.description: The Interrelationships between management and communication theories. Microsystems and macro-systems within an organization are emphasized in terms of intra-personal, interpersonal, small group and organizational communication theories.

596245.title: Rhetoric of Popular Culture
596245.description: Rhetorical theories as they apply to contemporary communication events. Various perspective of rhetorical theory are utilized to further understanding of communication in today's society.

596246.title: Rhetorical Dimensions of Sex and Gender
596246.description: Rhetorical dimensions of sex and gender American communication contexts. Explanation and evaluation of the creation and maintenance of masculinity and femininity in American culture from a rhetorical perspective.

596247.title: Processes of Social Influence
596247.description: Major theories of communication concerned with influence and persuasion in society. Communication effectiveness through strategic application of theory to effecting change and evaluating appeals for change by others.

596248.title: Communication in Business and the Professions
596248.description: Human behavior, structural demands and communication within organizations. Applying theory and behavioral research as a framework for generating managerial communication competencies such as interviewing, briefings, conference leadership and intergroup coordination.

596249.title: Persuasive Speaking
596249.description: Strategies and tactics appropriate to leading social policy persuasive campaigns. Analyze receiver variables, progressive use of persuasive materials, question and answer techniques, and the development of personal influence. Student presentations required.

596250.title: Advanced Argumentation
596250.description: Argument as applied to advocacy; logic and evidence as related to analysis of significant issues.

596251.title: Communication in the Legal Arena
596251.description: Review and evaluation of research into communication variables and legal practices, from interviewing to closing arguments. Courtroom observation required.

596252.title: Intercollegiate Forensics
596252.description: Directed activity in debate and other forensic events. Participation in intercollegiate speech competition is required for credit. May be repeated once for credit. (More than 6 hours of class work for each unit of credit.)

596254.title: America Speaks
596254.description: America's story told through the speeches that moved her. Critical evaluation of significant messages and what it would have been like to be part of the American audience exposed to famous speeches and speakers.
596254.prereqs: Prerequisite: HCOM 100 , HCOM 102 , POSC 100 , HONR 101A or GE Area 1C.

596259.title: Nonverbal Communication
596259.description: Physical actions, gestures and changes in the physiognomy that occur together with language and paralanguage in human communication; substitutions for language and modifications of it in varying cultures. (LING 360 and HCOM 360 are the same course.)

598601.title: Sport Communication
598601.description: Introduction to the theories and processes of sport communication. The communication processes of sport fans, coaches, athletes, teams, organizations and society. Application of these theories and processes to careers in sports communication, research and administration.

596261.title: Communication in Interpersonal Relationships
596261.description: Communication in the interpersonal relationship development setting with particular emphasis on current theoretical and methodological issues.
596261.prereqs: Prerequisite: HCOM 304 or HCOM 313 ; or graduate standing.

598163.title: Artificial Intelligence and Communication
598163.description: Theoretical, practical and ethical uses of AI for communication. Practice creating, evaluating and refining AI responses for different goals. The shared history of AI and communication studies. Discuss current and future social impacts of AI.
598163.prereqs: Prerequisite: HCOM 305 or HCOM 315 ; or graduate standing.

598364.title: Communication Theory
598364.description: Various theories and perspectives on human communication. Understanding basic forms of theories and developing theoretical perspectives on human communication.

596262.title: Applications of Intercultural Communication
596262.description: Nature and effects of intercultural communication within multicultural/multinational organizations. Intercultural leadership, negotiation, decision-making and communication competence. Analyze and practice a number of intercultural training approaches.

597722.title: Health Communication
597722.description: Introduces theory and research on communication in health and illness contexts, focusing on how messages from interpersonal, organizational, and media sources affect health beliefs and behaviors.
597722.prereqs: Prerequisite: 6 units in Human Communication Studies; or graduate standing.

596263.title: Directing Forensics
596263.description: Philosophies of forensics education, including coaching, judging and tournament administration. Strategies of implementation of these philosophies. May be repeated for a maximum of 12 units.
596263.prereqs: Prerequisite: HCOM 138 or HCOM 338 ; or graduate standing.

598809.title: Communication and the Art of Happiness
598809.description: Examine and practice how communication behaviors intersect with constructing happiness and wellbeing. Intentional activities related to gratitude, optimism, integrity, forgiveness, coping, resilience, kindness, compassion, social connections, committing to goals, mindfulness and organizational wellbeing - intersecting with relational and organizational communication.
598809.prereqs: Prerequisite: 6 units in Human Communication Studies; or graduate standing.

607231.title: Interpersonal Health Communication
607231.description: Managing physical and mental health can be helped or hindered by communicating with others (e.g., family members, friends and health care providers). Theory and research related to interpersonal issues in health communication.
607231.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 1C; or graduate standing.

596264.title: Contemporary Rhetoric
596264.description: Theories of how cultures and individuals manage meaning in public communication, including speeches, campaigns, print and electronic media. Applies classical, modern and contemporary critical frameworks of analysis.
596264.prereqs: Prerequisite: Six units in Human Communication Studies.

596265.title: Training and Development
596265.description: Communication in a training and development environment with particular emphasis on learning principles, instructional design, implementation and evaluation of training and needs assessment.
596265.prereqs: Prerequisites: HCOM 324 , HCOM 326 or graduate standing.

596266.title: The Dark Side of Interpersonal Communication
596266.description: Social scientific literature regarding the "dark side" of communication, which includes aspects of communication that are poorly understood, understudied and/or classified as destruction, dysfunctional, evil, immoral, malicious, criminal or abusive.
596266.prereqs: Prerequisite: HCOM 304 , HCOM 313 or graduate standing.

596267.title: Leadership: Toxic and Intoxicating
596267.description: Leadership from a communication theory perspective. Leadership dynamics to help gain insight into leadership and the influences.
596267.prereqs: Prerequisite: Fulfill Upper Division Writing Requirement.

596268.title: Intercultural Conflict: Theory and Practice
596268.description: Relationship between intercultural conflict theory and practice. Key cultural patterns that impact conflict . Theoretical and applied perspectives on intercultural conflict across contexts will be emphasized.

598182.title: Intergroup Communication
598182.description: This course explores social identity complexity and communication dynamics in different contexts including intergenerational, ethnolinguistic vitality, intercultural, ability-disability, sexual orientation, workplace, health, and sports. Intergroup theories such as social identity theory, cutting-edge studies and media illustrations will inform class discussion.
598182.prereqs: Prerequisite: HCOM 100 or HCOM 102 ; or graduate student status.

598810.title: Communication Studies Capstone
598810.description: Gives advanced students opportunity to integrate and synthesize what they have learned. Prepares them to be competent communicators in their personal, civic and professional roles and is the final class before graduation.

596278.title: Proseminar in Speech Communication
596278.description: Current research topics in the concentration areas of persuasion and argumentation, interpersonal communication, intercultural communication and organizational communication will be presented. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 12 units.
596278.prereqs: Prerequisite: 6 units in Human Communication Studies; or graduate standing.

597723.title: Internship in Communication Studies
597723.description: On-site involvement with communication frameworks as they function in ongoing organizational settings. Working in an organization and seminar activities. Application for internship must be submitted prior to enrollment.
597723.prereqs: Prerequisites: 9 units of upper division coursework in the major.

596279.title: Student-to-Student Tutorials
596279.description: Consult "Student-to-Student Tutorials" in this Catalog for more complete course description. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units.

596280.title: Independent Study
596280.description: Open to upper-division students in speech communication only with signed consent form from department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596281.title: Research in Speech Communication
596281.description: Research design and methods used in historical, descriptive and experimental research in speech communication. A "B" (3.0) or better is required for credit in the Communication Studies M.A.
596281.prereqs: Prerequisites: HCOM 300 , HCOM 308 ; or graduate standing.

598245.title: Seminar in Communication and Critical/Cultural Studies
598245.description: Advanced historical and contemporary work in critical/cultural studies of communication. Canonical theoretical texts and primary methods and areas of study. Culture and representation as sites of personal, social, cultural identities. Vocabulary and tools applicable to furthering progressive social, economic, political change.

596283.title: Qualitative Research Methods
596283.description: Perspectives in qualitative research methodology in communication studies (ethnography, naturalistic inquiry, case study, phenomenological research, textual/content analysis, archival analysis). Interpretive design; application of standards; data analysis; reporting conclusions.

596284.title: Seminar in Interpersonal and Relational Communication
596284.description: Theoretical and empirical examination of interpersonal and relational communication. Generation of theoretical frameworks and/or heuristic models of concepts and process under investigation.
596284.prereqs: Prerequisites: HCOM 313 , HCOM 324 , HCOM 420 or admission to the graduate program.

596285.title: Seminar in Group Communication
596285.description: Small group communication theory. Small group variables, methods and outcomes, and group process as a learning tool.

596286.title: Seminar in Intercultural Communication
596286.description: Theory and methodology in intercultural communication research. Specific variables examined include attribution, values, communication competence and acculturation/adaptation. Practice in completing original research in intercultural communication.

596287.title: Seminar in Organizational Communication
596287.description: Theoretical postulates concerning managerial and organizational communication. Research findings and case studies relating to communication determinants and organizational effectiveness. Communicative relationships among individuals, the work unit and the organization.
596287.prereqs: Prerequisites: HCOM 324 , HCOM 326 , HCOM 420 or admission to the graduate program.

596834.title: Fundamental Korean-B
596834.description: Continued development of listening and reading comprehension, speaking and writing, and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level. Further study of Korean customs, culture and civilization. Conducted primarily in Korean.

596835.title: Intermediate Korean-A
596835.description: Listening and reading comprehension, as well as oral and writing competence in Korean involving intermediate level language based on cultural materials with further exploration of Korean culture. Conducted primarily in Korean.

598784.title: Intermediate Korean - B
598784.description: Continued development of communicative competence in Korean with a focus on listening, speaking, reading, writing and culture. Vocabulary building and developing grammatical accuracy. Conducted primarily in Korean.

596836.title: Directed Study
596836.description: Supervised research projects in Korean language, literature, culture, linguistics or business. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of instructor and department chair.

598757.title: Korean Culture and Society: K-Pop
598757.description: Korean culture and society, as well as multicultural analysis of global issues, as reflected in Korean popular music. Examines K-pop as both text and industry. Conducted in English.

597783.title: Introduction to Latin American Studies
597783.description: Introduces salient features of Modern Latin America from an interdisciplinary perspective, emphasizing social, political, economic, and cultural trends. Analyze key historical moments, institutions, peoples, cultures, and issues to appreciate the diversity of Latin America today.

598796.title: Introduction to U.S.-Central American Studies
598796.description: Introduction to the interdisciplinary field of U.S.-Central American Studies. Racial, cultural, social, spiritual and political analysis of Black, Indigenous and Mestiza/o Central Americans and their migratory movements, cultural dynamics of diaspora, dislocation and memory in the U.S. (CHIC 105 and LTAM 105 are the same course.)

596506.title: Topics in Latin America
596506.description: Interdisciplinary examination and discussion of the history, geography, peoples and major issues of Latin America from pre-Colonial times to the present.

596507.title: Mexican Life and Culture
596507.description: Introduction to Mexican culture and civilization. Contemporary Mexican society with focus on social, political, environmental, cultural and historical issues. Requires travel to La Paz, Baja California, Mexico and will only be offered in summer or intercession. Letter grade or Credit/No Credit. (LTAM 350 and CHIC 350 are the same course.)

596508.title: Directed Study
596508.description: Supervised individual or small group study as an elective. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 6 units. Requires approval of program coordinator.

596509.title: Introduction to the Humanities
596509.description: Interdisciplinary introduction to the humanities as a set of related disciplines that apply conceptual, critical, historical and linguistic analyses to advance our understanding of what it means to be human.

596510.title: Introduction to the Social Sciences
596510.description: Major topics in the social sciences in order to understand their systematic study of human behavior, to realize the connections among particular issues and approaches, and to reflect critically on modern life.

598953.title: Explore Core: Truth
598953.description: Nature, significance and knowability of truth, exploring perspectives from philosophy, history, journalism, criminal justice, mathematics, engineering and the natural sciences. How is truth made or discovered? And why and when we should we trust the truths that emerge? (PHIL 133, BIOL 133, EGME 133, LBST 133 are the same course.)

598396.title: Introduction to Liberal Studies
598396.description: The natural world as theme, introductory exploration of values and modes of inquiry and expression in the arts and humanities, natural and social sciences.

596511.title: Inquiry and Composition in Liberal Studies
596511.description: Selected thematic interconnections between the arts and humanities, sciences and social sciences through reading, discussion and composition. Satisfies the upper-division writing course requirement for majors in Liberal Studies.

596512.title: Historical Dimension of Liberal Studies
596512.description: Origins and development of modes of thought and forms of expression in the three core areas of liberal studies, i.e., the natural sciences, social sciences, and arts and humanities.
596512.prereqs: Pre- or corequisites: LBST 300; GE Areas 1A, 1B and 1C.

596513.title: Historical Dimension of Liberal Studies
596513.description: Origins and development of modes of thought and forms of expression in the three core areas of liberal studies, i.e., the natural sciences, social sciences, and arts and humanities.
596513.prereqs: Prerequisite: LBST 302A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596514.title: Liberal Studies in the Humanities and Arts
596514.description: Interdisciplinary approach to the humanities and arts that examines their purposes, structures and major developments since 1900.
596514.prereqs: Prerequisites: Liberal Studies major/minor–GE Area 3B, LBST 302B; Liberal Studies major - LBST 301.

596515.title: Liberal Studies in the Sciences
596515.description: Interdisciplinary introduction to the character and aims of 20th-century science, current theories and knowledge, and the role of science and technology in contemporary society.
596515.prereqs: Prerequisites: Liberal Studies major/minor–GE Areas 2A and 5A or 5B, LBST 302B; Liberal Studies major - LBST 301.

596516.title: Liberal Studies in the Social Sciences
596516.description: Interdisciplinary introduction to modern social science in which major thinkers, ideas, movements and problems will be approached historically, comparatively and analytically.
596516.prereqs: Prerequisites: Liberal Studies major/minor–GE Area 4A, LBST 302B; Liberal Studies major - LBST 301.

596517.title: The California Experience
596517.description: Seven themes in California studies. Explores the California experience through readings, films and music, and three writing assignments that ask them to research one topic each in the arts/humanities, social sciences and natural sciences in California. (LBST 310 and HIST 310 are the same course.)

596518.title: A European Tour
596518.description: Interdisciplinary introduction to the development of European civilization in the pre-modern period through an examination of select sites. The geographical and environmental context, the peopling of Europe and the evolution of cultural, political, economic and religious ideas and institutions. (HIST 315 and LBST 315 are the same course.)
596518.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B or 3U; or HIST 110A.

597764.title: Cross-Cultural Social Thought
