597764.description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the variety of cultural and historical approaches to enduring questions of social life, organization, and cooperation. The differences, as well as interactions, between these approaches.

596519.title: Cross-Cultural Humanities
596519.description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the humanities through a series of questions humans have raised across cultures and historical periods. The commonalities of human concerns and the diversity and uniqueness of the answers given to them.

598719.title: Cross-Cultural History of Medicine
598719.description: The diversity of health and healing systems from the early modern period to the present. Employ an interdisciplinary approach to examine the science and ethics of health and healing across a variety of geographical, historical and cultural contexts. (LBST 325 and HIST 325 are the same course.)
598719.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 5A or 5B; junior or senior standing.

598370.title: History of Early Science and Technology
598370.description: Science and technology in the development of human culture, especially the interactions among science, technology and society in ancient Greece and China, medieval and Renaissance Europe, and Islam. (HIST 330 and LBST 330 are the same course).

596520.title: History of Science: Copernicus to the Present
596520.description: Science from the 16th century to the present, especially the scientific revolutions of the 17th and 20th centuries and the interaction between science, technology and culture.  (HIST 331 and LBST 331 are the same course.)

596521.title: Evolution and Creation
596521.description: Interdisciplinary study of evolutionary biology's impact on culture in context of religious doctrines of creation. Evolutionary theory and religious and philosophical reactions from Darwin to the present, including relevant educational and legal contexts. (PHIL 333 and LBST 333 are the same course.)

597741.title: Science on the Silver Screen
597741.description: Representations of science and scientists in film. Themes include images of scientists, the relationship between science and society, depictions of scientific personalities, and the emotional lives of scientists.

597781.title: Science, Technology, and Society
597781.description: Interdisciplinary examination of the relationships between science, technology, and social institutions and structures. Emphasis on developing and maintaining scientific literacy, understanding personal and public risk assessment, and participating in civic discussions of science policy.

597782.title: Food in the Social Sciences
597782.description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the study of food in the social sciences. The meanings of food in the construction of society and culture across time and space.

598016.title: Ancient Eats: Food and Foodways in the Ancient World
598016.description: Food in the Roman Empire and elsewhere in the ancient world. Farming, sustainability, trade, purchasing, processing, production, ingredients, terroir, recipes, tools, the place and function of feasts, and food in myth, cult and philosophy (LBST 341 and HIST 341 are the same course.)

598417.title: Knowledge in the Arts and Sciences
598417.description: Philosophical analysis and comparison of how the natural sciences, the social sciences, and the arts and humanities apply epistemological or aesthetic criteria to assess scientific and artistic activities. Evolution of these criteria in their social and ideological context.

598453.title: Interdisciplinary Thematic Research Seminar
598453.description: Develop, organize, create and evaluate a research proposal, annotated bibliography and research paper on a student-selected interdisciplinary topic. Present the project in oral, material or performance-based form. Satisfies the Senior Project requirement of the Interdisciplinary Thematic Emphasis. Must pass with a "C" (2.0) or better.
598453.prereqs: Prerequisites: Interdisciplinary Thematic Emphasis major; LBST 301 , LBST 302A , LBST 302B , LBST 303 , LBST 304 , LBST 305 .

596522.title: Senior Seminar in Cultural Diversity
596522.description: Interdisciplinary study of the historical and cultural experiences of racial and ethnic groups in America. Student-led discussions.
596522.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Overlay Z; LBST 301, LBST 305; senior standing.

596523.title: Senior Seminar in Humanities and Arts
596523.description: Interdisciplinary study of selected topics in the humanities and arts. Integrates and builds upon previous classes in Liberal Studies. Student-led discussions.

598397.title: Senior Seminar in Environmental Studies
598397.description: Interdisciplinary seminar examining and analyzing environmental problems from the perspectives of the natural sciences and the social sciences. Requires participation in class discussions and written papers on environmental topics.
598397.prereqs: Prerequisites: senior standing, LBST 301 ; LBST 304 or LBST 305 ; or graduate standing.

596524.title: Senior Seminar in Gender Issues
596524.description: Interdisciplinary study of gender issues in the modern period. Student-led discussions.

596525.title: Senior Seminar in Great Books
596525.description: Important books from early civilization to the present. Develops critical reading of texts, clear expression of ideas and integration of knowledge. Student-led discussions.

596526.title: Senior Seminar in Literature and Sciences
596526.description: Interdisciplinary examination of the relationships between literary and scientific communities, and of literature as a forum for the critique, appraisal and assessment of science in culture.

598439.title: Senior Seminar in The History of the Information Machine
598439.description: Computing technologies from the early modern period to the present in social and historical context. How to develop research projects exploring the interdependence and interaction between information, society and knowledge.

598179.title: Internship in Liberal Studies
598179.description: Learning experience for undergraduates at any public or private institution to which a Liberal Studies major/minor or Food Studies minor is related. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596527.title: Independent Study
596527.description: Individually supervised studies and/or projects. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Department consent and approval by the Liberal Studies department chair required.

596528.title: Languages of the World
596528.description: The world's 7,000 languages, highlighting their structural variety, history and use. Preserving the endangered languages and the development of language as a universal human cognitive capacity.

596529.title: Language and Linguistics
596529.description: Nature of language, its origin and development; language in culture, the structure of language and its systems of writing and transcription, and its application to other areas of humanistic and scientific knowledge.

596530.title: Introduction to Language Structure and Language Use
596530.description: Introduction to the nature, structure, development and use of English. How sounds are articulated and patterned in meaningful units (phonology); symbolic correspondence (phonics); rules of word formation (morphology); word history (etymology); and language use (pragmatics). (ENGL 206 and LING 206 are the same course.)

596531.title: The English Language in America
596531.description: American English, its origins, regional and social dialects and role in American history and in such institutions as schools, corporations, government and media.  Requirement for application to English Teaching Credential. (ENGL 305 and LING 305 are the same course.)

596532.title: Speech/Language Development
596532.description: Normal acquisition of phonology, morphology, semantics, syntax and pragmatics in children. Biological, cognitive and social bases of language acquisition. Meets the requirements for specialized preparation to serve as a teacher of exceptional children. (COMD 307 and LING 307 are the same course.)

596533.title: Introduction to Linguistic Phonetics and Phonology
596533.description: Nature and structure of sound systems in language. Thorough investigation of the International Phonetic Alphabet as applied to many different languages including English. Language Acquisition (L1) and Language Learning (L2); analytic methods and techniques.

596534.title: Nonverbal Communication
596534.description: Physical actions, gestures and changes in the physiognomy that occur together with language and paralanguage in human communication; substitutions for language and modifications of it in varying cultures. (LING 360 and HCOM 360 are the same course.)

597734.title: Meaning and Mind
597734.description: Philosophical issues about language and mind, including topics such as meaning, reference, truth, speech act and belief. (PHIL 375 and LING 375 are the same course).
597734.prereqs: Prerequisite: six units of philosophy or six units of linguistics or three units of each.

596535.title: Descriptive Linguistics
596535.description: Sounds (phonology), forms and meanings (morphology), and syntax of languages. Examples and problem-solving in various languages. (LING 406 and ANTH 406 are the same course.)

596536.title: Syntax
596536.description: Sentence structure in human language. Practice in syntactic analysis in a variety of languages.
596536.prereqs: Prerequisite: LING 106 , LING 406 or ENGL 303 ; or graduate standing.

596537.title: Sociolinguistics
596537.description: Social dialects in relation to the surrounding communities. Social stratification, acculturation, language maintenance, standardization, language planning and language change.
596537.prereqs: Prerequisite: LING 106, LING 406 or graduate standing.

596538.title: Language Acquisition
596538.description: Child language acquisition from birth to adult proficiency; stages and variation in child language; comparison of first- and second-language acquisition; current theories of language acquisition.

598785.title: English As A Global Language
598785.description: Surveys the ways in which English is used in diverse societies and cultures around the world. It also examines social, cultural, economic, and political implications of the spread of English for international and cross-cultural communication.
598785.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 1A with a “C-” (1.7) or better; or graduate standing.

596539.title: Anthropological Linguistics
596539.description: Nature and functions of language; language structure and change; classification of languages; use of linguistic evidence in anthropology. (ANTH 416 and LING 416 are the same course.)

596540.title: Psycholinguistics
596540.description: Theory and research on the psychological processes that make possible language acquisition and written language; speech production; and language acquisition. (PSYC 417 and LING 417 are the same course.)
596540.prereqs: Prerequisite: six units upper-division PSYC or LING courses; or graduate standing.

596541.title: Historical Linguistics
596541.description: Comparative method in diachronic linguistic methodology and theory, graphemics, glottochronology, language families, dialect geography and internal reconstruction. Fulfills the upper-division baccalaureate writing requirement for linguistics majors.

596542.title: Changing Words: History, Semantics and Translation
596542.description: Etymology, related problems of lexicography and translation. Recent developments in theory of semantic change as related to cultural shifts. Emphasizes words, collocations, idioms. (LING 442 and ENGL 442 are the same course.)
596542.prereqs: Prerequisite: LING 106, LING 351 or LING 430; or graduate standing.

597732.title: Language, Gender, Identity and Social Bias
597732.description: How gender, gender-intersecting identities, and social attitudes and biases are reflected in the structure and use of language; gender in language: does linguistic behavior influence thought?
597732.prereqs: Prerequisite: LING 106, LING 206 or LING 406;or graduate standing.

596543.title: Linguistic Fieldwork
596543.description: Methodology and practice of linguistic analysis and language description as practiced in the field. Data collection and processing of a non-Indo-European linguistic structure using native informants. Students can take a maximum of 6 units as an Undergraduate and 6 units as a Graduate student.
596543.prereqs: Prerequisite: LING 351 , LING 406 or graduate standing.

596544.title: Independent Study
596544.description: Supervised projects with consent of program coordinator. Topic varies with the student. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596545.title: Research Methods and Bibliography
596545.description: Principal books, periodicals and collections in general linguistics, specific languages and related fields; techniques of preparing research papers and field reports in linguistics. Must be taken prior to LING 597.

596546.title: Phonological Analysis
596546.description: Phonological systems that occur in languages; emphasizes terminology used to describe changes in the system and processes affecting it; problem solving of selected language date.
596546.prereqs: Prerequisite: LING 351 or LING 430 ; or graduate standing.

596547.title: Grammatical Analysis
596547.description: Word formation in a variety of languages with emphasis on the terminology used to describe morphological representation on various levels; problem solving of selected language data. (LING 507 and ANTH 507 are the same course.)

596548.title: Theories of Syntax
596548.description: Contemporary theories of grammar, such as transformational-generative, with emphasis on theoretical problems in the analysis of language structure.

596549.title: Graduate Seminar: Historical Linguistics
596549.description: History of language, including principles and techniques for the historical study and classification of individual languages and language families, writing systems, lexicostatistical methods and linguistic geography.

596550.title: Project
596550.description: Preparation and completion of an approved project

596551.title: Independent Graduate Research
596551.description: May be taken for credit for a maximum of six units. Requires consent of program coordinator.

598774.title: Explore Core: Migrant Lives
598774.description: Differing sociocultural experiences of different migrant groups. How immigration as a process impacts physical, cognitive and socioemotional development of migrants' children. Educational experiences of migrants and implications for schools and society. (CAS 131, AMST 131 and READ 131 are the same course)

597390.title: New Literacies for Academic Success
597390.description: Analyze reading and learning processes, reading interpretation and critical thinking strategies as applied to all types of academic reading; integration and synthesis of academic information.

598152.title: New Literacies for Academic Success
598152.description: Applying literacy and learning strategies to discipline-specific coursework. Co-curricular opportunities.

597392.title: Critical Reading, Thinking and Literacy
597392.description: Relationship of critical reading to critical thinking. Develop critical thinking skills with application in interpretation, analysis, criticism and advocacy of ideas encountered in academic readings.

597844.title: Critical Literacies for Advocacy and Community Engagement
597844.description: Exploring and applying intellectual habits and dispositions across dimensions of literacy. Evaluate and create information to facilitate collaborative solutions for fostering change in the community. Culminating project advocating for local change and action with global implication.

598609.title: Undocumented Youth in Education
598609.description: Experiences of undocumented youth in pre-K to college, exploring and analyzing literacy instruction in order to properly serve this student population in schools and universities. Service-learning component.

597393.title: Promoting Early Language and Literacy Development in Diverse Children
597393.description: Theories of language development. Function of receptive and expressive language development related to developing literacy. Relevance of family literacy as young children begin to read. Choosing appropriate books to foster language and literacy development. Theories of early childhood classroom instruction.

598067.title: Literacy Education for Social Change
598067.description: Guides students through theories of critical and de-colonial literacies, alongside exploration and practice in qualitative inquiry, in order to deeply reflect on meaningful educational and social change in schools and societies. Fieldwork component. (READ 360 and CHIC 360 are the same course.)

598775.title: Global Literacies
598775.description: Literacy experiences of linguistically, racially and culturally minoritized students around the globe and how structural inequalities within education help to understand the relationship between school, nationalism and identity. Draw implications as to how to teach literacy with a global perspective.
598775.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A; or graduate standing.

598776.title: Global Literacies
598776.description: Literacy experiences of linguistically, racially and culturally minoritized students around the globe and how structural inequalities within education help to understand the relationship between school, nationalism and identity. Draw implications as to how to teach literacy with a global perspective. Conducted in Spanish.
598776.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 4A; or graduate standing.

603114.title: Graduate Studies for Equity Minded Specialized Literacy Leaders
603114.description: Introduction to graduate studies in literacy education. Overview of the pedagogies and practices of equity-minded and anti-racist literacy leaders. Connects students to university and advisement resources and tools.

597395.title: Literacy in the Academic Disciplines
597395.description: Teaching reading and thinking in the subject area disciplines, including instructional methodology, assessment, materials and program design.

597396.title: Foundations of Literacy: Teaching and Learning
597396.description: Current trends in teaching elementary reading/language arts. Role of the teacher as a decision-maker in the elementary reading/language arts program.

597397.title: Research in Reading and Literacy Education
597397.description: Introduction to historical and current trends in research in reading, including principles of educational research methods, in order to read and evaluate research in Reading Education, and to develop research questions, apply principles of data collection and write research reports.

597398.title: Linguistics and Literacy Education
597398.description: Linguistics and its influence on reading materials and instruction. Trends in linguistics as they relate to teaching reading.

597399.title: Literacy Assessment and Analysis for Instruction
597399.description: Various assessment devices and trial teaching practices essential for precise intervention in reading/language arts. Analyze a reader, with attention to influences of linguistic, social, cultural, physical, psychological, intellectual and educational factors on learning to read and reading to learn.

597400.title: Literacy Curriculum: Design, Implementation and Evaluation
597400.description: Develop, organize, implement and evaluate appropriate reading/language arts curriculum using instructional goals for students in pre-K through post-secondary classrooms. Curriculum foundations, research, current issues, design and practice in the area of reading/language arts.

597401.title: The Sociocultural Context of Language and Literacy for English Learners
597401.description: Theory and research in teaching reading/language arts to students with diverse cultural, racial, linguistic and socio-economic backgrounds. Methods and approaches for teaching literacy skills. Emphasize second language learners. Requires case study.

597402.title: Strategic Interventions for Literacy Specialists: Practicum
597402.description: Analyze and diagnose reading/literacy difficulties. Research-based assessments, instructional strategies and methods of prevention and intervention. Individual remediation of student. Primary through secondary. Clinical supervised practicum requirement.

597403.title: Roles of the Literacy Leader/Specialist
597403.description: Developing and evaluating reading/language arts programs. Training in staff development and interpersonal relations with teachers, parents, consultants and administrators. Writing for publication, grant proposals and other professional responsibilities.

597405.title: Advanced Studies
597405.description: Synthesize and evaluate knowledge in such areas as behavior, teaching strategies, educational technology, program development, communication theory and interpersonal relations related to reading/language arts, and apply these understandings to authentic professional challenges.

597406.title: Project
597406.description: Individual research on an empirical project, with conferences with the instructor, culminating in a project. Requires consent of instructor or graduate adviser.

597407.title: Thesis
597407.description: Individual research with conferences with the instructor, culminating in a thesis. Requires consent of instructor or graduate adviser.

597408.title: Independent Graduate Research
597408.description: Independent inquiry for qualified graduate students. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Requires consent of instructor or graduate adviser.

598263.title: Mathematics For Liberal Arts Supplement
598263.description: Order of operations, calculator functions, fractions, percent, linear equations, inequalities, quadratics, exponential and logarithmic functions, sequences and series. Degree credit not awarded. (MATH 10S and ESM 10S are the same course.)

598264.title: Elementary Statistics Supplement
598264.description: Order of operations, mathematical expressions and functions. Conversion between fractions, proportions, decimals, percentages and probabilities. Average rate of change, equation of a line and intersection of two lines. Mathematical and statistical word problems. Data entry and use of statistical software. (MATH 20S and ESM 20S are the same course.)

603107.title: Differential and Integral Calculus Essentials
603107.description: Properties of functions. Rules and applications of limits, derivatives, antiderivatives. Integrals. Fundamental theorem of calculus. Differential equations. Requires department approval.

598822.title: Integral Calculus and Differential Equations
598822.description: Introduction to solving differential equations via the Laplace transform, series solutions and Fourier series. Techniques of integration, applications of integration, improper integrals.
598822.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 150A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598823.title: Introduction to Computational Linear Algebra
598823.description: Introduction to linear algebra and computation with applications. Linear algebra: Euclidean spaces, matrices, matrix arithmetic, solving systems of equations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Computation: variables, functions, conditionals, loops and plotting.
598823.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 150A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598398.title: Mathematics for Liberal Arts Students
598398.description: Survey of traditional and contemporary topics in mathematics, such as elementary logic, counting techniques, probability, statistics, and the mathematics of the social sciences. For non-science majors.
598398.prereqs: For students who require a support course: Corequisite: MATH 10S .

598130.title: Geography of Natural Resources: Environment, Development and Conflict
598130.description: Geographic perspectives on the human use of natural resources. Environmental impacts of resource extraction, distribution, and consumption. Resource governance and conflicts related to resource use. Resources and economic development.

598143.title: Immigrant Orange County
598143.description: Migration through the lens of Orange County. Requires research project including data collection (surveys or interviews or focus groups), data analysis and report writing. (SOCI 456 and GEOG 456 are the same course.)

596022.title: Urban Planning Principles
596022.description: Seminar/discussion on conceptual themes and legal foundations of American urban planning. Policy areas associated with urbanization and suburbanization processes: land use, economic development, redevelopment, housing systems, neighborhood dynamics and growth management. (GEOG 478 and POSC 478 are the same course.)
596022.prereqs: Prerequisite: GEOG 361 , POSC 320 or graduate standing.

596023.title: Geographic Information Systems: Introduction
596023.description: Methods and applications of computer-assisted mapping and geographic information systems. Instructional fee. (2 hours discussion, 3 hours lab)
596023.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 2A; or graduate standing.

596025.title: Mountain Field Geography
596025.description: Summer field study of the physical geography of mountain systems in the West. Alpine/subalpine glacial action, weather and climate, biogeography, soils, human impact and sustainability. Instructional fee required.

596026.title: Urban Planning Methods
596026.description: Seminar and Practicum on methods in urban planning. Analytical techniques and basic data sources. Population forecasting, housing surveys, economic development, fiscal impacts and area revitalization. Individual and team projects. (GEOG 484 and POSC 484 are the same course.)

596027.title: Geographic Information Systems: Principles and Applications
596027.description: Integrated computer-assisted methods for handling spatial data, including database design, data conversion and updating, information retrieval, analysis, modeling and mapping. Instructional fee.

596028.title: Environmental Remote Sensing
596028.description: Fundamentals of remote sensing science and digital image processing. Remote sensing principles and the processing and interpretation of remotely sensed data using image processing techniques and software.
596028.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 106 , MATH 107 , MATH 110 , MATH 115 , MATH 115A , MATH 115B , MATH 120 , MATH 125 , MATH 130 , MATH 135 , MATH 150A , MATH 150B , MATH 170A or MATH 170B ; or graduate standing.

598977.title: Urban Field Studies
598977.description: Field-based study of urban geography. Historical development, land use, demographics and migration, landscape interpretation, urban cultures and challenges, and sustainability. Instructional fee required.
598977.prereqs: Prerequisite: GEOG 160 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

596029.title: Digital Image Processing
596029.description: Beginning and advanced techniques in digital image processing. Provides working knowledge of remote sensing with a primary focus on how to analyze and interpret remotely sensed data using image processing techniques.

596030.title: Internship in Applied Geography
596030.description: Work specified number of hours in appropriate public or private organizations under the supervision of its staff and as coordinated by departmental faculty. Meet with instructor by arrangement. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units.

596031.title: Independent Study
596031.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596032.title: Geographic Research Design
596032.description: Preparation for thesis research and writing. How to select a topic, craft a research question, select appropriate research methods, delve into relevant geographic literature and write a thesis proposal. Required of all Geography M.A. students, who are strongly encouraged to take the course as soon as possilbe in their programs. Requires consent of instructor.

596033.title: Seminar in Physical Geography
596033.description: Research in physical geography: methods and contemporary themes. Case studies in climatology, geomorphology and plant geography.

596034.title: Seminar: Selected Topics in Geography
596034.description: Various topics selected from any of the subfields of geography. Chosen topic and general outline of the seminar are circulated prior to registration. May be repeated once with different topic.

598173.title: Political Ecology
598173.description: Overview of the primary literature of political ecology. Examines main theories and approaches and looks at specific environmental issues including environmental justice, urban ecology, land use and indigenous rights, development, agriculture, and ocean pollution.

598191.title: Cultural Ecology
598191.description: Exploration of the relationship between nature, culture and space in traditional rural societies. Focus on plant domestication, landscape management, diaspora ethnobotany, gender and nature, sacred landscapes and species, traditional medicine, and the sustainability of petty extractive activities.
598191.prereqs: Prerequisite: Graduate Level Standing in Geography or Environmental Studies.

598192.title: Southern California
598192.description: Economy, society, and environment in Southern California. Changing geographies of urban space, regional economy and society, regional-global linkages, and challenges of urban sustainability.

596035.title: Seminar in Human Geography
596035.description: Survey of methodology and case studies including: experiential environments; rural landscapes; urban, social and economic structure; geography and public policy; and Third World development. Meets the graduate level writing requirement.

596038.title: Independent Graduate Research
596038.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

603117.title: Introduction to Earth Sciences
603117.description: Introduction to the Earth sciences, including geology, oceanography and meteorology, as well as Earth's place in the solar system. Natural hazards, the interaction of the geosphere, atmosphere and hydrosphere, and the role of Earth's systems in everyday life. High school algebra recommended.

596039.title: Introduction to Geology
596039.description: Introduction to the science of rocks, fossils, volcanoes, earthquakes, landscapes and oceans. Natural hazards, geology in everyday life and geology as field of practice. High school algebra recommended.

596040.title: Introduction to Geology Laboratory
596040.description: Hands-on analysis and evaluation of rocks, maps, geologic time and Earth processes. Natural hazards, geology in everyday life and scientific inquiry.
596040.prereqs: Pre- or corequisite: GEOL 101 or GEOL 110T .

596041.title: Earth Science Investigations for Future Teachers
596041.description: For prospective elementary school teachers. A laboratory and activity-based introduction to the field of earth science: fundamental Earth; atmospheric, oceanic and astronomical science concepts; potential impacts of natural hazards on planet Earth.

596042.title: Topics in Earth Science
596042.description: Public interest topics in Earth science. Alternating topics include dinosaur world, earthquakes and volcanoes. Courses may include integrated labs, lectures and field trips that explore mainstream Earth science issues. (3 hours lecture, field trips.)

596043.title: Earth History
596043.description: Evolution of Earth as interpreted from rocks, fossils and geologic structures. Plate tectonics provides a unifying theme for consideration of mountain building, evolution of life and ancient environments. (2 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory, field trips)

596044.title: Earth History Supplemental Lab
596044.description: Supervised research on topics related to Earth history. Project will result in a term paper and/or web page. (3 hours laboratory, field trips)

597812.title: Directed Field and Laboratory Study
597812.description: Research under the supervision of a geology faculty member. Intended for students who may not have completed sufficient coursework to allow them to work independently, but who are eager for research experience. May be repeated for university credit.

598980.title: Geoscience Peer Mentoring for Student Success
598980.description: How to build and use academic, psychosocial and career support to aid in overall student success. Class participation and optional field trips.
598980.prereqs: Pre- or corequisite: GEOL 101 , GEOL 110T or GEOL 102 , with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596045.title: Earth Materials
596045.description: Identifying rock-forming minerals based on their chemical, physical and optical properties; relating mineral identification to rock lithology and classification; interpreting the significance of a rock's mineral assemblage in terms of its igneous, metamorphic, sedimentary or hydrothermal origin. (1 hour discussion,2 hours activity, 6 hours laboratory, field trips.)
596045.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 115 , MATH 125 , MATH 130 or MATH 150A ; ENGL 101 , GE Area 1A. Pre- or co-requisites: GEOL 201 , CHEM 120A .

596046.title: Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology
596046.description: Description, classification, occurrence and origin of igneous and metamorphic rocks. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory, field trips)
596046.prereqs: Prerequisite: GEOL 303A . Pre- or corequisites: CHEM 120B or CHEM 125 ; GEOL 380 .

596047.title: Topics in California-Related Geology
596047.description: Directed investigations of one aspect of Earth science. Alternating topics include geology of California, earthquakes, geologic hazards of California, geology of national parks, Earth's environmental crisis and California's water crisis. May be repeated for credit with a different topic. (3 hours lecture; optional field trips)

596048.title: Sedimentation and Stratigraphy
596048.description: Sedimentary rocks, including: classification, texture, mineralogy and provenance; introduction to sedimentary environments and interpretation of ancient environments in the rock record; study of stratigraphic methods and patterns. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory, field trips)

596049.title: Paleontology
596049.description: Identification, systematics, evolution, ichnology, biostratigraphy, taphonomy and paleoecologic analysis of fossil groups. (3 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory, field trips).

596050.title: General Oceanography
596050.description: Chemical, physical and geological nature of the oceans. (2 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory, field trips)

596051.title: Hydrology and Surface Processes
596051.description: The impact of surface water on the formation of soils, weathering, surface features (rivers) and groundwater. Applying hydrology as a predictive and postdictive tool on geologic, biotic and engineering problems.

596052.title: Earth’s Interior
596052.description: Geophysical, geochemical properties of mantle and core. Data collection techniques. Impact of internal processes on crustal/surface phenomena.
596052.prereqs: Prerequisites: GEOL 101L ; MATH 130 or MATH 150A ; PHYS 225 or PHYS 211 ; CHEM 120A .

596053.title: Structural Geology
596053.description: Faults, folds, mechanics of rock deformation and elementary tectonics; solution of problems by geometric, trigonometric and stereographic analysis. (1 hour lecture discussion, 2 hours activity, 6 hours laboratory, field trips)
596053.prereqs: Prerequisites: GEOL 303A , GEOL 380 ; PHYS 211 or PHYS 225 .

596054.title: Geologic Field Techniques
596054.description: Basic geologic field equipment. In-class and weekend field projects include: basic geologic mapping on topographic maps and aerial photographs; field note-taking methods; field data interpretation; preparing geologic maps; preparing stratigraphic columns and geologic cross-sections; technical report writing. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours in-field activity, weekend field trips)
596054.prereqs: Pre- or corequisites: GEOL 201 ; ENGL 101 or GE Area 1A; MATH 115 or MATH 125 .

598156.title: Data Collection and Analysis For Earth Scientists
598156.description: This course will introduce students to different data types typical in earth/environmental science applications, and how to plan, collect, analyze, interpret, and report on such data to answer a scientific question.
598156.prereqs: Prerequisite: GEOL 101L ; ENGL 101 or GE Area 1A; MATH 115 , MATH 120 , MATH 125 , MATH 130 , MATH 135 or MATH 150A . Pre- or corequisite: GEOL 201 .

596055.title: Optical Mineralogy and Petrography
596055.description: Principles of optical mineralogy and use of petrographic microscope to analyze minerals and textures of igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks. (1 hour lecture, 6 hours laboratory, field trip)

596056.title: Geochemistry
596056.description: Basic chemical and thermodynamic principles applied to the origin and alteration of igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks and economic mineral deposits.
596056.prereqs: Pre- or corequisites: GEOL 303B , CHEM 120B or CHEM 125 , MATH 130 or MATH 150A .

596057.title: Volcanology
596057.description: Volcanic eruptions and their deposits, hazards and impact on society. Classroom activities and field trips (required) will explore modern and ancient volcanic environments. (1 hour lecture discussion, 3 hours laboratory, field trips).
596057.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 120 , MATH 125 , MATH 130 or MATH 150A ; or graduate standing. Corequisite: GEOL 303B .

596058.title: Planet Earth for Educators
596058.description: Project-based course to prepare for teaching Earth Science in K-8 or credential program. Earth Science concepts, the Next Generation Science Standards, and how to teach using them. Develop lesson plans and activities, and practice teaching with peers. Not available for graduate degree credit in M.S. Geology; available for graduate credit in education program. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours activity)
596058.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Areas 2A and 5A; or graduate (not MS in Geology) standing.

598359.title: Earth Science Communication, Education and Outreach Methods
598359.description: Pedagogical and communication techniques for K-14 and public informal education within the contextual constructs of Earth Science. (3 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory, field trips)
598359.prereqs: Prerequisites: GEOL 101L or GEOL 102 ; junior or senior standing; or science teaching credential; or graduate standing.

598647.title: Coastal Processes
598647.description: How marine and terrestrial processes combine to influence coastal environments. How these processes are reflected in the resulting stratigraphy and morphology, how they impact humans, and how humans impact these processes.

596059.title: Hydrogeology
596059.description: Occurrence, movement and utilization of groundwater resources; geological, geophysical and hydrological methods for groundwater exploration and development. Well hydraulics and ground-water contamination. (1 hour lecture discussion, 3 hours laboratory, field trips)
596059.prereqs: Prerequisites: GEOL 101L or GEOL 102 ; MATH 130 or MATH 150A ; or graduate standing.

596060.title: Paleoclimatology
596060.description: Methods and archives used to understand past climate; examining atmospheric circulation, oceanic circulation and the Earth's energy budget in the context of past climate change. (1 hour lecture discussion, 3 hours laboratory, field trips)

596061.title: Geophysics
596061.description: Seismic refraction, gravity, magnetic and electrical techniques and fundamentals as applied to determine subsurface structure, groundwater and location of mineral resources. (1 hour lecture discussion, 3 hours laboratory, field trips). PHYS 226 or PHYS 212 recommended.
596061.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 150A or MATH 130 ; PHYS 225 or PHYS 211 .

596062.title: Environmental Geology
596062.description: Geologic processes, hazards, mineral and energy resources and their interaction with planning and environmental regulations. (3 hours lecture, 3 hours lab, field trips)
596062.prereqs: Prerequisites: GEOL 335 ; MATH 120 , MATH 125 , MATH 130 or MATH 150A ; CHEM 100L , CHEM 115 or CHEM 120A ; ENGL 301 or ENGL 360 or ENGL 363 .

596063.title: Quaternary Tectonics
596063.description: Processes and products of relatively young Quaternary tectonics. Evaluating surface tectonic features, their ages, deformation styles and structural regimes. Assessment of past and contemporary deformation rates. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory, field trips)

597799.title: Engineering Geology
597799.description: Geology applied to engineering works. Earth materials, processes; site evaluation techniques; geologic hazard analysis; case histories. (1 hour lecture, 3 hours laboratory, field trips)

596064.title: Geology Field Camp I
596064.description: Advanced geologic mapping in a variety of geologic settings. Requires field report, map and cross-sections. Instructional fee required. (45 hours per week for four weeks during summer)
596064.prereqs: Prerequisites: GEOL 303B , GEOL 321 , GEOL 335 , GEOL 360 , GEOL 380 .

596065.title: Directed Studies
596065.description: Directed studies in specialized areas of the geological sciences, such as petroleum geology, sedimentology, optical and instrumentation techniques. Library research and written reports required. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 units. Not available for M.S. Geology graduate credit.

596066.title: Geological Sciences Internship
596066.description: Geological sciences work experience, salaried or volunteer, with industry, government or private agencies. Student intern will be supervised by faculty adviser and employer. (1 hour of seminar per week plus a total of 120-150 hours of work experience)
596066.prereqs: Prerequisites: Geological Sciences major; junior or senior standing.

596067.title: Geological Sciences Tutorial
596067.description: Provides a maximum of 6 hours per week of supervised tutoring or teaching experiences (including office hours) for undergraduate students assisting in laboratory or field geology classes.  Not available for M.S. geology graduate credit.
596067.prereqs: Prerequisite: at least 20 units in Geological Sciences in good academic standing.

596068.title: Undergraduate Thesis
596068.description: Extension of an advanced course, conducted independently by the student under faculty supervision, culminating in a paper of professional quality. Must be taken for credit for a maximum of three units. Requires approval of thesis adviser for first unit. Completion of thesis proposal that is approved by thesis adviser and the Department Undergraduate Adviser for second and subsequent units.

596069.title: Independent Study
596069.description: Independent study of a topic selected in consultation with and completed under the supervision of the instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Not available for M.S. geology degree credit.

596070.title: Advanced Geological Concepts and Methods
596070.description: Current advances in geological concepts emphasizing Southern California geology. Develop tools to construct a thesis proposal: research planning; developing thesis topics; bibliographic methods; research design (laboratory and field); research proposal preparation. May include seminars, group projects and field trips. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours activity, field trips)

596071.title: Advanced Topics in Geochemistry
596071.description: Special topics on modern techniques and recent advances in geochemistry, such as geochronology and environmental isotope geochemistry. May be repeated once for credit with different topic. (3 hours lecture; field trips)

596072.title: Advanced Topics in Geology
596072.description: Modern techniques and recent advances in geology such as basin analysis, carbonate sedimentology, paleontology, paleolimnology, igneous petrology, tectonics and studies of the Mesozoic Era. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 12 units. (2 hours discussion; 3 hours field laboratory; field trips)

596073.title: Advanced Topics in Hydrogeology
596073.description: Modern techniques and recent advances in hydrogeology, such as groundwater modeling, well hydraulics and aquifer analysis, contaminant hydrogeology, hydrogeochemistry and environmental sampling and protocols. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 12 units. (2 hours discussion; 3 hours field laboratory; field trips)

596074.title: Advanced Topics in Engineering Geology
596074.description: Modern techniques and recent advances in engineering geology, such as Quaternary geology, landslide analysis and paleoseismology. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 9 units. (2 hours discussion; 3 hours field laboratory; field trips)

596075.title: Geoscience Seminar
596075.description: Attendance at departmental and other seminars. Discussion and/or written assignments based on seminar topics required. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units.

596076.title: Directed Graduate Studies in the Geosciences
596076.description: Directed studies of specialized geoscience topics not covered by existing courses and tailored to individual student interest. Literature research, recitations and written reports required. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units.

607268.title: Project
607268.description: Complete M.S. (non-thesis option). Generate a non-thesis culminating product (conforming to UPS 330.163). Requires approval of faculty adviser. Proposal approved by faculty adviser before enrolling in third and subsequent units. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596077.title: Thesis
596077.description: Completion of M.S. Thesis proposal that is approved by the thesis committee and the Department Graduate Committee Chair for second and subsequent units. Design, analyze and present a research problem culminating in a thesis for the master's degree. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires approval of thesis adviser for the first unit.

596078.title: Independent Graduate Research
596078.description: Independent research on an approved topic. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Requires approval of adviser and Department Graduate Committee.

596794.title: Fundamental German-A
596794.description: Develop listening and reading comprehension, speaking and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level. Introduction to customs and culture of German-speaking countries. Conducted primarily in German.

596795.title: Fundamental German-B
596795.description: Continued development of listening and reading comprehension, speaking, writing and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level. Further study of customs and culture of German-speaking countries. Conducted primarily in German.

596799.title: Directed Study
596799.description: Supervised study projects in the German language. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of instructor and department chair.

596810.title: Independent Study
596810.description: Supervised research projects in German language or literature to be taken only with consent of instructor and department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596128.title: World Civilizations to the 16th Century
596128.description: Development of Western and non-Western civilizations from their origins to the 16th century.

596129.title: World Civilizations Since the 16th Century
596129.description: Development of Western and non-Western civilizations from the 16th century to the present.

598708.title: Imagining Technology in History
598708.description: How human cultures historically have imagined and represented technology in literature, philosophy, religion and the arts. Examine, through case studies from world history, how diverse cultures have grappled with the impact of technology on human existence.

598818.title: Explore Core: Teens in Trouble
598818.description: Teens in trouble through multiple lenses. The physiological and environmental conditions that impact adolescents. How societies interpret and react to teens in trouble. Apply holistic knowledge to developing personal and/or economic well-being and promoting societal responsibilities to youth. (CAS 130, BIOL 130, BUAD 130, and HIST 130 are the same course)

596130.title: United States to 1877
596130.description: Political, social, economic and cultural development of the United States to 1877. Old World background, rise of the new nation, sectional problems, the Civil War and Reconstruction.

596131.title: United States Since 1877
596131.description: U.S. history from the late 19th century to the present. Economic transformation, political reform movements, social, cultural and intellectual changes and the role of the United States in world affairs.

596132.title: Survey of American History
596132.description: American history from prehistoric times (before 1492) to the present according to chronological time periods. Basic themes that pervade the entire sweep of the nation's history. Satisfies state requirement in U.S. History.

596133.title: Survey of American History with Emphasis on Ethnic Minorities
596133.description: Survey of American history from prehistoric times (before 1492) to the present with special emphasis on the role of race and ethnicity. (HIST 190, AFAM 190, ASAM 190 and CHIC 190 are the same course.)

598709.title: Ideas, Books, And Beliefs: Texts that Changed History
598709.description: Probes a central historical question: how ideas change, by examining the role of fictional and non-fiction texts in fundamentally altering a people's belief systems.

598369.title: The History of Asian Pacific Americans
598369.description: Origins and evolution of Asian American communities and cultures, with an emphasis upon the southern California region, through selected books, oral histories, films, outside speakers and excursions. (HIST 201 and ASAM 201 are the same course.)

598751.title: Discovering My Roots: Genealogy, Family, History
598751.description: The meanings and forms of family in world history by engaging the methods and practices of history research: theoretical literature, genealogy databases, oral histories, personal digital archives, family history rooms. Produce substantive research on own families. (HIST 202 and AGNG 202 are the same course).

598710.title: Baseball History
598710.description: Examines history of baseball through art, films, memoirs, music and fiction. In playing, watching, writing about and contemplating the nation's most creative, complicated and exported sport, diverse Americans have defined themselves and their connections to other regions of the world.

598752.title: How to be a Leader, Ancient Greek Style
598752.description: Introduces major approaches to the subject of leadership in ancient Greece through ancient poetry, history, philosophy, and biography. Discuss and analyze ancient texts to enable students to develop their own answers to the challenges of contemporary leadership.

598711.title: Clashing Steel: Classic and Medieval War and Society
598711.description: History of the global emergence and experience of organized violence, evolution of strategy and tactics, the impact of technology on warfare, and the relationship between military and civilians in pre-modern eras. Topically examines social and cultural reactions to war.

598712.title: Roar of Cannons: Modern War and Society
598712.description: Developments following the introduction of gunpowder. The evolution of military strategy and tactics, impact of technology on warfare, and relationship between war and civilian populations.

596134.title: Historical Thinking
596134.description: Nature of history, history of historical thought and history's relationship to the humanities and social sciences. Seminar required of all history majors. History majors must earn at a "C" (2.0) or better.

596135.title: Historical Writing
596135.description: Research, writing and library usage (including computer-assisted bibliographic searches) as related to history. Meets the classroom portion of the upper-division writing requirement for history majors. Seminar required of all history majors. History majors must earn at least a "C" (2.0) in this course.

598713.title: History, Film and Trouble
598713.description: Historical films can be dangerous, and many governments try to censor or ban them. Discusses historical films that deal with trouble: periods and actions in the past that bring embarrassment and shame in the present.

598900.title: Jazz and Modernity
598900.description: Jazz in 20th-century history and politics; its interaction with literature, film, the visual arts and dance in the context of aesthetic and philosophical movements and concepts of race and gender.

596136.title: The California Experience
596136.description: Seven themes in California studies. Explores the California experience through readings, films and music, and three writing assignments that ask them to research one topic each in the arts/humanities, social sciences and natural sciences in California. (LBST 310 and HIST 310 are the same course.)

596137.title: World War II
596137.description: History of World War II: Films, documentaries, lectures and discussion.

598753.title: Imagining Alexander the Great
598753.description: Ways in which the historical figure of Alexander the Great has been represented and interpreted by writers and artists for over two millennia in the cultures of Europe, the Middle East, North Africa and South Asia.

598714.title: Travels in Time
598714.description: The encounters of travelers with people and places around the world through time. Locations and time periods will vary.

596138.title: A European Tour
596138.description: Interdisciplinary introduction to the development of European civilization in the pre-modern period through an examination of select sites. The geographical and environmental context, the peopling of Europe and the evolution of cultural, political, economic and religious ideas and institutions. (HIST 315 and LBST 315 are the same course.)
596138.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B or 3U; or HIST 110A.

596139.title: Modern European History 1789 - Present
596139.description: Major political, social, economic and cultural developments in Modern Europe: French Revolution, industrial revolution, liberalism, socialism, nationalism, imperialism, urbanization, modernity, the World Wars, Russian Revolution, inter-war period and post-1945 period.

598715.title: Cross-Cultural History of Medicine
598715.description: The diversity of health and healing systems from the early modern period to the present. Employ an interdisciplinary approach to examine the science and ethics of health and healing across a variety of geographical, historical and cultural contexts. (LBST 325 and HIST 325 are the same course.)
598715.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 5A or 5B; junior or senior standing.

598399.title: College Algebra
598399.description: For students planning to take MATH 130 or MATH 135. Equations, inequalities, and systems of equations. Properties of functions and their graphs, including polynomial functions, rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, with applications. Sequences and series. If both MATH 115 and MATH 125 are taken and the student receives a "C" or better in both courses, then the second course is the course that receives credit. If the student only succeeds in one of the two courses, then credit is given for the course successfully completed.

598273.title: College Algebra (A)
598273.description: First semester of a two-semester sequence for students planning to take calculus who are not MATH/QR ready. Linear and quadratic equations with additional focus on foundation-level mathematics to support algebraic properties of linear and quadratic functions, graphs and applications. (MATH 115A and ESM 115A are the same course).

598274.title: College Algebra (B)
598274.description: Second of a two-semester sequence for students planning to take calculus who are not MATH/QR ready. Equations, inequalities and systems of equations. Properties of functions, including polynomial functions, rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, with and their properties and applications. (MATH 115B and ESM 115B are the same course.)
598274.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 115A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596610.title: College Algebra Workshop
596610.description: Supplementary problem-solving workshop in a collegial setting. May be repeated once for credit.

598141.title: Trigonometry
598141.description: Properties of the trigonometric functions and their use in mathematical models. Use of identities in solving trigonometric equations.
598141.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 115 or MATH 115B ; or MATH 115A , MATH 115B (corequisite); all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596611.title: Elementary Statistics
596611.description: Explore and analyze data with real-world applications. Design surveys and experiments. Graphical and numerical summaries. Correlation, regression and analysis of contingency tables. Confidence intervals and hypothesis testing via simulation and using normal, t, chi-squared distributions.
596611.prereqs: For students who require a support course: Corequisite: MATH 20S / ESM 20S .

596612.title: Precalculus
596612.description: For students planning to take MATH 150A. Functions and their use in mathematical models, including linear functions, polynomial and rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, and trigonometric functions. If a student takes MATH 115 and MATH 125 and earns a "C" or better in both courses, the second course receives credit. If the student earns a "C" or better in one of the two courses, credit is given for the course successfully completed.

596613.title: Precalculus Workshop
596613.description: Supplementary problem-solving workshop in a collegial setting.

596614.title: Calculus for the Natural Sciences
596614.description: Survey differential and integral calculus, emphasizing applications for the natural sciences. If a student takes MATH 130 and MATH 135 and receives a "C" (2.0) or better in both courses, the second course receives credit. If the student receives a "C" (2.0) or better in only one of the courses, credit is given for that course.
596614.prereqs: Prerequisites: passing ALEKS score for BIOL, GEOL, EARTH freshmen; or passing MQE score or exempt; or MATH 115 , MATH 115A and MATH 115B , or MATH 125 with “C” (2.0) or better. BIOCHEM, CHEM, MATH, PHYS, ECS majors who pass ALEKS must enroll in MATH 150A .

596615.title: A Short Course in Calculus Workshop
596615.description: Supplementary instruction student-centered workshop focusing on problem-solving in calculus.

596616.title: Business Calculus
596616.description: Survey of differential and integral calculus with applications, including derivatives, integrals and max-min problems. For students of business and economics. If a student takes MATH 130 and MATH 135 and earns a C or better in both courses, the second course receives credit. If the student only succeeds in one of the two courses, then credit is given for the course successfully completed. Six units of credit are given if both MATH 135 and MATH 150A are taken.
596616.prereqs: Prerequisite: passing score on ALEKS for freshman CBE majors; all others, passing score or exemption on MQE, or MATH 115 or MATH 125 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596617.title: Business Calculus Workshop
596617.description: Supplementary instruction student-centered workshop focusing on problem-solving in business calculus.

596618.title: Calculus I
596618.description: Properties of functions. The limit, derivative and definite integral concepts; applications of the derivative, techniques and applications of integration. Six units of credit are given for both MATH 130 and MATH 150A, or for both MATH 135 and MATH 150A. Biology, geology and earth science majors who pass ALEKS must take MATH 130. CBE majors who pass ALEKS must take MATH 135.
596618.prereqs: Prerequisite: passing score on ALEKS; or passing score or exemption on MQE; or MATH 125 with “C” (2.0) or better; or MATH 115 , MATH 116 , both with a “C” (2.0) or better; or MATH 115A , MATH 115B , MATH 116 , all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596619.title: Calculus II
596619.description: Techniques of integration, improper integrals and applications of integration. Introduction to differential equations. Parametric equations, sequences and series.

596620.title: Calculus I Workshop
596620.description: Supplementary problem-solving in a collegial setting.

596621.title: Calculus II Workshop
596621.description: Supplementary problem-solving in a collegial setting.

596625.title: Mathematical Structures I
596625.description: First of two semesters of fundamental discrete mathematical concepts and techniques needed in computer-related disciplines. Logic, truth tables, elementary set theory, proof techniques, combinatorics, Boolean algebra, recursion and graph theory. Must have completed four years of high school mathematics.

596626.title: Mathematical Structures II
596626.description: Second of two semesters of fundamental discrete mathematical concepts and techniques needed in computer-related disciplines, focusing on linear algebra.

598824.title: Strategies of Problem Solving
598824.description: Fundamentals of problem solving via contest problems, logic puzzles, games, riddles, paradoxes. Mathematical content may include symbolic logic, sets, mappings, cardinality, infinite sets, graph theory, modular arithmetic, probability, combinatorics. Requires three years of high school mathematics, including two years of algebra and one year of geometry.

596622.title: Student-to-Student Tutorials
596622.description: Consult "Student-to-Student Tutorials" in this catalog for more complete course description. May be taken Credit/No Credit only.

598825.title: Differential Equations and Linear Algebra
598825.description: Solutions to differential equations and systems of differential equations. Role of linear algebra in solving differential equations. Introduction of vector spaces, bases, eigenvalues. Modeling using modern computing software.
598825.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 107 with a “C” (2.0) or better; MATH 106 or MATH 150B with a “C” (2.0) or better.

603108.title: Foundations of Data Science
603108.description: Topics in data collection, data wrangling, exploratory analysis, visualization, statistical modeling, prediction and classification, and model outcome interpretations; taught through robust computer programming.  Applications include real data from a wide range of fields following reproducible practices
603108.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 125 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596623.title: Calculus III
596623.description: Calculus of functions of several variables. Partial derivatives and multiple integrals with applications. Parametric curves, vector-valued functions, vector fields, line integrals, Green's Theorem, Stokes' theorem, the Divergence Theorem, vectors and the geometry of 3-space.

596624.title: Introduction to Linear Algebra and Differential Equations
596624.description: Introduction to the solutions of ordinary differential equations and their relationship to linear algebra. Topics include matrix algebra, systems of linear equations, vector spaces, linear independence, linear transformations and eigenvalues.

597805.title: Calculus III Workshop
597805.description: Supplementary problem-solving workshop in a collegial setting.

598683.title: Linear Algebra and Differential Equations Workshop
598683.description: Supplementary problem-solving workshop in a collegial setting.

596627.title: Strategies of Proof
596627.description: Logic, set theory and methods for constructing proofs of mathematical statements. A bridge to the rigors of upper-division mathematics courses containing significant abstract content.
596627.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 106 or MATH 150B , with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598684.title: Problem Solving Across Mathematical Concentrations
598684.description: Consists of four modules corresponding to problem solving strategies in the areas of pure mathematics, applied mathematics, teaching mathematics, and probability and statistics. General techniques of mathematical problem solving.

596628.title: Modern Algebra
596628.description: Integers, rational numbers, real and complex numbers, polynomial domains, introduction to groups, rings, integral domains and fields.
596628.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 250A ; MATH 280 ; MATH 207 or MATH 250B ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596629.title: Fundamental Concepts of Elementary Mathematics
596629.description: Structure and form of the mathematics that constitutes the core of the K-8 mathematics curriculum, including number sense, number theory and problem solving.

596630.title: Fundamental Concepts of Elementary Mathematics
596630.description: Structure and form of the mathematics that constitutes the core of the K-8 mathematics curriculum, including the real number system, geometry, probability and statistics and problem solving.
596630.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 303A with a “C” (2.0) or better; GE Area 2A.

596631.title: Vector and Tensor Analysis
596631.description: Vector analysis, including coordinate bases, gradient, divergence and curl, Green's, Gauss' and Stokes' theorems. Tensor analysis, including the metric tensor, Christoffel symbols and Riemann curvature tensor. Applications will be drawn from differential geometry, continuum mechanics, electromagnetism, general relativity theory.
596631.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 250A with “C” (2.0) or better; MATH 250B or MATH 207 with “C” (2.0) or better.

596632.title: Linear Algebra
596632.description: Theoretical aspects of abstract vector spaces. Linear transformations: isomorphisms, matrix representations, change of coordinates, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalizability, Jordan canonical form. Theoretical aspects of inner product spaces.
596632.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 250A ; MATH 280 ; MATH 207 or MATH 250B ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596633.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
596633.description: Theory and methods of solutions for ordinary differential equations, including Laplace transform methods and power series methods. Oscillation theory for second order linear differential equations and/or theory for systems of linear and nonlinear differential equations.
596633.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 250A ; MATH 207 or MATH 250B ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

598838.title: Fundamental Concepts of Elementary Mathematics Workshop
598838.description: Supplementary problem-solving workshop in a collegial setting.

596634.title: Introduction to Mathematical Computation
596634.description: Introduction to problem-solving on the computer using modern interactive software. Numerical and symbolic computation. Variety of problems arising in mathematics, science and engineering. Also serves as preparation for subsequent computer-based courses in mathematical modeling.
596634.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 250B with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: MATH 250B .

596635.title: Mathematical Probability
596635.description: Probability theory; discrete, continuous and multivariate probability distributions, independence, conditional probability distribution, expectation, moment generating functions, functions of random variables and the central limit theorem.
596635.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 250A with a “C” (2.0) or better.

603109.title: Introduction to Computational Statistics
603109.description: Topics include permutation-based inference, simulation via parametric bootstrap, visualization for inference and prediction, Monte Carlo, and optimization for data science; taught through robust computer programming. Applications include real data from a wide range of fields following reproducible practices.
603109.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 237 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596636.title: Statistics Applied to Natural Sciences
596636.description: Introduction to the theory and application of statistics. Elementary probability, estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, variance analysis, non-parametric tests. Computer-aided analysis of real data. Graphical techniques, generating and interpreting statistical output, presentation of analysis.

596637.title: Numerical Analysis
596637.description: Approximate numerical solutions of systems of linear and nonlinear equations, interpolation theory, numerical differentiation and integration, numerical solution of ordinary differential equations. Computer coding of numerical methods.
596637.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 250A ; MATH 207 or MATH 250B ; MATH 107 and MATH 207 , or CPSC 120A and CPSC 120L , or MATH 320 , or CPSC 121 .

596638.title: Advanced Calculus I
596638.description: Development of the theoretical foundations of calculus with an emphasis on mathematical rigor and formal proof. Algebraic and topological properties of the real numbers; limits of sequences and functions; continuity, differentiation and integration of functions of one variable; infinite series.
596638.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 250A ; MATH 280 ; MATH 207 or MATH 250B ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596639.title: Mathematical Model Building
596639.description: Introduction to mathematical models in science and engineering. Dimensional analysis, discrete and continuous dynamical systems, and numerous other topics. Emphasizes deriving equations and using mathematical tools to make predictions.
596639.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 250A ; MATH 207 or MATH 250B ; MATH 107 and MATH 207 , or CPSC 120A and CPSC 120L , or MATH 320 , or CPSC 121 ; all with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596640.title: History of Mathematics
596640.description: History of mathematics through its methods and concepts. Designed to help the student become proficient in writing and reading mathematical literature. Satisfies the upper-division writing requirement for mathematics majors.
596640.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 150B or MATH 106 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

603110.title: Statistics for the Secondary Teacher
603110.description: Statistics structure and form that constitute the core of the 7-12 mathematics curriculum, including: study design and exploratory data analysis; inference (confidence intervals and hypothesis tests); and association (linear regression, two-way categorical tables and chi-squared analysis).
603110.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 335, MATH 338; or graduate standing.

596641.title: Algebra and Probability for the Secondary Teacher
596641.description: Mathematical topics relevant to the teacher of secondary mathematics. Problem-solving approach to different areas including algebra, number theory, combinatorics and probability, while maintaining a historical perspective.
596641.prereqs: Prerequisites: “C” (2.0) or better in 12 units of upper-division Mathematics excluding MATH 303A , MATH 303B , MATH 338 , MATH 380 , MATH 403A or MATH 403B ; or graduate standing.

596642.title: Logic and Geometry for the Secondary Teacher
596642.description: Parallel to MATH 401, but emphasizing Euclidean geometry, logic and problem-solving from a historical perspective.
596642.prereqs: Prerequisites: “C” (2.0) or better in 12 units of upper-division Mathematics excluding MATH 303A , MATH 303B , MATH 338 , MATH 380 , MATH 403A or MATH 403B ; or graduate standing.

596643.title: Fundamental Concepts of Middle School Mathematics I
596643.description: Content background in mathematics to help satisfy credentialing requirements for teaching mathematics at the middle school level. Gaining a thorough understanding of algebra, including patterns, functions and the use of technology.
596643.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 2A; or graduate standing.

596644.title: Fundamental Concepts of Middle School Mathematics II
596644.description: Content background in mathematics to help satisfy credentialing requirements for teaching mathematics at the middle school level. Focuses on gaining a thorough understanding of advanced algebra, geometry, probability and statistics and the use of technology.
596644.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 2A; or graduate standing.

596645.title: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations
596645.description: First order linear and quasi-linear partial differential equations. Classification of second order linear partial differential equations. Divergence theorem, Green's identities, Fourier analysis, Sturm-Liouville theory, integral transforms and their application to boundary-value problems for the potential, wave, and diffusion equations.
596645.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 250A ; MATH 306 or MATH 310 with “C” (2.0) or better; or MATH 250B or MATH 207 with “C” (2.0) or better; 6 units upper-division math, excluding MATH 303A , MATH 303B , MATH 320 , MATH 338 , MATH 380 , MATH 403A , MATH 403B ; or graduate standing.

596646.title: Abstract Algebra
596646.description: Sets, mappings, groups, rings, modules, fields, homomorphisms, advanced topics in vector spaces and theory of linear transformations, matrices, algebras, ideals, field theory, Galois theory.
596646.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 302 , MATH 307 , all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

596647.title: Complex Analysis
596647.description: Complex differentiation and integration, Cauchy's theorem and integral formulas, maximum modulus theorem, harmonic functions, Laurent series, analytic continuation, entire and meromorphic functions, conformal transformations and special functions.
596647.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 350 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

596648.title: Topology
596648.description: Topological spaces and continuous functions, connectedness and compactness, metric spaces and function spaces.
596648.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 350 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

596649.title: Foundations of Geometry
596649.description: Foundations of Euclidean and non-Euclidean geometries through transformations and formal axiomatics.

596650.title: Differential Geometry
596650.description: Differential geometry of curves and surfaces. Frenet-Seret formulas, Gauss-Weingarten equations, Gauss-Bonnet theorem.

596651.title: Number Theory
596651.description: Basic concepts of classical number theory with modern applications. Divisibility, congruences. Diophantine approximations and equations, primitive roots, continued fractions. Applications to public key cyprotography, primality testing, factoring methods and check digits.

596652.title: Mathematical Statistics
596652.description: Introduction to mathematical statistics, emphasizing statistical estimation and hypothesis testing. Theory and applications. Begin with a condensed review of fundamental concepts from MATH 335; particularly, important discrete and continuous probability distributions.

598000.title: Modern Approaches to Data Analysis
598000.description: Nonparametric statistical inference, including methods based on rank and order; resampling, including bootstrap; smoothing histograms, including kernel and smoothing-spines; clustering with logistic and multinomial models, hierarchical clustering and k-means; inference based on posterior distributions, learning and neural networks. (3 hours lecture, 2 hours activity)
598000.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 335 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596653.title: Introduction to Stochastic Processes
596653.description: Stochastic processes, including Markov chains, Poisson Process, Wiener Process. Applications to birth and death processes and queuing theory.
596653.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 335 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

596654.title: Intermediate Data Analysis
596654.description: Simple and multiple linear regression, testing hypotheses, dummy variables, ANOVA, ANCOVA, confounding and interaction, diagnostics, influence and outliers, transformation and weighting and model selection. Introductory nonlinear and logistic regression. Use R statistical software.
596654.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 170B , MATH 207 or MATH 250B with a “C” (2.0) or better; MATH 338 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

596655.title: Advanced Numerical Analysis
596655.description: Advanced topics in numerical analysis selected from iterative methods for linear systems, approximation of eigenvalues and eigenvectors, numerical methods for ordinary and partial differential equations, optimization methods and approximation theory, emphasizing error and convergence analysis and computer coding.
596655.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 340 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

596656.title: Advanced Calculus II
596656.description: Sequences and series of functions. Continuity, differentiation and integration of functions of several variables. Advanced topics in analysis, such as Lebesgue integration or the theory of metric spaces.
596656.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 350 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

598018.title: Short-Term Actuarial Models
598018.description: Typical loss models used in the fields of insurance and actuary. Policy deductibles, limits, inflation, co-insurance on expected loss. MLE, method of moments, Bayesian method for estimating parameters when data are complete or censored. Credibility theory, methods for determining reserve.

598761.title: Long-Term Actuarial Models
598761.description: Continuous and discrete future lifetime random variables. Survival models. Mortality tables. Expected present values of life insurances and annuities. Premium and reserve calculations. Option pricing using binomial tree and Black-Scholes models.
598761.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 335 or graduate standing. Corequisite: FIN 415.

598789.title: Introduction to General Relativity Theory
598789.description: Geometric formulation of special relativity. Vector and tensor analysis in flat and curved spacetimes. Stress-energy tensors. Curvature. Einstein field equations. Applications, which may include black holes, gravitational radiation, cosmology, stellar structure.
598789.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 250B or MATH 207 ; PHYS 227 ; or graduate standing.

596657.title: Advanced Mathematical Model Building
596657.description: Capstone course for students with strong mathematical preparation. Stochastic processes, Monte Carlo integration, differential equations, nonlinear dynamics, perturbation methods, and/or numerical techniques. Develops mathematical tools and approaches for modeling phenomena observed in applications.
596657.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 335 or MATH 370 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing. Corequisite: MATH 335 .

596658.title: Combinatorics
596658.description: Analyze discrete structures, including existence, enumeration, and optimization. Permutations and combinations, combinatorial identities, the inclusion-exclusion principle, recurrence relations, Polya counting. Basic definitions and properties of graphs, Eulerian and Hamiltonian graphs, trees, graph colorings and chromatic number, planar graphs.
596658.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 302 or MATH 307 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

598557.title: GRAM Seminar
598557.description: Mathematical problem solving, professional development, REU proposal preparation, Resume building, Statement of goals and interests, Use of LaTeX in mathematical writing, Reading and analyzing mathematical arguments, preparation and delivery of professional mathematical presentations

596659.title: MARC Proseminar
596659.description: Intended to increase the contact of MARC Fellows with minority scientists of national repute who will present seminars.
