Fellows will read and discuss relevant primary literature, attend the seminars, and meet with speakers before and after the seminars. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 units. Requires selection as a MARC Fellow. (BIOL 480M, CHEM 480M and PSYC 480M are the same course.)

596662.title: Internship in Applied Mathematics
596662.description: Work experience in advanced mathematics through positions in business, industry or government. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
596662.prereqs: Prerequisites: 15 units of upper-division Mathematics courses.

596663.title: Student-to-Student Tutorials
596663.description: Consult "Student-to-Student Tutorials" in this catalog for more complete course description. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units.  May be taken Credit/No Credit only.

596664.title: Undergraduate Research
596664.description: Methods of research in the mathematical sciences through a research project supervised by a departmental faculty member. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 units.

596665.title: Senior Thesis
596665.description: Preparation, presentation and defense of a thesis. Topic approved by the undergraduate research committee. Thesis formatted in accordance with journal in field. May not be repeated for credit.
596665.prereqs: Prerequisite: 6 units MATH 497 (up to 2 units concurrently).

596666.title: Independent Study
596666.description: Special topic in mathematics, selected in consultation with and completed under supervision of instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 units.

596660.title: Advanced Linear Algebra and Applications
596660.description: Topics and computational methods from linear algebra useful in graduate studies in applied mathematics. Finite and infinite dimensional vector spaces, linear transformations and matrices. Introduction to Hilbert spaces. Projection theorem and some of its applications.
596660.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 350 ; or Mathematics graduate standing. Corequisite: MATH 500B .

596661.title: Applied Analysis
596661.description: Topics from analysis useful in graduate studies in applied mathematics. Topics may include initial and boundary value problems, including series solutions, eigenvalues and eigenfunctions, Fourier analysis, generalized functions, an introduction to the calculus of variations, and transform methods.
596661.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 350 ; or Mathematics graduate standing. Corequisite: MATH 500A .

596667.title: Foundations of Numerical Analysis
596667.description: Numerical methods for linear and nonlinear systems of equations, eigenvalue problems. Interpolation and approximation, spline functions, numerical differentiation, integration and function evaluation. Error analysis, comparison, limitations of algorithms.
596667.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 320 , or CPSC 120A and CPSC 120L , or CPSC 121 ; MATH 500A , MATH 500B ; or graduate standing.

596668.title: Scientific Computing and Applications
596668.description: Numerical methods for initial and boundary-value problems for ordinary and partial differential equations. The finite element method. Error analysis, comparison, limitations of algorithms.
596668.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 320 , or CPSC 120A and CPSC 120L , or CPSC 121 ; MATH 500A , MATH 500B ; or graduate standing.

596669.title: Foundations of Probability and Statistics
596669.description: Theory and applications of probability models including univariate and multivariate distributions; expectations and transformations of random variables.
596669.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 320 , or CPSC 120A and CPSC 120L , or CPSC 121 ; MATH 335 , MATH 500A , MATH 500B ; or graduate standing.

596670.title: Computational Statistics and Data Analysis
596670.description: Theory and applications of sampling theory, statistical estimation and hypothesis testing. Topics may include machine learning and data analysis techniques.

596671.title: Mathematical Modeling
596671.description: Mathematical modeling concepts. Topics may include: dimensional analysis, scaling and sensitivity; system concepts, state space, observability, controllability and feedback; dynamical systems, models and stability analysis; optimization models.

596672.title: Parameter Estimation and Inverse Problems
596672.description: Development and analysis of mathematical models in such areas as mechanics, economic planning, operations management, environmental and ecological sciences, biology and medicine.

598180.title: Probability and Statistical Inference
598180.description: Fundamentals of probability theory, including random variables, joint and conditional distributions, expected values, major probability limit theorems, and some well-known distributions. Maximum likelihood, method of moments, sufficiency, Bayesian estimation, properties of estimators, confidence and credible intervals, and hypothesis testing.

597993.title: Advanced Topics in Statistics
597993.description: Introduction to cutting-edge developments in statistics. Topics may include Spatial Statistics, Time Series Analysis and Forecasting, SAS Programming for Statistical Data Analysis, Statistical Computing in SAS/SQL, and Experimental Design.

598648.title: Topics In Statistical Learning
598648.description: Statistical learning methods for exploratory and inferential statistics, computational techniques for inference and applying statistical software. Supervised learning, linear methods for regression and classification, regularization, kernel smoothing, model assessment and selection, additive models, trees, boosting, neural network and SVM.

596673.title: Statistical Computing
596673.description: Numerical methods in linear and nonlinear regression including Gauss-Jordan, QR, and Gauss-Newton algorithms. Maximum likelihood computation, including Newton, Fisher-scoring, quasi-Newton, and EM algorithms. Bayesian computations, including numerical integration, Monte-Carlo integration, and Markov chain Monte Carlo. Nonparametric inference including Bootstrap.
596673.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 320 , or CPSC 120A and CPSC 120L , or CPSC 121 ; or MATH 530 .

596675.title: Categorical Data Analysis
596675.description: Inference for two-way contingency tables, generalized linear models, logistic regression, logit and probit models, log-linear models, model fitting and estimation of log-linear parameters, strategies in model selection, log-linear models for ordinal variables, Poisson regression and Poisson log-linear models.

596676.title: Multivariate Analysis
596676.description: Multivariate normal distribution, comparison of several multivariate means, multivariate linear regression models, elliptically contoured distributions, estimation of orthogonal and oblique factors, inference for structured covariance matrices, simultaneous equation models, classification functions, procrustes analysis and graphical models.

596677.title: Bayesian Statistics
596677.description: Fundamentals of Bayesian inference including informative and noninformative priors for single and multiparameter models, Bayesian asymptotics, hierarchical models, Metropolis Hastings and Gibbs sampler algorithms, model checking, Bayesian design of experiments, Bayesian linear models and generalized linear models, and neural networks.

596678.title: Statistical Consulting
596678.description: Ethics, the communication aspects of consulting with clients, the formulation of statistical problems, recommendations of design protocols, selection of appropriate statistical methods, data analysis and interpretations of results including writing proper reports. Course based on case studies.
596678.prereqs: Prerequisites: MATH 533 , MATH 534 , MATH 536 , MATH 538 with a ”C” (2.0) or better.

597804.title: Studies in Historical Mathematics
597804.description: Topics in mathematics history emphasizing impact of different cultures on mathematical thought and practice across time. Meets graduate writing requirement.

596679.title: Studies in Geometry
596679.description: Topics relating to the high school curriculum from an advanced standpoint, including the axiomatic method and non-Euclidean geometry.

596680.title: Studies in Algebra
596680.description: Topics relating to the high school curriculum from an advanced standpoint including algorithms, fields and polynomials.

596681.title: Studies in Statistics
596681.description: Calculus-based course designed to teach appropriate strategies and tools to effectively address problems in statistics. Project design, exploratory data analysis and interpretation, and effective communication of results.

596682.title: Studies in Analysis
596682.description: Topics relating to the high school curriculum from an advanced standpoint, including limits, continuity, differentiation and integration.

596683.title: Studies in Discrete Mathematics
596683.description: Topics relating to the high school curriculum from an advanced standpoint, including induction, recursion, probability and combinatorics.

596684.title: Studies in Mathematical Problem Solving
596684.description: Problem solving via non-routine and enrichment-type problems from several different branches of mathematics.

596685.title: Industrial Project in Computational Applied Mathematics
596685.description: May be repeated for credit. Students in the Applied Master's Program may take for credit for a maximum of 6 units.

596686.title: Independent Graduate Research
596686.description: Normally taken in conjunction with required graduate courses. Also offered without being attached to any course. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596687.title: Teaching Mathematics in Secondary School
596687.description: Research, standards, objectives, technology and methods for teaching mathematics. Required of mathematics majors for the general single subject credential. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours activity)
596687.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to Teacher Education Program in Mathematics. Corequisite: EDSC 440F .

598962.title: Externship in Single Subject Teaching
598962.description: Eight-week practicum (150 hours) fieldwork in single subject classrooms. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit. Students sign up for the appropriate departmental offering. Requires admission to the Single Subject Credential Program. May be repeated once for credit. (EDSC 449E, ARTE 449E, KNES 449E, MAED 449E, MUSE 449E, and THTR 449E are the same course.)
598962.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to Single Subject Credential Program.

598670.title: Management of Acute and Critical Conditions in Obstetrics
598670.description: Incorporate triage theory and advanced pathophysiology concepts into diagnosing and managing acute and critical obstetric conditions to inform advanced practice in women's health care.

597124.title: Women’s Health Care: Newborn Assessment and Management
597124.description: Assessing and managing newborns through the first 28 days of life.
597124.prereqs: Prerequisites: Nursing Women’s Health Care MS student; NURS 570 , NURS 572 , NURS 573A .

597125.title: Internship in Intermediate Nurse Midwifery Practice
597125.description: Clinical application of knowledge in midwifery practice for childbearing women and newborns with moderate to high risk factors. Co-management and collaborative management. Clinical management of women needing gynecologic and primary care.
597125.prereqs: Prerequisites: NURS 570 , NURS 572 , NURS 573A . Corequisites: NURS 574 , NURS 576 .

597126.title: Intermediate Women’s Health Care Practicum
597126.description: Clinical application of knowledge in Advanced Practice Nursing for care of women with moderate to high risk conditions in pregnancy. Co-management and collaborative management. Clinical management of women needing gynecologic and primary care. (Minimum 9 hours practicum per week)

597127.title: Advanced Nurse Midwifery Internship
597127.description: Synthesis of clinical knowledge and skill for advanced practice in women's health. Residency incorporates full scope practice and primary care to prepare for independent practice as a nurse-midwife.
597127.prereqs: Prerequisite: successful completion of all didactic and clinical courses related to the Nurse Midwifery specialty.

597128.title: Advanced Women’s Health Care Practicum
597128.description: Synthesis of clinical knowledge and skill for advanced practice in women's health. Residency incorporates full scope practice and primary care to prepare for independent practice as a women's health care nurse practitioner. (Minimum 9 hours practicum per week)
597128.prereqs: Prerequisite: successful completion of all courses related to specialty.

598015.title: Fellowship in Midwifery and Women’s Health Practice
598015.description: For certified nurses in advanced midwifery and women's health care, focusing on independent practice, research and/or health policy development. Student will be mentored by an established certified nurse-midwife or nurse practitioner for completion of objectives.
598015.prereqs: Prerequisites: completion of all courses required for MSN and completion of midwifery, midwifery/nurse practitioner, or nurse practitioner certification.

597142.title: Professional Role for the Advanced Practice Nurse as a Midwife or Nurse Pract.
597142.description: Critical thinking and decision-making theory specific to issues in women's health care. Professional, ethical, legal, public policy aspects of nurse practitioner/nurse-midwifery practice. Legal basis of practice, national international trends in women's health care, developing strategic business skills, promoting the profession.
597142.prereqs: Prerequisite: second-year graduate standing in Women’s Health Care.

597143.title: Comprehensive Clinical Practicum
597143.description: Low- to high-risk patient assessment and management through case study and skills lab competency. Simulated patient evaluation/management and comprehensive examination demonstrating student's application of knowledge and skills. A full-year course over two semesters. (Minimum 6 hours per week per semester)

597144.title: Comprehensive Clinical Practicum
597144.description: Low- to high-risk patient assessment and management through case study and skills lab competency. Simulated patient evaluation/management and comprehensive examination demonstrating student's application of knowledge and skills. A full-year course over two semesters. (Minimum 6 hours per week per semester) Requires consent of instructor.

597146.title: Project
597146.description: Identify specific issues/problems in degree concentration; develop and complete project.

597145.title: Project
597145.description: Identifying specific issues/problems in degree concentration; developing and completing project. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 units.

597147.title: Thesis
597147.description: Individual research with conferences with instructor, culminating in a thesis.

597148.title: Independent Graduate Study
597148.description: Independent inquiry resulting in oral or written report. May be repeated with different content for a maximum of six units.

598281.title: Theoretical Perspectives for Advanced Nursing Practice
598281.description: Theories in nursing and other health care disciplines with particular emphasis on utility in practice; evaluate specific theoretically based strategies for individual nurse or patient change and those for planned changes within organizations.

598617.title: Data Management, Quality Improvement and  Evaluation for Advanced Nursing Practice
598617.description: Provides necessary skills and knowledge to use evidence and health data for quality improvement in a health setting. Uses quality systems to evaluate change and common methods used in quality improvement processes.

597149.title: Advanced Evidence-Based Practice in Nursing
597149.description: Reading, interpreting and evaluating studies using quantitative and qualitative methods in nursing and other health care disciplines; develop initial literature review for integrative scholarship proposal.

597150.title: Leadership, Management and Economics in Advanced Nursing Practice
597150.description: Analyzing leadership theories and organizational models within healthcare delivery systems. Principles of change theory, financial management, strategic planning, program development and implementation. Fiscally sound leadership management in providing healthcare for individuals and populations.

597151.title: Epidemiology and Clinical Prevention
597151.description: Applying epidemiological principles and approaches related to health and illness in at-risk populations. Use epidemiological models and inquiry to determine population needs and promote interventions to enhance health-related quality of life and prevent illness.

597152.title: Informatics in Healthcare
597152.description: Use information systems/technology resources to implement quality improvement initiatives and support practice and administrative decision-making. Standards and principles for selecting and evaluating information systems and patient care technology and related ethical, regulatory and legal issues.

597153.title: Healthcare Policy, Ethics and Advocacy for Nurses
597153.description: How national and international health policies, advocacy efforts, ethics and economics impact health care delivery and its outcomes and influence advanced practice nursing. Development of health care policy, delivery models, reimbursement mechanisms and economic perspectives.

598450.title: DNP Clinical practicum: Professional Role Development
598450.description: Supervised clinical opportunities in selected clinical settings to enhance professional role development in advanced nursing practice. Synthesize prior graduate learning experience; focus on evidence-based best practices to enhance safety, quality and efficiency in the student's nursing specialty area. May be repeated for a maximum of 18 units.

607240.title: Advanced Practice Nurse in Pathophysiology
607240.description: Principles of normal body functioning, pathophysiologic and psychological changes occurring with altered health across life span. Clinical case studies utilized to demonstrate the pathophysiologic bases for assessment and management of common health problems.

607241.title: Advanced Practice Nurse Health Assessment
607241.description: Application of theoretical concepts related to comprehensive health assessment of patients across the lifespan.
607241.prereqs: Prerequisite: DNP standing; NURS 641. Corequisite: NURS 642L.

607242.title: Advanced Practice Nurse Health Assessment Laboratory
607242.description: Clinical application of advanced health assessment skills and strategies necessary for advanced practice nursing role in a particular area of specialization. This course is a laboratory course.
607242.prereqs: Prerequisite: DNP standing; NURS 641. Corequisite: NURS 642.

607243.title: Advanced Practice Nurse Clinical Pharmacology
607243.description: Advanced course of pharmacology and pharmacotherapeutic content and application relevant to the advanced practice nurse.
607243.prereqs: Prerequisites:  DNP standing; NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L.

607244.title: Advanced Practice Nurse Primary Care: Acute Problems
607244.description: Theory and research related to the most basic and common acute or episodic problems affecting patients and families across the lifespan. Concepts of quality health care, health promotion, disease management, resource management and shared-decision making.
607244.prereqs: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 640, NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643.Corequisite: NURS 648L.

607245.title: Advanced Practice Nurse Primary Care: Acute Problem Practicum
607245.description: Clinical field study applying theory and research, while developing skills related to providing care to individuals with preventive, acute, episodic health conditions in selected primary care settings off campus. Collaborative management.
607245.prereqs: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 640, NURS 642, NURS 642L.Corequisite: NURS 648.

597998.title: Nursing Curriculum Development
597998.description: A systematic study of principles of curricula for nursing academic programs, patient education, and staff development. Education philosophies, objectives, selection and organization of learning experiences and evaluation methods.

597999.title: Instructional Design in Nursing Education for Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) Students
597999.description: Course design; using instructional strategies, simulation and technology in classroom and online teaching environments; assessing and evaluating student learning. Ethical, legal and cultural competencies for nurse educators. Requires consent of instructor.

607246.title: Common Procedures in Primary Care
607246.description: Clinical lab simulation for common procedures performed in primary care clinical practice. Pelvic exams, prostate exams, PAP smears, IUD insertion/removal and cervical biopsies. Joint aspirations/injection, X-ray interpretation and suturing.
607246.prereqs: Prerequisite: DNP standing, NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643.

607247.title: Advanced Practice Nurse Primary Care of Women:  Obstetric Health
607247.description: This course focuses on theory and research related to the obstetrical health care needs. Assessment, management, and education/counseling needs of women during pregnancy are emphasized. Social, physiological, legal and ethical issues associated with pre- and postnatal care are included.
607247.prereqs: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643, NURS 648, NURS 648L, NURS 653. Corequisite: NURS 654L.

607248.title: Advanced Practice Nurse Clinical Practicum:  Obstetric Health
607248.description: Clinical application of theory and research through clinical experiences in selected primary care settings designed to provide students with competencies in the assessment, diagnosis, management, and education/counseling in selected OB and Gynecological populations.
607248.prereqs: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 641, NURS 642. NURS 642L. NURS 643, NURS 648, NURS 648L, NURS 653. Corequisite: NURS 654

607249.title: Advanced Practice Nurse Primary Care of Pediatrics
607249.description: This course focuses on the study of common health problems affecting pediatric patients and their families.  Emphasis includes theory and research related to comprehensive assessment, appropriate clinical decision making, differential diagnoses, management, and patient/family education of common pediatric health problems.
607249.prereqs: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643, NURS 648, NURS 648L, NURS 653, NURS 654, NURS 654L. Corequisite: NURS 658L.

607250.title: Advanced Practice Nurse Pediatric Clinical Practicum
607250.description: Clinical field study applying theory, research and developing clinical skills in selected populations within primary care settings. Emphasizes developmental needs of clients in relation to family, social and cultural structures in caring, managing care and treating pediatric clients.
607250.prereqs: Prerequisites: DNP standing, NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643, NURS 648, NURS 648L, NURS 653, NURS 654, NURS 654L. Corequisite:  NURS 658.

607251.title: Primary Care of Adult/Geriatric Patient with Chronic Health Problems
607251.description: Common acute and chronic health problems affecting geriatric clients. Theory and research related to comprehensive assessment, appropriate clinical decision making, treatment options and differential diagnosis.
607251.prereqs: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643, NURS 648, NURS 648L, NURS 653, NURS 654, NURS 654L, NURS 658, NURS 658L. Corequisite:  NURS 660L

607252.title: Primary Care of Adult/Geriatric Patient with Chronic Health Problems Clinical
607252.description: Clinical practicum applying theory, research, and developing clinical skills related to the care of adult and elderly patients and their families diagnosed with acute or chronic healthcare problems. Emphasis includes assessment, diagnosis, management, patient/family education, lifestyle modification and counseling strategies.
607252.prereqs: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643, NURS 648, NURS 648L, NURS 653, NURS 654, NURS 654L, NURS 658, NURS 658L. Corequisite:  NURS 660.

597129.title: Advanced Pharmacology for Anesthesia I
597129.description: Pharmacology and physiology as an integral part of modern anesthesia practice. The pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, pharmacotherapeutics, pharmacy and toxicology of intravenous medications and anesthetic gases used for induction of anesthesia.

597130.title: Anesthesia Basic Principles
597130.description: Introduction to the art and science of anesthesia. Provides introductory knowledge and psychomotor preparation prior to commencing a clinical residence.

597131.title: Anesthesia for Surgical Procedures and Special Populations
597131.description: Selected scientific foundations of anesthesia practice, focusing on cardiopulmonary and renal systems.

598282.title: Advanced Physiology for Nurse Anesthetists
598282.description: Cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, neurological, hematological and cellular physiology; emphasizing how these systems relate to anesthesia management.
598282.prereqs: Prerequisites: NURS 542 , NURS 542L . Corequisites: NURS 682 , NURS 684 , NURS 685L .

597132.title: Advanced Pharmacology for Anesthesia II
597132.description: Pharmacology and physiology as an integral part of modern anesthesia practice. Pharmacodynamics pharmacokinetics, pharmacotherapeutics, pharmacy, toxicology of muscle relaxants, narcotics, beta and alpha adrenergics, and autonomic nervous system drugs.

597133.title: Nurse Anesthesia Practicum I
597133.description: Supervised increasingly complex clinical experience to provide clinical application of the foundational principles in anesthesia: 6 hours of practicum per week.

597134.title: Pediatric and Obstetric Anesthesia
597134.description: Instruction and assessment of the anatomy, physiology and pathophysiology of the pediatric and obstetric patient. Anesthesia considerations and case management strategies for several types of pediatric and obstetric surgical and non-surgical procedures.

597135.title: Nurse Anesthesia Practicum II
597135.description: Supervised increasingly complex clinical experience provides clinical application of principles in anesthesia. (15 hours practicum per week.)

597136.title: Advanced Pathophysiology for Anesthesia I
597136.description: Cardiac and pulmonary pathophysiology for anesthesia practice. Anesthesia case management for each disease process and the use of current evidence to guide practice. Regional anesthesia principles and lab. Acute and chronic pain management principles relating to anesthesia practice..

597137.title: Nurse Anesthesia Practicum III
597137.description: Supervised increasingly complex clinical experience provides clinical application of the foundational principles in anesthesia. (18 hours practicum per week)

597138.title: Advanced Pathophysiology for Anesthesia II
597138.description: Incorporates the pathophysiologic basis for anesthesia management, including neurologic, endocrine, and gastro-intestinal care. Integrates concepts of pharmacology related to anesthesia and the application of current scientific research findings in these populations.

597139.title: Nurse Anesthesia Practicum IV
597139.description: Supervised increasingly complex clinical experience provides clinical application of the foundational principles in anesthesia (18 practicum hours per week.)

597140.title: Professional Nurse Anesthesia Role: Comprehensive Clinical Integration
597140.description: The professional component of nurse anesthesia practice emphasizing ethical, medical and legal responsibilities of the practitioner, including various aspects that impact the profession of nurse anesthesia. Review of anesthesia topics for national anesthesia certification examination. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 units.

597141.title: Nurse Anesthesia Residency
597141.description: Culminating preceptored clinical experience provides clinical practice in all areas of anesthesia management. (18 hours practicum per week)

598283.title: Advanced Pharmacology III
598283.description: Pharmacology and physiology as an integral part of modern anesthesia practice. Pharmacodynamics pharmacokinetics, pharmacotherapeutics, pharmacy, toxicology of adjunct drugs, including antibiotics, diabetic agents, antiretrovirals, asthma medications, cardiac medications and antihypertensives.

597873.title: Seminar in Integrative Clinical Scholarship
597873.description: Proposal Development as applied to clinical scholarly work for DNP project. Course requires 95 hours in a clinical setting with faculty consultation. Outcome is a proposal for a scholarly clinical doctoral project.

597154.title: Integrative Clinical Scholarship I: Evidence-Based Practice
597154.description: Under supervision of a faculty project chair. Clinical project on a topic in student's areas of interest and specialization. Role of DNP in clinical inquiry and evaluation, and related leadership. Principles of proposal writing as applied to clinical problems.

597155.title: Integrative Clinical Scholarship II: Evidence-Based Practice
597155.description: Implementing DNP project within a clinical setting, using theory integration and evidence-based change from nursing science and other disciplines. Incorporating principles of practice inquiry, evidence-based practice, and/or practice inquiry. Integrating core DNP concepts and competencies.

597156.title: Integrative Clinical Scholarship III: Evidence-Based Practice
597156.description: Evaluating and completing DNP project within a clinical setting. Incorporating principles of practice inquiry, evidence-based practice, and/or practice inquiry. Integrating core DNP concepts and competencies.

597879.title: Independent Doctoral Study
597879.description: Independent doctoral level inquiry in nursing resulting in oral or written report.

598494.title: Fundamental Persian-A
598494.description: Develop listening and reading comprehension, speaking and writing, and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level. Introduction to Persian customs, cultures and civilization. Conducted primarily in Persian.

596840.title: Fundamental Persian-B
596840.description: Continued introduction to Persian culture. Students express themselves in oral and written forms at a basic/intermediate level about cultural topics, such as technology, art, daily activities, work environment, leisure, travel and multiculturalism. Conducted primarily in Persian.

596841.title: Directed Study
596841.description: Supervised research projects in Persian language, literature, culture, linguistics or business. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of instructor and department chair.

596842.title: Independent Study
596842.description: Supervised research projects in Persian language, literature, culture, linguistics or business. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of instructor and department chair.

597157.title: Introduction to Philosophy
597157.description: Nature, methods and some of the main problems of philosophy. Primarily for freshmen and sophomores. Not a prerequisite for advanced courses.

597158.title: Meaning, Purpose, and the Good Life
597158.description: Introduction to Western and Eastern approaches to perennial topics in philosophy concerning human flourishing and the nature of persons. Questions considered include, "What is happiness?" "What is the good life?" "Does life have meaning and purpose?" and "What is a person?"

597159.title: Critical Thinking
597159.description: Developing non-mathematical critical reasoning skills, including recognition of arguments, argument evaluation and construction of arguments.

597160.title: Introduction to Logic
597160.description: Logical structure of language and correct reasoning: deduction, induction, scientific reasoning and informal fallacies.

597161.title: Religions of the World
597161.description: Introduction to at least five religious world views from an historical and comparative perspective, with descriptive analyses of their belief systems, moral codes and symbolic rituals: Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism and Sikhism. (RLST 110 and PHIL 110 are same course.)

597162.title: Introduction to Ethics
597162.description: Problems of human conduct and moral evaluation: standards for moral assessment of conduct and persons; morality and its relation to mores, social demands and personal commitments.

598954.title: Explore Core: Truth
598954.description: Nature, significance and knowability of truth, exploring perspectives from philosophy, history, journalism, criminal justice, mathematics, engineering and the natural sciences. How is truth made or discovered? And why and when we should we trust the truths that emerge? (PHIL 133, BIOL 133, EGME 133, LBST 133 are the same course.)

598242.title: Video Games, the Arts and Philosophy
598242.description: Introduction to art, visual art, games and game theory. Aesthetics of games and interactive visual media. Epistemic and moral relations of virtual worlds to reality. Ultimate value of game-play and visual arts to life's meaning and purpose.

597163.title: History of Philosophy: Greek Philosophy
597163.description: Origins of Western philosophy and its development through Socrates, Plato and Aristotle.

597164.title: History of Philosophy: Medieval Philosophy
597164.description: Study of philosophies from Late Antiquity through the Renaissance and Reformation. Topics include: Hellenistic philosophy, Scholasticism, and rise of Christian, Jewish, and Islamic philosophy. Figures include: Plotinus, Augustine, Maimonides, Avicenna, Catherine of Siena, Thomas Aquinas, and William of Ockham.

597165.title: History of Philosophy: Rationalism and Empiricism
597165.description: Rationalism of Descartes, Spinoza and Leibniz, and the empiricism of Locke, Berkeley and Hume.

597166.title: History of Philosophy: Kant and the 19th Century
597166.description: Rationalism and empiricism as a background to Kant. Revolutionary aspects of Kant's critical philosophy. Subsequent trends in 19th century philosophy, emphasizing such figures as Hegel, Schopenhauer, Marx, Mill, Kierkegaard and Nietzsche.

597167.title: Gender and Sexuality Studies
597167.description: Interdisciplinary introduction to women's issues and research in relevant disciplines. (GSS 302 and PHIL 302 are the same course.)

597168.title: Introduction to the Philosophy of Science
597168.description: The ongoing debates within philosophy of science about the claims of scientific progress, and the limits of scientific knowledge and the scientific method, with an eye on the impact of science on society and of society on science.
597168.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 5A or 5B; or lower-division philosophy course.

597169.title: Aesthetics: Philosophy of Art and Beauty
597169.description: Conditions and aims of art and of aesthetic experience.

597170.title: Business and Professional Ethics
597170.description: Nature and limits of the moral rights and responsibilities of business and the professions (including law, medicine, science, engineering, journalism, management and teaching).

597171.title: Environmental Ethics
597171.description: Conceptual and moral foundations of environmental ethics, focusing on ecosystem and wildlife conservation policies, animal rights, a land ethic, competing policy analyses and obligations to future generations.

597172.title: Medical Ethics
597172.description: Ethical issues raised by recent technical developments in medicine and of the moral rights and responsibilities of patients and health-care professionals.

597173.title: Philosophical Argument and Writing
597173.description: Philosophical concepts, distinctions and methods are used to teach philosophical and argumentative writing that is clear, critical, expressive and precise. Designed to satisfy the classroom portion of the upper-division writing requirement for philosophy majors.

598415.title: Contemporary Moral Issues
598415.description: Applying ethical and social/political theories to contemporary moral problems. Topics selected from current issues in law, business, medicine, sexual morality, and gender/multicultural studies, including abortion, racism, crime, punishment, welfare, domestic violence and pornography.

603105.title: Ethics, Artificial Intelligence and Robots
603105.description: Ethical issues related to technological advancements of AI and robotics. Topics include: AI?s accountability, transparency, implicit biases, value alignment; robots? ethical guidelines and potential moral/legal status; and possible massive human job displacement resulting from AI and robotics.

597175.title: Existentialism
597175.description: Introduction to existentialist perspectives on freedom, meaning, responsibility, authenticity and self-deception. Typically includes discussion of Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Heidegger and Sartre.

597177.title: Philosophy of Sex and Love
597177.description: Philosophical approaches to love, friendship, marriage and eroticism. Nature of love, relationship between sexuality and love, gender roles and gender equality. Investigates ethical and legal controversies in sexuality, marriage and privacy.

597178.title: Evolution and Creation
597178.description: Interdisciplinary study of evolutionary biology's impact on culture in context of religious doctrines of creation. Evolutionary theory and religious and philosophical reactions from Darwin to the present, including relevant educational and legal contexts. (PHIL 333 and LBST 333 are the same course.)

597179.title: Philosophy of Feminism
597179.description: Philosophical speculations on how the difference of gender and sex is relevant to every area of human life. What does it mean to be a woman, to be the gender and embodiment of female?  What do women know? (PHIL 343 and GSS 343 are the same course.)
597179.prereqs: Prerequisite: three units of philosophy or gender and sexuality studies.

597180.title: Social and Political Philosophy
597180.description: Individualism, community, freedom, authority, justice, human rights and alienation, from the perspective of social and political theory.

597181.title: Philosophy, Literature and Cinema
597181.description: Aesthetics of literature and film, emphasizing how storytelling deepens our imagination and understanding of identity, culture, society and values through use of word and image.

597182.title: Asian Philosophy
597182.description: Asian philosophies such as Taoism, Confucianism and Buddhism (especially Zen): world views, conceptions of human nature and the good life. Applications to martial and non-martial arts. Comparisons with Western philosophies, religions and values.

597183.title: Philosophy and Law in America
597183.description: Moral issues in American law, including free speech, affirmative action and punishment. Influence of politics on legal reasoning and the Constitution. Tension between legal reasoning and equal treatment under the law, and how philosophical theories of law respond to this.
597183.prereqs: Prerequisites: completion of GE Area 1A, 1B or 3B.

597184.title: First Course in Symbolic Logic
597184.description: Recognition and construction of correct deductions in the sentential logic and the first-order predicate calculus.

597185.title: Meaning and Mind
597185.description: Philosophical issues about language and mind, including topics such as meaning, reference, truth, speech act and belief. (PHIL 375 and LING 375 are the same course).
597185.prereqs: Prerequisite: six units of philosophy or six units of linguistics or three units of each.

597186.title: Philosophical Approaches to Race, Class, and Gender
597186.description: Despite the history of analyzing race, class, and gender as separate phenomena, the three are integrally connected. Focus on the interstitial connections among the three to gain knowledge of the formation of race, class and gender.

597187.title: American Philosophy
597187.description: Examines and critiques significant philosophical themes, texts, and trends in the philosophy of the Americas in the late 19th and early 20th century, especially the classical pragmatists (e.g. Peirce, James, Dewey, Addams, DuBois), and their contemporary interpreters (e.g. Misak, Haack, Talisse).

597189.title: Marx and Marxism
597189.description: Marx and his followers in philosophical perspective. Theories of human nature, society and intellectual activity; conceptual tools for the analysis of social phenomena; sources; and followers, both critical and dogmatic.

597190.title: Postmodernism
597190.description: Such modern and post-modern movements as phenomenology, hermeneutics, critical theory, post-structuralism, deconstruction, the Frankfurt school and French feminism; influences of these movements on political, literary and psychoanalytic theory.

597191.title: Directed Study
597191.description: Supervised individual study as an elective. May be repeated with different content for a maximum of 6 units. No more than 3 units may be taken with any one adviser in any one semester. Requires approval of department.

597192.title: Ethical Theory
597192.description: Major ethical theories as advanced by such authors as Aristotle, Kant, Mill and Rawls.

597193.title: Metaphysics
597193.description: Metaphysics and metaphysical issues such as reality, universals, space, time, substance, identity and difference, causality, permanence and change, freedom and determinism, minds and bodies.

597194.title: Phenomenology
597194.description: Ephemeral structure of experience and subjectivity. Conceptualizations of the subject, consciousness, embodiment and engagement with the world. Primary figures include Edmund Husserl, Martin Heidegger and Maurice Merleau-Ponty.
597194.prereqs: Prerequisite: PHIL 315 ; any lower-level course in philosophy.

598963.title: Second Semester Student Teaching
598963.description: A 450-hour practicum in a single subject in public schools. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit. Departmental course offerings are: ARTE 449I, EDSC 449I, KNES 449I, MAED 449I, MUSE 449I, THTR 449I.

596688.title: Seminar in Secondary Teaching
596688.description: See description under Department of Secondary Education.

596689.title: Independent Study
596689.description: Special topic in mathematics education, selected in consultation with and completed under supervision of the instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596690.title: Teaching Problem Solving in Middle School Mathematics
596690.description: Seminar to explore techniques of problem-solving for mathematics teachers of grades 5-9. Review of research on problem solving at the middle school level. Review of state and national documents on middle school mathematics education. Emphasis on problem-solving in algebra, geometry, and probability.
596690.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 403B ; or Secondary Education or Transformative in Secondary Education graduate standing.

596691.title: Teaching Mathematics at the College Level
596691.description: Strengthens student effectiveness in teaching mathematics at the college level. Strategies that promote student engagement, collaboration, retention and success, as well as appropriate use of technologies.

596552.title: Business and Its Legal Environment
596552.description: Federal, state and international laws and ethical issues affecting business, including the legal system, litigation and alternative dispute resolution, the Constitution, torts, criminal law, contracts, various forms of business organizations, employment laws and discrimination, and consumer and environmental protection.

596553.title: Family Business Dynamics
596553.description: The unique challenge of managing and growing family businesses. Explore strategic, organizational and interpersonal issues associated with family businesses through real-world cases and projects. Requires completion of lower-division business core.
596553.prereqs: Prerequisite: not an CBE premajor or Undecided/undeclared major. Not eligible for graduate credit.

596554.title: Managing Operations
596554.description: Integrates selected general management concepts with operations management concepts and techniques. Emphasizes the development of competencies required for effective planning, designing, operating, controlling and improving processes that produce and deliver quality goods and services.
596554.prereqs: Co-requisites: BUAD 301 , ISDS 361A ; International Business major - BUAD 301 ; Business Minor - MGMT 246 .

596555.title: Organizational Behavior
596555.description: Individual, group and organizational influences on human behavior in organizations. Topics include personality and emotions, motivation, decision-making, group and team effectiveness, leadership, power and politics, organizational culture and change.
596555.prereqs: Co-requisites: BUAD 301 , ISDS 361A ; International Business major - BUAD 301 ; Business Minor - MGMT 246 .

598400.title: Human Resource Management
598400.description: Human resource management functions in organizations. Topics include selection, recruiting, training, compensation and performance appraisal.
598400.prereqs: Prerequisites: CBE (not pre-business) major BUAD 301 with a “C” (2.0) or better; other major BUAD 210 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

596556.title: International Law for Business
596556.description: International laws and ethical issues affecting businesses including: the WTO and UN; international agreements, treaties and regional organizations (e.g., EU, NAFTA); international contracts; and national and international regulation of imports, exports and competition.

596557.title: Commercial Law
596557.description: Philosophy, institutions and role of law and ethical considerations in commercial transactions. Case studies in sales, storage and shipment of goods, commercial paper, debtor and creditor rights and remedies, bankruptcy, secured transactions and suretyship.

596558.title: Law for Small Business
596558.description: Federal and state laws and ethical issues affecting small businesses (e.g., sole proprietorships), including litigation involving negligence, product liability, discrimination, consumer protection and workers' compensation claims.

596559.title: International Business and Management
596559.description: Fundamental course in international business and international management. Overview of international business, and emphasizes a managerial approach that involves examining the various roles of managers in an international setting.

598431.title: Entertainment Business
598431.description: Business and management aspects of media-based (film, television, etc.) and ground-based (live theater, sports, etc.) entertainment enterprises.
598431.prereqs: Prerequisites: business majors (no pre-business), MGMT 246 ; all non-business majors, BUAD 210 or MGMT 246 .

596560.title: Operations Planning and Control
596560.description: Analytical approach to explore planning and scheduling material, capital and human resources to meet customer demand. Topics include master scheduling, material requirements planning/ERP, production activity control, inventory management, warehouse management and physical distribution.
596560.prereqs: Prerequisites: MGMT 339 ; not CBE pre-major or undeclared major; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596561.title: Purchasing and Supply Management
596561.description: Operational and strategic role of purchasing/supply management in organizations. Develops skills and knowledge in supplier selection/evaluation, negotiation, cost/price analysis, contract management, global sourcing, commodity analysis, value analysis. Exercises, cases, guest speakers.
596561.prereqs: Prerequisites: MGMT 339 ; not CBE pre-major or undeclared major; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596562.title: Quality Management
596562.description: Measurement and improvement of productivity and quality in organizations. Problem-solving and process management tools. Case analyses and research projects address issues of people and technology. How to improve your organization: manufacturing or service, department or company.
596562.prereqs: Prerequisites: MGMT 339 ; not CBE pre-major or undeclared major; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598766.title: Logistics Management
598766.description: Foundational concepts and current issues in logistics management with an emphasis on transportation management. Topics include modes of transportation, reverse logistics, sustainability, network/facility location, delivery planning, e-commerce logistics, warehouse management and finance in logistics.
598766.prereqs: Prerequisite: MGMT 339 ; or CBE (not pre-MBA) graduate standing.

596563.title: Supply Chain Management
596563.description: Managing materials, capital and information flows throughout multiple organizations in a supply chain from acquisition of materials to delivery of finished goods and services to the final customers. Presentation and case studies on various issues in supply chain management.
596563.prereqs: Prerequisites: MGMT 339 ; not CBE pre-major or undeclared major; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596564.title: Staffing
596564.description: Theories and techniques related to employee staffing. Topics include the planning, legal issues, job analysis, measurement, internal and external recruitment and selection, and decision-making.
596564.prereqs: Prerequisites: MGMT 343 , PSYC 391 , POSC 422 or CRJU 422 with a “D” (1.0) or better; CBE major (not pre-major) or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596565.title: Compensation
596565.description: Developing equitable compensation and benefit programs in order to retain a productive workforce. Topics include job analysis and evaluation, pay structures, salary survey, individual compensation, incentive systems and benefits.
596565.prereqs: Prerequisites: ISDS 361A with a “C” (2.0) or better or MGMT 343 , PSYC 391 , POSC 422 or CRJU 422 with a “D” (1.0) or better; CBE major (not pre-major) or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596566.title: Management of Service Organizations
596566.description: Develop skills to successfully manage service businesses. Topics include managing service firms through integration with operations, strategy, marketing, technology and organizational issues. Provides theory, tools and experiential insight into how these aspects can be successfully used in a service-oriented business.
596566.prereqs: Prerequisites: Business Administration major - MGMT 339 ; International Business major - BUAD 301 ; or CBE (not pre-MBA) graduate standing.

596567.title: Training and Development
596567.description: Theoretical and practical issues involved in designing and implementing training and development programs in work organizations. Topics include planning, designing and delivering training interventions, and evaluating training effectiveness.
596567.prereqs: Prerequisites: MGMT 343 , PSYC 391 , POSC 422 or CRJU 422 with a “D” (1.0) or better; CBE major (not pre-major) or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596568.title: Business and Society
596568.description: Open to nonbusiness majors. Analyze and interpret real-world interrelationships between firms and their external environments. Contemporary and emerging trends in areas, such as technology, politics, economics, natural environment, business ethics and other societal aspects.
596568.prereqs: Prerequisites: MGMT 339 , MGMT 340 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing and not pre-MBA.

596569.title: Labor-Management Relations
596569.description: Impact of labor-management relations upon labor, management and the public. Proper grievance procedure, collective bargaining and settlement of disputes.
596569.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE(not pre-business) major - BUAD 301 with a “C” (2.0) or better; other major - BUAD 210 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

596571.title: Team Leadership Skills
596571.description: Interpersonal skills required to lead teams effectively. Topics include self-awareness, managing stress, creative problem-solving, communicating supportively, effective use of power and influence, motivating others, managing conflict, empowering employees, building effective teams, leading positive change.
596571.prereqs: Prerequisites: MGMT 339 , MGMT 340 ; CBE major, not pre-major; or Communications major; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596572.title: Project Management
596572.description: Principles and techniques of effective project management. Managerial, organizational and behavioral concepts, as well as effective tools, techniques and software for planning, communications, coordination and control of the project.
596572.prereqs: Prerequisites: MGMT 339 ; CBE major (not pre-major); or Civil and Environmental Engineering or Environmental Studies major; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596573.title: Employment Law
596573.description: Federal and state laws, and ethical issues affecting employment relationships and discrimination. Topics include the laws of agency and employees, independent contractors, the hiring process and procedures, wages, hours, benefits, termination of employment, OSHA and workers' compensation.
596573.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE(not pre-business) major - BUAD 301 with a “C” (2.0) or better; other major - BUAD 210 with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

596574.title: Entertainment Business Law
596574.description: Overview of entertainment industry legal issues in media, publishing, recording and hospitality enterprises. Topics include intellectual property, contracts, labor union representation and government regulation.
596574.prereqs: Prerequisites: Business major (not pre-business) - MGMT 246 ; non-business major - BUAD 210 or MGMT 246 ; or CBE graduate standing (not pre-MBA).

596575.title: Internet Legal Issues
596575.description: Federal, state and international laws and ethical issues affecting business and the Internet/information technology, including intellectual property (patents, copyrights, trademarks and trade secrets), e-commerce, online contracting, taxation, privacy, obscenity, defamation, information security and network crimes.
596575.prereqs: Prerequisites: MGMT 246 ; CBE major (not premajor); or Communications or Theatre major; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596576.title: Seminar in Strategic Management
596576.description: Integrative cases from top management viewpoint. Analyze the firm's internal and external environment. Formulate strategic decisions to develop and sustain competitive advantage. Implement strategic decisions, organization design and control.
596576.prereqs: Prereq: BUAD 301 , FIN 320 , MGMT 339 , MGMT 340 , ISDS 361A , MKTG 351 with “C” (2.0) or better; no CBE pre-major; or grad standing (no pre-MBA). Coreq: ECON 315 or ECON 320 ; ISDS 351 , ISDS 361B . ISDS 351 exempt: ACCT/ACCT and Bus Analytics conc; Jt Emphases

598926.title: Managing Enterprises in Technology-Intensive Environments
598926.description: The course is designed for future managers and entrepreneurs who will work in technology-intensive environments. This course introduces conceptual models and frameworks to enable more effective decision making, resource allocation and performance assessment in such dynamic and complex environments.
598926.prereqs: Prerequisite: ISDS 351 , MGMT 339 , MGMT 340 ; or CBE graduate standing (not pre-MBA)

596577.title: Cross-Cultural Management
596577.description: Develop a more comprehensive understanding of the ways in which culture affects management decisions.
596577.prereqs: Prerequisite: MGMT 339 or MGMT 340 ; or graduate standing.

598030.title: Lean Startup Entrepreneurship
598030.description: Theory and techniques of lean startup entrepreneurship, including customer development, product-market fit and go-to-market strategy. Applies lean startup techniques in consultation with actual startup firms.
598030.prereqs: Prerequisites: CBE undergraduate student - MGMT 339 ; non-CBE undergraduate student - BUAD 210 ; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596578.title: Entrepreneurial Management
596578.description: How to plan, organize and control new ventures. Setting up business-level strategy and corresponding systems to improve venture performance. Casework, research and fieldwork with selected local businesses.
596578.prereqs: Prerequisites: CBE undergraduate student - MGMT 339 ; non-CBE undergraduate student - BUAD 210 ; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596579.title: Entrepreneurial Leadership
596579.description: Leadership roles, organizational development and human resource management of new ventures. Determining the policies, procedures and culture needed to facilitate employee productivity and effectiveness. Casework, research and fieldwork with selected local businesses.
596579.prereqs: Prerequisites: CBE undergraduate student - MGMT 340 ; non-CBE undergraduate student - BUAD 210 ; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596580.title: New Venture Creation and Funding
596580.description: How to develop and test product and service concepts for new ventures, set business strategy, design operating systems develop financial forecasts, and comply with related laws and regulations. New venture student teams prepare business plans and make funding presentations. (MGMT 465A and EGGN 465A are the same course).
596580.prereqs: Prerequisites: CBE undergraduate and Physics-Business majors - FIN 320 , MGMT 340 , MKTG 351 ; other undergraduate major - BUAD 210 ; or graduate standing (not pre-MBA). Corequisite: Engineering undergraduate major - EGCE 401 / EGEC 401 / EGME 401 .

596581.title: New Venture Launch
596581.description: Student teams will launch new ventures. New ventures may be startup businesses or new profit centers within existing businesses. Prepare a final report and oral presentation on the venture's progress. (MGMT 465B and EGGN 465B are the same course.)
596581.prereqs: Prerequisites: MGMT 465A ; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598435.title: Entertainment Operations
598435.description: Applies management theories to media-oriented entertainment industries, including film and its ancillary markets (home entertainment, television, streaming, cable), music and video games, among others.
598435.prereqs: Prerequisites: Business (not pre-business) major - MGMT 339 ; other major - BUAD 210 or MGMT 339 ; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598434.title: Hospitality and Tourism Management
598434.description: Provides skills and tools for managing business processes, operations and resources in different areas of the hospitality industry (e.g., lodging, theme parks, casinos, special event management).
598434.prereqs: Prerequisites: Business (not pre-business) major - MGMT 339 ; other major - BUAD 210 or MGMT 339 ; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598564.title: Healthcare Management
598564.description: Understand the challenges and structure of the U.S. healthcare system. Role of healthcare managers in managing access, staffing, quality, capacity, supply chain and information technology in healthcare organizations. Apply managerial concepts for effective decision making in healthcare.

598927.title: Music Business
598927.description: All aspects of the music business, including music business revenue streams, artist management, music marketing, data analytics in the music business, record deals, songwriting royalties, music publishing, music copyright, music supervision, and emerging trends in the music industry.
598927.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 2A; Business major - BUAD 301 ; Music major - MUS 319 ; or graduate standing.

596582.title: Global Strategic Management
596582.description: Conceptualization, formulation and implementation of successful global business strategies. Managing cultural differences, strategic alliances and acquisitions in the global market space.
596582.prereqs: Prerequisite: BUAD 301 ; completion of all International Business core courses; or graduate standing.

596583.title: Internship
596583.description: Planned and supervised work experience. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units for credit/non-credit. Maximum of 3 units and cannot be repeated for letter-grade option. Consent of department internship adviser and one semester in residence at the university is required.
596583.prereqs: Prerequisites: six units of upper-division management courses including MGMT 339 ; Management or International Business concentration; minimum junior standing; 2.5 or better GPA; or graduate standing.

596584.title: Independent Study
596584.description: Open to qualified students desiring to pursue directed independent inquiry. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Not open to students on academic notice. Requires approval by department chair.

596585.title: Seminar in Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) and Managerial Ethics
596585.description: How to generate a competitive advantage through ethics-based business strategies, and how to enhance social responsibility in conducting business activities in finance, accounting, marketing, entrepreneurship, corporate governance, HR and management and information technology.

596587.title: Operations Management
596587.description: Role of operations function in designing, producing and delivering products and services in manufacturing and service firms. Includes strategy and processes to meet market needs, internal and external coordination in a supply chain, long- and short-term decision-making tools and techniques.
596587.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE graduate (not Economics) standing. Corequisite: ISDS 513 or ISDS 540 .

596588.title: Legal and Ethical Environment of Business
596588.description: Federal, state and international laws and ethical issues affecting business, including criminal law, contracts, the Uniform Commercial Code, torts and product liability, employment relationships and discrimination, and various kinds of business organizations, such as corporations, LLC, partnerships and sole proprietorships.
596588.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE graduate standing and not Economics graduate standing.

596590.title: Seminar in Organizational Behavior
596590.description: Understanding and predicting human behavior to enhance individual, team and organizational performance. Applying effective principles of motivation, team building, influence, leadership and conflict management.
596590.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE graduate standing. Corequisite: BUAD 501A .

596591.title: Seminar in Team Leadership Skills
596591.description: Graduate seminar to develop hands-on skills to lead high-performance work teams. Topics include self-awareness, stress management, valuing diversity, supportive communication, creative problem solving, influence and leadership, motivating others, managing conflict, empowering and building effective teams.

596592.title: Supply Chain Management
596592.description: Effective supply chain strategies emphasizing how to plan and integrate supply chain components into a coordinated system. Concepts and models important in supply chain planning. Risk pooling and inventory placement, integrated planning and collaboration and information sharing. Various models and methods for supply chain analysis and optimization.

596593.title: Leading and Managing People in Entrepreneurial Organizations
596593.description: Prepares managers to analyze organizational policies, procedures and culture to improve employee productivity and effectiveness. Explores leadership skills needed to execute these changes. Includes a consulting project that applies student learning to a small and/or entrepreneurial organization.

596594.title: Seminar in Human Resource Management
596594.description: Cases, problems and significant personnel administration literature in personnel administration and human relations.

598511.title: Project Management
598511.description: Principles, techniques and tools of effective project management. Topics include needs identification, project planning, scheduling and control, project organization and communication, and use of project management software to manage large, complex global projects and programs.

598401.title: Managing Multinational Organizations
598401.description: Management practices and processes in five geographical areas; market-structures and management characteristics different from those in the United States. Constraints that vary between countries because of cultural, legal, economic and/or political differences.
598401.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE graduate (not Economics or pre-MBA) standing.

597818.title: Leadership Dynamics
597818.description: Dynamics of effective leadership in organizations. Major principles and practices driving the leadership field.

596595.title: Leading Organizational Change
596595.description: Develop executive-level capabilities to lead, manage and implement organizational change. Build change leadership skills through exposure to a variety of industries, organizations and decision-making scenarios.
596595.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 509 or POSC 526 ; or CBE graduate (not Economics or pre-MBA) standing.

596596.title: Negotiation
596596.description: Builds on knowledge of individual behavior and social perception with a key focus on integrative bargaining strategies and tactics. Aims to help argue for goals more persuasively, while also enriching others' goals.

597819.title: Leadership, Power and Influence
597819.description: Socio-economic approaches to leadership. Organizational influence processes, power, and politics in organizations and communities.

596597.title: Independent Graduate Research
596597.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Not open to students on academic notice. Requires consent of instructor, department chair and associate dean.

598405.title: Professional Selling
598405.description: Steps of the sales cycle as an interpersonal influence process. Selling skills and techniques based on communication and buyer behavior concepts. Written sales projects and oral presentations are expected.
598405.prereqs: Corequisite: MKTG 351 (not CBE pre-major or undeclared).

596598.title: Principles of Marketing
596598.description: Applying current theories and concepts in effectively marketing goods and services to define target customers from a domestic and global perspective. Includes market research, identifying target customers, developing product offers, branding, pricing, marketing communications and distribution channels.
596598.prereqs: Corequisite: CBE undergraduate major, CBE pre-major - BUAD 301 ; other major - at least junior standing; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598402.title: Marketing Information Technology
598402.description: Information sources, databases and tools applied by marketers to transform data into useful formats for the strategic decision-making process. Includes segmentation, target marketing and positioning, media selection, market share, break-even analysis, pricing, sales forecasting and profit scenario analysis.
598402.prereqs: Prerequisites: Business Administration major, Economics major - MKTG 351 , BUAD 301 , ISDS 361A ; other major (not CBE pre-major or undeclared) - MKTG 351 ; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598403.title: Consumer Behavior
598403.description: Consumer buying patterns, motivation and search behavior. Consumer decision-making process. Inter-disciplinary concepts from economics, sociology, psychology, cultural anthropology and mass communications. Case analyses and research projects.
598403.prereqs: Prerequisites: CBE undergraduate major - BUAD 301 (prerequisite), MKTG 351 (corequisite); other major (not CBE pre-major or undeclared) - MKTG 351 (corequisite).

598404.title: Marketing Research Methods
598404.description: Marketing research process. Problem formulation, identifying data sources, data collection, analysis techniques, preparing research reports and application of these concepts to marketing research projects.
598404.prereqs: Prerequisites: Business Administration major, Economics major - BUAD 301 , ISDS 361A , MKTG 351 ; other major (not CBE pre-major or undeclared) - MKTG 351 .

598406.title: Advertising and Promotions Strategy
598406.description: How to develop and implement advertising, sales promotion, public relations, direct marketing, sponsorship marketing and personal selling strategies that convey a single voice to a firm's customers' attention with effective and efficient communications program.
598406.prereqs: Prerequisite: MKTG 351 (not CBE pre-major or undeclared); or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598805.title: Strategic Selling and Negotiation
598805.description: Advanced instruction and skill development in selling situations, presentation skills, negotiation, handling conflict, reading buyers, managing CRM information; and practicing more in-depth probing questions. Become better prepared for sales careers.
598805.prereqs: Prerequisite: MKTG 315 or CBE graduate standing (not pre-MBA).

598407.title: Managing the Sales Force
598407.description: Sales manager's role in organizing and deploying a field sales force, developing effective sales training programs, designing complete motivation and compensation plans, asserting strong leadership and evaluating sales people's performance. Relies heavily on case studies and group discussion.
598407.prereqs: Prerequisite: MKTG 351 (not CBE pre-major or undeclared); or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598408.title: Retail Marketing Strategy
598408.description: Evolution of retailing into global, high technology industry; developing integrated marketing and financial strategies. Positioning retail offers to establish and maintain relationships with target customers. Evolving market conditions, buying behavior, retail venues, channel relationships, information, communication and decision support systems, merchandise management.
598408.prereqs: Prerequisite: MKTG 351 (not CBE pre-major or undeclared); or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598409.title: Sports Marketing
598409.description: Develop understanding of: sports marketing, its role in business and society; different functional areas. Develop ability to apply theories and knowledge to solve problems faced by sports marketers.
598409.prereqs: Prerequisite: MKTG 351 (not CBE pre-major or undeclared); or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598213.title: Sales and Consumer Product Strategies
598213.description: Theories, concepts and current professional practices of sales strategy, retail distribution, strategic marketing and category management based on analyzing customer purchasing behavior and sales data.
598213.prereqs: Prerequisite: MKTG 351 (not CBE pre-major or undeclared).

596599.title: Marketing Analytics: Decision Making in the Information Age
596599.description: Applying analysis and modeling techniques to a broad range of marketing decision making domains. (MKTG 443 and ISDS 443 are the same course.)
596599.prereqs: Prerequisites: ISDS 361A , MKTG 351 ; not CBE pre-major or undeclared; or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

597824.title: Social Media Marketing and Analytics
597824.description: Theoretical concepts and practical skills used by organizations in developing social media marketing strategies and in generating and utilizing analytics. Create social media content and produce actionable analytics from the social media content. (MKTG 444 and ISDS 444 are the same course.)
597824.prereqs: Prerequisites: MKTG 353 , ISDS 361A (not CBE pre-major or undeclared); graduate student (not pre-MBA) - ISDS 513 or ISDS 540 (prerequisite) and MKTG 519 (corequisite).

598410.title: Global Marketing
598410.description: Theories of international trade and role of marketing decisions across national boundaries and markets. Concepts and principles of marketing strategies in organizations: recognition of environmental differences; market assessments; entry alternatives; positions of global independence; marketing problems; and critical implications.
598410.prereqs: Prerequisite: MKTG 351 (not pre-business, pre-economics major or undeclared); or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

597817.title: Visual Marketing
597817.description: Develop marketing communications through image creation tools, such as Adobe Photoshop, Prezi, Adobe Premiere, Apple iMovie, and Google Sketch Up.
597817.prereqs: Prerequisites: MKTG 351 for undergraduate students; MKTG 519 for graduate students.

596600.title: Digital Marketing
596600.description: Marketing goods, services and ideas on the Internet. Integrating e-commerce into a total marketing strategy for businesses ranging from entrepreneurial to multinational corporations. History and emergence of e-commerce, utility of the Internet as a tool to increase effectiveness, efficacy and competitiveness.
596600.prereqs: Prerequisite: MKTG 351 (not CBE pre-major or undeclared); or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598411.title: Marketing for Entrepreneurs
598411.description: Covering market analysis for new products and services, competitive analysis, alternatives for entering markets, associated costs and launch feasibility. Casework, research and fieldwork with selected local businesses.
598411.prereqs: Prerequisite: MKTG 351 (not CBE pre-major or undeclared); CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing - MKTG 519 .

596601.title: Managing Services Marketing
596601.description: Unique marketing needs and challenges faced by service firms in an increasingly challenging global environment. Strategies for marketing services in a variety of industries: entertainment, tourism, hospitality, health care, financial services. Strategies used by manufacturing firms using service as a competitive strategy.
596601.prereqs: Prerequisite: MKTG 351 (not CBE pre-major or undeclared); or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

607230.title: A.I. in Marketing: The Next Frontier
607230.description: How A.I. is revolutionizing the marketing landscape, from advertising and analytics to customer service and sales. Use practical insights and case studies to illustrate A.I.-driven marketing techniques; preparing students to navigate the evolving marketing ecosystem.
607230.prereqs: Prerequisite: MKTG 351 (not CBE pre-major or undeclared); or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598412.title: Export/Import Marketing Strategies
598412.description: Export and import strategies, including international logistics. Export and import process for large companies and small international businesses. Logistics planning and choosing the best incoterms, export process and evaluating alternative export strategies. Outsourcing and other government regulatory requirements and documentation.
598412.prereqs: Prerequisite: MKTG 351 (not pre-business, pre-economics major or undeclared); or CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

598659.title: Film and TV Marketing
598659.description: Film and TV content marketing is evolving rapidly, driven by technological, market and consumer trends. Provides a foundational understanding of the current methodologies for marketing and promoting film and TV content across all platforms. (CTVA 482 and MKTG 482 are the same course.)
598659.prereqs: Prerequisite: CTVA 100 with a “C” (2.0) or better.

597815.title: Multicultural Marketing
597815.description: Multicultural marketing is a discipline that recognizes divergent influences in a varied population and creates customized marketing programs that reach various audiences. Students gain an understanding of the dynamics in a diverse market environment while identifying target audiences and appropriate marketing strategies.

596602.title: Developing Marketing Strategies
596602.description: Developing marketing strategies involving products as well as services. Case analysis and group interaction. Students will finalize and present portfolio of projects and internships completed over the duration of marketing program.
596602.prereqs: Prerequisites: senior standing, MKTG 351 ; three of the following - MKTG 315 , MKTG 353 , MKTG 370 , MKTG 379 ; or graduate (not pre-MBA) standing, MKTG 519 .

596603.title: Internship
596603.description: Planned and supervised work experience. May be repeated once for credit. Consent of department chair and one semester in residence at Cal State Fullerton required.
596603.prereqs: Prerequisites: MKTG 351 , 3 units upper-division MKTG course; Marketing concentration or International Business major; at least junior standing; 2.5 GPA; or graduate standing.

596604.title: Independent Study
596604.description: Open to undergraduate students desiring to pursue directed independent inquiry. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Not open to students on academic notice. Requires approval by Department Chair.

596605.title: Marketing Management
596605.description: Key marketing concepts and their applications to marketing research, segmentation, selecting target markets, product development, pricing, promotion and distribution. Develops senior-level executive decision-making skills from global, ethical and socially responsible perspectives. Requires understanding and application in a major project.
596605.prereqs: Prerequisite: CBE graduate (not Economics or pre-MBA) standing. Corequisite: BUAD 501A .

598928.title: Introduction to Marketing Analytics
598928.description: Strategic overview of the knowledge sets, tools and systems of business organizations to collect and analyze market data to guide executive decisions and optimize components of the marketing mix. Introduction to various approaches to marketing analytics.

598929.title: Consumer Analytics and Social Media
598929.description: How social media content and analytics impact marketing, generating and understanding these analytics, and using this data to create and measure marketing responses. Processes and tools used by managers to enhance strategic decision-making and value creation.

598930.title: Marketing Intelligence Dashboards
598930.description: Develop hands-on analytical and decision-making skills using data visualization technologies and digital dashboards. Topics include marketing analytics, emphasizing the tools that help marketing managers visualize data that stakeholders can leverage when making key strategic decisions.

598013.title: Marketing Analytics for Managers
598013.description: Organizations are increasingly becoming data-driven and are actively seeking managers with knowledge and experience in data analysis and marketing analytics. Focuses on the integrative application of various marketing analytics techniques to solve typical business problems. (ISDS 543 and MKTG 543 are the same course).

596607.title: Strategic Market Intelligence
596607.description: Qualitative and quantitative methods for collecting and analyzing information about customers and competitors. Apply these techniques and learn how market information can be leveraged to make better strategic decisions.
596607.prereqs: Prerequisites: MKTG 519 , ISDS 361A or ISDS 513 ; graduate (not Economics or pre-MBA) standing.

597816.title: Product and Brand Management
597816.description: How to develop products and brands that deliver value to consumers using qualitative and metric approaches.

596608.title: Contemporary Topics in Marketing
