596608.description: Frameworks and practices for the 21st-century U.S. marketer. How to develop brand strategy and drive competitive advantage in an increasingly diverse marketplace through case studies, discussions and guest speakers.
596608.prereqs: Prerequisites: MKTG 519 ; CBE graduate (not pre-MBA) standing.

596609.title: Independent Graduate Research
596609.description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Not open to students on academic notice. Requires consent of instructor, department chair and associate dean.

596692.title: Engineering Graphics
596692.description: Sketching, Visualization, Geometry, CAD principles and applications. Orthographic projections, pictorials. Multiview drawing, including auxiliary, section and detail views. Standards and conventions. Dimensioning, tolerances, GDT. Design processes, cost analysis and freshman project. (1 hour lecture, 3 hours laboratory).

598897.title: Explore Core: Fear and Fantasy
598897.description: Fear and fantasy through multiple disciplinary lenses and methods. The experience, representation and response to fear across cultures, generations and time periods. Use multidisciplinary approaches to understanding fear and fantasy, drawing from developmental psychology, art, popular culture, history and engineering. (AMST 132, ART 132, CAS 132 and EGME 132 are the same course)

598935.title: Explore Core: Truth
598935.description: Nature, significance and knowability of truth, exploring perspectives from philosophy, history, journalism, criminal justice, mathematics, engineering and the natural sciences. How is truth made or discovered? And why and when we should we trust the truths that emerge? (PHIL 133, BIOL 133, EGME 133, LBST 133 are the same course.)

596693.title: Digital Computation
596693.description: Computers and their numerical applications. Programming languages, MathCAD, spreadsheet, digital computation methods in statistics and solving algebraic equations. Applications of general purpose software for engineering analysis. (EGME 205 and EGGN 205 are the same course.)

596694.title: Thermodynamics
596694.description: Energy and its transformation; heat and work; conservation of mass and energy, system properties, irreversibility and availability. Ideal gases, heat engines and refrigeration (both ideal and actual), equipment selection and sizing.
596694.prereqs: Prerequisites: CHEM 120A or CHEM 123 ; MATH 150B , PHYS 225 .

596431.title: Teaching Lifetime Physical Activity
596431.description: Provides history, skills, rules, progressions and sport-specific teaching strategies to promote active participation and experiential learning of lifetime physical activities.

596432.title: Teaching Human Movement Forms in Physical Education
596432.description: Provides history, skills, rules, progressions and sport-specific teaching strategies to promote active participation and experiential learning in dance, combatives and gymnastics. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours activity)

596433.title: Basic Hatha Yoga
596433.description: Basic yoga postures, beginning meditation, breathing and relaxation techniques presented from a theoretical and experiential perspective. Awareness, concentration, and other practices that accompany the study of Hatha Yoga. (1 hour lecture, 2 hours activity) (KNES 246A  and RLST 246A are the same course)

607239.title: Intermediate Hatha Yoga
607239.description: Intermediate and advanced yoga sequences, including postures, breathing practices, meditation techniques and guided relaxation. Yoga philosophy and movement based on various Hatha Yoga traditions. (KNES 246B and RLST 246B are the same course).

597882.title: Introduction to Recreation and Leisure Time Physical Activities
597882.description: The broad field of recreation and leisure, including an overview of professional preparation and survey of the recreation professions in college, commercial, government and nonprofit organizations.
597882.prereqs: Prerequisite: KNES 202 ; Junior standing or above.

596436.title: Exercise Techniques for Strength Training
596436.description: Practical experiences in resistance exercise lifting and spotting techniques. Free-weight exercises, such as squatting and Olympic lifting. Proper set up and execution of machine-based exercises.

596437.title: Techniques of Coaching
596437.description: Factors related to coaching strategies and techniques: philosophy, ethics, legal issues, gender, multicultural and equity issues, leadership, motivation, team management, budget, recruiting, equipment purchase, skill acquisition, season planning, conditioning, nutrition and drugs.

596438.title: Stress Management
596438.description: Nature of stress and physiological and psychological effects of prolonged stress responses. Short- and long-term somatic and behavioral techniques (exercise, relaxation, meditation, nutrition, time management and goal setting) for management of stress. (PUBH 342 and KNES 342 are the same course.)

596439.title: Physiology of Exercise
596439.description: Description and explanation of functional and structural changes in the body brought on by acute exercise and chronic training.
596439.prereqs: Prerequisite: KNES 191A / BIOL 191A or KNES 210 / BIOL 210 .

596440.title: Physiology of Exercise Laboratory
596440.description: Laboratory techniques in physiology of exercise designed to provide students fundamental knowledge of and practical experiences in test methodologies used to evaluate fitness components. (3 hours laboratory)

596441.title: Measurement and Statistics in Kinesiology
596441.description: Measurement theory and statistics used in evaluating health and human performance, focusing on analyzing and interpreting data in different environments.
596441.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Areas 2A, 5A, 5B, 5C. Pre- or corequisite: KNES 202 .

596442.title: Principles of Strength and Conditioning
596442.description: Acute effects and chronic adaptations to various forms of resistance training across the lifespan.

596443.title: Principles of Teaching Group Fitness
596443.description: Provide content knowledge and practical experience concerned with teaching group exercise. Emphasis will be placed on teaching principles, techniques, safety and a variety of exercise formats.

596444.title: Physical Activity and Lifelong Well-Being
596444.description: Integrating physiological, psychological and sociological understandings of the human being in relationship to physical activity as a lifelong pursuit. Physical fitness, nutrition, stress reduction, socialization, and individual differences in human behavior. (PUBH 353 and KNES 353 are the same course.)

596445.title: Cardiovascular Exercise Testing and Prescription
596445.description: Methods of graded exercise testing in the apparently healthy adult. Guidelines for aerobic exercise prescription. Cardiovascular disease and identification of risk factors.

597852.title: Movement Anatomy
597852.description: The musculoskeletal system and its function in producing human movement from a functional perspective; the relationship between selected elements of myology and osteology as they relate to human motion.
597852.prereqs: Prerequisite: KNES 191A / BIOL 191A or KNES 210 / BIOL 210 .

597853.title: Principles of Human Movement
597853.description: Basic mechanical principles and their application in the study of human movement.

596446.title: Adapted Physical Education
596446.description: Study of the disabled whose unique needs in motor development determine their least restrictive environment in physical activity. Programs of games, sports and exercise in diversified settings; legally mandated regulations.

596447.title: Motor Development
596447.description: Examine changes in human motor behavior across the lifespan, factors that underlie these changes, and the application of theoretical concepts to development of movement-based age appropriate programs.

596448.title: Pathologies in Sport/Exercise
596448.description: Common pathologies seen in sport and/or exercise, including prevention strategies, etiologies, diagnoses, management approaches and possible complications.
596448.prereqs: Prerequisite: KNES 191A / BIOL 191A , KNES 210 / BIOL 210 or BIOL 361 .

596452.title: Human Motor Control and Learning
596452.description: Neural, musculoskeletal and psychological mechanisms underlying the control and learning of movement skills across the lifespan.
596452.prereqs: Prerequisite: KNES 191A / BIOL 191A or KNES 210 / BIOL 210 .

596453.title: Management of Sport/Exercise Emergencies
596453.description: Catastrophic and life-threatening injuries and illnesses common to sport/exercise. Epidemiology, prevention strategies and management approaches.
596453.prereqs: Prerequisite: KNES 360 . Pre- or corequisite: KNES 202 or KNES 365 .

596454.title: Principles of Musculoskeletal Rehabilitation
596454.description: Theoretical foundation of the rehabilitation process for musculoskeletal injuries. Topics include the integration of therapeutic exercise and modalities to achieve specific rehabilitation goals across various patient populations and clinical settings.

596455.title: Philosophy of Human Movement
596455.description: The philosophy of human movement in athletics, sport, kinesiology, play, dance and other human movement forms from ancient Greeks to the present. Philosophical theories of human movement relative to personal identity, reality, being, values and nature of competition.

596456.title: History of Sports, Games and Culture
596456.description: Historical interpretations of the role of sport, games, play, dance and recreation in human life. Connections between sporting and movement practices, as well as the broader cultural, political, intellectual and economic patterns that have shaped societies throughout world history.

596457.title: Psychology of Sport and Physical Activity
596457.description: Introduction to theory and research of psychological processes that influence human performance in numerous movement settings including sport, exercise, and rehabilitation. Individual difference variables, social psychological variables and assessment and intervention.

596458.title: Sport Sociology
596458.description: Sport and social institutions and social processes. Understanding sport as a social phenomenon.

596459.title: Instructional Analysis of Human Movement
596459.description: Variables and principles which contribute to effective observation, analysis and instruction of human movement skills across the life span.
596459.prereqs: Prerequisite: junior standing or above. Pre- or corequisite: KNES 361 .

596460.title: Movement and the Child
596460.description: Characteristics of the child; physical growth and development; basic mechanical principles related to human movement and motor learning; and concepts related to the design of physical activity programs that are appropriately challenging for children at various developmental levels. SMPP-PE students require KNES 494.

596461.title: Movement and the Adolescent
596461.description: Implement physical education programs at the secondary level. Cognitive, affective and psychomotor development; structure, concepts and principles related to human movement and motor learning; concepts related to the design of secondary school movement programs. SMPP-PE students require KNES 494.

598614.title: Teaching Elementary Physical Education
598614.description: Design and implement developmentally-appropriate physical education programs at the elementary school level. Provides fieldwork experiences to practice teaching techniques at a local elementary school under supervision. SMPP-PE students require KNES 494.

596462.title: Physical Education Tutorial
596462.description: Supervised experience in performance or laboratory situations through tutoring or assisting in instruction. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. A maximum of 3 units may be applied toward the major. Requires consent of instructor and tutorial adviser.

598615.title: Peer Mentoring for KNES Student Success
598615.description: Department permission required after mentor application is approved. Develop mentorship skills through seminar learning and serving as a peer mentor to fellow students. Enhance communication, cultural competency, leadership, motivational, goal achievement, personal management and student success skills. Barriers to and resources for college student success.
598615.prereqs: Prerequisite: KNES major; junior or senior standing.

597884.title: Recreation Staff Management and Communication
597884.description: Introduces seminar participants to effective staff management and communication in recreation organizations in the public and non-profit sectors. Will focus on key management issues in recreation organizations, including effective staff leadership.
597884.prereqs: Pre- or corequisite: KNES 304 ; or graduate standing.

596465.title: Issues in Youth Sports
596465.description: Interdisciplinary examination of current trends and issues in youth sport, focusing on non-school based community programs. The structural characteristics of sport and physical activity programs as they pertain to proper development of children and adolescents.
596465.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 381 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

596466.title: Legal Issues in Kinesiology
596466.description: Introduction to the legal system and the law as applied to sport and exercise settings, including the areas of sports, fitness and healthcare and recreational activities; understanding the concepts of ethics, negligence and risk management.
596466.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 202 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

598268.title: Clinical Anatomy
598268.description: Develop hands-on skills for future healthcare practitioners. Emphasizes skills for identifying musculoskeletal structures visually and via palpation, and then testing their function. Use anatomical and live human models to develop and demonstrate skills.
598268.prereqs: Prerequisite: KNES 360 ; or Athletic Training graduate standing.

596467.title: Applied Sport Psychology
596467.description: Application of principles from sport psychology literature to enhance athletes' and coaches' performance.
596467.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 383 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

596468.title: Applied Exercise Psychology
596468.description: Understanding and applying the principles from exercise psychology to the promotion of physical activity in a variety of settings including preventive, clinical, community and rehabilitative programs.
596468.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 383 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

597994.title: Physical Activity Promotion and Behavior
597994.description: Apply behavior change principles and theories to the promotion of physical activity as well as develop and evaluate physical activity interventions.

596469.title: Teaching Physical Education
596469.description: Objectives, methods and materials for teaching Physical Education K-12. Required before student teaching. Part of the 12-unit education block and may not be taken separately. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to earn a preliminary Single Subject credential.
596469.prereqs: Prerequisite: Single Subject Credential Program Physical Education student. Corequisite: KNES 449E .

598945.title: Externship in Single Subject Teaching
598945.description: Eight-week practicum (150 hours) fieldwork in single subject classrooms. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit. Students sign up for the appropriate departmental offering. Requires admission to the Single Subject Credential Program. May be repeated once for credit. (EDSC 449E, ARTE 449E, KNES 449E, MAED 449E, MUSE 449E, and THTR 449E are the same course.)
598945.prereqs: Prerequisite: Single Subject Credential Program Physical Education student. Corequisite: KNES 442 .

598946.title: Second Semester Student Teaching
598946.description: A 450-hour practicum in a single subject in public schools. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit. Departmental course offerings are: ARTE 449I, EDSC 449I, KNES 449I, MAED 449I, MUSE 449I, THTR 449I.

596472.title: Seminar in Secondary Teaching
596472.description: Student teaching in a single subject in public schools. Credit/No Credit only. Requires a "B" (3.0) or better for credit.
596472.prereqs: Prerequisites: EDSC 440S , EDSC 440F , KNES 442 , KNES 449E . Corequisite: KNES 449I .

596473.title: Program Design for Strength and Conditioning
596473.description: Outcomes associated with different strength training regimens. Periodization and planned variation of the acute program variables of frequency, intensity, volume and rest across cycles of training to prevent overtraining and promote peak performance.
596473.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 351 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

596474.title: Sports Medicine
596474.description: Various general medical pathologies, pharmacological issues and ergogenic aids related to sport/exercise.
596474.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 348 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

596475.title: Clinical Exercise Physiology
596475.description: Applying exercise physiology concepts to clinical/pathological situations in order to determine the therapeutic and functional benefits of physical activity.
596475.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 348 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

596476.title: Physical Dimensions of Aging
596476.description: Scientific evidence concerning the relationship between level of physical activity and physical, cognitive and psychosocial well-being during aging. Changes that occur during aging, changes related to inactive lifestyles, and the positive effects of an active lifestyle on preventing disease and disability.
596476.prereqs: Prerequisites: junior or senior standing; 6 upper-division KNES units or 6 units from AGNG 133 / HUSR 133 / PSYC 133 / SOCI 133 , BIOL 306 , PSYC 362 , SOCI 443 ; or graduate standing.

596477.title: Functional Performance Assessment and Programming for Older Adults
596477.description: Development of technical and personal skills related to functional performance assessment and to the development and implementation of physical activity programs for healthy and frail older adults.

596478.title: Environmental Exercis Physiology
596478.description: Interrelationship between the physical environment and the human while exercising under different states of fitness and acclimatization.
596478.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 348 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

596479.title: Practice of Personal Training
596479.description: Physiological responses and adaptations associated with strength and aerobic training to design fitness programs across the lifespan. Scientific foundation, client evaluation, exercise technique, safety and legal issues, program design and special populations.
596479.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 351 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

596480.title: Measurement Techniques in Strength and Conditioning
596480.description: Understand theory, operate equipment and analyze resultant data related to endurance, strength and power testing. Exposure to a variety of assessment techniques commonly performed in strength and conditioning, biochemistry, and exercise physiology.
596480.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 351 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

596481.title: Worksite Health Promotion
596481.description: Philosophy, rationale and guidelines for developing health promotion programs in the corporate setting. Unique considerations in assessing needs, planning and implementing programs, evaluating effectiveness and coordinating activities in the workplace are discussed. (PUBH 460 and KNES 460 are the same course.)
596481.prereqs: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 or KNES 202 ; not freshman standing; or Public Health minor; or graduate standing.

596482.title: Biomechanical Analysis of Human Movement
596482.description: Analytical approach to mechanics of human motion. Quantitative video analysis techniques are introduced and applied to select movement analysis projects.
596482.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 361 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

596483.title: Biomechanics of Musculoskeletal Injury
596483.description: Biomechanical analysis of human movement patterns and how they are related to the development of various musculoskeletal injuries. Biomechanical assessment and correction for prevention and rehabilitation of musculoskeletal injury will also be developed.
596483.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 361 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

596487.title: Nutrition for Exercise and Performance
596487.description: Role of different nutrients (macro and micro) to provide energy during exercise, enhance performance and support recovery after exercise. Fluid replenishment, nutritional supplements, nutritional immunology and the female athlete.
596487.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 348 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

596488.title: Motor Control and Movement Dysfunction
596488.description: Contemporary motor control theories and how they are applied to the development of therapeutic exercise programs for children and adults with balance and movement disorders caused by disease and/or trauma to the neurological system.
596488.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 371 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

598394.title: Gender and Sexuality Issues in Sport
598394.description: Sociocultural study of historical and contemporary gender norms and sexuality in sport, recreation and leisure; emphasizing ways femininity, masculinity and sexual orientation affect access, inclusion and participation.
598394.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 381 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

597874.title: The Socio-Cultural Study of the Olympic Games: Ancient to Modern
597874.description: Historical, sociological and philosophical aspects of the Olympic Games from its creation in classical Greek antiquity to the emergence of the modern Olympics. Draw upon methods from multiple disciplines to examine the Olympic Games.
597874.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 381 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

598125.title: Sport, Film, and Culture
598125.description: Using popular film, this course examines sport and its connection to culture and society to better understand sport's place in human culture.
598125.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 381 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

596489.title: Practicum
596489.description: Planning, preparing, coaching, teaching in public school, college or community physical education or recreation programs. May be repeated for a maximum of six units. Credits not applicable toward major or graduate program. Credit/No Credit only. Requires consent of faculty sponsor, field supervisor, fieldwork coordinator, and department chair.

596490.title: Internship in Kinesiology
596490.description: Seminar for analysis of field experiences, including appropriate theory, skills and techniques, in addition to supervised experience in an approved fieldwork location agency. Internship must be specific to the discipline of kinesiology. Minimum of 120 hours per semester. Application forms must be completed and approved prior to enrollment. May not be repeated for credit toward the major. Requires consent of faculty sponsor, field supervisor, and fieldwork coordinator.
596490.prereqs: Prerequisites: minimum of 9 units of upper-division Kinesiology coursework completed.

596491.title: Independent Study
596491.description: Topics based on a study plan prepared in cooperation with a faculty supervisor. Culminates in a paper, project, comprehensive examination. Application forms must be completed and approved prior to enrollment. Maximum of three units in any one semester; may be repeated once.
596491.prereqs: Prerequisites: minimum of 15 upper-division Kinesiology courses completed; junior or senior standing.

596492.title: Statistical Methods in Kinesiology
596492.description: Statistical theory, data collection procedures, techniques for analysis and interpretation of data.

596493.title: Research Methods in Kinesiology
596493.description: Fundamental tools of research. Types of research, process of scientific inquiry and critical analysis of research. Topic selection and development of a research proposal.
596493.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 508 with a “C” (2.0) or better; graduate standing.

598269.title: Evidence-Based Practice in Athletic Training
598269.description: Introduction to the research process and evidence-based practice (EBP) in athletic training and allied health. Topics include asking clinical questions, searching for evidence and critical appraisal of the literature. Focus on the current literature to inform clinical decision-making.

596494.title: Advanced Study of the Philosophical Perspective of Human Movement
596494.description: Methods of the philosophical process of human movement.

596495.title: Graduate Internship
596495.description: On-the-job training experiences supervised by a fully trained practitioner. Minimum of 120 hours per semester plus conferences with faculty sponsor. Application forms must be completed and approved prior to enrollment. Upon completion of the internship, a written evaluation must be submitted. Not open to students on, or subject to, academic notice. Requires consent of faculty sponsor, field supervisor, field coordinator and chair.

598395.title: Advanced Study in Physiology of Exercise
598395.description: Current issues and research in physiology of exercise with emphasis on physiological control during acute exercise. Includes written, oral and laboratory assignments.

596496.title: Applied Strength and Conditioning
596496.description: Anatomical and physiological bases for programs that develop physical fitness and performance.

596497.title: Advanced Study in Teaching Human Movement
596497.description: Historical perspectives and current trends in pedagogical research and the resultant principles that undergird the science of teaching human movement.

596498.title: Advanced Study in Biomechanics
596498.description: Advanced methods and concepts associated with the quantification of human movement. Biomechanical analysis of force plate and three-dimensional video data.

598270.title: Leadership and Administration in Athletic Training
598270.description: Analyze the technical, practical, legal and ethical aspects of leadership and administration in athletic training and other health care organizations.

598271.title: Athletic Training Administration Clinical Experience
598271.description: Practical application of administrative tasks, patient care skills and clinical decision-making in various athletic training and healthcare settings. Targets healthcare-related policies and procedures, and preseason preparation as part of the sports medicine team.

596499.title: Advanced Study in Human Motor Control and Learning
596499.description: In-depth study of contemporary trends and issues in motor control/learning research. Application of research to practice.

598272.title: Prevention and Management of Exercise-Related Emergencies
598272.description: Knowledge and application of concepts related to the prevention, recognition, clinical diagnosis, and management of emergencies in sport/exercise. Hands-on patient-care skills.
598272.prereqs: Prerequisite: Athletic Training graduate standing. Corequisite: KNES 585 .

598246.title: Clinical Evaluation and Diagnosis I: Lower Extremity
598246.description: Recognizing, evaluating and diagnosing musculoskeletal pathologies in the lower extremity. Using an evidence based approach to performing a comprehensive, systematic clinical examination in the athletic training setting.

598247.title: Clinical Evaluation and Diagnosis II: Upper Extremity
598247.description: Recognizing, evaluating and diagnosing musculoskeletal pathologies in the upper extremity. Using an evidence based approach to performing a comprehensive, systematic clinical examination in the athletic training setting.

598248.title: Clinical Evaluation and Diagnosis III: Head, Neck and Spine
598248.description: Recognition, evaluation and clinical diagnosis of musculoskeletal and neurological pathologies of the head, neck and spine. Uses an evidence-based approach to performing a comprehensive, systematic clinical examination in the athletic training setting.

598249.title: Pathophysiology of Illness
598249.description: Recognizing, evaluating and managing systemic illnesses and other health conditions. Pharmacological considerations for treating illnesses.

598250.title: Therapeutic Interventions I
598250.description: Theory and application of therapeutic interventions for musculoskeletal injuries. Pathophysiology of human tissue in response to injury, the neuropathway of pain perception and the influence of various interventions on the early phases of the rehabilitation process.

598251.title: Therapeutic Interventions II
598251.description: Theory and application of therapeutic interventions for musculoskeletal injuries. Re-establishing normal joint mechanics and movement patterns following injury by addressing muscular strength, endurance, power and neuromuscular control. Emphasizes fitness and functional movement patterns before return-to-activity.

598252.title: Therapeutic Interventions III
598252.description: Theory and application of non-traditional therapeutic interventions for the treatment of musculoskeletal injuries. Topics include existing evidence for non-traditional modalities, exercise, manual therapies, pharmacotherapy, biologics, etc.

596500.title: Advanced Study in Sport and Exercise Psychology
596500.description: Current issues and research in sport and exercise psychology. Topics include motivation, personality, leadership and group dynamics, attention/concentration, exercise adherence/compliance, sport and exercise injury, and behavioral change strategies.

596501.title: Consultation in Applied Sport Psychology
596501.description: Factors related to effective consultation for enhancing athletic performance. Knowledge of consultation issues will be derived from the existing best practices and literature with the purpose of drawing practical applications for the new professional. May be repeated once for credit.

596502.title: Advanced Study in Sociocultural Perspectives of Human Movement
596502.description: In-depth study of the theories and methods of the sociocultural perspective and their application to the study of human movement phenomena.

598566.title: Psychology of Injury
598566.description: Psychological theory, research and practice in relation to the prevention, occurrence, and rehabilitation of sport injuries. Major topics include psychological risk factors for injury, psychological responses to injury, and psychological interventions to prevent injuries and enhance injury rehabilitation. Requires department consent.
598566.prereqs: Prerequisite: KNES 589 with a “B-” or better.

598253.title: Emergency Management Clinical Experience
598253.description: Practical application of patient care skills and clinical decision-making in various athletic training and healthcare settings. Complete a rotation at an assigned clinical site while supervised by a CSUF ATP preceptor. Acute care of athletic-related injuries.

598255.title: Athletic Training Clinical Seminar I
598255.description: Develop clinical decision-making skills within Evidence Based Practice framework. Integrate theory from didactic courses with practical experience gained during concurrent clinical rotations. Lower extremity musculoskeletal evaluation and acute care techniques.
598255.prereqs: Prerequisite: Athletic Training graduate standing. Corequisite: KNES 587 .

598254.title: Athletic Training Clinical Experience I
598254.description: Practical application of patient care skills and clinical decision-making in various athletic training and healthcare settings. Complete a clinical rotation at an assigned clinical site while supervised by a CSUF ATP preceptor.

598256.title: Athletic Training Clinical Seminar II
598256.description: Develop clinical decision-making skills within Evidence Based Practice framework. Integrate theory from didactic courses with practical experience gained during concurrent clinical rotations. Musculoskeletal and general medical evaluation and rehabilitative exercise techniques.

598257.title: Athletic Training Clinical Experience II
598257.description: Practical application of patient care skills and clinical decision-making in various athletic training and healthcare settings. Complete a clinical rotation at an assigned clinical site while supervised by a CSUF ATP preceptor.

598258.title: Athletic Training Clinical Seminar III
598258.description: Developing clinical decision-making skills within Evidence Based Practice framework. Integrate theory from didactic courses with practical experience gained during concurrent clinical rotations. Head and spine evaluation and techniques for evaluating efficacy of non-traditional therapies.

598259.title: Athletic Training Clinical Experience III
598259.description: Practical application of patient care skills and clinical decision-making in various athletic training and healthcare settings. Complete a clinical rotation at an assigned clinical site while supervised by a CSUF ATP preceptor.

598260.title: AT Project
598260.description: Culminating experience for AT students that requires engagement in the scholarship of application. Demonstrate the ability to identify clinical problems and apply effective, evidence-based interventions. Present projects to faculty in a public forum following project completion.

598261.title: Athletic Training Clinical Experience IV- Immersive
598261.description: Intensive clinical experience of the totality of care provided by athletic trainers. Participate in the full-time, day-to-day role of an AT as appropriate for the clinical setting while supervised by a CSUF ATP preceptor.

596503.title: Project
596503.description: Directed independent inquiry. Not open to students on, or subject to, academic notice. Requires classified graduate standing, successful completion of an oral presentation of the project, and signature of all committee members on or before the census date of the semester in which the student elects to enroll.

596504.title: Thesis
596504.description: Student will select and have approved a research proposal, conduct the research, and prepare a formal analysis and report. Not open to students on, or subject to, academic probation. Requires classified graduate standing, successful completion of an oral presentation of the thesis, and signatures of all committee members on or before the census date of the semester in which the student elects to enroll.

596505.title: Graduate Independent Research
596505.description: Student research in a specific area of human movement studies. Application forms must be completed and approved prior to enrollment. Upon completion of the research, a written report must be submitted. Not open to students on, or subject to, academic notice. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Requires consent of the faculty adviser and chair.

596833.title: Fundamental Korean-A
596833.description: Develop listening and reading comprehension, speaking and writing, and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level. Introduction to Korean customs, culture and civilization. Conducted primarily in Korean.

597368.title: Health Psychology
597368.description: Biopsychosocial (biological, psychological, social) processes that affect the physical and mental condition of human beings. Health promotion, prevention, evaluation, treatment  (patients in treatment settings, patient-provided dynamics), chronic and terminal illness, and cultural influences on health and healthy care delivery. PSYC 351 is recommended.
597368.prereqs: Prerequisites: PSYC 101 , three upper-division psychology courses (PSYC 351 recommended) all with a “C” (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

598495.title: Psychopharmacology
598495.description: Basic neurophysiological principles of pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics that underlie the effects of drugs on experience and behavior. Recreational drugs and abused drugs that can contribute to psychological disorders. Psychological, medical and social implications of pharmacotherapy.

607264.title: Racial/Ethnic Health Psychology
607264.description: Preventing disease/illness and promoting health psychology for racial/ethnic persons living in the U.S. (e.g., Latinx, Black/African American, Asian/Asian American, Native American/Indigenous, Middle Eastern, North African communities). Racism as a stressor affecting health. Interventions to reduce community health disparities.
607264.prereqs: Prerequisites: PSYC 101 and completion of three upper-division psychology courses; or graduate standing.

597369.title: MARC Proseminar
597369.description: Intended to increase the contact of MARC Fellows with minority scientists of national repute who will present seminars. Fellows will read and discuss relevant primary literature, attend the seminars, and meet with speakers before and after the seminars. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 units. Requires selection as a MARC Fellow. (BIOL 480M, CHEM 480M and PSYC 480M are the same course.)

597370.title: Survey of Clinical Psychology
597370.description: Methods, diagnosis, therapeutic techniques, research, educational requirements, professional requirements, ethics, graduate school preparation, choosing graduate programs.

607265.title: Personnel Psychology
607265.description: Comprehensive survey of the psychological approaches applied to personnel recruitment, selection, job design, utilization, training performance criteria, separation and retention of personnel in the workplace.
607265.prereqs: Prerequisites: PSYC 101, PSYC 391; or graduate standing.

607266.title: Organizational Psychology
607266.description: Comprehensive survey of approaches to organizational culture, structure and change. Focus on organizational behavior, such as teamwork, leadership, motivation, job satisfaction, conflict, power and management strategies.
607266.prereqs: Prerequisites: PSYC 101, PSYC 391; or graduate standing.

597736.title: Teaching of Psychology
597736.description: Experience in communicating research, theory, and applications of psychology, with emphasis on individual tutoring. Section 1 (Undergraduate Course Assistantship) includes additional aspects of course instruction; Section 2 (Peer Mentors) includes various outreach services. May be repeated for credit (not for major or minor) towards graduation for a maximum of 6 units.

597371.title: Field Placement in Psychology
597371.description: Supervised experience in which psychological principles or methods are applied in a fieldwork setting. Mandatory class meetings to discuss and write about experiences of integrating psychological theory with practice. Required of majors.
597371.prereqs: Prerequisites: nine units of 300-level psychology courses at CSUF by course registration; 2.0 GPA in psychology courses.

597372.title: Independent Research
597372.description: Study plan must be approved by university census date. Individual empirical research or library investigation under the supervision of a faculty member. No more than three units of credit toward the major. May be repeated for credit toward graduation. Requires consent of Instructor.

597373.title: Issues and Perspectives in Psychological Research
597373.description: Current theoretical, professional and methodological issues in psychology.

597374.title: Professional and Legal Issues
597374.description: Introduction to methodological, ethical and legal issues in the field of Clinical Psychology.
597374.prereqs: Prerequisite: M.S. Clinical Psychology graduate standing.

597728.title: Career and Lifestyle Development
597728.description: Survey of career and lifestyle development throughout the lifespan. Major theories and strategies in career counseling. Integrating knowledge of career development with the practice of counseling. (COUN 502 and PSYC 502 are the same course).

597375.title: Research Design
597375.description: Principles and methods of planning and carrying out systematic psychological research, interdependence of research design and statistical evaluation of results. Practice in formulating testable hypotheses.
597375.prereqs: Prerequisites: PSYC 201 , PSYC 465 with a “B-” (2.7) or better; or graduate standing.

597376.title: Seminar: Advanced Topics in Psychological Research
597376.description: Content of seminar may vary each semester. A topic is selected for in-depth study from one or more specialty areas within the field of psychology. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 9 units.

598075.title: Addictions Counseling
598075.description: Etiology and treatment of addictive behaviors (e.g. substance abuse, gambling). Biological, psychological and systemic factors. Current approaches to assessment, intervention, prevention programs and relapse prevention, including Motivational Interviewing. Role of co-occurring disorders. Using community resources to help client and client's family. (COUN 535 and PSYC 535 are the same course).
598075.prereqs: Prerequisites: COUN 500 , COUN 511A ; or COUN 500 , COUN 511B ; or PSYC 501 , PSYC 545 .

598759.title: Crisis and Traumatic Stress: Theory, Research, and Intervention
598759.description: Overview of the crisis and traumatic stress fields, with an emphasis on intervention. History of the fields, the effects of exposure to traumatic stress, and approaches to assessing and ameliorating maladaptive outcomes.

597377.title: Advanced Psychopathology
597377.description: In-depth study of diagnosis, etiology theories, research and prevention of adult and child psychopathology.
597377.prereqs: Prerequisite: M.S. Clinical Psychology graduate standing.

597378.title: Theories of Psychological Intervention
597378.description: Psychology (Clinical) program. In-depth coverage of psychotherapy. Principle theoretical approaches covered are: psychodynamic, humanistic, and behavioral/ cognitive behavioral.
597378.prereqs: Prerequisite: M.S. Clinical Psychology graduate standing.

597379.title: Psychotherapy Techniques
597379.description: Psychology (Clinical) program. Skills course in conducting diagnostic interviews and basic therapeutic techniques. Role playing and video feedback. (2 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory)
597379.prereqs: Prerequisites: PSYC 501 , PSYC 545 , PSYC 547 all with a grade of “B-” (2.7) or better.

597380.title: Marriage, Family and Child Therapy
597380.description: Psychology (Clinical) program. Marriage, family and child therapy: theory, techniques and research.
597380.prereqs: Prerequisite: M.S. Clinical Psychology graduate standing.

597381.title: Group Psychotherapy
597381.description: Role of interpersonal learning and communication in the behavior change and skill development in group psychotherapy. Lecture, discussion, role plays and videos will focus on psychoeducational groups in an ethical and diversity-sensitive framework.
597381.prereqs: Prerequisite: M.S. Clinical Psychology graduate standing.

597382.title: Child and Adolescent Treatment
597382.description: Psychology (Clinical) program. Specific therapy techniques, including behavioral, and general approaches to the treatment of children and adolescents.
597382.prereqs: Prerequisites: PSYC 501 , PSYC 545 , PSYC 547 all with a “B-” (2.7) or better.

597383.title: Clinical Psychology Assessment
597383.description: Psychology (Clinical) program. Theory, administration, scoring and interpretation of measures of intelligence and objective personality inventories.
597383.prereqs: Prerequisites: PSYC 461 with a “B-” (2.7) or better; or graduate standing in clinical psychology.

597729.title: Intimate Partner and Couples Counseling
597729.description: Treating intimate partners and couples, including overview of current theories, assessment, goal-setting, interventions, ethical issues and diversity issues. Assessing and treating intimate partner violence. Sexual dysfunctions and sex therapy. (COUN 562 and PSYC 562 are the same course)

597385.title: Cross-Cultural Psychology
597385.description: Cross-cultural issues as they apply to clinical psychology, specifically psychotherapy. Practical, research and theoretical issues.
597385.prereqs: Prerequisites: PSYC 501 , PSYC 545 , PSYC 547 all with a “B-” (2.7) or better.

597386.title: Fieldwork
597386.description: Psychology (Clinical) program. Supervised clinical work in mental health agencies. (Minimum of 12 hours field experience per week.) Must be taken for a letter grade. (Course may be repeated by third-year students. Repetition will not count toward study plan units and should be taken CR/NC.)
597386.prereqs: Prerequisites: PSYC 548 , PSYC 560 all with a “B-” (2.7) or better.

597387.title: Fieldwork
597387.description: Psychology (Clinical) program. Supervised clinical work in mental health agencies. (Minimum of 12 hours field experience per week.) Must be taken for a letter grade. (Course may be repeated by third-year students. Repetition will not count toward study plan units and should be taken CR/NC.)
597387.prereqs: Prerequisite: PSYC 594A with a “B-” (2.7) or better.

597388.title: Thesis Research
597388.description: Supervised individual major research project, written as a thesis and presented and defended successfully to a faculty thesis committee. Consent of thesis adviser required.

597389.title: Independent Graduate Research
597389.description: Empirical research in a selected area of psychology. Design, conduct and write with the collaboration of a member of the faculty. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires supervising research instructor consent.

596092.title: Personal Health
596092.description: Basic concepts relating to health and well-being from a holistic perspective. Mental, emotional, physical and socio-environmental dimensions of health, sexuality and relationships; nutrition and physical fitness; use and abuse of drugs; health care services and current health problems.

598066.title: Introduction to Environmental Health and Safety
598066.description: How environmental and safety hazards influence public health and sustainability. Multiple perspectives on water, air, and solid waste pollutions, sustainability and public safety issues.

596093.title: Introduction to Aging Studies
596093.description: Multidisciplinary overview of: characteristics, strengths and problems of older persons; diversity in aging process involving gender, race, ethnicity, subculture; services to older adults; gerontology as an academic discipline and a field of practice. (AGNG 133, SOCI 133, PUBH 133, HUSR 133 and PSYC 133 are the same course.)

598284.title: Introduction to Public Health
598284.description: Introduction to the discipline of public health. Basic concepts and terminologies of public health. Topics include community health; environmental and occupational health; epidemiology; and healthcare policy and management.

598560.title: Exploration of Health and Allied Health Professions
598560.description: Overview of health-related professions in the U.S., including the healthcare system and major current concerns. Career exploration into health and allied health professions, including occupational, academic and extracurricular preparation. Develop knowledge to enhance preparation for graduate school.

596094.title: CPR, Automated External Defibrillator and First Aid
596094.description: Provides knowledge and skills necessary to respond to injuries and sudden illnesses in the community. Successful completion provides American Red Cross certifications in infant, child and adult Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR), Automated External Defibrillator (AED) and standard first aid. Credit/No Credit only. (PUBH 203 and KNES 203 are the same course)

597858.title: Integrative Health
597858.description: Theoretical and philosophical foundations of integrative health. Differences between biomedical and integrative approaches to health promotion, prevention, and treatment, Eastern and Western therapies, and various global medical systems.
597858.prereqs: Prerequisite: junior or senior standing; or Pre-Health Professions minor.

596095.title: Promotion of Optimal Health
596095.description: Advanced health concepts and practices. Common health problems, causative factors and methods for prevention. Preventive and promotive health concepts and practices; integrating physiological, psychosocial, spiritual, cultural and environmental factors that inhibit or facilitate optimal health. Elective for nursing majors only.
596095.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 1A or 1C; not freshman standing.

607253.title: Latinx Health
607253.description: Identification and examination of sources of health disparities and inequities among Latinxs; intersectionality; and health promotion best practices grounded in Latinx cultural capital and strengths.
607253.prereqs: Pre-requisites: PUBH 201, minor in Public Health or Pre-Health Professions. Co-requisite: PUBH 320.

607254.title: Public Health and the Environment
607254.description: This course introduces essential concepts in environmental health by exploring the impact of food production, transportation, and individual lifestyle choices on public health.
607254.prereqs: Prerequisites: non-freshman; completion of any Biology or Chemistry course in GE Area 5A or 5B

598537.title: Concepts in Public Health
598537.description: Theoretical and practical issues of public health as a profession. Resources, roles in various settings, ethical issues, academic and professional development in public health.
598537.prereqs: Prerequisites: Public Health major; not freshman standing.

596096.title: Drugs and Society
596096.description: Psychoactive substances from an interdisciplinary perspective. Social, historical, biological and legal aspects of substance use.

607255.title: Violence in Public Health Context
607255.description: The problem of violence from a public health perspective. Characteristics and epidemiology of major forms of violence that levy significant burden on public health across populations in various geographic settings. Public health approaches to preventing violence and reducing its harm.
607255.prereqs: Prerequisite: PUBH 201 with a “C-” (1.7) or better.

596097.title: Consumer Health
596097.description: Analyze and evaluate health information, products and services; medical quackery, fraudulent health practices, and laws and agencies protecting the consumer.
596097.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 1A or 1C; not freshman standing.

597856.title: Barrios and Health
597856.description: Links between urban environments and health. How community development and the grassroots help shape health in barrios. Requires service learning with non-profit organizations. (CHIC 338 and PUBH 338 are the same course.)

596098.title: Stress Management
596098.description: Nature of stress and physiological and psychological effects of prolonged stress responses. Short- and long-term somatic and behavioral techniques (exercise, relaxation, meditation, nutrition, time management and goal setting) for management of stress. (PUBH 342 and KNES 342 are the same course.)

596099.title: Measurement and Statistics in Health Science
596099.description: Measurement theory and statistics used to evaluate health and human performance, focusing on analyzing and interpreting data in different environments. Lecture, discussion, cooperative learning and field observation. Active participation and experiential learning.
596099.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 1A or 1C; not freshman standing.

598285.title: Applied Measurement and Statistics in Health Science
598285.description: Designed to give practical experience answering fundamental public health questions that arise in health science. Builds on concepts learned in PUBH 349, using quantitative methods and real-world datasets.
598285.prereqs: Pre- or corequisites: Public health major; PUBH 349.

596100.title: Nutrition
596100.description: Concepts of nutrition as they relate to nutritional needs, practices and problems throughout the life cycle. Nutritional counseling and education of individuals/groups toward health promotion and disease prevention.
596100.prereqs: Prerequisites: non-freshman; completion of any Biology or Chemistry course in GE Area 5A or 5B

598393.title: Physical Activity and Lifelong Well-Being
598393.description: Integrating physiological, psychological and sociological understandings of the human being in relationship to physical activity as a lifelong pursuit. Physical fitness, nutrition, stress reduction, socialization, and individual differences in human behavior. (PUBH 353 and KNES 353 are the same course.)

596101.title: Contemporary Issues in Children’s Health
596101.description: Overview of common causes of, interrelationships between, and prevention of morbidity and mortality among children and youth; preventive and promotive health concepts and practices; connections between health and learning are explored.
596101.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 1A or 1C; not freshman standing.

598854.title: Climate Change and Global Health
598854.description: Explore global health outcomes of climate change through social-ecological systems that influence patterns of infectious and chronic diseases worldwide. Cross-cutting themes, such as health equity and justice.

598212.title: Peer Mentoring for Public Health Student Success
598212.description: Develop mentorship skills through seminar learning and serving as a peer mentor to fellow students. Enhance communication, cultural competency, leadership, motivational, goal achievement, personal managementand student success skills.Barriers to and resources for college student success. Requires mentor application approval.

598368.title: Program Design in Kinesiology and Health Promotion
598368.description: Provides skills necessary for developing, implementing and evaluating human movement and/or health promotion programs for specific target populations.
598368.prereqs: Prerequisites: PUBH 349 , PUBH 349L ; or Public Health minor.

596102.title: Epidemiology
596102.description: Applying epidemiologic procedures to the understanding of the occurrence and control of infectious and chronic diseases, mental illness, environmental health hazards, accidents and geriatric problems.
596102.prereqs: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 ; PUBH 349 , KNES 349 or SOCI 303 .

598164.title: Introduction to the U.S. Healthcare System
598164.description: Addresses concepts related to U.S. health services organization, delivery, financing, and quality assessment and improvement. Historical influences and trends, contemporary challenges, and strategies to address these challenges are examined.

596463.title: Worksite Injury Prevention and Rehabilitation
596463.description: How work style, equipment, and environment contribute to worksite musculoskeletal injuries. Strategies that can minimize human error, injuries, discomfort and dissatisfaction through injury prevention and rehabilitation of the worker.
596463.prereqs: Prerequisites: KNES 202 or PUBH 320 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

596103.title: Community Health Education
596103.description: Multiple settings for community health education practice and professional roles and skills that are required for health educators. Identification of community health education concepts with application to various segments of the nation's health.
596103.prereqs: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 ; or Public Health or Pre-Health Professions minor.

596104.title: Promoting Health in Diverse Populations
596104.description: Impact of cultural variables on health/illness. Current and potential strategies to improve health care delivery to underrepresented groups. Identifying cultural competence skills that are essential for health educators.
596104.prereqs: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 ; or Public Health or Pre-Health Professions minor; or graduate standing.

596105.title: Environmental Health
596105.description: Overview of environmental factors such as noise, water and land pollutions, pests and contaminants that influence human and ecological health on the regional scale. Methods of control to prevent diseases from environmental agents.
596105.prereqs: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 or Public Health minor.

596106.title: Global Issues in Environmental Health
596106.description: Overview of environmental factors, such as air pollution, population dynamics, urbanization and energy production, that influence human and ecological health on the global scale. Methods of control to prevent diseases form environmental agents.
596106.prereqs: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

596107.title: Chronic Disease Epidemiology
596107.description: Areas in chronic disease epidemiology, the leading causes of death and disability, and the risk factors related to causes and the prevention of disease. May be repeated once for credit.

596108.title: Infectious Disease Epidemiology
596108.description: Applies epidemiological concepts to the study and control of infectious diseases in human populations. Epidemiological profile, including agents, modes of transmission, occurrence, clinical characteristics and prevention methods of specific infectious disease.

607256.title: Statistical Programming for Health Data Management and Visualization
607256.description: Provides applied statistical programming, data management and visualization skills for epidemiology and public health using real-world health data. Experience interpretating and communicating epidemiology and public health data programming outputs.
607256.prereqs: Prerequisites: PUBH 349, KNES 349, SOCI 303, or MATH 120; PUBH 349L; Public Health Major.

597862.title: Health Policy
597862.description: Health policy actors and processes in the United States. Roles of Congress, the President, bureaucracy and interests groups in health policy and policy process are explored, including an introduction to policy analysis. (PUBH 424 and POSC 424 are the same course).

596109.title: Alternative Healing Therapies
596109.description: Framework for understanding the philosophies, principles and use of alternative healing therapies. Includes analyzing research to demonstrate effectiveness and experiential learning.
596109.prereqs: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 or Public Health minor.

598218.title: Spirituality and Health
598218.description: Relationship between spirituality and health. Topics include: relevance of spirituality in one's life; impact of spirituality on decision making, health behavior; relationship of spirituality and health throughout lifespan; links between spirituality, health outcomes; diverse spiritualities.
598218.prereqs: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

596110.title: Determinants of Health Behavior
596110.description: Contemporary research on the health effect of human behavior. Introduction to theoretical foundations and practical applications of behavior in the context of health: physical, psychological, cultural and social health. Current issues and theories of health behavior.
596110.prereqs: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 or Public Health minor.

596111.title: Applied Health Promotion in Aging Populations
596111.description: Promotion/risk reduction program content, development, implementation and evaluation. Topics include weight control, stress management, substance abuse, physical fitness and accident prevention. (PUBH 450 and AGNG 450 are the same course.)
596111.prereqs: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 ; junior or senior standing; or Kinesiology or Sociology major; or Public Health or Gerontology minor; or graduate standing.

596112.title: Designing Health Education Curricula
596112.description: Theory and skills necessary to develop curriculum based on analysis of individual, community and societal needs and interests.

596113.title: Worksite Health Promotion
596113.description: Philosophy, rationale and guidelines for developing health promotion programs in the corporate setting. Unique considerations in assessing needs, planning and implementing programs, evaluating effectiveness and coordinating activities in the workplace are discussed. (PUBH 460 and KNES 460 are the same course.)
596113.prereqs: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 or KNES 202 ; not freshman standing; or Public Health minor; or graduate standing.

596114.title: Occupational Health and Safety
596114.description: Occupational health principles, including anticipation, recognition, evaluation and control of occupational hazards are presented to heighten awareness of workplace hazards on human health. Occupational health laws, regulations and methods of compliance.
596114.prereqs: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

596115.title: Toxicology in Public Health
596115.description: Fundamental toxicological concepts, including absorption, distribution, storage, biotransformation and elimination of toxicants, target organ toxicity and risk assessment. Toxicological effects of environmental agents, such as pesticides, industrial chemicals, household chemicals and food contaminants.
596115.prereqs: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

596116.title: Air Pollution and Health
596116.description: Health effects of air pollutants on local, regional, and global scales are addressed. Health effects of urban smog, particulate matter, indoor, outdoor, and occupational exposures. Health implications from global warming, ozone-depletion and acid rain.
596116.prereqs: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

596117.title: Introduction to International Health
596117.description: Issues in international health emphasizing core disease conditions. Introduction to leading causes of death and disability within an international context, as well as programmatic and policy responses to improve international health.
596117.prereqs: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

598618.title: Hazardous Materials, Regulations and Emergency Response
598618.description: Principles of hazardous material management, hazardous waste handling and chemical emergency response. Understand chemical classifications and waste disposal requirements; analyze federal and state environmental health and safety regulations; and evaluate exposure mitigation strategies and emergency response planning and execution.

598742.title: Food Safety
598742.description: Overview of public health response in safeguarding and investigating food safety issues and food-borne illnesses. Discussion of various requirements in managing a food protection program to identify and prevent important biological and chemical agents of foodborne illnesses.
598742.prereqs: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 , GE Area 5B; Public Health minor; or graduate standing.

598892.title: Fundamentals of Industrial Hygiene
598892.description: Introduction to essential industrial hygiene concepts; various hazards or environmental contaminants encountered in the workplace; exposure evaluation methods and effective controls.
598892.prereqs: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor; or graduate standing.

597863.title: Childhood Obesity, Nutrition and Social Context
597863.description: Multidisciplinary approach to understanding childhood obesity in diverse/underserved populations, including basic biological processes, the role of nutrition, health consequences and cultural factors associated with childhood obesity.
597863.prereqs: Prerequisites: PUBH 350 ; PUBH 320 or Public Health, Pre-Health Professions or Food Studies minor; or graduate standing.

598165.title: Nutritional Assessment
598165.description: Overview of nutritional assessment. Gain practice in and understand four primary nutritional assessment techniques: anthropometric, biochemical, clinical and dietary.
598165.prereqs: Prerequisites: PUBH 350 ; PUBH 320 or Public Health, Pre-Health Professions or Food Studies minor; or graduate standing.

598484.title: Public Health Planning, Research and Evaluation
598484.description: Identify and apply foundational methodological concepts in research used in public health. Research designs, sampling, data collection and analytic strategies, reporting, valid sourcing and ethical considerations.

596118.title: Transdisciplinary Perspectives on HIV/AIDS
596118.description: Multilevel examination of the HIV/AIDS pandemic from the perspectives of several disciplines within an overarching public health framework. Analysis at the levels of individuals and physical, social-structural and cultural environments.
596118.prereqs: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 , PUBH 401 ; or graduate standing.

598503.title: Health in a Global Society
598503.description: Health effects of globalization. Health concerns arising from political, economic and social interconnectedness and the need to find common solutions to ensure human health worldwide.
598503.prereqs: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

596119.title: Health Science Practicum
596119.description: A requirement for health science majors offering an opportunity to plan, implement and evaluate special community-based projects under faculty supervision. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Credit/no credit only.

596120.title: Internship in Public Health
596120.description: Supervised observation and field experience in community health settings as conducted by government, voluntary, professional or industrial/corporate organizations. May be repeated once for credit.
596120.prereqs: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 ; all PUBH 400-level classes except PUBH 475 ; senior standing.

598485.title: Independent Study
598485.description: Topics based on a study plan prepared in cooperation with a faculty supervisor. Culminates in a paper, project, comprehensive examination or performance. Application forms must be completed and approved prior to enrollment. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units; only three units in any one semester.
598485.prereqs: Prerequisites: minimum of 15 upper-division Public Health courses; junior or senior standing.

596121.title: Issues in Public Health
596121.description: Historical perspectives, definitions and discussion of current public health issues. Prepares public health professionals to draw on knowledge and skills from a variety of disciplines to define, critically assess, evaluate and resolve public health problems.

596122.title: Advanced Methods in Epidemiology
596122.description: Advanced application of epidemiologic procedures to the understanding of the occurrence and control of diseases and other health problems. Emphasis is given to study design, data quality, statistical analysis and causal inference.

607278.title: Communicating for Public Health Practice
607278.description: This course introduces students to the applied study of communication theory and data visualization to improve the public?s health. Explores varied modalities of both written and oral communication including online dissemination, focusing on tailoring messages and mediums to intended audiences.

596123.title: Measures and Methods in Public Health
596123.description: This course introduces concepts and methods to describe population patterns of health and their determinants. Students will focus on what to measure, how to measure, and minimizing bias. These concepts and skills are used to critically analyze public health data.

598177.title: Qualitative Research and Field Methods in Health
598177.description: Theory, epistemology, sampling, data collection, data analysis and reporting results in qualitative research and evaluation. Field work in communities and applications to health.

596124.title: Research Methods in Public Health
596124.description: Fundamental tools of research. Types of research, process of scientific inquiry and critical analysis of research. Topic selection and development of a research.

596125.title: Advanced Environmental Health
596125.description: Ecological impacts of human activities and the need to control factors that are harmful to human health. A framework is provided for investigation/management of health hazards. Principles of environmental health emphasizes the relationships between population, natural resources, disease, toxicology and pollution.

596127.title: Public Health Administration
596127.description: Principles, practices and skills essential to successful public health administration. U.S. health care system and factors that shape it. Public health services and administration, patterns of diseases, managed care, ethics and quality of care.

598487.title: Program Planning and Evaluation
598487.description: Comprehensive theories and methods for planning and evaluating health promotion programs. Techniques for collecting and analyzing quantitative and qualitative data. Skills for measuring effectiveness of health promotion programs. (PUBH 535 and AGNG 535 are the same course)
598487.prereqs: Prerequisite: Public Health or Aging Studies graduate standing.

598488.title: Advanced Study in Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
598488.description: Psychological, social, ecological, economic and political theories relevant to the mission and process of health promotion. Applying behavioral change techniques and health education methodology to health promotion targeting individuals and whole communities.

598489.title: MPH Student Internship
598489.description: Apply classroom knowledge to practical problems in the field, acquire additional knowledge and skills, carry out a mutually beneficial project, produce a written analytical evaluation and interact regularly with public health professionals.

598490.title: MPH Integrative Learning Experience
598490.description: Faculty-mentored, student-driven project that synthesizes program foundational and emphasis competencies into an integrated learning experience resulting in a high-quality written product.

598491.title: Thesis
598491.description: Student will select and have approved a research proposal, conduct the research and prepare a formal analysis and report. Not open to students on, or subject to, academic probation. Requires graduate classified status, successful completion of an oral presentation of the thesis and signatures of all committee members on or before the census date of the semester in which the student elects to enroll.

598492.title: Graduate Independent Research
598492.description: Student research in a specific area of public health. Application forms must be completed and approved prior to enrollment. Upon completion of the research, a written report must be submitted. Not open to students on, or subject to, academic notice. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units; only 3 units in any one semester. Requires consent of the faculty adviser and chair.

597039.title: Individual Instruction
597039.description: Individual study with assigned instructor. Performance technique, repertoire and other responsibilities as assigned. Jury examination required. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 4 units. Requires jury recommendation.

597040.title: Senior Project
597040.description: Independent investigation of an area of special interest in music culminating in a research paper, lecture, or lecture-recital. May be taken for credit for a maximum of two units.

597041.title: Recital
597041.description: Preparation and presentation of representative works in the principal performance area. In the semester of recital presentation, MUS 498 is coupled with MUS 491. Requires 400 jury level in the principal performance area (400 jury level in composition for composition majors).
597041.prereqs: Corequisite: MUS 365I , MUS 365G , MUS 465K or MUS 365V ; MUS 491 .

597042.title: Independent Study
597042.description: Special topic in music selected in consultation with and supervised by the instructor. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units..

597043.title: Introduction to Graduate Study in Music
597043.description: Required of all music graduate students within the first nine study-plan units. Basic bibliography, literature and research techniques, as well as other materials useful in graduate study.

598965.title: Arranging/Composing for Large Jazz Ensembles
598965.description: Writing for large jazz ensembles and commercial string ensembles: wind, brass, and rhythm sections, adding French horns and strings. Advanced textures and voicings of Sammy Nestico, Thad Jones, Maria Schneider and Bob Brookmeyer. Arrangements performed by CSUF students. Previous experience in arranging large ensembles may be substituted for the prerequisite.

597044.title: Seminar in Music Theory
597044.description: Theoretical subjects (form/style analysis, history of music theory, etc.) to be chosen by instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

597045.title: Seminar in Music of the Renaissance
597045.description: Forms, styles and characteristics of music between 1400 and 1600. Analysis of works by representative composers and theoretical writers.

597046.title: Seminar in Music of the Baroque Period
597046.description: Musical forms, styles and performance practices of the Baroque period. Analysis of representative works.

597047.title: Seminar in Music of the Classic Period
597047.description: History and literature of music from approximately 1730 to 1820. Analysis of representative works.

597048.title: Seminar in Music of the Romantic Period
597048.description: Structure and development of music in the 19th century. Analysis of representative works.

597049.title: Seminar in Twentieth-Century American Music
597049.description: History and literature of American art music in the 20th century. Analysis of representative musical works and repertories, as well as musical, historical and social developments.

598843.title: Seminar in Film Music
598843.description: Broad and up-close look at the use of music in American films and the history of the American motion picture industry, especially as related to music. May include international, non-American film music.

598844.title: Seminar in Popular Music
598844.description: History of and analytical approaches to musical idioms in popular culture. Analyze representative albums, songs and criticism.

597050.title: Seminar in Piano Pedagogy
597050.description: Graduate-level study of advanced learning theories, musical issues and pedagogical methods involved in teaching piano through lectures, discussions and student presentations. Practice teaching required. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

598652.title: Seminar in Jazz History
598652.description: Jazz forms, styles, performance practices and theory. Requirements can be met by performance and/or analysis. May be repeated for a maximum of six units.

597053.title: Seminar in Piano Literature
597053.description: Advanced study of piano literature, with performances and analyses by class members and lectures by the instructor. Requirements can be met by performance and/or analysis. May be repeated for credit.

597054.title: Seminar in Advanced Choral Conducting and Interpretation
597054.description: Choral conducting techniques. Lab work with student groups and concert conducting. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires conducting experience.

597055.title: Individual Instruction
597055.description: Individual study with assigned instructor. Performance technique, repertoire and other responsibilities as assigned. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 5 units. Requires jury recommendation.

597056.title: Individual Instruction
597056.description: Individual study with assigned instructor. Performance technique, repertoire and other responsibilities as assigned. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 10 units. Requires jury recommendation.

597057.title: Project
597057.description: The culminating experience of all M.M. students, and of M.A. Music Education and M.A. Piano Pedagogy students who so elect. Number of units is variable depending on options chosen in conjunction with advisers from activities, such as public recitals, lecture, corollary essay, original composition(s) or a significant research study. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 3 units.

597058.title: Thesis
597058.description: Individual investigations of specific problems in the area of concentration by candidates for the M.A. degree. Students must submit an enrollment request form by week one of the preceding semester.

597059.title: Independent Graduate Research
597059.description: Research and study projects in areas of specialization beyond regularly offered coursework. Oral and/or written reports required. Students must submit an enrollment request form by week one of the preceding semester. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units.

598908.title: School Instrumental Music
598908.description: Develop a literature programming/marching band philosophy and a base of knowledge regarding available resources and materials for a successful career in a variety of school settings.

597060.title: Music Education Practicum
597060.description: For Music Education majors. Observation and application of musical concepts and materials, repertoire selection, sequential pedagogy, classroom delivery skills, and concurrent development of management skills, aural and visual discrimination skills, error detection and transposition skills.

597061.title: Clinical Practice in Conducting
597061.description: For Music Education majors. Clinical practice and field applications of concepts, materials and procedures as applied to field situations, as in public and private schools. Each student observes, analyzes, assists when appropriate, and document a variety of actual classroom teaching situations and performances at various levels.

597062.title: Microcomputers and MIDI for School Music Classrooms
597062.description: Pre-service and in-service music teachers learn how to use microcomputers and musical instrument digital interface (MIDI) for classroom management and pedagogical purposes. Students gain experience with software for word processing, database, spreadsheet, music notation, music pedagogy, and MIDI.

597063.title: Principles and Methods of Teaching Music in the Public Schools
597063.description: History, principles of public education, grades K-12, with emphasis on music. Philosophy, methods, materials and procedures for organizing and teaching music in elementary and secondary schools. A "B-" (2.7) or better is required to earn a preliminary Single Subject credential.
597063.prereqs: Prerequisite: Teacher Education Credential Program student. Pre- or Corequisites: EDSC 440F , EDSC 440S .

598909.title: Externship in Single Subject Teaching
598909.description: Eight-week practicum (150 hours) fieldwork in single subject classrooms. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit. Students sign up for the appropriate departmental offering. Requires admission to the Single Subject Credential Program. May be repeated once for credit. (EDSC 449E, ARTE 449E, KNES 449E, MAED 449E, MUSE 449E, and THTR 449E are the same course.)
598909.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to Single Subject Credential Program.

598910.title: Second Semester Student Teaching
