598910.description: A 450-hour practicum in a single subject in public schools. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit. Departmental course offerings are: ARTE 449I, EDSC 449I, KNES 449I, MAED 449I, MUSE 449I, THTR 449I.

597064.title: Seminar in Secondary Teaching
597064.description: For candidates who have declared for the single subject credential in music.

598547.title: Seminar in Choral Pedagogy
598547.description: For graduate students seeking better knowledge of choral music instruction. Topics: strategies for cognitive transfer; learning theory; classroom management; conducting gesture; choral tone; sequencing instruction; philosophical foundations of education; pacing; instructional techniques; advocacy; assessment; and current issues in music education.

597065.title: Medical Terminology
597065.description: Introduction to medical terminology using word building (roots, suffixes, prefixes, spelling, and pronunciation) as they relate to anatomical structure and function. Additional topics include medical terminology related to pharmacology, abnormal conditions, surgical procedures, and diagnosis and treatment of medical conditions. (KNES 205 and NURS 205 are the same course.)

597066.title: Professional Nursing
597066.description: Examine professional nursing roles, including nursing history, ethics, research, theories and frameworks. Introduces advocacy, health promotion, genetics, genomics, inter-professional practice and patient safety. Instructional technologies and information literacy. Meets upper-division writing requirement.

597067.title: Nursing Research/Evidence-Based Practice
597067.description: Understanding and appraising research evidence, and the role of research in developing nursing knowledge. Examine research methods and analyze current issues in relation to integrating and implementing evidence-based practice.

597068.title: Health Assessment
597068.description: Health assessment across the lifespan. Basic knowledge and skills necessary to perform assessments, including interviewing, history taking and foundational physical assessment skills are acquired. Developmental and culturally competent assessment skills and ability to recognize deviations from normal.
597068.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s program in Nursing. Corequisite: NURS 321L .

597069.title: Health Assessment Professional Practice Laboratory
597069.description: Practice history talking, physical examination techniques, and risk identification on peers during supervised campus laboratory sessions. Apply the skills and techniques acquired to intervene and reduce risks and/or promote health with individual clients during clinical laboratory. Credit/No Credit only. (3 hours laboratory).
597069.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to pre-licensure pathway to the bachelor or master’s program in Nursing; Corequisite: NURS 321 .

597070.title: Concepts of Professional  Nursing
597070.description: Professional nursing role within the health care environment, including nursing theory and interpersonal communication. Theory and evidence-based nursing practice. Influence of culture and professional values on the role of the professional nurse. Meets undergraduate writing requirement.
597070.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s program in Nursing.

597071.title: Integrated Pathophysiology and Pharmacology
597071.description: Normal physiology and anatomy, altered physiologic states and nursing management of selected pathophysiologic disorders and diseases. Core drug knowledge, pharmacotherapeutics, pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics. Drug classifications by categories affecting various body systems and disease states.
597071.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s program in Nursing.

597072.title: Cultural Diversity in Health and Illness
597072.description: Development approach to providing culturally appropriate nursing care. Growth, development and sociocultural factors that influence the health and illness of various cultural groups and explores factors that impact the use of health care resources.
597072.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to prelicensure Nursing pathway.

597864.title: Health Assessment
597864.description: Concepts and principles of comprehensive assessment of the health status, emphasizing interviewing skills, health histories, physical and psychosocial findings required for detailed health and family histories across the life span with consideration of the influence of culture.
597864.prereqs: Pre- or corequisite: NURS 305 . Corequisite: NURS 340L .

597865.title: Health Assessment Lab
597865.description: Learn and demonstrate appropriate interviewing and technical skills in examining the client, emphasizing the history and physical assessment and health promotion.

597073.title: Pathophysiology
597073.description: Builds upon and explores major pathophysiological concepts using a body systems approach that is critical to clinical decision making in nursing. Recognize pathophysiological manifestations as they relate to disease processes.
597073.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Areas 5A, 5B. Pre- or corequisites: NURS 305 , NURS 310 .

598455.title: Critical Thinking in Nursing
598455.description: Use problem-based clinical case studies to critically analyze approaches to selected problems in nursing practice. Includes application of test-taking strategies, the nursing process, use of evidence-based practice concepts, and analysis of clinical practice issues.
598455.prereqs: Prerequisite: completion of one semester in the prelicensure Nursing pathway.

598555.title: Peer Mentoring for Nursing Student Success
598555.description: Facilitates overall development by augmenting leadership, relationship building, communication skills, cultural sensitivity and effective goal setting through the experience of mentoring student peers. Learn to convey skills of self-management, resource utilization and confidence to others. Requires minimum of one semester in the nursing program.

597074.title: Population Health Nursing
597074.description: Introduction to population health, public health core functions and services related to community as client. Epidemiology, ethical principles, mandates, multidisciplinary theories/models, research utilization and client advocacy applied to the nursing process for best practices for diverse, vulnerable, at risk populations.
597074.prereqs: Prerequisites: NURS 340 , NURS 340L , NURS 345 ; GE Area 4A. Corequisite: NURS 402L .

597075.title: Population Health Nursing Lab
597075.description: Practicum for community-oriented population nursing practice. Use community assessment, epidemiology, environmental, health education, political action and case-management frameworks to guide evidence-based nursing care delivery to persons, families and populations in community settings.

597076.title: Foundations of Nursing Practice
597076.description: Concepts of physiological integrity; psychosocial integrity, safe, effective care environments and health promotion/maintenance. Beginning competencies required for care of adult and older adult clients with acute and chronic health problems across a variety of practice settings.
597076.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s in Nursing. Corequisite: NURS 403L .

597077.title: Foundations of Nursing Practice Lab
597077.description: Acquire basic nursing skills in simulated and actual clinical settings. Interpersonal communication, safety documentation and selected basic nursing interventions required for clients with acute and chronic health problems.
597077.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s in Nursing. Corequisite: NURS 403 .

597078.title: Mental Health Nursing
597078.description: Integrates theory from nursing, related fields, communication and critical thinking in providing nursing care for multicultural individuals, families, groups and specific populations with mental illness. Providing professional nursing care that promotes mental health and adaptation to mental illness.
597078.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s in Nursing; PSYC 101 , NURS 321 , NURS 321L , NURS 322 , NURS 323 , NURS 403 , NURS 403L . Corequisite: NURS 404L .

597079.title: Mental Health Nursing Lab
597079.description: Develop interpersonal communication skills and therapeutic use of self. Develop role of nurse as provider, designer and coordinator of care for individuals, families and community groups with mental health care needs.
597079.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s in Nursing; NURS 321 , NURS 321L , NURS 403 , NURS 403L . Corequisite: NURS 404 .

597080.title: Management of Medical Surgical Adult and Older Adult Clients
597080.description: Nursing theory for care of adult and older adult clients with medical-surgical health alterations. Diagnostic and therapeutic nursing interventions relevant to medical-surgical health alterations. Nursing process and critical thinking to manage acute and chronic medical-surgical problems.
597080.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s in Nursing; NURS 321 , NURS 321L , NURS 403 , NURS 403L . Corequisite: NURS 405L .

597081.title: Management of Medical-Surgical Adult and Older Adult Clients Laboratory
597081.description: Opportunities to practice advanced nursing skills in simulated and actual clinical settings. Further development of the nursing role in providing and coordinating care for adult and older adult clients with acute and chronic medical-surgical health alterations.
597081.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s in Nursing; NURS 321 , NURS 321L , NURS 403 , NURS 403L . Corequisite: NURS 405 .

597082.title: Reproductive Health Nursing
597082.description: Nursing theory for caring diverse and multicultural women, newborns and families. Integrating and applying theory from nursing and related fields, standards of clinical practice, evidence-based practice, communication and critical thinking with the nursing process.
597082.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s program in Nursing; NURS 321 , NURS 321L , NURS 403 , NURS 403L , NURS 404 , NURS 404L , NURS 405 , NURS 405L . Corequisite: NURS 406L .

597083.title: Reproductive Health Nursing Laboratory
597083.description: Integrating and applying the nursing process in providing care for multicultural women, neonates and their families. Developing the role of nurse as provider, designer and coordinator of care for women across the lifespan.
597083.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s in Nursing; NURS 321 , NURS 321 , NURS 403 , NURS 403L , NURS 404 , NURS 404L , NURS 405 , NURS 405L . Corequisite: NURS 406 .

597084.title: Child Health Nursing
597084.description: Integrating and applying nursing process in providing age-appropriate care and advocating for infants, children and adolescents. Collaborating with the child, family and other members of the health care team to promote and adapt to illness.
597084.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s in Nursing; NURS 321 , NURS 321L , NURS 403 , NURS 403L , NURS 404 , NURS 404L , NURS 405 , NURS 405L . Corequisite: NURS 407L .

597085.title: Child Health Nursing Lab
597085.description: Apply the dimensions of health, health care and nursing in addressing the health care needs of infants, children and adolescents, focusing on health promotion, risk reduction and disease prevention.
597085.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s program in Nursing; NURS 321 , NURS 321L , NURS 403 , NURS 403L , NURS 404 , NURS 404L , NURS 405 , NURS 405L . Corequisite: NURS 407 .

597086.title: Nursing Externship
597086.description: Gain additional clinical experience while employed in a clinical setting. Under the direct supervision of a registered nurse preceptor, provide direct care to selected patients, consistent with the student's level of clinical experience. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. (1 hour seminar, 9 hours clinical externship)
597086.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s in Nursing; NURS 321 , NURS 321L , NURS 323 , NURS 403 , NURS 403L , NURS 404 , NURS 404L , NURS 405 , NURS 405L , NURS 406 , NURS 406L , NURS 407 , NURS 407L .

597087.title: Leadership/Management in Professional Nursing
597087.description: Integrating the leadership role with professional nursing. Theories of leadership, management and organizations; their application to health care agencies. Importance of collaboration, accountability and advocacy in the leadership role.
597087.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s in Nursing; NURS 321 , NURS 321L , NURS 403 , NURS 403L , NURS 404 , NURS 404L , NURS 405 , NURS 405L , NURS 406 , NURS 406L , NURS 407 , NURS 407L . Corequisite: NURS 410L .

597088.title: Leadership/Management in Professional Nursing Laboratory
597088.description: Practicum for leadership role within professional nursing. Concepts of decision making, critical thinking, ethics, advocacy, power, quality, safety, inter-professional collaboration, performance improvement, group dynamics and functioning as a team member are demonstrated.
597088.prereqs: Prerequisites: NURS 406 , NURS 406L , NURS 407 , NURS 407L ; or admission to Integrated Community College or RN to BSN pathway. Corequisite: NURS 410 .

597089.title: Management of the Adult with Complex Health Alterations
597089.description: Nursing theory for caring adult and older adult clients with complex health alterations. Diagnostic and therapeutic nursing interventions relevant to advanced medical-surgical health alterations. Nursing process and critical thinking to manage and coordinate care.
597089.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s in Nursing; NURS 321 , NURS 321L , NURS 403 , NURS 403L , NURS 404 , NURS 404L , NURS 405 , NURS 405L , NURS 406 , NURS 406L , NURS 407 , NURS 407L . Corequisite: NURS 411L .

597090.title: Management of the Adult with Complex Health Alterations Laboratory
597090.description: Design and coordinate advanced medical surgical nursing care for adult and older adult clients with complex health alterations. Advanced medical-surgical and critical care nursing. Critical thinking, organization, leadership and time management skills. Credit/no credit only.
597090.prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to prelicensure pathway to the bachelor’s or master’s program in Nursing; NURS 321 , NURS 321L , NURS 403 , NURS 403L , NURS 404 , NURS 404L , NURS 405 , NURS 405L , NURS 406 , NURS 406L , NURS 407 , NURS 407L . Corequisite: NURS 411 .

598616.title: Capstone Theory
598616.description: The transition to practice, emphasizing critical thinking, coordinating care and focusing on applying theory and nursing process for purposes of planning, implementing and evaluating care delivery for patients.
598616.prereqs: Prerequisites: NURS 411 , NURS 411L ; Nursing major. Pre- or corequisites: NURS 402 , NURS 402L ; or NURS 410 , NURS 410L .

597091.title: Capstone Nursing Practicum
597091.description: Supervised practicum experience focusing on applying theory and nursing process for purpose of planning, implementing and evaluating care delivery for patients as individuals and cohorts.

597093.title: Leadership/Management in Professional Nursing
597093.description: Compares application of management and organizational theories within professional nursing leadership. Concepts of professionalism, ethics, advocacy, power, quality/safety, collaboration, change, group dynamics, finance and decision making.
597093.prereqs: Prerequisites: NURS 305 , NURS 310 , NURS 340 , NURS 340L , NURS 345 .

597868.title: Art and Science of Nursing
597868.description: Concepts of the humanistic art and science of nursing and inter-professional collaboration. Emphasize trans-generational health behaviors and aging. Competencies identified by regulatory/accrediting bodies compared to student learning outcomes.
597868.prereqs: Prerequisites: NURS 305 , NURS 310 , NURS 340 , NURS 340L , NURS 345 .

597094.title: Independent Study in Nursing
597094.description: Individually supervised studies and/or projects. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

598669.title: Theoretical and Research Perspectives for Advanced Nursing Practice
598669.description: Develop knowledge and utilize theory, evidence-based practice, and research methods, interpretation, critique, and utilization. Must pass with a "C" (2.0) or better.

597097.title: Seminar in Nursing Research
597097.description: Concepts and issues related to evidence-based practice. Developing and refining the directed project/research proposal. Proposal includes problem/purpose statements, literature review, measurement tools, work plan, timeline, method and evaluation (analysis/synthesis) plan.

597098.title: Advanced Decision Making: Nursing Issues Seminar
597098.description: Applies critical thinking and decision making theory to professional issues within the context of ethical/legal and public policy considerations and with multidisciplinary health teams.

597099.title: Advanced Nursing: Vulnerable Populations
597099.description: Applies epidemiological model to analyze the health risk factors that place populations at risk for health conditions, and plan nursing interventions to promote health and prevent disease.

597100.title: Development and Evaluation of Nursing Curricula
597100.description: Major components of, and processors for, curriculum development and program evaluation. Analyze a curriculum and utilize a program evaluation model to recommend curricular revisions.

597101.title: Theoretical Basis of Leadership and Organizations in Nursing
597101.description: Theoretical bases for organizational context, structure and function. Models for leadership within a health care industry that deals with diverse client populations.

597102.title: Instructional Design in Nursing Education
597102.description: Course design and instructional strategies to include teaching modalities, including use of simulation and evaluating student learning.

597103.title: Nursing Service Economics
597103.description: Applying critical thinking and decision-making theory to economic control techniques within the organizational context of complex health care systems. Review budgeting terminology and concepts in detail, as well as current trends and regulatory requirement for operations.
597103.prereqs: Prerequisite: admission to the Nursing Leadership concentration.

597104.title: Nursing Service Leadership Practicum I
597104.description: Supervised learning experiences in leadership in nursing. Applying organizational and nursing theories and identifying researchable problems in nursing leadership. (1 hour seminar and 8 hours practicum per week.)
597104.prereqs: Prerequisite: NURS 513 . Pre- or corequisite: NURS 511 .

598543.title: Nursing Service Administration Practicum II
598543.description: Synthesis of theory and practice to develop and utilize techniques for strategic management in nursing service administration. Issues relevant to advanced nursing roles. (1 hour seminar and 8 hours practicum per week, each semester)

598037.title: Nurse Educator Teaching Practicum
598037.description: Applying theories and concepts in curriculum development, evaluation, instructional strategies, and student evaluation in nursing education. Work with an experienced nurse educator in the academic or agency setting under the supervision of the instructor.
598037.prereqs: Prerequisites: NURS 502 , NURS 505B , NURS 510 , NURS 512 , NURS 517 .

598166.title: Nurse Educator Clinical Practicum
598166.description: Working with a master's or doctorally prepared nurse with advanced clinical knowledge and skills, the student will demonstrate expanded clinical knowledge and proficiency in the student's area of clinical practice.
598166.prereqs: Prerequisites: NURS 502 , NURS 505B , NURS 510 , NURS 512 , NURS 517 , NURS 540 , NURS 542L , NURS 552 .

597105.title: Assessment and Evaluation in Nursing Education
597105.description: Assessment and evaluation strategies utilized in nursing education. Conceptual frameworks; formative and summative strategies for assessing, testing and evaluation learning; clinical evaluation; and course and program evaluation.

597861.title: Healthcare Quality and Safety
597861.description: Patient safety and its relationship to overall improvement in the quality of health care emphasizing the leaders' role in creating and sustaining a culture of safety.

597876.title: Informatics in Healthcare
597876.description: Using information systems/technology resources to implement quality improvement initiatives and support practice and administrative decision-making. Standards and principles for selecting and evaluating information systems and patient technology, and related ethical, regulatory and legal issues.
597876.prereqs: Prerequisite: Admission to the MSN or DNP program.

597875.title: Advanced Concepts in Leadership of Health Care Systems
597875.description: Focuses on advanced concepts in health care leadership, including health work environments, ethics, human resources, innovation management, interdisciplinary collaboration and organizational governance.
597875.prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate standing in MSN, Nursing Leadership concentration; NURS 502 , NURS 507 , NURS 511 , NURS 513 .

597106.title: Advanced Health Assessment: Ambulatory Pediatrics
597106.description: Knowledge/skills required to conduct a pediatric assessment appropriate to the age of the child/adolescent and the nature of the visit. Collection, analysis and application of health/physical assessment data on children within the school environment.
597106.prereqs: Prerequisites: undergraduate course in Health Assessment; admission to the school Nursing program.

597108.title: School Nurse Specialist I
597108.description: Advanced theory and practice of school nursing, emphasizing the health care provider role of the school nurse with children of varying ages, including those with special needs and learning disabilities.

597109.title: School Nurse Specialist II
597109.description: Advanced practice role of school nurses focusing on program level issues. Management, coordination, resource utilization, advocacy, health care policy and communication with school staff, educators, administrators, clients and families within school districts.

597110.title: School Nurse Specialist Practicum
597110.description: Field study applying theory, research, and clinical skills related to the multifaceted role of the professional school nurse. Planning, coordinating, and providing health care in school/community settings. Assessing and managing children's health care needs.
597110.prereqs: Prerequisite: NURS 530 . Pre- or corequisite: NURS 532 .

597111.title: Advanced Pathophysiology: Clinical Implications for Nurses
597111.description: Principles of normal body functioning, pathophysiologic and psychological changes occurring with altered health across life span. Clinical case studies utilized to demonstrate the pathophysiologic basis for assessment and management of common health problems. May be repeated once for credit.

597112.title: Advanced Health Assessment
597112.description: Apply theoretical concepts related to comprehensive health assessment of patients across the lifespan. Analyze, synthesize and apply comprehensive health assessment data, including the bio-psychosocial, development and environmental needs of patients and families.
597112.prereqs: Prerequisite: Nursing graduate standing. Corequisite: NURS 542L .

597113.title: Advanced Health Assessment Laboratory
597113.description: Clinical application of advanced health assessment skills and strategies necessary for advanced practice nursing role in a particular area of specialization. (3 hours practicum per week)

597114.title: Health Promotion/Disease Prevention
597114.description: National clinical preventive services guidelines for health promotion, disease prevention, health assessment and screening pertinent to various age groups. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 units. Requires consent of instructor.

597115.title: Primary Care of Women I: Family Planning/Gynecology
597115.description: Primary health care by advanced practice nurses for women, including assessment, diagnosis prevention, research and management of common gynecologic and family planning problems. Supporting reproductive pathophysiology and patient education. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

597116.title: Primary Care: Acute Problems I
597116.description: Theory and research related to the problems affecting patients and families across the lifespan. Health promotion, disease prevention, assessment, differential diagnosis, management and patient/family education and counseling related to these conditions. Quality health care, resource management and shared-decision making.

597117.title: Advanced Practice Nurse Clinical Practicum II
597117.description: Continued clinical field study applying theory, research and developing clinical skills related to the provision of care to pediatric and adult patients and their families, including gynecology and family planning, in increasingly complex clinical situations. (9 hours practicum per week)

597118.title: Advanced Pharmacology: Prescriptive Authority
597118.description: Advanced course of pharmacology and pharmacotheurapeutic content and application relevant to the Advanced Practice Nurse. May be repeated once for credit.

597119.title: Basic Women’s Health Assessment and Management I
597119.description: Reviews theory, pathophysiology, diagnosis and management of ambulatory care for women during childbearing and postpartum/family planning periods in culturally diverse populations. Research findings within the framework of the normalcy of childbearing.
597119.prereqs: Prerequisite: graduate standing with Women’s Health concentration.

597120.title: Intrapartum Management
597120.description: Theory, pathophysiology, diagnosis and management of women during labor, birth and the immediate postpartum.
597120.prereqs: Prerequisite: graduate standing with Nurse Midwifery Specialty. Corequisite: NURS 570 .

597121.title: Internship in Basic Midwifery Practice
597121.description: Applying basic midwifery knowledge in the clinical setting. Clinical internship of health promotion, diagnosis and management of low risk childbearing women and newborns. Clinical management of women needing gynecologic and primary care.
597121.prereqs: Prerequisite: graduate standing with Nurse Midwifery specialty. Pre- or corequisites: NURS 570 , NURS 572 .

597122.title: Basic Women’s Health Care Practicum
597122.description: Applying basic Advanced Practice Nursing knowledge in the clinical setting. Clinical practicum of health promotion, diagnosis and management of low risk childbearing women. Clinical management of women needing gynecologic and primary care. (minimum 12 hours practicum per week)
597122.prereqs: Prerequisite: graduate standing with Nurse Practitioner specialty. Pre- or corequisite: NURS 570 .

597123.title: Intermediate Women’s Health Assessment and Management I
597123.description: Theory, research, assessment, pathophysiology, diagnosis and management of complications related to ambulatory health care of women. Reviews domestic violence. Evaluation of research findings.

597195.title: Epistemology
597195.description: Nature of knowledge, belief, certainty, truth, perception, and the a priori; examinations of skepticism, traditional responses to skepticism and the foundations of knowledge.

597196.title: Philosophy of Language
597196.description: Key problems in the philosophy of language such as the nature of language, function of language in communication, meaning and reference of proper names, and the connection between thought and language. Not available for graduate degree credit.
597196.prereqs: Prerequisite: PHIL 290 or PHIL 300 or PHIL 375 / LING 375 .

597197.title: Philosophy of Mind
597197.description: Contemporary philosophical approaches to the nature of mind. Topics include: artificial intelligence, the relation between the mind and the brain, the nature of consciousness, the possibility of neuroscience providing a complete explanation of experience from the first-person point of view.

597198.title: Seminar in Values
597198.description: For philosophy majors prior to graduation as a capstone course. Important issues or problems in value theory (such as ethics, aesthetics and political philosophy). May be repeated once for credit.
597198.prereqs: Prerequisites: PHIL 315 ; 6 units of upper-division philosophy; or graduate standing.

597200.title: Seminar in the History of Philosophy
597200.description: For philosophy majors prior to graduation as a capstone course. Important work, figure, school or problems in the history of philosophy. May be repeated once for credit.
597200.prereqs: Prerequisites: PHIL 315 ; 6 units of upper-division philosophy; or graduate standing.

597201.title: Seminar in Contemporary Philosophy
597201.description: For philosophy majors prior to graduation as a capstone course. Specific contemporary philosophical issues, problems or figures chosen by the instructor. May be repeated once for credit.
597201.prereqs: Prerequisites: PHIL 315 ; 6 units of upper-division philosophy; or graduate standing.

597202.title: Senior Internship in Ethics and Society
597202.description: Supervised internship in professional setting. Required course project on philosophical and ethical issues. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
597202.prereqs: Prerequisite: 6 units from the following: PHIL 120 , PHIL 312 , PHIL 320 , PHIL 313 , PHIL 314 , PHIL 345 , PHIL 355 .

597203.title: Independent Study
597203.description: Develop competency in research. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. No more than 3 units may be taken with any one adviser in any one semester.

597205.title: Survey of Physics
597205.description: Basic concepts of physics for the non-science major. Physical concepts in real-world contexts such as global warming. How our ideas about motion, energy, heat and temperature, light and color, electricity, and atoms form a framework for understanding the natural world.

597206.title: Survey of Physics Laboratory
597206.description: Experiments that demonstrate important concepts in astronomy and physics. For non-science majors.

598862.title: Quantum Computing for Everyone
598862.description: Introduction to the new field of quantum computing. What is quantum physics?  What is entanglement? What makes a quantum computer so special? Preparation for reading and understanding popular science articles on advances in quantum computing and other quantum technologies.

597208.title: Elementary Physics
597208.description: Introduction to mechanics and thermodynamics. Designed for life and health science majors.
597208.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 125 , MATH 130 or MATH 150A . Corequisite: PHYS 211L .

597209.title: Elementary Physics: Laboratory
597209.description: Laboratory for PHYS 211. (3 hours laboratory). Instructional fee required.

597210.title: Elementary Physics
597210.description: Introduction to electricity and magnetism, wave motion and optics. Designed for life and health science majors.
597210.prereqs: Prerequisites: PHYS 211 , PHYS 211L with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: PHYS 212L .

597211.title: Elementary Physics: Laboratory
597211.description: Laboratory for PHYS 212. Instructional fee required. (3 hours laboratory).

597212.title: Fundamental Physics: Mechanics
597212.description: Classical Newtonian mechanics; linear and circular motion; energy; linear/angular momentum; systems of particles; rigid body motion; wave motion and sound.

597213.title: Fundamental Physics: Laboratory
597213.description: Laboratory for PHYS 225. Instructional fee required. (3 hours laboratory)

597214.title: Fundamental Physics: Electricity and Magnetism
597214.description: Electrostatics, electric potential, capacitance, dielectrics, electrical circuits, resistance, emf, electromagnetic induction, magnetism and magnetic materials, and introduction to Maxwell's equations.
597214.prereqs: Prerequisite: PHYS 225 with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisites: MATH 150B , PHYS 226L .

597215.title: Fundamental Physics: Laboratory
597215.description: Laboratory for PHYS 226. Instructional fee required. (3 hours laboratory)

597216.title: Fundamental Physics: Waves, Optics, and Modern Physics
597216.description: Geometrical and physical optics, wave phenomena; quantum physics, including the photoelectric effect, line spectra and the Bohr atom; the wave nature of matter, Schroedinger's equation and solutions; the Uncertainty Principle, special theory of relativity.
597216.prereqs: Prerequisite: PHYS 226 with a “C” (2.0) or better. Corequisite: PHYS 227L , except for Biochemistry, Chemistry and Mechanical Engineering majors, who may enroll for one unit (optics component); all others must enroll for three units.

597217.title: Fundamental Physics: Laboratory
597217.description: Laboratory for PHYS 227. Instructional fee required. (3 hours laboratory)

597218.title: Survey of Mathematical Physics
597218.description: Mathematical techniques required for upper-division physics courses, including differential vector operators, complex variables, partial and ordinary differential equations, special functions, Fourier transforms and series, matrices and operators, probability and statistics.

597219.title: Energy and Sustainability
597219.description: Basic physical principles applied to the generation and use of energy. Conventional and alternative energy sources. Environmental consequences of energy use, greenhouse effect, global warming. Energy conservation principles.

598685.title: Physics of Sound
598685.description: Applying physical principles in music, including topics such as sound wave propagation, time periodicity, vibrations, resonance, acoustics and human perception. Selected topics in stringed, woodwind, brass instruments, the human voice, recording and playback, and digital vs. analog music.

597220.title: Thermodynamics, Kinetic Theory, and Statistical Physics
597220.description: Laws of thermodynamics with physical, chemical and engineering applications; kinetic theory of gases. Introduction to statistical physics with reexamination of laws of thermodynamics.

597221.title: Computational Physics
597221.description: Previous computing experience recommended. Basic numerical methods in physics. Applications include curve fitting and minimization, numerical simulation of classical particles, waves and Fourier analysis, quantum square well, Monte Carlo methods and diffusion. Hands-on computing with high-level languages, graphics and symbolic mathematics. (1 hour lecture, 4 hours activity)

607269.title: Measurement and Data Analysis in the Physical Sciences
607269.description: Estimate measurement instrumentation errors and uncertainties. Propagate experimental errors and uncertainties. Parameter estimation and uncertainty analysis in physical models. Statistical analysis of uncertainties and limiting distributions. Nature of science, scientific claims and reporting.
607269.prereqs: Prerequisite: MATH 250A with a minimum grade of “C” or better; completion of G.E. area 5C.

597222.title: Classical Mechanics
597222.description: Classical mechanics and associated mathematical and numerical techniques: Newtonian dynamics; Lagrangian and Hamiltonian dynamics.

597223.title: Electromagnetic Theory I
597223.description: Applying vector calculus and special mathematics techniques to electric and magnetic phenomena in matter.

597224.title: Electromagnetic Theory II
597224.description: Applying Maxwell's equations to the propagation of EM waves in dielectrics, plasmas, and conductors. Selected topics in radiation, diffraction and eigenfunction expansions of static and waveguide fields. Special relativity: Einstein's postulates, Lorentz transformations, relativistic motion of charged particles.

597225.title: Quantum Mechanics 1
597225.description: Modern physical theories and associated mathematical techniques. Early quantum mechanics development; Schrodinger's equation; one dimensional systems; the harmonic oscillator.

597226.title: Methods of Experimental Physics
597226.description: Experiments using analog, digital, and integrated circuits including: filtering circuits, diodes, transistor amplifiers, operational amplifiers, triggers, and digital logic. Introduction to automated experimentation. (1 hour lecture, 6 hours laboratory). Instructional fee required.

597227.title: Modern Optics
597227.description: Wave propagation. Fourier optics, introduction to spatial filtering and image enhancement, lasers, analytical ray tracing, matrix methods in optics.

597228.title: Thermal and Statistical Physics
597228.description: Disciplines of thermodynamics statistical mechanics and kinetic theory (and their applications); their unifying microscopic foundation.

597229.title: Introduction to the Solid State of Matter
597229.description: Physical properties of matter in the solid state, as explained by atomic theory. Crystal structure, thermal, electric and magnetic properties of metals, semi-conductors, band theory and solid state devices.

597230.title: Quantum Mechanics 2
597230.description: Concepts and theory of quantum mechanics. Angular momentum, hydrogen atom, approximation methods.

597231.title: Atomic/Molecular Physics
597231.description: Theory of atoms and small molecules including perturbation methods. Topics include the interaction of atoms and molecules with electric and magnetic fields and electromagnetic radiation, angular momentum coupling, anti-symmetrization, and the spectroscopy of atoms and simple diatomic methods.

597232.title: Experimental Physics
597232.description: Techniques and methods of experimental physics including: use of sensors, transducers, time series, power spectra, phase sensitive detection, computer interfacing and signal conditioning. Experiments cover several areas of physics. (1 hour lecture, 6 hours laboratory). Instructional fee required.

597233.title: Internship
597233.description: Professional physics work in industry or government to provide an in-depth experience. Written report is required. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of the chair.
597233.prereqs: Prerequisites: Physics major; junior or senior standing.

597234.title: Student-to-Student Tutorials
597234.description: Learn through teaching, increase mastery of subject matter, develop awareness of teaching problems and competence in teaching techniques. Consult "Student-to-Student Tutorials" in this catalog for more complete course description. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Requires consent of chair.

597235.title: Independent Study
597235.description: Topic in physics, selected in consultation with and completed under the supervision of the instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires approval of study plan by department chair and instructor.

597236.title: Mathematical Physics
597236.description: Advanced techniques in mathematical physics: calculus of variation, coordinate transformations, tensor analysis, special functions, series solutions of differential equations, orthogonal functions, partial differential equations, numerical techniques for the solution of differential equations, complex variables, integral transforms, probability, Monte Carlo methods.

597237.title: Statistical Mechanics and Thermodynamics
597237.description: Fundamental principles of classical and quantum statistics. Non-interacting Boltzmann, Bose and Fermi systems. Superconductivity, BE condensation and phase transitions. Fluctuation and kinetic theory, interacting particles via Monte Carlo techniques. Laws of thermodynamics and applications. PHYS 520 recommended.
597237.prereqs: Prerequisites: PHYS 310 or equivalent upper-division Thermodynamics, PHYS 510 .

597238.title: Analytical Mechanics
597238.description: Advanced techniques for solution of problems in classical mechanics: Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations of the equations of motion, variation techniques, conservation theorems, canonical transformations, Hamilton-Jacobi theory, numerical techniques, selected applications.

597239.title: Electromagnetic Theory I
597239.description: Classical electromagnetic theory: boundary value problems in electrostatics, multipoles, electrostatics of macroscopic media, magnetostatics, time-varying fields, Maxwell's equations, plane electromagnetic waves and wave propagation.

597240.title: Solid State Physics
597240.description: Fundamental physics of matter in solid state systems. Crystal structure; metals (Drude theory, Sommerfeld theory, band structure, semiclassical model of electron dynamics, magnetic properties, phonons in metals); semiconductors and superconductors; experimental techniques.

597241.title: Quantum Physics I
597241.description: Principles and techniques of modern quantum mechanics, applications to simple three-dimensional systems, properties of angular momentum. PHYS 455 recommended.

597242.title: Quantum Physics II
597242.description: Advanced topics in quantum physics: scattering theory, electron spin, perturbation theory and applications, approximation methods for time dependent problems, systems of identical particles.

598226.title: Advanced Experimental Physics
598226.description: Advanced techniques of experimental physics. Experiments cover several areas of physics, such as atomic spectroscopy, optics, condensed matter physics, quantum mechanics and magnetic resonance. (1 hour lecture, 6 hours laboratory).

597243.title: Project
597243.description: Planning, preparation and completion of a project in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the master's degree. Credit to be obtained only upon formal completion of a project paper approved by the department graduate committee. May be taken for credit for a maximum of three units.

597244.title: Thesis
597244.description: Planning, preparation and completion of an acceptable thesis in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the master's degree. Credit to be obtained only upon formal submission of thesis. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

597245.title: Independent Graduate Research
597245.description: Open only to graduate students and only with consent of a faculty member. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires written approval of study plan by department committee and by instructor.

598465.title: Introduction to Portuguese Language and Culture
598465.description: Introduction to the Lusophone world through the study of the language, customs, culture and products of Portuguese-speaking communities. Develop cultural and communicative competence at an introductory level. Conducted in Portuguese.

598466.title: Intermediate Portuguese Language and Culture
598466.description: Continued study of the language, customs, culture and products of Portuguese-speaking communities in Europe, Africa and the Americas. Develops cultural and communicative competence at an intermediate level. Conducted in Portuguese.

596845.title: Introduction to Luso-Brazilian Culture and Civilization
596845.description: Main currents of Portuguese culture and civilization and Brazil's intellectual and artistic development from discovery to independence. Conducted in Portuguese.

598672.title: Portuguese Phonology and Dialectology
598672.description: Comprehensive description of the sound systems of Portuguese dialects. Introduction to principles of phonetic analysis and how Portuguese sounds are produced, how they fall into patterns and how they change in different phonological environments.
598672.prereqs: Prerequisite: PORT 214 or equivalent proficiency in Portuguese.

596847.title: Independent Study
596847.description: Supervised projects in Portuguese language or literature to be taken with consent of instructor and department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

597246.title: American Government
597246.description: People, their politics, and power; contemporary issues, changing political styles and processes, institution and underlying values of the American political system. Satisfies state requirements in U.S. Constitution and California State and local government.

597247.title: Introduction to the Study of Politics
597247.description: Introduction to the study of politics and its foundations: power; war and diplomacy; government and its administration in the U.S. and internationally; institutions; law; justice; and ideology.

598418.title: California Government and Politics
598418.description: California state and local government institutions and politics, including direct democracy and current policy issues. The role of California state and local governments in the federal system, including comparisons with other state and local governments. Satisfies state requirement in California state and local government.

598720.title: Research Methods in Political Science
598720.description: Quantitative research methods and research paper writing in political science. Introduction to research design, statistical measures and making causal claims.

597747.title: Introduction to State and Local Politics
597747.description: Importance of federal structure and role of state constitutions in state governance. Comparative study of political institutions, processes, and policy in the 50 states. Compare the operation of city, county and metropolitan governments.

597248.title: Introduction to Local Government
597248.description: Introduction to the evolution and variety of local governments in the United States. Topics include urban political machines and reform, home rule, urban policy, local politics, planning, intergovernmental relations and local government finance.

597249.title: Political Behavior
597249.description: Analyze issues and divisions in American politics, as viewed through voting, protest and other behaviors. Race, class, ideology and parties.

597250.title: Introduction to Public Policy
597250.description: Federal domestic policy making. Structure, functions and relationships among American national institutions, including executive, legislative and judicial branches, media, political parties and pressure groups.

598835.title: Political Psychology
598835.description: Psychological processes underlying political phenomena. Topics include ideological differences, the role of personality, emotions, cognitive styles, group identities, race/gender/class, political leadership and the media in influencing people's political behavior. (PSYC 318 and POSC 318 are the same course).

597251.title: Introduction to Public Administration
597251.description: Introduces public administration through current trends and problems of public sector agencies in such areas as organization behavior, public budgeting, personnel, planning and policy making. Examples and cases from the Criminal Justice field. (POSC 320 and CRJU 320 are the same course.)

597252.title: Research in Public Management
597252.description: Research concepts, computer applications and information management applied to public administration and policy analysis. Instructional fee.
597252.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 . Pre- or corequisite: POSC 320 .

597253.title: Leadership for Public Service
597253.description: Conceptions of leadership as applied in governmental and nonprofit sectors. Types of leaders; tools for leaders; leadership in public policy-making settings. Includes student project and extend leadership concepts; participation in CSUF Student Leadership Institute or similar activity. (POSC 322 and CRJU 322 are the same course.)
597253.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 , POSC 200 or GE Area 4A.

598068.title: Nonprofit Organizations
598068.description: Introduction to the nonprofit sector, including the difference between public, for-profit and non-profit organizations, the history and rise of the sector, IRS tax rules and other government regulations, and best practices for nonprofit administration. Will highlight Orange County nonprofits.

598020.title: The Politics of the Arab-Israeli Conflict
598020.description: Politics of the Arab-Israeli conflict, concentrating on Israel and Palestinians. Historical roots of conflict, recent efforts to forge peace agreements and current politics.

597254.title: Politics in Nation-States
597254.description: Compares patterns of political behavior and interaction in various political systems.
597254.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 4A; POSC 100 or HONR 201B .

597256.title: Political Philosophy
597256.description: Major thinkers in the Western tradition of political philosophy from Plato to the present; the principal concepts and theories.

597257.title: International Relations
597257.description: Political relationships among governments and other participants within the global system: internal and external factors influencing foreign policies of the great powers, their allies and minor powers; role of non-state actors, such as the United Nations, multinational corporations and liberation movements.

597258.title: American Foreign Policy
597258.description: Formation and implementation of American foreign policy since 1945; the origins of the Cold War and the reasons for its end; debates about American grand strategy after the Cold War and 9/11.

597260.title: Law, Politics and Society
597260.description: Law as emergent from political processes, rooted within social norms and communities. Law as a feature of the modern state, a tool for seeking advantage, domination and/or liberation. An overview of legislative, judicial, administrative, and other political processes that produce law.
597260.prereqs: Prerequisites: GE Area 4A; POSC 100 or HONR 201B .

597261.title: Religion and Politics in the United States
597261.description: Relationship of politics and religion, especially in the U.S. The colonial and constitutional experience, Supreme Court decisions on religious issues, the principal theorists of moral discourse in the public forum, contemporary issues of concern. (RLST 381 and POSC 381 are the same course.)

597742.title: Cal State DC
597742.description: For students in the Cal State DC Internship Program. Learn about the culture, history, and politics of Washington, DC and how to prepare for a career in applied politics. Requires enrollment in Cal State DC Internship Program.
597742.prereqs: Prerequisites: POSC 100 or HONR 201B , junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

597263.title: Capital Punishment
597263.description: Issues relating to the use of capital punishment in the U.S., and arguments in support of and opposition to the death penalty. (CRJU 404 and POSC 404 are the same course.)
597263.prereqs: Prerequisites: POSC 100 , POSC 300 or HONR 210B ; junior standing or above; or graduate standing.

597264.title: Campaigns and Elections
597264.description: Modern political campaigns in America focusing on new types of candidates and electoral organizations; money, media and consultants; and methods of predicting and interpreting election results.
597264.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

598955.title: Direct Democracy
598955.description: The origins and practice of the initiative, referendum and recall processes at the local and state levels, focusing on strategies, role in democracy and impact on different demographic groups in society.
598955.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

597265.title: Polls, Statistics and Political Interpretation
597265.description: Quantitative research methods in political science. Introduction to research design and statistical measures employed in analyzing social science research data.

597266.title: Political Parties
597266.description: Structure and methods by which the political parties operate in the American political system with some comparisons to their structure and operation in other democratic societies.
597266.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

597268.title: Practicing Politics
597268.description: Politics as practiced and understood by practitioners of the art. Features guest lecturers and focuses on electoral politics.

597269.title: U.S. Congress
597269.description: Who gets elected to Congress, how it works and how it interacts with other institutions. Congressional elections, committees, parties, staff and how Congress responds to pressures and exerts influence.
597269.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

597270.title: Presidents and the Presidency
597270.description: Presidential power, the resources on which that power is based and the limitations on the use of that power. Relations between the President and Congress, the bureaucracy, the press and the public.
597270.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

597271.title: Film and Politics
597271.description: American politics from the 1920s to the present as seen through eyes of filmmakers. View films, read material relevant to films and write several papers linking film themes to the literature of American politics.
597271.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

597272.title: Government and the Economy
597272.description: Regulation and deregulation of business. Industrial policy. Government taxes and expenditures. Emphasis on national government.
597272.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 320 , any economics course, or graduate standing.

597273.title: Human Resources Management
597273.description: Civil service and the merit system; recruitment procedures and examinations; position classification, salary structures, retirement plans, in-service training, employee organizations and personnel supervision. Examples and cases from the criminal justice field. Emphasizes themes and topics from criminal justice. (POSC 422 and CRJU 422 are the same course.)

597274.title: Diversity in Public Management
597274.description: Issues in public employment related to gender, race and ethnicity, disability, veteran status, age, culture and other current topics. Focus on leadership, mentoring, recruitment and discrimination. Topics of current interest include representative bureaucracy, equity and intersectionality.

597746.title: Health Policy
597746.description: Health policy actors and processes in the United States. Roles of Congress, the President, bureaucracy and interests groups in health policy and policy process are explored, including an introduction to policy analysis. (PUBH 424 and POSC 424 are the same course).

598243.title: Policy Analysis
598243.description: Provides conceptual approach and skills required to understand and project the outcomes and effects of public policy; scope of approaches undertaken in policy analysis from both a political and an economic perspective.

598244.title: Education Politics and Policy
598244.description: History and expansion of public education in the United States. Roles of school districts and the state and federal governments in setting education policy. Current issues of education policy and public higher education.

597275.title: Metropolitan Politics and Policymaking
597275.description: Policy issues and alternatives in urban and metropolitan problem areas, such as law enforcement, transportation, housing or poverty.

597276.title: Women and Politics: A Comparative Perspective
597276.description: Relationship between women and politics from an international-comparative point of view. Considers theory and practice in its examination of the political roles, behavior, perspectives and expectations of women throughout the world.
597276.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

598505.title: Civil Disobedience and Social Justice
598505.description: The violation of law as protest. Definitions and types of disobedience and the policing and punishment of dissent. Analysis of protest as a strategy for social justice. (CRJU 435 and POSC 435 are the same course.)
598505.prereqs: Prerequisites: for CRJU 435 - CRJU 100 , CRJU 300 ; or graduate standing. For POSC 435 - POSC 100 ; or graduate standing.

597278.title: Latin American Politics
597278.description: Systematic analysis of government and politics in selected Latin American states. Considers democratization, state structures, relation of politics to economics and alternative theories and approaches to comparative political analysis as applied to a region marked by ethnic and racial diversity.
597278.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

597279.title: Western European Democracies
597279.description: Comparative study of the government and politics of Western European democracies, including their cooperation within the European Union. Analyze domestic as well as foreign policies.
597279.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

597280.title: Problems in Political Philosophy
597280.description: Current issues and problems in political philosophy in the context of major global events and trends. See department for exact title and topics in a given semester. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 9 units.

597282.title: Corruption, Ethics and Public Policy
597282.description: Ethical problems that face persons in the public service. Practical decision-making.
597282.prereqs: Prerequisite: POSC 100 or HONR 201B ; or graduate standing.

598144.title: Introduction to the Study of Religion
598144.description: An introduction to the academic study of religion, exploring the social and cultural dimensions of religion, as well as religious consciousness and perception. Key concepts, theorists and methodological approaches.

598077.title: Religion and the Quest for Meaning
598077.description: Nature of religious experience as the human pursuit of meaning and transcendence, exploring its central themes, phenomena and questions; its principal types of figures and communities; and its major categories of sacred rituals, objects, seasons and places.

598078.title: Religions of the World
598078.description: Introduction to at least five religious world views from an historical and comparative perspective, with descriptive analyses of their belief systems, moral codes and symbolic rituals: Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism and Sikhism. (RLST 110 and PHIL 110 are same course.)

598079.title: Introduction to Christianity
598079.description: Overview of the Christian tradition, including Eastern Orthodox, Roman Catholic and Protestant expressions. Beliefs, practices and authority structures.

598080.title: Introduction to the New Testament
598080.description: An academic introduction to the New Testament, viewed within its historical, social and religious context. A scholarly investigation of the New Testament through historical and textual methods. Includes comparing the differences among New Testament books.

598081.title: Introduction to Judaism
598081.description: The Jewish tradition - its scriptures, laws, customs, holidays and world view in their historical setting.

598123.title: Basic Hatha Yoga
598123.description: Basic yoga postures, beginning meditation, breathing and relaxation techniques presented from a theoretical and experiential perspective. Awareness, concentration, and other practices that accompany the study of Hatha Yoga. (1 hour lecture, 2 hours activity) (KNES 246A  and RLST 246A are the same course)

607267.title: Intermediate Hatha Yoga
607267.description: Intermediate and advanced yoga sequences, including postures, breathing practices, meditation techniques and guided relaxation. Yoga philosophy and movement based on various Hatha Yoga traditions. (KNES 246B and RLST 246B are the same course).

598082.title: Introduction to Islam
598082.description: Religion of Islam, its background and main teachings: the rise of Islam; the caliphate; Islamic theology, teachings, mysticism and philosophy.

598083.title: Introduction to the Asian Religions
598083.description: Main teachings of a major South Asian, Far Eastern or "Oriental" religion per semester, including such religions as Jainism, Hinduism, Sikhism, Taoism, Shintoism and Zoroastrianism. May be repeated for credit with different subject matter.

598084.title: Introduction to Buddhism
598084.description: Introduction to the origins and development of Buddhism. The major teachings found in all traditions of Buddhism, the three major traditions of Buddhism and the position of Buddhism in the U.S.

598085.title: Methods of Studying Religion
598085.description: Academic study of religion to include the definition, functions and varieties of religion; the methods used to study it; and key figures who have shaped the development of this discipline.

598071.title: Anthropology of Religion
598071.description: Beliefs and practices in the full human variation of religious phenomena, with an emphasis on primitive religions. Forms, functions, structures, symbolism, and history and evolution of religious systems. (ANTH 305 and RLST 305 are the same course.)

598086.title: Contemporary Practices of the World’s Religions
598086.description: Comparative study of how the beliefs, practices and moral codes of the world's major religions influence the way nations and individuals behave in the spheres of daily life, culture, ethics, business and politics.

598673.title: Non-violence, Animal Rights and Diet in Jainism
598673.description: Development of the beliefs, practices, culture, philosophy and art of the Jain religion. Examine core Jain principles, such as nonviolence and non-possessiveness and their contemporary relevance. Fieldtrip to a major Jain site in Southern California.

598105.title: Religion and Film
598105.description: In this course we use film as a powerful medium through which we explore the meaning of life, relationships, moral quandaries, religious and ontological issues.

598076.title: The Bible as Literature
598076.description: Literary qualities of biblical literature and the influence of major themes upon Western literary traditions. (CPLT 312 and RLST 312 are the same course.)

598146.title: Psychology of Religion
598146.description: A survey of classical and contemporary empirical psychological research investigating religious beliefs, experiences and practices. Topics include religious behavior across the lifespan; the social psychology of religious organizations; and religious connections to morality, coping, and psychopathology. (RLST 321 and PSYC 321 are the same course).

598070.title: African American Religions and Spirituality
598070.description: African-American belief systems and denominations. Folk beliefs among Blacks, African-American religious groups and the role of the Black Church in politics and social change in the Black community. (AFAM 325 and RLST 325 are the same course.)

598135.title: Religion and Sexuality
598135.description: Connection between religion and sexuality. The religious ideas behind political and public debates related to sexuality and consideration of the private realm, such as sexual identity, family life, gender roles and reproduction.

598094.title: Hindu Tradition to 400 B.C.E.
598094.description: Hindu thought in its earliest period. Overview of Vedic literature, especially its religious content and the major rituals of the early Veda; philosophical developments in the Upanisads or later Veda; and related sacred writings.

598095.title: Hindu Tradition from 400 B.C.E.
598095.description: Hindu thought after the Vedic period. The beginnings of Hindu philosophies, classical Hindu practice, devotionalism, modern or neo-Hindu groups appearing in the 19th century, and the contributions of thinkers, such as Ramakrishna and Gandhi.
598095.prereqs: Prerequisite: RLST 105 , RLST 110 or GE Area 3B.

598090.title: History and Development of Early Christian Thought
598090.description: Historical study of the diversity of Christian beliefs, movements and key figures from New Testament times to the late Middle Ages, including important creeds and councils, spiritual movements, and central figures such as Augustine and Aquinas.

598091.title: History and Development of Modern Christian Thought
598091.description: Historical study of the diversity of Christian beliefs, movements and key figures from the late Middle Ages to the present, including the context and thinkers of the Reformation era, post-Reformation controversies and recent debates and trends.

598092.title: History and Development of Jewish Thought: Biblical and Rabbinical Eras
598092.description: Hebrew Scriptures in their historical context, development of rabbinical Judaism and the Talmud, and Judaism in the Christian and Muslim worlds down to the close of the Spanish "Golden Age" (1150).

598093.title: History and Development of Jewish Thought: Medieval and Modern Eras
598093.description: Maimonides' legacy, impact of mysticism, rise of anti-Semitism, emancipation of European Jews, the Holocaust, Israel's founding and history, and contributions of Jews to American culture.

598099.title: Religion in Latino/a Life
598099.description: National and international expressions of Latino/a religiosity - from popular religion to Marian devotion to curanderismo -  through film, historical documents, poetry, theology, art, sociology and ethnic studies. (RLST 367 and CHIC 367 are the same course.)

598529.title: New Religious Movements in the U.S.A.
598529.description: Beliefs, history, ritual and organizational makeup of nontraditional modern religions in America, such as Scientology, the Unification Church, Hare Krishna (ISKCON) and Rajneeshism as presented by guest speakers. Discussion of "cult," "sect" and the occult.

598096.title: History and Development of Islamic Thought: The Beginning to 1258
598096.description: Islamic theology, law, culture, and spirituality up to the close of the classical period in 1258. Interpretation of the Qur'an, formation of Hadith literature, development of Islamic law, divisions within Islam, rise of mysticism, contributions to science and art.

598097.title: History and Development of Islamic Thought: 1259 to Modern Times
598097.description: Islamic thought from the close of the classical period to the present, with emphasis on 20th century developments. Emergence of modern Middle East, reform movements, Islamic response to nationalism and modernity, recent Islamic resurgence.

598133.title: Women in Islam
598133.description: Status and roles of Muslim women from the perspectives of the basic Islamic texts (The Qur'an and Prophetic Traditions). Rights, marriage and divorce, seclusion and dress codes, and religious, economic and socio-political participation.

598134.title: Issues in Contemporary Islam
598134.description: Some of the contentious issues in Islam. Concepts of piety, peace, jihad, fundamentalism, terrorism, democracy, human rights, leadership of women and sexuality; the intellectual arguments surrounding these topics.

598100.title: Conceptions of the Afterlife
598100.description: How selected religious traditions have sought to answer the question: "What happens when I die." Resurrection, reincarnation, immortality of the soul, heaven and hell. RLST 110 recommended.

598101.title: Religion and Violence
598101.description: Interdisciplinary exploration of major theories, developments and documents connected to the relationship between religious practices and motivations for engaging in, preventing or rejecting violent behavior.

598102.title: Religion and Politics in the United States
598102.description: Relationship of politics and religion, especially in the U.S. The colonial and constitutional experience, Supreme Court decisions on religious issues, the principal theorists of moral discourse in the public forum, contemporary issues of concern. (RLST 381 and POSC 381 are the same course.)

598103.title: Religion, the Media and Contemporary Culture
598103.description: Reporting about religion in secular media; impact of traditional and social media on societal values; ethical challenges faced by journalists; uses of media by religious organizations.
598103.prereqs: Prerequisite: AMST 201 , COMM 233 , HIST 180 , RLST 100 , RLST 105 or RLST 110 .

598120.title: History of the Christian Church to the Reformation (1517)
598120.description: Christian Church from its origins in the apostolic preaching through the late Middle Ages and the beginning (1517) of the Reformation in both the East and West. (HIST 412A and RLST 412A are the same course.)
598120.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U, 4A, HIST 110A or HIST 110B ; or graduate standing.

598121.title: History of the Christian Church from the Reformation to the Present
598121.description: Western church as an institution from the Reformation (1517) to the present. Orthodoxy, Catholicism and Protestantism in historical perspective. (HIST 412B and RLST 412B are the same course.)
598121.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U, 4A, HIST 110A or HIST 110B ; or graduate standing.

598538.title: History of the Jews
598538.description: The Jewish people from the biblical period to the present. The literature of each period, as well as the relationships which exist between the Jewish communities and the societies in which they exist. (HIST 412C and RLST 412C are the same course.)
598538.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U, 4A, HIST 110A or HIST 110B ; or graduate standing.

598119.title: Roman Empire
598119.description: Roman imperial institutions and culture with attention to the rise of Christianity. (HIST 417B and RLST 417B are the same course.)
598119.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 4A or HIST 110A ; or graduate standing.

598118.title: The Holocaust
598118.description: The history and origins, implementation and results of the European-wide programs of persecution and genocide carried out by Nazi Germany and their collaborators against the Jews during the period 1933-1945. (HIST 435A and RLST 435A are the same course.)
598118.prereqs: Prerequisite: HIST 110B or any modern European upper-division course.

598122.title: Islamic Civilization: Arab Era
598122.description: Arab predominance in the Middle East from the rise of Islam to the Mongol invasions of the 13th century. (HIST 466A and RLST 466A are the same course.)
598122.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U or HIST 110A ; or graduate standing.

598540.title: Islamic Civilization: Imperial Age
598540.description: Mongol invasions of the Middle East and their effects. Ottoman Turkish, Safavid Persian and Moghul Empires to 1800. (HIST 466B and RLST 466B are the same course.)
598540.prereqs: Prerequisite: GE Area 3B, 3U or HIST 110A ; or graduate standing.

598106.title: Major Religious Thinkers and Concepts
598106.description: Religious thinkers and concepts dealing with Western, Eastern and non-traditional religious ideas from ancient to modern times. Fulfills university upper-division baccalaureate writing requirement. May be repeated once with a different topic.

598107.title: Independent Study
598107.description: Supervised research projects in comparative religion to be taken with consent of instructor and the department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

598229.title: Think Like Einstein
598229.description: Science influences everyday lives. To think like a scientist (and an informed citizen), students need skills in critical thinking, argumentation and logical reasoning. Course develops these skills and provides practice applying them to a range of topics. This course is intended for first time freshmen.

598861.title: STEMinar
598861.description: Preparation for continued success in a CNSM major through discussions and activities designed to expand academic knowledge and skills, promote a growth mindset, and increase awareness of opportunities in STEM careers. For CNSM second-semester freshmen and new transfer students.
598861.prereqs: Prerequisite: NSM undergraduate major and minor

597409.title: The Teaching Experience: Exploration
597409.description: Exploring one's self in relation to other people in the schools, and an encounter with the teaching experience through fieldwork. Accompanying seminar helps extend observations and explore relevant issues. (2 hours fieldwork, 2 hours seminar). (EDSC 110, EDEL 110, SCED 110 and SPED 110  are the same course.)

597410.title: The Teaching Experience: Exploration
597410.description: Exploring one's self in relation to other people in the schools, and an encounter with the teaching experience through fieldwork. Accompanying seminar helps extend observations and explore relevant issues. (2 hours fieldwork, 2 hours seminar). (EDSC 110, EDEL 110, SCED 110 and SPED 110  are the same course.)

597411.title: Educational Technologies for Secondary Teachers
597411.description: Develop personal proficiency in educational technologies to facilitate teaching process. Develop digital literacy through presentation, spreadsheet, word processing/publication software, interactive online tools; internet search and retrieval; information literacy; electronic communication/collaboration; awareness of legal and ethical issues in the digital world. Meets technology requirement for California Preliminary Single Subject Teaching Credential.

597412.title: The Teaching Experience: Participation
597412.description: History, philosophy, sociology of secondary education. Introduction to California Teaching Performance Expectations and Teaching Performance Assessment; needs of special populations, English learners, struggling readers; content standards and major curriculum reform documents. Includes 45 hours of observation in public schools on specific course requirements. May be repeated once for credit with consent of instructor.

597413.title: Adolescent Development
597413.description: Biological, cognitive and socio-cultural development of adolescents. Contexts of adolescent development, including family, peers, school, work and leisure. Health and safety issues of adolescents.

597414.title: Developing Literacy in Secondary Schools
597414.description: Strategies for developing content-based reading/writing abilities, comprehension skills and vocabulary of secondary students. Methods of teaching reading, writing and language skills for English learners and native English speakers. Diagnostic assessment strategies. Letter grade.

597415.title: Diversity in Secondary Schools
597415.description: Principles of educational equity and diversity. Strategies for providing students equitable access to the core curriculum. How teaching is shaped by diversity in California society. Analyze personal and institutional biases.

597416.title: Teaching and Learning from Language Learners in Secondary Schools
597416.description: Research-based approaches and strategies for teaching English learners in secondary schools. Theories of language acquisition and development. Cognitive, linguistic, socio-cultural and political factors that affect English language development. Legal issues pertaining to the education of English learners.

597417.title: Supervised Fieldwork in Secondary Schools
597417.description: A field experience in a single subject in public schools with guided observation and reflection. Requires admission to the Single Subject Credential Program.

597418.title: General Pedagogy in Secondary Schools
597418.description: Interrelationship of pedagogical theory and practice, classroom management, instructional planning, assessment of student learning, student engagement, and teacher professionalism. Requires admission to the Single Subject Credential Program.

597837.title: Teaching Science in the Secondary Schools
597837.description: Principles, methods, and materials for teaching science in the secondary schools. A "B-" (2.7) or better is required to earn a California Preliminary Single Subject Teaching Credential. Requires admission to the Single Subject Credential Program.

597419.title: Teaching World Languages in the Public Schools
597419.description: Principles, methods, and materials for teaching world languages in K-12 schools with an emphasis on secondary levels. A "B-" (2.7) or better is required to earn a California preliminary Single Subject Teaching credential. Requires admission to the Single Subject Credential Program.

597835.title: Teaching Foundational-Level Mathematics in Secondary Schools
597835.description: Principles, objectives, strategies and methods for teaching foundational-level mathematics in secondary schools. A "B-" (2.7) or better is required to earn a California preliminary Single Subject Teaching credential. Requires admission to the Single Subject Credential Program.

597836.title: Teaching Social Science in Secondary Schools
597836.description: Principles, strategies, and materials for teaching social science in secondary schools. A "B-" (2.7) or better is required to earn a California Preliminary Single Subject Teaching credential. Requires admission to the Single Subject Credential Program. May be repeated once for credit.

597832.title: Methods and Inquiry for Bilingual Teachers
597832.description: Prepares bilingual teacher candidates for teaching Spanish-speaking students. Program models for bilingual instruction, methods for teaching reading and content areas in bilingual settings, materials and assessment. Conducted in Spanish and English; 20 hours of fieldwork required. (EDEL 446 and EDSC 446 are the same course)

597841.title: Methods and Inquiry for Korean Bilingual Teachers
597841.description: Prepares bilingual teachers to teach Korean-speaking students. Program models for bilingual instruction and methods for teaching Korean language and content areas in bilingual settings. 10 hours of fieldwork in schools is required. (EDSC 446K and EDEL 446K are the same course). Requires Korean fluency and consent of Korean Bilingual Authorization coordinator.

598471.title: Methods and Inquiry for Mandarin Bilingual Teachers
598471.description: Mandarin fluency is required. Course prepares bilingual teachers to teach Mandarin-speaking students. Course includes an examination of program models for bilingual instruction as well as methods for teaching Mandarin language and content areas in bilingual settings. 10 hours of fieldwork in schools is required. Requires consent of Mandarin Bilingual Authorization coordinator.

597834.title: Methods and Inquiry for Vietnamese Bilingual Teachers
597834.description: Prepares bilingual teachers to teach Vietnamese-speaking students. Program models for bilingual instruction; methods for teaching Vietnamese language and content areas in bilingual settings. 10 hours of fieldwork in schools is required. Requires consent of Vietnamese Bilingual Authorization coordinator. (EDSC 446V and EDEL 446V are the same course).

597420.title: Externship in Single Subject Teaching
597420.description: Eight-week practicum (150 hours) fieldwork in single subject classrooms. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit.
