596839.title: Student-to-Student Tutorials
596839.description: Consult Student-to-Student Tutorials in this catalog for more information. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

596747.title: Leadership and Personal Development
596747.description: Introduces personal challenges and competencies that are critical for effective leadership. How personal development of life skills such as critical thinking, goal setting, time management, physical fitness and stress management relate to leadership, officership and the Army profession. Group Physical Training (PT) three days a week to build muscular endurance and unit cohesion. (1.5 hours of lecture, 3 hours laboratory, 3 hours PT).

596748.title: Introduction to Tactical Leadership
596748.description: Leadership fundamentals, such as setting direction, problem solving, listening, presenting briefs, providing feedback and using effective writing skills. Dimensions of leadership values, attributes, skills and actions in the context of practical, hands-on and interactive exercises. Group Physical Training (PT) three days a week to build muscular endurance and unit cohesion.

596749.title: Innovative Team Leadership
596749.description: Dimensions of creative and innovative tactical leadership strategies and styles by examining team dynamics and two historical leadership theories that form the basis of Army leadership framework: trait and behavioral theories. Practice aspects of personal motivation and team building in the context of planning, executing and assessing team exercises. Group Physical Training (PT) three days a week to build muscular endurance and unit cohesion.

596750.title: Foundations of Tactical Leadership
596750.description: Challenges of leading tactical teams in the complex Contemporary Operating Environment (COE). Dimensions of terrain analysis, patrolling and operation orders. Theoretical basis of the Army leadership framework explores the dynamic of adaptive leadership in the context of military operations. Group Physical Training (PT) three days a week to build muscular endurance and unit cohesion.

596751.title: Adaptive Tactical Leadership
596751.description: Challenges cadets to study, practice and evaluate adaptive tactical leadership skills as they are presented with challenging scenarios related to squad tactical operations. Students receive systematic and specific feedback on their leadership attributes and actions. Group Physical Training (PT) three days a week to build muscular endurance and unit cohesion.

596752.title: Leadership in Changing Environments
596752.description: Increasingly intense situational leadership challenges to build cadet awareness and skills in leading tactical operations up to platoon level. Combat, stability and support operations. Explore, evaluate and develop skills in decision-making, persuading and motivating team members in the contemporary operating environment (COE). Group Physical Training (PT) three days a week to build muscular endurance and unit cohesion.

596753.title: Developmental Leadership
596753.description: Develop proficiency in planning, executing and assessing complex operations, functioning as a member of a staff and providing performance feedback to subordinates. Situational opportunities to assess risk, make ethical decisions and lead fellow ROTC cadets. Lessons on military justice and personnel processes to prepare for transition to becoming Army officers. Group Physical Training (PT) three days a week to build muscular endurance and unit cohesion.

596754.title: Adaptive Leadership
596754.description: Dynamics of leading in the complex situations of current military operations in the contemporary operating environment (COE). Differences in customs and courtesies, military law, principles of war and rules of engagement in the face of international terrorism. Aspects of interacting with non-governmental organizations, civilians on the battlefield and host nation support. Group Physical Training (PT) three days a week to build muscular endurance and unit cohesion.

596755.title: Military History Seminar
596755.description: Selected case studies in military history as they relate to the modern challenges facing the American profession of arms. Written reports, oral presentations, discussion and field study. Satisfies commissioning requirements.

598493.title: Independent Study
598493.description: Independent study provides the student with the opportunity to meet Army commissioning requirements when the normal course of study is not possible due to course sequencing. Students will be assigned special projects which will require the demonstration of military principles.

596911.title: Introduction to Music
596911.description: Musical enjoyment and understanding through a general survey of musical literature representative of a variety of styles and performance media. Music will be related to other arts through lectures, recordings, and concerts. For non-music majors.

596912.title: Music Theory for Non-Music Majors
596912.description: Basic theory and practical applications to improve music performance and listening skills. Sight-singing and relationship to keyboard and simple melodic instruments. For non-music majors.

596913.title: Diatonic Harmony
596913.description: Scales and intervals, triads and their inversions, harmonizations, non-harmonic tones, modulation and seventh chords. For Music majors or by permission of department only.
596913.prereqs: Corequisite: MUS 121 required for Music majors, recommended for others.

596914.title: Introduction to Chromatic Harmony
596914.description: Scales and intervals, triads and their inversions, harmonization, non-harmonic tones, modulation and seventh chords. Introduction to chromaticism, secondary dominants and secondary leading tone chords. For Music majors or by permission of department only.
596914.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 111 , MUS 121 . Corequisite: Music major - MUS 122 ; recommended for others.

596915.title: Musicianship I - Diatonic
596915.description: Application of materials in MUS 111. Sight-singing, dictation and keyboard exercises. For Music majors or by permission of department. (2 hours activity)

596916.title: Musicianship II - Diatonic
596916.description: Application of materials in MUS 112. Sight-singing, dictation and keyboard exercises. For Music majors or by permission of department only. (2 hours activity)

596917.title: Survey of Western Musical Literature
596917.description: Literature of music in Western civilization. Students should be able to read music in order to analyze form and style. For Music majors or by permission of department only.
596917.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 111 , MUS 121 ; Music major or minor.

596918.title: Piano Class for Music Majors
596918.description: Keyboard skills for students whose major performance instrument is not piano. For Music majors or by permission of department only. (1 hour lecture, 2 hours activity)
596918.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 111 ; Music major or minor.

596919.title: Individual Instruction
596919.description: Individual study with assigned instructor. Performance technique, repertoire and other responsibilities as assigned. Jury examination required. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 4 units. Requires jury recommendation.

596920.title: Individual Instruction
596920.description: Individual study with assigned instructor. Performance technique, repertoire and other responsibilities as assigned. Jury examination required. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 4 units. Requires jury recommendation.

596921.title: Chromatic Harmony
596921.description: Chromatic practice of the 19th century. Secondary dominants; ninth, 11th and 13th chords; sequence; Neapolitan and augmented sixth chords. For Music majors or by permission of department only.
596921.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 112 , MUS 122 . Corequisite: MUS 221 for Music majors, recommended for others.

596922.title: Jazz Harmony and Analysis
596922.description: Provides tools to understand the principles of jazz harmony and form. Description of chords, including seventh, ninth and 13th chords; altered chords; modulation as found in jazz music; and modes. (4 hours activity)
596922.prereqs: Prerequisite: MUS 264 . Pre- or corequisite: MUS 221 .

596923.title: Musicianship III - Chromatic
596923.description: Application of materials in MUS 211. Sight-singing, dictation and keyboard exercises. For Music majors or by permission of department only. (2 hours activity)

596924.title: Jazz Improvisation I
596924.description: Application of scales and their relationship to chords. Modes, jazz rhythmic phrasing, blues progressions and cycle of dominant seventh chords. Basic jazz keyboard drills and ear training. Requires ability on a standard jazz instrument. (2 hours activity)
596924.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 111 , MUS 121 ; Music major or minor.

596925.title: Music Production and Performance
596925.description: Training and experience in the production of live performance, including house management, stage management, and publicity, as well as guided observation and reflection on a diverse range of musical events. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 9 units.

596926.title: Orchestral Instruments/Brass Instruments
596926.description: Techniques and materials for teaching orchestral instruments. Intended for Music Education majors. (3 hours activity)

596927.title: Orchestral Instruments/Percussion Instruments
596927.description: Techniques and materials for teaching orchestral instruments. Intended for Music Education majors. (3 hours activity)

596928.title: Orchestral Instruments/String Instruments
596928.description: Techniques and materials for teaching orchestral instruments. Intended for Music Education majors. (3 hours activity)

596929.title: Orchestral Instruments/Woodwind Instruments
596929.description: Techniques and materials for teaching orchestral instruments. Intended for Music Education majors. (3 hours activity)

596930.title: Piano Class for Music Majors
596930.description: Keyboard skills for students whose major performance field is not piano. For Music majors or by permission of department only. (1 hour lecture, 2 hours activity)
596930.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 182 with a “C” (2.0) or better; Music major or minor.

596931.title: Piano Class for Music Majors
596931.description: Keyboard skills for students whose major performance field is not piano. Meets minimum piano proficiency requirements for degree. For Music majors or by permission of department only. (1 hour lecture, 2 hours activity)
596931.prereqs: Prerequisite: MUS 282A with a “C” (2.0) or better; Music major or minor.

596932.title: Voice Class for Instrumentalists
596932.description: Vocal skills for students whose major performance field is not voice. Prepares music education students to work with young singers in group settings by understanding their own vocal problems and the solutions in a variety of vocal styles. Satisfies voice-proficiency requirement for music credential candidates. (2 hours activity)

596933.title: Instrument Class for Singers, Pianists, and Guitarists
596933.description: Instrumental skills for music majors and minors other than Instrumental Music Education. Prepares Choral and General-Music music-education students to work with beginning instruments in group settings. Study of ranges, transpositions and techniques of various orchestral instruments. (3 hours activity)

596934.title: Functional Skills for Keyboard Majors
596934.description: Development of the ability to sight-read, harmonize, transpose and improvise. (4 hours activity)

596935.title: Individual Instruction
596935.description: Individual study with assigned instructor. Performance technique, repertoire and other responsibilities as assigned. Jury examination required. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 4 units. Requires jury recommendation.

596936.title: Individual Instruction
596936.description: Individual study with assigned instructor. Performance technique, repertoire and other responsibilities as assigned. Jury examination required. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 4 units. Requires jury recommendation.

596937.title: History of Jazz
596937.description: Historical study of jazz music in America, along with its antecedents; chronological development and stylistic evolution with consideration of related trends. Listening, reading and written work. Intended for non-music majors. May not be used as a music-major elective.

596938.title: World Music
596938.description: Art, folk and popular music of selected world areas; topics vary according to semester and are chosen from Latin American, North American, Asian, African, and European cultures and traditions. Listening, reading and written work. Intended for non-music majors. May not be used as a music-major elective.

596939.title: Music of Mexico
596939.description: Historical survey of folk, popular and art music traditions of Mexico and music in Mexican American/Chicano society; pre-Cortesian and contemporary indigenous musical practices; relationship of music to Mexican history and culture. Listening, reading and written work. Intended for non-music majors. May be used as a music-major elective. (MUS 304 and CHIC 304 are the same course.)

596940.title: Women in Music
596940.description: Contributions women have made as composers and performers, and as musical patrons, as well as the historical limitations to which women musicians have been subject. Listening, reading and written work. Intended for non-music majors. May be used as a music-major elective.

596941.title: History of Rock Music
596941.description: Rock music around the world; its origins and the development of national styles. Emphasis on listening. For non-music majors.

596942.title: Jazz and Commercial Arranging
596942.description: Harmonic practices in commercial music; stage band and jazz writing techniques. May be repeated once for credit.

596943.title: 16th-Century Counterpoint
596943.description: Sixteenth-century counterpoint in two, three and four parts, covering motet, canon, double counterpoint.

596944.title: Form and Analysis
596944.description: Structural elements of music such as motive, phrase and period: binary, ternary, rondo, sonata allegro and larger musical forms in representative musical works.

596945.title: 20th-Century Techniques to 1945
596945.description: Compositional practices from 1890 to 1945; written examples in the various styles. Sight singing, keyboard practice and dictation. (1 hour lecture, 2 hours activity)

596946.title: Orchestration
596946.description: Instrumentation and scoring. Writing and analyzing orchestral music.

596948.title: Music and Child Development
596948.description: Relationship of music to child growth and development for the child ages five to 12. Survey of age-appropriate music materials.
596948.prereqs: Prerequisites: Music major or minor; junior standing or above.

596949.title: Music in American Society
596949.description: Music in its relationship to American culture and society. Sociological approach through the study of musical repertoires and concert life, as well as audience participation in musical consumption. Listening, reading and written work. Intended for non-music majors. May not be used as a music-major elective.

596950.title: History and Literature of Western Music
596950.description: History and literature of European music, from early Greek beginnings through the Renaissance. Listening, reading and written work. Intended for music majors.

596951.title: History and Literature of Western Music
596951.description: History and literature of European music of the Baroque and Classic eras. A grade of "C" (2.0) or better fulfills the course requirement of the university upper-division baccalaureate writing requirement for music majors. Listening, reading and written work. Intended for music majors.

596952.title: History and Literature of Western Music
596952.description: History and literature of European and American music, from the Romantic era to the present. Intended for music majors.
596952.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 151 , MUS 211 , MUS 221 , MUS 351A , MUS 351B .

596953.title: Survey of Public School Choral Music Materials
596953.description: Examination and analysis of choral repertoire suitable for junior and senior high choruses.

596954.title: Film Music
596954.description: Historical survey of the use of music in motion pictures. Analysis and examination of film scores. Listening, reading and written work. Intended for non-music majors. May be used as a music-major elective.

596955.title: African American Music Appreciation
596955.description: Black music in America; the sociological conditions that help produce various forms of black music. (AFAM 356 and MUS 356 are the same course)

596956.title: Blacks in the Performing Arts
596956.description: African-American culture through the performing arts. Blacks in the entertainment industry as a means of understanding and revealing important aspects of African-American culture. (AFAM 357, MUS 357 and THTR 357 are the same course.)

596957.title: Jazz Improvisation II
596957.description: Continuation of modal patterns and jazz rhythms for improvisation. Melodic construction in improvisation. Emphasizes playing II-V-I progressions in major and minor keys. Form, stylistic analysis and ear training. (2 hours activity)

596958.title: Guitar Performance Workshop
596958.description: Weekly workshop performances by students, faculty and guests. Recommended for guitar majors each semester. May be repeated for a maximum of 2 units. (2 hours activity)

596959.title: Instrumental Workshop
596959.description: Weekly workshop performances by students, faculty and guests. Recommended for instrumental majors each semester. May be repeated for a maximum of 2 units. (2 hours activity)

596961.title: Vocal Workshop
596961.description: Techniques of artistic performance explored through classroom demonstrations, master classes, and recitals on and off campus. Additional recital and performance attendance required. May be repeated for a maximum of 2 units. Requires enrollment in applied vocal study or consent of Vocal Area Coordinator. (2 hours activity)

596962.title: Harpsichord Class for Music Majors
596962.description: Harpsichord as an instrument, the application of Baroque stylistic characteristics, and training in the rudiments of continuo playing in ensemble with voices and instruments. Requires 300 jury level in piano or organ. (2 hours activity)

596963.title: Organ Class for Music Majors
596963.description: Organ as an instrument, the playing techniques and repertoire. Differences between piano and organ techniques. Requires 300 jury level in piano. (2 hours activity)

596964.title: Diction for Singers (English and Italian)
596964.description: Introduces the International Phonetic Alphabet as the fundamental tool for improvement of singing diction. Refining English and Italian diction through group, individual exercises. Not a substitute for formal foreign-language study. (2 hours activity)
596964.prereqs: Prerequisites: Music major or minor; sophomore standing or above.

596965.title: Diction for Singers (German)
596965.description: Problems of basic phonetics in German as applied to singing diction. Continued study of the International Phonetic Alphabet with oral and written exercises. Not a substitute for formal foreign-language study; prior study of German recommended. (2 hours activity)

596966.title: Diction for Singers (French)
596966.description: Problems of basic phonetics in French as applied to singing diction. Continued study of the International Phonetic Alphabet with oral and written exercises. Not a substitute for formal foreign-language study; prior study of French recommended. (2 hours activity)

596967.title: Instrumental Conducting
596967.description: Principles, techniques and methods of conducting orchestral and band groups. (4 hours activity)

596968.title: Instrumental Conducting
596968.description: Continuation of MUS 382A, including laboratory experience in conducting instrumental groups, using standard instrumental literature. (4 hours activity)

596969.title: Choral Conducting
596969.description: Principles, techniques and methods of conducting choral groups. Requires one semester of voice class. (4 hours activity).

596970.title: Choral Conducting
596970.description: Continuation of MUS 383A, including laboratory work with class and vocal ensembles, using standard choral repertoire. Requires plus one semester of voice class. (4 hours activity)

596971.title: Jazz/Commercial Keyboard
596971.description: Provides skills to play underlying harmonies and keyboard voicings found in jazz and popular music. (2 hours activity)

596972.title: Piano-Vocal Collaboration
596972.description: Collaborative skills for pianists and vocalists, with representative examples from standard teaching literature for voice and piano. Classroom performances, outside rehearsals, listening and recital attendance required. May be repeated for a maximum of 2 units. (2 hours activity)

596973.title: Individual Instruction
596973.description: Individual study with assigned instructor. Performance technique, repertoire and other responsibilities as assigned. Jury examination required. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 4 units. Requires jury recommendation.

596974.title: Individual Instruction
596974.description: Individual study with assigned instructor. Performance technique, repertoire and other responsibilities as assigned. Jury examination required. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 4 units. Requires jury recommendation.

596976.title: Recital
596976.description: Preparation and presentation of representative works in the principal performance area. In the semester of recital presentation, MUS 398 will substitute for one unit of MUS 393. Requires 300 jury level in the principal performance area.
596976.prereqs: Corequisite: MUS 365I , MUS 365G , MUS 465K or MUS 365V .

596977.title: Major Performance Ensemble/Symphony Orchestra
596977.description: Study and performance of standard and contemporary music literature. Public concerts on campus and in the community each semester. Concert tour may be included. May be repeated for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 15 units or for a maximum of 6 units by students in graduate music programs. Requires audition. (More than 3 hours major production)

596978.title: Major Performance Ensemble/Concert Choir
596978.description: Study and perform standard and contemporary music literature. Public concerts on campus and in the community each semester. Concert tour may be included. May be repeated for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 15 units or for a maximum of 5 units by students in graduate music programs. Required of music majors every semester of residence. (More than 3 hours major production) May be repeated for credit. Requires audition.

596979.title: Major Performance Ensemble/University Symphonic Winds
596979.description: Study and perform standard and contemporary music literature. Public concerts on campus and in the community each semester. Concert tour may be included. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 15 units or for a maximum of five units by students in graduate music programs. Requires audition. (More than 3 hours major production)

596980.title: Major Performance Ensemble/Opera Theatre
596980.description: Musical, dramatic and language techniques of music theatre. Assignments made according to casting requirements. Public performance of scenes, programs or complete operas. Open to majors and non-majors. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of fifteen units or for a maximum of five units by students in graduate music programs. Requires audition. (3 or more hours activity).

596981.title: Major Performance Ensemble/University Singers
596981.description: Study and perform standard and contemporary music literature. Public concerts on campus and in the community each semester. Concert tour may be included. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of fifteen units or for a maximum of five units by students in graduate music programs. (More than 3 hours major production) May be repeated for credit. Requires audition.

596982.title: Major Performance Ensemble/Wind Symphony
596982.description: Study and perform standard and contemporary music literature. Public concerts on campus and in the community each semester. Concert tour may be included. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of fifteen units or for a maximum of five units by students in graduate music programs. For advanced wind and percussion students accepted by audition. (More than 3 hours major production)

596983.title: Major Performance Ensemble/Opera Orchestra
596983.description: Performance in the orchestra for collaborative Music Department / Theatre Department productions. Includes musical preparation, joint rehearsal preparation and performances. May be repeated for credit: maximum 15 units for undergraduates; 6 units for graduate students. (3 or more hours activity)

596984.title: Major Performance Ensemble/Jazz Ensemble I
596984.description: Study and perform advanced-level standard and contemporary jazz literature for large ensemble. Public concerts on campus and in the community each semester. Concert or jazz festival tours may be included. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of fifteen units or for a maximum of five units by students in graduate music programs. Requires audition and consent of instructor. (3 or more hours activity)

596985.title: Major Performance Ensemble/The Singing Titans
596985.description: Perform high-quality choral literature for tenor and bass voices. Improve competence in sight singing, musicianship and vocal skills. Open to music majors and non-majors. May be repeated for credit: maximum 15 units for undergraduates; 5 units for graduate students. (3 or more hours activity).

596986.title: Major Performance Ensemble/Jazz Ensemble II
596986.description: Study and perform standard and contemporary jazz literature for large ensemble. Public concerts on campus and in the community each semester. Concert or jazz festival tours may be included. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of fifteen units or for a maximum of five units by students in graduate music programs. Requires audition or consent of instructor. (3 or more hours activity)

596987.title: Major Performance Ensemble/University Band
596987.description: Study and performance of standard and contemporary music literature. Public concerts on campus and in the community each semester. May be repeated for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 15 units or for a maximum of 6 units by students in graduate music programs. (More than 3 hours major production)

596988.title: Jazz Singers
596988.description: Study and perform standard and contemporary vocal jazz literature. Public concerts on campus and in the community each semester. Concert/festival tours may be included. Open to non-music majors by audition. May be repeated for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 15 units or for a maximum of 6 units by students in graduate music programs. Requires audition and/or consent of instructor. (3 or more hours activity).

596989.title: Major Performance Ensemble/Titan Voices
596989.description: Learn and perform a wide variety of high-quality choral literature written especially for soprano and alto voices, while improving competence in sight singing, musicianship and vocal skills. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 15 units or for a maximum of five units by students in graduate music programs. (3 or more hours activity).

596990.title: Cello Choir
596990.description: Study, rehearse and perform music for cello via workshops, sectionals, masterclasses and joint concerts with guest artists. Concert tours may be included. May be repeated for credit: maximum 15 units for undergraduates; 6 units for graduate students. Audition required for non-music majors. (2 hours activity)
596990.prereqs: Prerequisite: Music major; or graduate standing.

596991.title: Percussion Ensemble
596991.description: Study and perform music written for percussion ensemble. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of fifteen units or for a maximum of five units by students in graduate music programs. (2 hours activity)

596992.title: Brass Ensemble
596992.description: Study and perform music written for large brass choir/ensemble. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 15 units or for a maximum of 5 units by students in graduate music programs. Audition required for non-music majors. (2 hours activity)
596992.prereqs: Prerequisite: Music major; or graduate standing.

596993.title: Guitar Orchestra
596993.description: Numerous public performances, on and off campus, of music written for large ensemble of classical guitars. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of fifteen units or for a maximum of five units by students in graduate music programs. (2 hours activity)

596994.title: Clarinet Choir
596994.description: Study and performance of music for clarinet choir. May be repeated for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 12 units or for a maximum of five units by students in graduate music programs. Requires audition. (2 hours activity)

596996.title: Diverse Instrument Ensemble
596996.description: Ensemble of diverse instruments and voices. Performs a wide range of repertoire for indeterminate instrumentation, as well as arrangements and transcriptions of music from the Middle Ages to the present. Open to all performance areas, including electric and acoustical instruments. May be repeated for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 16 units or for a maximum of 6 units by students in graduate music programs. Requires audition. (2 hours activity)

596997.title: Chamber Music Ensemble/Brass
596997.description: Study and perform music written for small brass ensembles. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 15 units or for a maximum of 5 units by students in graduate music programs. Audition required for non-music majors. (2 hours activity)
596997.prereqs: Prerequisite: Music major; or graduate standing.

596998.title: Collegium Musicum
596998.description: Study and performance of instrumental and vocal music from the middle Ages, Renaissance, and Baroque. May be repeated for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 12 units or for a maximum of 5 units by students in graduate music programs. Requires  audition. (2 hours activity)

596999.title: Chamber Music Ensemble/Guitar
596999.description: Study, read and perform representative chamber literature of all periods. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 15 units or for a maximum of 5 units by students in graduate music programs. For qualified classical guitar students and other music students by consent of instructor. (2 hours activity)

597000.title: Chamber Music Ensemble/Jazz Combo
597000.description: Study, read and perform jazz repertoire representative of various styles. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of fifteen units or for a maximum of five units by students in graduate music programs. (2 hours activity)

597001.title: Chamber Music Ensemble/Keyboard
597001.description: Study, read and perform representative chamber literature of all periods. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 15 units or for a maximum of 5 units by students in graduate music programs.  For qualified wind, string or keyboard students. (2 hours activity)

598548.title: Chamber Ensemble/Contemporary Music
598548.description: Techniques of contemporary music and preparing small group performances of contemporary instrumental, vocal and electroacoustic chamber music literature from the 20th and 21st centuries. Requires audition.

597002.title: Chamber Music Ensemble/Strings
597002.description: Study, read and perform representative chamber literature of all periods. Multiple sections offer differing ensemble experiences: string quartet, string trio and string quintet. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 15 units or for a maximum of 5 units by students in graduate music programs. For qualified wind, string or keyboard students. (2 hours activity)

597003.title: Chamber Music Ensembles/Woodwind
597003.description: Study, read and perform representative chamber literature of all periods. Section 1: Woodwind Quintets, Section 2: Small, Mixed Ensembles. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 15 units or for a maximum of 5 units by students in graduate music programs. For qualified wind, string or keyboard students. (2 hours activity)

597004.title: Chamber Music Ensemble/Saxophone
597004.description: Study, read and perform representative chamber literature of all periods. May be taken for credit every semester by undergraduate music majors for a maximum of 15 units or for a maximum of 5 units by students in graduate music programs. For qualified wind, string or keyboard students. (2 hours activity)

597006.title: 18th-Century Counterpoint
597006.description: Eighteenth-century counterpoint in two, three and four parts, covering invention, canon, double and triple counterpoint and fugue.
597006.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 211 , MUS 221 ; or graduate standing.

597007.title: Advanced Form and Analysis
597007.description: Continuation of MUS 319; larger musical works.

597008.title: Compositional Techniques since 1945
597008.description: Compositional practices from 1945 to the present, including synthesis of sound. Written examples in various styles.
597008.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 320 , MUS 351C ; or graduate standing.

597009.title: Composition
597009.description: Composition of smaller forms in various contemporary styles. Not available for use on graduate study plans.
597009.prereqs: Pre- or Corequisite: MUS 319 or MUS 320 .

596947.title: Introduction to Music Technology
596947.description: Computer software applications for sound design and music production. Demonstrations and assignments dealing with techniques for creating music in the digital domain utilizing Logic Pro.
596947.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 211 , MUS 221 ; or graduate standing.

597010.title: Applications of Music Technology
597010.description: The applications of digital audio utilizing Pro Tools software. Topics include types of microphones, basic recording techniques, digital audio, midi sequencing and plug-ins via class lectures and Pro Tools assignments.
597010.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 211 , MUS 221 ; or graduate standing.

597011.title: Music in Childhood
597011.description: Songs, creative activities, and materials for teaching music to elementary school-aged children. Teaching-learning strategies. Not available for graduate degree credit.
597011.prereqs: Prerequisites: EDSC 320 ; junior standing or above.

597012.title: Survey of Marching Bands
597012.description: Techniques, materials, administration for marching band. Charting for field shows and parade activities. (1 hour lecture, 2 hours activity)

597014.title: Jazz History and Style
597014.description: History and literature of jazz music, including African roots, developments and aspects of style periods, and the contemporary state of jazz. Intended for music majors. Listening, analysis and a term paper.
597014.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 351A , MUS 351B ; or graduate standing.

607223.title: American Popular Music Literature
607223.description: The historical continuum of U.S. American popular music of various styles, from the early 19th century through today.
607223.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 351A, MUS 351B, MUS 351C; or graduate standing.

597015.title: Choral Literature
597015.description: Choral literature, from Medieval, Renaissance and Baroque eras analyzed in historical perspective; investigation of performance practice issues.
597015.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 351A , MUS 351B ; or graduate standing.

597016.title: Choral Literature
597016.description: Choral literature, from Classic, Romantic and Contemporary eras analyzed in historical perspective; investigation of performance practice issues.
597016.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 351A , MUS 351B ; or graduate standing.

597017.title: Piano Literature
597017.description: Representative styles and schools of piano literature; solo and ensemble repertoire - contrapuntal forms, sonatas and variations.
597017.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 351A , MUS 351B ; or graduate standing.

597018.title: Piano Literature
597018.description: Representative styles and schools of piano literature; solo and ensemble repertoire - character pieces, fantasies, suites and etudes.
597018.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 351A , MUS 351B ; or graduate standing.

597019.title: Wind Ensemble Literature
597019.description: Comprehensive survey of the history and literature of the wind ensemble. Developments in musical style and repertory and the social and historical contexts for the wind ensemble.
597019.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 351A , MUS 351B ; or graduate standing.

597020.title: Opera Literature
597020.description: Operatic literature and performance practices from the Baroque period through the present. Stylistic and historical considerations of selected works examined in detail.
597020.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 351A , MUS 351B ; or graduate standing.

597021.title: Song Literature
597021.description: Open to all music majors. German Lieder with representative examples of periods and styles. Historical contexts, poetry and compositional techniques. Prior study of German recommended.
597021.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 319 , MUS 351A , MUS 351B ; or graduate standing.

597022.title: Song Literature
597022.description: Open to all music majors. French melodie with representative examples of periods and styles. Historical contexts, poetry and compositional techniques. Prior study of French language recommended.
597022.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 319 , MUS 351A , MUS 351B ; or graduate standing.

597023.title: Symphonic Literature
597023.description: Literature of the symphony orchestra, from the classical era through the mid-20th century.
597023.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 351A , MUS 351B ; or graduate standing.

597024.title: Guitar Literature
597024.description: Historical survey of the literature for Baroque and classical guitar, lute and vihuela; study of transcriptions for modern guitar.
597024.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 351A , MUS 351B ; or graduate standing.

597025.title: Guitar Pedagogy
597025.description: Fundamentals of teaching and coaching classical guitar. Materials and methods for individual and group instruction.
597025.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 351A , MUS 351B ; or graduate standing.

597026.title: World Music for Music Majors
597026.description: Art, folk and popular music of selected world areas; topics vary according to semester and are chosen from Latin American, North American, Asian, African and European cultures and traditions.
597026.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 351A , MUS 351B , MUS 351C ; or graduate standing.

597028.title: Violin Playing Topics
597028.description: Various topics of violin playing and performing. Discussion and demonstration includes both technical and musical elements applicable to violin performance. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. For music majors whose primary instrument is violin.

597027.title: Jazz Improvisation III
597027.description: Continuation of Jazz improvisational pedagogy and techniques with an emphasis on performance application. Form, stylistic analysis and ear training. (2 hours activity)

596960.title: Keyboard Workshop
596960.description: Weekly workshop performances by students, faculty and guests. Recommended for keyboard majors each semester. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 10 units. (2 hours activity)
596960.prereqs: Corequisite: MUS 191 , MUS 192 , MUS 291 , MUS 292 , MUS 391 , MUS 392 , MUS 491 , MUS 492 , MUS 591 or MUS 592 .

597029.title: Advanced Vocal Workshop
597029.description: Advanced techniques of artistic performance through faculty/guest artist teaching, demonstrations, master classes, exercises professional writing. Combine informal and formal performances, journaling, reading assignments, writing program notes and preparing audition portfolios.
597029.prereqs: Prerequisite: B.M. or M.M. Vocal Performance major. Corequisite: MUS 591 , MUS 592 , MUS 491 or MUS 492 .

597030.title: Pedagogy Observation and Internship
597030.description: Observation of and supervised internship in piano teaching. Teaching techniques and development of lesson plans and materials will be included. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 6 units. (2 hours activity)
597030.prereqs: Pre-or Corequisite: MUS 467A , MUS 467B or MUS 467C . Prerequisite: junior standing or above; or graduate standing.

597031.title: Piano Pedagogy
597031.description: Materials and methods for beginning and elementary students. Concurrent enrollment in MUS 466 recommended.
597031.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 282B ; junior standing or above.

597032.title: Piano Pedagogy
597032.description: Materials and methods for intermediate and early advanced students. Concurrent enrollment in MUS 466 recommended.
597032.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 282B ; junior standing or above.

597033.title: Piano Pedagogy
597033.description: Materials and methods for class piano. Concurrent enrollment in MUS 466 recommended.
597033.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 282B ; junior standing or above.

597034.title: Vocal Pedagogy
597034.description: Physiology, anatomy and acoustics as they apply to singing; fundamental principles of vocal pedagogy for studio and public school teaching. Outside practice teaching required. Requires prior or concurrent college-level applied vocal study.

597035.title: Jazz Pedagogy
597035.description: Preparation to teach jazz in high schools and colleges. Background in administration, preparation, rehearsal and evaluation of the various types of jazz ensembles: big bands, combos and vocal jazz groups. Requires 300 applied level; MUS 281B, MUS 281P, MUS 281W recommended.

597036.title: Piano Pedagogy Practicum
597036.description: Supervised piano teaching in individual and group learning environments. Emphasizes keyboard technique, literature, communication skills, lesson plans and piano curriculum. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.. (6 hours activity)
597036.prereqs: Prerequisites: MUS 467A , MUS 467B , MUS 467C ; or graduate standing.

597037.title: Performance Techniques for Voice
597037.description: Stage movement and characterization techniques for the classically trained singer. Style in performance with reference to art songs, arias and small scenes from operatic and music theatre literature. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 units. Requires audition. (1 hour lecture, 2 hours activity)
597037.prereqs: Pre- or corequisite: MUS 291 , MUS 292 or graduate standing.

607224.title: Piano-Vocal Collaboration
607224.description: Collaborative skills for pianists and vocalists, with representative examples from standard literature for voice and piano. Classroom performances, outside rehearsals, listening and recital attendance required. May be repeated for a maximum of 2 units. (2 hours activity)
607224.prereqs: Prerequisite: MUS 291 or MUS 292 ; or graduate standing.

598869.title: Piano-Instrumental Collaboration
598869.description: Advanced collaborative skills for pianists and instrumentalists, with representative examples from standard literature for instruments with piano. Classroom performances, outside rehearsals, listening and recital attendance required. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 units. (2 hours activity)
598869.prereqs: Prerequisite: MUS 291 or MUS 292 ; or graduate standing.

597038.title: Individual Instruction
597038.description: Individual study with assigned instructor. Performance technique, repertoire and other responsibilities as assigned. Jury examination required. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 4 units. Requires jury recommendation.

596862.title: Advanced Writing in Cultural Studies
596862.description: Cultural studies approaches (race, gender and sexuality, social class, social movements, identity and power, etc.) in Hispanic/Latinx contexts. Refining critical and analytical competencies and developing academic writing at an advanced level. Conducted in Spanish.

597997.title: Spanish Editorial Convergence Writing Model
597997.description: Review and analyze new editorial business models that have worked in the Spanish language markets within the U.S and Puerto Rico.

597962.title: Spanish American Cinema: Historical and Cultural Representations
597962.description: Cinema and literature as vehicles to analyze Spanish America historical and cultural realities such as stratification, gender and political practices. Taught in Spanish.

596863.title: Spanish Visual Representations of Cultural Transformations in the 20th Century
596863.description: Traces the development of modern Spanish society from the Second Republic of 1930 to 1983's democracy. How films are texts capable of expressing social, historical or political issues and cultural changes. Conducted in Spanish.

596864.title: Spanish Literature to Neoclassicism
596864.description: Spanish literature from its beginnings to 1700. Representative works of each genre. Conducted in Spanish.
596864.prereqs: Prerequisites: SPAN 315 , SPAN 375 ; or graduate standing in Spanish.

596865.title: Spanish-American Literature to Modernismo
596865.description: Spanish-American literature to modernismo. Conducted in Spanish. (LTAM 440 and SPAN 440 are the same course.)
596865.prereqs: Prerequisites: SPAN 316 , SPAN 375 ; or graduate standing in Spanish.

596866.title: Spanish-American Literature Since Modernismo
596866.description: Spanish-American literature from modernismo to the present. Conducted in Spanish. (LTAM 441 and SPAN 441 are the same course.)
596866.prereqs: Prerequisites: SPAN 316 , SPAN 375 ; or graduate standing in Spanish.

596867.title: Spanish Literature Since Neoclassicism
596867.description: Representative works of Spanish literature from 1700 to the present. Conducted in Spanish.
596867.prereqs: Prerequisites: SPAN 316 , SPAN 375 ; or graduate standing in Spanish.

596868.title: Spanish Phonology and Dialectology
596868.description: Phonology of Spanish, specifically, the sound system, suprasegmentals and connected speech. Description and analysis of the dialectal varieties of Spanish. Conducted in Spanish.
596868.prereqs: Prerequisite: SPAN 301 or graduate standing in Spanish.

596869.title: Spanish Morphology and Syntax
596869.description: Analytical procedures of general linguistics as applied to Spanish word and sentence structure. Conducted in Spanish.
596869.prereqs: Prerequisite: SPAN 301 or graduate standing in Spanish.

596870.title: Spanish/English Bilingualism and Language Contact
596870.description: Comprehensive study of topics related to Spanish-English Bilingualism and language contact. Analyze the linguistic situation of the Hispanic groups in the United States within psycholinguistic, grammatical and sociolinguistic theoretical frames. Conducted in Spanish.
596870.prereqs: Prerequisite: SPAN 301 or graduate standing in Spanish.

598674.title: Foundations of Translation
598674.description: The underpinnings of translation as an academic and professional field. Overview of theoretical frameworks under which translation is studied as a cognitive, sociocultural and ethical enterprise.
598674.prereqs: Prerequisite: SPAN 468 or graduate standing in Spanish.

598675.title: Practice in Translation I
598675.description: Key theoretical concepts. Practical experience with the particularities of, and challenges posed by, translating commercial, cultural, financial and literary texts.
598675.prereqs: Prerequisite: SPAN 470 or graduate standing in Spanish.

598676.title: Practice in Translation II
598676.description: Review key theoretical concepts and gain practical experience with the particularities of, and challenges posed by translating legal, medical, political, scientific and technical texts.
598676.prereqs: Prerequisite: SPAN 470 or graduate standing in Spanish.

596871.title: Senior Seminar: Topics in Spanish Peninsular Literature
596871.description: Selected topics of the literature of Spain. Subject matter will change. May be repeated once for credit. Conducted in Spanish.
596871.prereqs: Prerequisites: SPAN 375 , senior standing in Spanish; or graduate standing in Spanish.

598634.title: Senior Seminar: Topics in Spanish Linguistics
598634.description: Selected topics in Spanish linguistics. Subject matter will change. May be repeated once for credit. Conducted in Spanish.
598634.prereqs: Prerequisites: SPAN 301 ; senior or graduate standing in Spanish.

596872.title: Senior Seminar: Topics in Spanish-American Literature
596872.description: Selected topics of the literature of Spanish America. Subject matter will change. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Conducted in Spanish.
596872.prereqs: Prerequisites: SPAN 375 , senior standing in Spanish; or graduate standing in Spanish.

596873.title: Independent Study
596873.description: Supervised research projects in Spanish language, literature, culture, linguistics or business. May be repeated  for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of instructor and department chair.

598677.title: Research and Teaching Methods in Spanish
598677.description: Provides a foundation in approaches, methods and materials for graduate-level research in Hispanic linguistics, literatures and cultures; and for teaching Spanish as a foreign language from the perspectives of second language acquisition research.

597756.title: Early Modern Trans-Atlantic Encounters: Spain and the Americas
597756.description: Transatlantic literature, emphasizing representatives of exchanges, clashes and cultural reactions that arose. Analyze literary works, theoretical texts and cultural events that shape and reflect the power dynamics of transatlantic crossing.

596875.title: Graduate Seminar: Historical Linguistics
596875.description: Principles of historical linguistics as seen through the evolution of Classical Latin (phonology, morphology, syntax and lexicon) into contemporary Spanish. Conducted in Spanish.

596876.title: Graduate Seminar: Spanish Poetry
596876.description: Chronological overview of Peninsular poetry with special attention on specific authors and movements. Conducted in Spanish.

596877.title: Graduate Seminar: Spanish-American Poetry
596877.description: Chronological overview of Spanish-American poetry from 1888 (Latin American Modernism) to Vanguardist and present day poetry and "Anti-Poetry." Conducted in Spanish.

596878.title: Graduate Seminar: Spanish-American Novel
596878.description: Historical overview of the development of the Spanish- American novel from the Colonial period (picaresque) to the Modern Experimental Novel. Conducted in Spanish.

596879.title: Graduate Seminar: Spanish Prose and Narrative Fiction
596879.description: An in-depth study of major prose and narrative works from various historical periods of Spanish literature. Conducted in Spanish.

596880.title: Graduate Seminar: Spanish Drama
596880.description: Chronological overview of Peninsular drama, emphasizing major authors and their most representative works. Conducted in Spanish.

596881.title: Graduate Seminar: Hispanic Topics
596881.description: Contemporary Spanish culture, contemporary Spanish-American culture, El Ensayo y La Critica Literaria Hispano-Americana. May be repeated once with different subject matter. Conducted in Spanish.
596881.prereqs: Prerequisite: SPAN 430 , SPAN 440 , SPAN 441 or SPAN 461 .

598722.title: Graduate Seminar: Topics in Spanish Linguistics
598722.description: Provides theoretical principles and practical tools for advanced, graduate-level analysis of topics in Spanish Linguistics. Topics include Dialectology, Language and Gender, Second Language Acquisition, and Advanced Syntax. Conducted in Spanish.
598722.prereqs: Prerequisite: SPAN 466 , SPAN 467 or SPAN 468 ; or graduate standing in Spanish.

598788.title: Project
598788.description: Demonstrate the culmination of knowledge gained through graduate coursework and independent thinking. Students present their research at a colloquium or academic conference and submit an article-length paper as their final project.

596882.title: Independent Graduate Research
596882.description: Supervised research projects in Spanish language or literature. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires fluency in Spanish and consent of instructor.

597517.title: The Teaching Experience: Exploration
597517.description: Exploring one's self in relation to other people in the schools, and an encounter with the teaching experience through fieldwork. Accompanying seminar helps extend observations and explore relevant issues. (2 hours fieldwork, 2 hours seminar). (EDSC 110, EDEL 110, SCED 110 and SPED 110  are the same course.)

597518.title: Introduction to Positive Behavior Support
597518.description: Basic theory and technology of applied behavior analysis as it applies to individual, class-wide, and school-wide Positive Behavior Support. Assessing and evaluating school environments in terms of how events and conditions support behavior. Requires 10 hours field observation. Flexible options for observation hours may be discussed with the Instructor.

597519.title: Exceptional Individual
597519.description: Overview of all areas of exceptionalities and topical review of characteristics of individuals with exceptional needs. Participate in various simulations and activities designed to enhance understanding of diversity in our society. Requires 20 hours of field experience.

597520.title: Early Childhood Special Education
597520.description: Characteristics of young children ages birth-5 years with disabilities, developmental delays and those "at risk" for developmental delays. Rationale for early intervention and preschool programs, program models and service delivery approaches.
597520.prereqs: Prerequisite: any course in Child and Adolescent Studies or graduate standing.

597521.title: Introduction to Autism
597521.description: Introduction to the field of autism. Foundations and characteristics of autism spectrum disorders and up-to-date evidence-based best practices for teaching students with ASD.
597521.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Mild to Moderate Support Needs, Extensive Support Needs, or Early Childhood Special Education)

598936.title: Collaboration and Consultation: Teaching Performance Assessment Seminar
598936.description: Preparation for completing California Teaching Performance Assessment (CalTPA) Cycles 1 and 2, which are requirements for a Preliminary Education Specialist Credential. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive credit. Credit /No Credit only.
598936.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Mild to Moderate Support Needs or Extensive Support Needs).

597522.title: Working with Families of Individuals with Disabilities
597522.description: Characteristics of family systems; functional assessment of family needs, concerns and priorities. Effective communication, collaborative skills and identification of community resources.
597522.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Mild to Moderate Support Needs, Extensive Support Needs, or Early Childhood Special Education)

598937.title: Early Childhood Special Education: Beyond Preschool
598937.description: For Early Childhood Special Education teachers who hold an Educational Specialist-EC credential prior to July, 2022. Focuses on eight Teacher Performance Expectations, PK/K standards, DAP curriculum, English Language learners in TK/K, working with orthopedically handicapped and other health-impaired young children.
598937.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary or Clear Education Specialist in Early Childhood Special Education Credential student.

597523.title: Exploring the Intersection of Culture, Language, Dis/ability, and the IEP
597523.description: Introduction to language and culture for communities with multiple identities. Foundations and characteristics of plurilingualism and disabilities through current evidence-based practices for  assessing and teaching. Requires 10 hours field observation. Flexible options for observation hours may be discussed with the instructor.

598195.title: Inclusive Education
598195.description: Introduces the concepts, strategies, and legislation for including children with disabilities alongside their typically developing peers in natural environments. Emphasis includes best practices such as Universal Design for Learning (UDL), environmental assessment, and collaboration with families and school personnel.
598195.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Early Childhood Special Education) student.

597524.title: Introduction to Collaboration/Consultation
597524.description: Support beginning Education Specialists in ways that will foster lifelong learning and a successful career in teaching. Train in skills that promote collaboration with colleagues and successfully including students with special needs into general education environments when appropriate.

597525.title: SPED Curriculum and Instruction in the General Ed Classroom - Math and Science
597525.description: Emphasizes education students with disabilities in general education, while learning standards, field-based learning, problem solving, direct instruction and accommodations/modifications designed for K-12 mathematics and science teaching in inclusive settings.
597525.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Mild to Moderate Support Needs or Extensive Support Needs).

597526.title: Reading and Language Arts Instruction
597526.description: Principles of reading and language arts instruction, assessing reading strengths and weaknesses, and planning and implementing instruction based on assessment for a wide variety of learners. Familiarity with the California Core Curriculum and Reading Language Arts Framework.
597526.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Mild to Moderate Support Needs or Extensive Support Needs).

597527.title: Literacy for Early Childhood Special Education Specialists
597527.description: Basic principles of and teaching techniques for emergent literacy in reading, writing and verbal and non-verbal communication for children with disabilities birth to age five.
597527.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Early Childhood Special Education) student.

597838.title: Teaching Performance Assessment Support: Assessing Learning and Culminating Teaching Experience
597838.description: TPA support within social studies or science for the Multiple Subject Credential program. Credit/No Credit only. A "B" (3.0) or better is required to receive a grade of credit. May be taken for credit for a maximum of two units. (EDEL 453B and SPED 453B are the same course.)
597838.prereqs: Prerequisites: EDEL 430 , EDEL 433 , EDEL 434 , EDEL 435 , EDEL 438 ; admission to student teaching.

597529.title: Characteristics of Individuals with Mild/Moderate Disabilities
597529.description: Individuals with diverse cognitive, social-emotional and physical characteristics and their educational needs.

597530.title: Characteristics of Individuals with Moderate/Severe Disabilities
597530.description: Individuals with diverse cognitive, social-emotional, behavioral and physical characteristics and their educational needs.

607237.title: Characteristics of Students with Mild to Extensive Support Needs
607237.description: Understanding characteristics of school-aged children with mild to extensive support needs and pertinent critical issues in special education.

597531.title: Curriculum and Methods for Individuals with Mild to Moderate Support Needs
597531.description: Curriculum development, instructional methodology and materials for teaching individuals with mild to moderate support needs. Instructional strategies permitting access to the core curriculum.
597531.prereqs: Prerequisite: Special Education Credential Program student.

597532.title: Curriculum and Methods for Individuals with Moderate/Severe Disabilities
597532.description: Curriculum development, instructional methodology and materials for teaching individuals with moderate/severe disabilities. Functional academics, life skills and adaptations to core curriculum.
597532.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Extensive Support Needs) student.

597533.title: Curriculum, Methods and Intervention in Early Childhood Special Education
597533.description: Early childhood special education foundations course, focusing on very young children birth to five years in curriculum development, instructional planning, designing engaging room environments, technology applications and intervention. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
597533.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Early Childhood Special Education) student.

603115.title: Initial Student Teaching in General Education and Special Education Settings
603115.description: Student teaching in a department-approved special education or inclusive general education/special education setting, related to skills and competences specified for the completion of the university or state-approved endorsements or certificates. May be repeated for credit. Credit/No Credit only.
603115.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Mild to Moderate Support Needs or Extensive Support Needs).

597534.title: Student Teaching for Special Educators in the K-8 General Education Classroom
597534.description: Ten-week participation in a K-8 general education classroom as an Education Specialist Candidate, as assigned by the department. Co-teaching, differentiated standards-based instruction, accommodations/modifications, CWPBS, pre-referral, remediation. Requires CSET.
597534.prereqs: Prerequisites: SPED 322 , SPED 371 , SPED 425 . Corequisites: SPED 429 , SPED 432 , SPED 433 .

597535.title: Directed Teaching in Special Education (A)
597535.description: Directed teaching in department-approved mild/moderate placement to meet California's Mild/Moderate credential requirements. Credit/No Credit only.
597535.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Mild to Moderate Support Needs) student.

597536.title: Directed Teaching in Special Education (B)
597536.description: Directed teaching in department-approved moderate/severe or early childhood placement to meet California's Moderate/Severe or early childhood special education credential requirements. Credit/No Credit only.
597536.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Extensive Support Needs) student.

597537.title: Directed Teaching in Special Education: Early Childhood Experience
597537.description: Supervised practice field/clinical experience with exceptional individuals ages birth to five years related to skills and competencies specified for the completion of university or state-approved endorsements or certificates. May be repeated once for credit. Credit/No Credit only.
597537.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Early Childhood Special Education) student.

597538.title: Directed Teaching in Special Education: Preschool
597538.description: Supervised practice field/clinical experience with exceptional individuals ages birth to 3-5 years related to skills and competencies specified for completing university or State-approved endorsements or certificates. May be repeated once for credit. Credit/No Credit only.
597538.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Early Childhood Special Education) student.

597539.title: Field Studies: Special Education
597539.description: Intern support seminar for candidates that are teaching on an education specialist intern credential. Course is designed to offer support for interns through peer discussions and mentorship around common challenges in classrooms such as classroom management, IEP development, differentiation, supporting English language development, etc.  May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Credit/No Credit only.
597539.prereqs: Prerequisite: Special Education Credential Program student.

597540.title: Senior Educational Practicum
597540.description: Advanced level of educational practicum within school and/or agency settings. May be repeated once for credit. Requires approval by department chair and instructor.

597541.title: Independent Study
597541.description: Supervised individual studies under the direction of faculty member. Experimental, research or creative projects. May be repeated once for credit.

597542.title: Introduction to Graduate Studies
597542.description: Prerequisite to the MSE in Secondary Education. Prepares entering graduate students to develop study plans and identify pressing issues in secondary education. May be taken before or during the first semester. (EDSC 501 and SPED 501 are the same course.) Requires capacity for electronic communication, including e-mail, attachments and web courseware.

597543.title: Teaching Students with Autism
597543.description: Overview of evidence-based strategies and methodologies for teaching students with Autism spectrum disorders.

598938.title: New Teacher Induction, Assessment and Support, Year 1
598938.description: Preparation and professional development for new teachers in accordance with the California Standards for the Teaching Profession. (EDSC 502A, EDEL 502A, SPED 502A are the same course.)

598939.title: Pedagogy, Assessment and Support for New Teachers: Semester 1
598939.description: Formative assessment and professional development for new teachers via utilization of state-approved formative assessment system. Inquiry into teaching effectiveness including analyzing teaching and learning context and assessment. Requires participation in the Fullerton Teacher Induction Program. (EDEL 502E, EDSC 502E, SPED 502E are the same course.)

598940.title: Pedagogy, Assessment and Support for New Teachers: Semester 2
598940.description: Formative assessment and professional development for new teachers via utilization of state-approved formative assessment system. Inquiry into teaching effectiveness, including action research, review and reflection on teaching and learning. Requires participation in the Fullerton Teacher Induction Program. (EDEL 502F, EDSC 502F, and SPED 502F are the same course.)

598941.title: Pedagogy, Assessment and Support for New Teachers (Semester 3)
598941.description: Formative assessment and professional development for new teachers. Focus on inquiry into teaching effectiveness, including analysis of inquiry and assessment of teaching and learning. Requires participation in the Fullerton Teacher Induction Program. (EDSC 502G, EDEL 502G, SPED 502G are the same course.)

598942.title: Pedagogy, Assessment and Support for New Teachers (Semester 4)
598942.description: Formative assessment and professional development for new teachers. Focus on inquiry into teaching effectiveness, including analysis of inquiry and assessment of teaching and learning. Requires participation in the Fullerton Teacher Induction Program. (EDSC 502H, EDEL 502H, SPED 502H are the same course.)

597544.title: Advanced Proficiency in Educational Technologies
597544.description: Theoretical basis and strategies for improving teaching and learning in secondary school classrooms through multimedia technologies. Utilize technology for curricular, instructional and assessment purposes to support all students in learning. Meets the Professional Teacher Induction Program Technology standard. (EDSC 504 and SPED 504 are the same course.) Must have been issued a preliminary single subject credential.

597545.title: Research Methods and Statistics
597545.description: Educational research methodology and statistics. Various methods of education research, formulation of research hypotheses and preparation of research documents. Understanding descriptive and inferential statistics in educational research.

597546.title: Infant Assessment and Intervention
597546.description: Transdisciplinary model for assessing infant birth to three years of age at risk for developmental delays, and their families. Culturally sensitive assessments and family-focused interventions used to develop Individualized Family Service Plans (IFSP).
597546.prereqs: Prerequisites: Education Specialist Credential student; SPED 400 .

597547.title: Preschool Assessment and Intervention
597547.description: Assessing preschool-age children at risk for developmental delays and their families using formal and informal testing instruments. Translating child and family assessments into preschool special education program planning.
597547.prereqs: Prerequisite: SPED 400 . Corequisites: SPED 482C , SPED 489D , SPED 522 .

597548.title: Assessment in Special Education
597548.description: Application of measurement and data analysis in the K-12 classroom.
597548.prereqs: Prerequisites: SPED 488 for credential students; SPED 501 for master’s students.

597549.title: Positive Behavior Support
597549.description: Advanced theory and technology of applied behavior analysis as it applies to individual, class-wide, and school-wide Positive Behavior Support. Regulations mandated by AB 86.
597549.prereqs: Prerequisite: Preliminary Education Specialist Credential program (Mild to Moderate Support Needs, Extensive Support Needs, or Early Childhood Special Education)

597550.title: Collaborative and Consultative Seminar
597550.description: Staff development, theory and communication skills needed to work with decision-making groups. Design state-mandated induction plan for professional growth.
597550.prereqs: Prerequisite: SPED 429 or Special Education graduate standing.

597551.title: Seminar: Individuals with Moderate/Severe Disabilities
597551.description: Selected issues, emphasizing independent investigation into the contributions of contemporary theory and research, and reviewing emerging trends.

597552.title: Seminar: Individuals with Mild/Moderate Disabilities
597552.description: Selected issues, emphasizing independent investigation into the contributions of contemporary theory and research, and reviewing emerging trends.

597553.title: Seminar: Issues and Trends in Collaborative/Consultative Services
597553.description: Contemporary research and practices as they apply to collaborative and consultative services in school and agency settings.

597554.title: Seminar in Special Education: Early Intervention
597554.description: Theoretical bases, research related to assessment and service delivery approaches and current issues and trends in early childhood intervention.
597554.prereqs: Prerequisites: Preliminary ECSE Credential; SPED 400 , SPED 514 , SPED 515 .

597555.title: Bilingual/Multicultural Special Education: Assessment, Curriculum and Instruction
597555.description: Preparation to teach special needs students who come from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds. Curriculum development, assessment practices and review of instructional needs.
597555.prereqs: Prerequisite: SPED 425 or Special Education graduate standing.

597556.title: Issues and Trends in Special Education
597556.description: Philosophical, social, economic and educational issues that underlie decision-making with respect to curriculum and methods in special education.
597556.prereqs: Prerequisites: Special Education graduate standing; SPED 501 , SPED 531 , SPED 532 or SPED 535 .

597557.title: Culminating Seminar in Special Education
597557.description: Graduate capstone seminar for qualified candidates preparing for the comprehensive examination designed to assess competencies in the field of special education. Requires completion of all master's courses on study plan.

597558.title: Project
597558.description: Individual research on an empirical project, with conferences with the instructor, culminating in a project. Requires consent of instructor.

597559.title: Thesis
597559.description: Conduct individual research; conferences with the instructor culminating in a thesis. Requires consent of instructor.

597560.title: Independent Graduate Research
597560.description: Independent inquiry. For qualified graduate students. Requires consent of instructor.

598678.title: Developmental ESL Writing
598678.description: Learn to improve language use, as well as generate and organize ideas. Intended for non-native English-speaking students (particularly non-US residents) as a prerequisite for ENGL 101P.
598678.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages

597758.title: Foundations of English Learner Education
597758.description: Overview of classroom-based research and models of language acquisition related to teaching second language learners. Theories and concepts associated with instructed English language development and content-based instruction in school setting.
597758.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages

598149.title: Advanced Writing for Nonnative English Speakers
598149.description: Meets upper-division writing requirement for approved majors. Graduate programs may use to satisfy GLWR. Intended for non-native English speaking students. Develops both language skills and ability to write using various rhetorical modes.
598149.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages

597767.title: English Grammar for ESOL Teachers
597767.description: English grammar usage, terminology, error identification, and remediation. ESOL approaches, techniques, materials, and technologies for teaching grammar within communication-based classroom.
597767.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages

598679.title: English Sound System for ESOL Teachers
598679.description: Study and reinforce sound, syllable, stress and intonation patterns of American English for instruction and remediation of ESOL learners.
598679.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages

597770.title: Principles of ESOL Instruction
597770.description: Teaching beginning to advanced English learners. Approaches and techniques for teaching listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Applying functional language analysis in content classes.
597770.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
597770.prereqs: Prerequisite: TESL 300 or graduate standing in TESOL.

597786.title: Principles of ESOL Assessment
597786.description: Assessment purposes/uses for English Learners. Standards and standardized tests in schools. Fair, equitable assessment of language and content.
597786.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
597786.prereqs: Prerequisite: TESL 300 and TESL 407 , or graduate standing in TESOL.

597787.title: Cultural Foundations for ESOL Teachers
597787.description: Major cultural and intercultural concepts. Comparison of cultural practices in U.S. and other cultures. Application of cultural information to teaching ESOL in schools.
597787.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
597787.prereqs: Prerequisite: TESL 300 or graduate standing in TESOL.

597788.title: Practice Teaching and Professional Development for ESOL Teachers
597788.description: Synthesis of teaching and assessment concepts. Lesson planning, micro-teaching, service-learning. Personal teaching philosophy. Pre-employment professional ESOL teacher development.
597788.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
597788.prereqs: Prerequisite: TESL 407 . Pre- or corequisite: TESL 408 or TESL 445 .

598956.title: Task Development for Language Teaching and Testing
598956.description: Plan and create authentic tasks for language classes and tests. Identify languageuse situations, select tasks to adapt, plan and develop tasks. Analyze reading,listening passage characteristics. Create semi-scripted listening passages. Developpractice or assessment activities targeting specific language points.
598956.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
598956.prereqs: Prerequisite: TESL 300 , TESL 407 or graduate standing.

598167.title: Independent Study
598167.description: Supervised independent study in applied linguistics, cultural foundations of ESOL instruction, and principles of ESOL instruction and assessment. To be taken with consent of instructor and department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
598167.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages

596883.title: Fundamentals in TESOL
596883.description: Prepares for coursework offered in the M.S. TESOL and TESOL Certificate Programs and for careers in TESOL. Learn requisite skills for teaching ESL/EFL classes at all levels of instruction and to be professionals in the field. May be repeated once for credit.
596883.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages

596884.title: Advanced Principles of TESOL: Listening/Speaking Focus
596884.description: Theories, methods and procedures for teaching listening and speaking skills to second language learners. Planning and delivering communicative ESL/EFL lessons.
596884.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
596884.prereqs: Prerequisites: FREN 466 , JAPN 466 , SPAN 466 , SPAN 467 , or LING 406 ; TESL 500 .

596885.title: Advanced Principles of TESOL: Reading/Writing Focus
596885.description: Theories, methods and procedures for teaching functional and academic reading and writing skills to second language learners. Planning and delivery of content-based ESL/EFL lessons.
596885.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
596885.prereqs: Prerequisites: FREN 466 , JAPN 466 , SPAN 466 , SPAN 467 , or LING 406 ; TESL 500 .

596886.title: Teaching English Abroad
596886.description: Understanding the cultural and socio-political significance of teaching English outside the U.S. Methods, techniques, materials, classroom management and evaluation in programs abroad. Create or adapt materials for a selected country or region.
596886.department: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages

596887.title: Pedagogical Grammar in TESOL
596887.description: Systematic approach to the theories and practical aspects of teaching grammar to non-native speakers of English within a communicative framework. Ordering, selecting and preparing appropriate materials and activities. Expands on concepts introduced in TESL 500.
